What is it do you think that shall achieve?
I cannot concentrate with you about!
I shall review this work once the time permits!
Whatever are you are going on about?
Of all the things, you think that takes priority?
Would that your birthright gave you better sense.
So wasteful of my realm's resources, boy.
What are you prattling about now?

CHOICE.Zagreus: How about a moody blue color of some sort for the drapery there.
Perhaps a rich green hue for the drapery will feel a little homelier?
A crimson color for the drapery is sure to be a better fit for the decor.
You know what, I changed my mind about the drapery.
I miss the way things used to be, dear Drapery.
The time has come once more to modify the drapery.
Helps keep things colorful to change the drapery from time to time.
Either those curtains go, or I do.

CHOICE.Hades: Would that you cared about more than the drapery.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Back there, let's change the color theming up a little bit.
This color ought to suit the hall back there.
This is the color suited for our hall back there.
We should redecorate the hall back there like so.
Let's try this color on for size instead.
I'd like to see it in this color once again.
This color seemed to suit the hall quite well.
Let's change the colors up back there again.
A fine hallway requires a fine rug, I always say! I say it sometimes...
Oh we absolutely need to get this rug, right over there.
By my decree, this House is not a house without this rug.
If there's a finer rug to set back there, I'll likely end up getting it as well.
Should make my bedchambers a little more presentable I guess.
What time is it? That's right: Rug-switching time!
Hrm I don't know let's try a different rug.
Let's try a different rug there, if you please.
I've had a change of heart about that rug if you don't mind.
I think we both know that it's time to change the rug.
Think this rug's really going to tie the whole room together.

CHOICE.Hades: You could make better use of your limitless time.
Would that your sense of taste exceeded rugs.
The poets doubtless shall be singing of your rug.
What have you done to my floor surfaces?
It ties nothing of the sort.
Are you quite finished alternating rugs?
Meddling with rugs again are we?
Oh leave the blasted rugs alone for once.

CHOICE.Zagreus: The lounge could use a decent rug I think.
This stately rug should match the lounge decor.
The lounge's regulars might like this rug I guess.
A serviceable rug for a serviceable lounge.
Should check the music stand to hear this one.
Another piece for the music stand.
More music for the music stand is always good.
Can hardly wait to listen to this one.
More substantive material for the music stand.
More music to soothe the senses.
Not going to say no to more music.
New music for the music stand? OK!
Think I'm going to enjoy listening to this piece.
Think I'm going to enjoy listening to this piece, potentially over and over.
Always room for some new music in my life.
Diamonds for a piece of music seems like a fair exchange!
Time to load up the old music stand.
Excited to give this one a listen.
I believe I'm eligible for the rank of Warden, Resources Director?
Make me a Fixer, Resources Director, I'm ready.
All right, Resources Director, I'm ready to be an Agent.
Need a new Cleaner, Resources Director? Because I'm ready.
To the realm, Resources Director! Thus I become a Shadow.
With this donation, I accept the honorable rank of Dusk.
Resources Director, it's my humble privilege to achieve the rank of Wraith.
I scarce believe it but I'm eligible now to become Overseer.
This is for the realm, Resources Director. Thus I become a Specter.
The rarest rank achievable is mine... the rank of One.
Somehow I've done it... the final rank... Unseen One... like Father.
Director, I believe I'm eligible for the next tier.
I do believe I'm eligible now.
My badge is due for an upgrade I think!
Here, in the name of Hades.
You drive a hard bargain, Resources Director.
Can't you give me a better deal?
What if I ask really nicely, Resources Director?

CHOICE.Skelly: What you need more practice, pal?
Just go, pal. You can do it.
Go on, boyo, get out of here.
Don't stick around on my account, boyo.
Need another fancy weapon there or what?
What do you need there pal?
I'll just hang out a while.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Care to join me out there?
I'll gain more Darkness with this.
Should help me gain more Darkness.

CHOICE.Skelly: Ooh change of plan I like it!
Want to try that thing out?
You using that thing now huh?
Ooh would you look at that.
Care for a warm-up with that?
Bet you couldn't hit me with that, pal.
Time to give that thing some work I guess.
You be careful with that one boyo.
Pretty mean knife you got there.
That some kind of fishing pole or what?
Scared to get up close and personal, boyo?
What, you going to sock it to me, pal?
Yeah, give me your best shot!
Keep your finger on the trigger at all times, pal.
Nothing to it, pal, just point and shoot.
Know how to use that thing?
You got a license for that thing?
I got your chopping block right here, pal.
Stick it to me, boyo, come on!
Just watch the ribs with that, OK?
Go on and clock me with that if you want.
I still don't get what that's supposed to be.
Give me one of them arrows right in the eye!
Couple of practice shots or something?
Go on, boyo, shoot me, let's see you do it!
How about you give me your best shot!
Bet you can't hit me repeatedly from there.
I'll hold them off, boyo, you do your thing!
Forget about me, boyo! Save yourself!
Oh I got your back, there, pal!
Come on, bozo, pick on someone your own size!
Whoever kills me gets a big promotion!
Hah what a bunch of bozos!!
Look at all these guys, come on!
Heeey bozo, let's see what you got!
You bozos look like you could use some practice!
You mess with my pal, you mess with me!
Hey pick on somebody my size!
Think you can break these bones?
Nyah, come get me and all that!
Hope I don't die and drop this precious loot!
You don't have what it takes!!
Hey, may I have your attention for a sec?
Come on, you bozos, do it!
I'm here, kill me, you bozos!
Come on, kill me, you goofs!
Come on, kill me, I'm here!!
Come on, do it, kill me!!
You want a piece of me you guys?!
Come on, you bozos, let's see what you got!
Got some real fancy bozos over here!
These guys don't look so tough!
Oh I can take a hit!!
Come give me your best shot!!
You beat me, I'll just keep coming back!
Go on and sock it to me, here!
Can't even kill an unarmed skeleton!
How about a stationary target for a change?
Want me to move, make me!
Come give me your best shot!
Oh, help me, boyo, I'm so scared!
You know who you're dealing with?

CHOICE.Megaera: You don't want to know what I think.

CHOICE.Hades: You truly are an idiot, aren't you.
Do not so much as think about it.
I do not think so, boy.
Wretches of the Underworld, this is your chance.
Come forth, wretches, and stop this meddler.
Do not presume that you escape my notice, boy.
You really think you can get out of here?
Let's see if you can live through this.
Nobody gets out of here, whether alive or dead.
You're out well past your curfew, boy.
I've tolerated your impudence for long enough.
You think you can just walk away from here?
If I could have a minute of your time...
Let's see your relatives upon Olympus get you out of this.
Allow me, boy, to introduce some of my loyal subjects.
Champions of Elysium, now prove yourselves!
Come, heroes of Elysium, and vanquish the intruder!
That does not belong to you.
My coffers are not yours for pillaging.
My subjects wish to have a word with you.
No need to be in such a hurry, boy.
I thought I'd find you here.
All right, wretches, get to work!
Those troves are not for you!
Get your hands off my trove!
I'll give these wretches not a minute more.
I shall deal with you later, then.
You lived through all of that?
Who is going to clean all of this up?
It seems I need to look for better help.
Back to the lowest depths with them.
Enough, I've better things to do.
That's all the time we have.
I expected more from the Exalted.
Why do I pay these wretches.
You did not earn this, boy.
I should not be the supervisor here.
Again you make a mockery of me.
I've no more time for this.
I ought have left them all in Erebus.
I trust they inconvenienced you at least.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Wha, that thing, that's... the sun...
So much water... Uncle Poseidon's realm
Huh... to see this each day...

text.Zagreus: Achilles thinks that I'm the... god of blood?
Patroclus... so that's his name.
That shade... that was Patroclus...?

CHOICE.Zagreus: This one, Contractor. Ought to make the Underworld a better place, I think.
Let's make it happen. I'll have to keep an eye out for this next I'm out there.
I like the sound of this. Work approved and here's the fee, good Contractor!
Here you go! I'll be on the lookout for this when I'm in the area.
Here! The Underworld could always use a little extra renovating, right?
I like the sound of this one here, good Contractor. Go make it happen!
Work is approved, upon my father's name! Not like he's paying any heed.
I'm hereby authorizing this expenditure! And I look forward to seeing the result.
House Contractor, my good shade, I've yet another job for your distinguished team.
Let's go with this assignment, Contractor! My father surely would approve.
This looks to be an excellent investment, Contractor! Go on and make it so.
The ever-shifting chambers of the Underworld ought be a little livelier with this.
Contractor, I would ask that you pursue this job. I'll be excited to see the result!
Your asking price, good Contractor. Well worth the fruits of your hard work, I'm sure.
Since Father's not paying us any heed, what say with go with this assignment, Contractor?
I grant you funding and autonomy to do this job upon your earliest convenience, Contractor.
All right! If this isn't a good expenditure of resources, then I don't know what is.
On my authority, I'd like it if you did this job for me, is that all right?
Paid in full up front, let's see what we get!
House Contractor, I have a new job for you.
All right, House Contractor, go do your thing.
Let's lighten things up a little around here.
Let's see how this one turns out.
All right, let's see what we got.
This should help liven the mood a bit.
One more embellishment for the old House.

text.Zagreus: You've done so much for us, House Contractor. Why don't you do a little something for yourself?

text.Hades: If that mess of a table enhances the Contractor's productivity, then so be it.

text.Zagreus: Work authorized! A fountain chamber in the depths of Tartarus sounds like an excellent idea.
The more I know about the Boons I'm offered, the better off I'll be.

text.Hades: You won't be better off, believe you me.

text.Zagreus: What is this...
If my father can be even more frustrating, that's something I have to see.

text.Hades: Oh, you are in for it, now, boy...

text.Zagreus: Hey that sounds handy, there...
Approved! Wouldn't mind an extra helping of gemstones while I'm ransacking out there.

text.Hades: You wish to mine my realm for gemstones, be my guest.

text.Zagreus: Sign me up, Contractor. This ought to pay for itself in no time at all!

text.Hades: Counting on resources you have not yet earned?

text.Zagreus: What's that, there, something from the Fates?
The Fated List of Minor Prophecies... that sounds somewhat exciting, I suppose.
Whoa, a Rod of Fishing? Here?
I positively cannot wait to see what sorts of foul creatures I'll dredge up with this!

text.Hades: Cheap blessing from Poseidon on a stick, and nothing more.

text.Zagreus: Access to the administrative chamber, huh...
Father always said if I wanted privileged access again, I'd have to earn it.

text.Hades: Do not touch anything again in the administrative chamber.

text.Zagreus: Hey that's the Court Musician's sentence, long past due...
There we go!
In the name of Hades, I commute our court musician's sentencing, effective now!

text.Orpheus: Oh, um, hello.

text.Hades: Ah, Orpheus.

text.Zagreus: The Sisyphus contract. I can buy it out...
In the name of Hades, I hereby release Sisyphus from the terms of his pact!

text.Hades: You what? All this, just for that wretched shade.

text.Zagreus: Orpheus' contract. I can release him...
In the name of Hades, I hereby release Orpheus from the terms of his pact!

text.Hades: What, where did you unearth that blasted contract?

text.Zagreus: It's the revised Achilles Pact...
In the name of Hades, the shade of Achilles is hereby no longer barred from visiting Elysium!

text.Hades: Such leniency with binding pacts shall tarnish our good reputation at this rate.

text.Zagreus: There's Nyx's work order...
House Contractor? With this gift of Darkness, I decree the Eldest Sigil shall be restored!

text.Hades: You waste your time; the Sigil shall never work for you.

text.Nyx: How very thoughtful, child.

text.Zagreus: Hey that's new...
This ought to help Orpheus keep his boundless libraries of music in order. Just have to fill it in.

text.Orpheus: Oh, my...

text.Hades: Our court musician need not be so indulged.

text.Zagreus: Hoh, what's this.
This style reminds me of the surface. Good motivating factor!

text.Hades: You spend exorbitant resources on festoonery?

text.Zagreus: Have to admit, this style really suits me, right?

text.Hades: I'll have no part in paying for such things.

text.Zagreus: This style's a bit formal for my tastes, but I can get used to it!

text.Hades: You wish to throw away your gemstones, fine by me.

text.Zagreus: They say this one's the hottest style this side of Elysium.

text.Hades: Who are these self-appointed judges, I would like to know!

text.Zagreus: This style seems appropriately grim for the job, I think

text.Hades: Are you quite finished with your decorating yet?

text.Zagreus: Soon as I saw this lovely style, I knew I had to have it!

text.Hades: It would be lovely if you let me work in peace!

text.Zagreus: I'd like to think Master Chaos would approve of this style.

text.Hades: Your resources to waste the way you please.

text.Zagreus: I rather like this style, so let's go ahead and make it official.

text.Hades: To trifles such as that, in times such as these!

text.Zagreus: I rather like this style, so let's go ahead and make it official.

text.Hades: To trifles such as that, in times such as these!

text.Zagreus: If I'm to keep seeing my chamber walls, they might as well not be completely barren.

text.Hades: Why don't you clean your chambers rather than adorn them?

text.Zagreus: Hey, they're my bedchambers, I can have whatever wall-scrolls I want.

text.Hades: If that is how you wish to spend your wealth.

text.Zagreus: My mate Lord Dionysus can inspire me to keep a bright and healthy attitude toward life.

text.Hades: Hahaha, healthy attitude? From him?

text.Zagreus: Should help make my messy chambers even messier.
Should make a nice enough addition to my chambers.
Least we have a backup singer if we need one.
Think I've outgrown my other bed, not that there's been a lot of time for sleep of late.

text.Hades: You do not need another blasted bed!

text.Zagreus: Anything to liven things up even the slightest bit around here.
I think those columns still could use some sprucing up.

text.Hades: The columns were just fine the way they were.

text.Zagreus: Was thinking it'd be good to change those columns up a bit.

text.Hades: Those columns are for function not for show!

text.Zagreus: If anybody needs to see their own reflection down the hall, well, now they can!

text.Achilles: Heh.

text.Hades: Reflect upon your many failings with that, boy.
Leave that poor Contractor alone.

text.Zagreus: Let us hereby have better seating, on which I shall never rest, you mark my words!

text.Hades: Hrm.

text.Zagreus: It seems my princely duty to commission this fine portrait of myself!

text.Hades: I ought have named you Narcissus instead.

text.Zagreus: Since this is Father's House it's only fair the walls be slathered with his sour look.

text.Hades: You dare to thusly mock me, boy?

text.Zagreus: Wonder how they got Meg to pose with the other two. They look downright civil!

text.Hades: You wish to see the Fury Sisters, go to Tartarus.

text.Zagreus: Nyx deserves a place of honor around here. How about... right over there on that wall?

text.Hades: Nyx surely is unwanting of attention such as that.

text.Zagreus: Every self-respecting House needs a portrait of a girl from Crete.

text.Hades: Another tastelessly constructed piece.

text.Zagreus: This piece has the power to embarrass several members of this House all in one swoop.

text.Hades: I much prefer the walls to remain bare.

text.Zagreus: Oh gods, am I becoming hopelessly obsessed with Theseus...?

text.Hades: You'll never be a match for such a champion.

text.Zagreus: I'd like to see the depths of Tartarus adorn those walls back there!

text.Hades: Why don't you go see Tartarus firsthand?

text.Zagreus: This artful piece of terrifying Asphodel should add some atmosphere.

text.Hades: What are you doing to my hall up there?

text.Zagreus: A painting of the finest spot in all the Underworld seems suitable to have in here.

text.Hades: Why settle for a painting when you could just go get yourself killed there, now?

text.Zagreus: This thought-provoking piece seems like a decent conversation-starter for the hall.

text.Hades: What is that utterly preposterous design?

text.Zagreus: A hideous rendition of a grizzled skeleton seems suitable decor.

text.Hades: May it strike fear into these worthless shades.

text.Zagreus: Father always wanted a sundial, though that aside, let's have a sundial back there, posthaste!
Perhaps the mystery of whether it's day or night around here will finally be solved?

text.Thanatos: So be it.

text.Hades: A sundial, at last? Indeed?

text.Zagreus: I think those pedestals over there are just a bit too modest for my tastes.

text.Hades: Hrm, I do suppose that gold suits those sufficiently...

text.Zagreus: If Achilles is going to stand around eternally, it might as well take place on something soft.

text.Achilles: Ah.

text.Hades: He is a shade, boy! What use has he for supple carpeting?

text.Zagreus: Oh I think Thanatos would love this one. Or totally ignore it?

text.Thanatos: What is this, Zag.

text.Hades: Thanatos is far too industrious to require such a thing!

text.Zagreus: Should soften up that corridor down there.

text.Thanatos: Heh.

text.Hades: Thanatos has no need for such embellishments!

text.Zagreus: Where else is Thanatos going to stash loose odds and ends?
Here, Thanatos, why don't you have yourself this little table?

text.Thanatos: This can't be...

text.Hades: What use has Death Incarnate for such things?

text.Zagreus: Let's lighten up that southwest hall a bit.

text.Thanatos: What?

text.Hades: The prior dimness of that hall was entirely intentional!

text.Zagreus: Perhaps Death Incarnate would like to take a load off every now and then.

text.Thanatos: Appreciate that.

text.Hades: Thanatos would never sit down on the job!

text.Zagreus: What is it about fountains that makes everything feel a little fancier?

text.Thanatos: Really?

text.Hades: What good shall that do all the way down there?

text.Zagreus: I've not seen the famous Heracles about, and so, let's have a marble effigy of him, instead!

text.Hades: Daedalus ought stick to chamber work.

text.Zagreus: Always hoped we'd have fountain here precisely in that location.
Ah yes, more comfortable seating I shall never use.

text.Hades: I'd better not catch anybody sitting down on that.

text.Zagreus: Think this is going to be a better look for the lounge seating.

text.Hades: Green is perhaps last among the list of colors I would have selected!

text.Zagreus: I think the lounge will be better off for these tables here.

text.Hades: There were no complaints on record of the prior tables!

text.Zagreus: The Head Chef certainly is going to need a place to safely care for all the fish I've been hauling in.

text.Hades: Last that I checked, this was not Poseidon's domain!

text.Zagreus: A fine display of dead meats seems very much in theme, I have to say!

text.Hades: You ought to be displayed with all the rest.

text.Zagreus: Who am I to stop the shades there in the lounge from cooking up whatever it is they're making?
Whew. It's a big job, having to sweep up after Cerberus sheds everywhere.

text.Hades: It wasn't your fault, Cerberus.
Blame yourself for that, not Cerberus.

text.Zagreus: This ought to make the lounge a little more presentable. Until Cerberus wrecks it again.

text.Hades: Finally you cleared the mess you caused.

text.Zagreus: Should make the entryway into the lounge a bit more welcoming.

text.Hades: I welcome you to go about your business, boy!

text.Zagreus: If some big light-refracting orb won't fill the lounge with revelry, I don't know what will.

text.Hades: Blood and darkness, what have you done now?

text.Zagreus: Now this is just the sort of outlandish purchase that makes me briefly feel slightly better about myself.

text.Hades: I pity those who have depended on our lounge for its formal, understated atmosphere.

text.Zagreus: These adorable little creatures forced to live in a cage ought to lighten the mood.

text.Megaera: Oh, hey.

text.Hades: Those bats are for reconnaissance not for your mood!

text.Zagreus: It can't be eaten, as I understand, but it can be displayed for all to see!

text.Hades: I see you're cultivating quite the mess.

text.Zagreus: Cerberus won't touch these things, although some shades seem to enjoy them fine.
The comfort and the safety hazard of a roaring fire seems the perfect touch for our fine lounge, I say.

text.Hades: Go cast yourself in there, why don't you, boy.
What are we supposed to do with that?

text.Zagreus: At least somebody will enjoy it around here, even if it's just a painted skeleton.

text.Hades: Would that you were a painted skeleton yourself.

text.Zagreus: This seems a suitably fine resting-pad for Cerberus.

text.Hades: The dog is perfectly content such as it is.

text.Zagreus: For Cerberus, only the greatest bed will do.

text.Hades: Don't you disturb the dog, you hear me, boy?

text.Zagreus: For Cerberus, only the greatest bed will do.

text.Hades: What do you think the dog shall do with that?

text.Zagreus: Maybe this knitted effigy of some sort of surface creature will keep Cerberus occupied.

text.Hades: Cerberus has much better things to do than play with toys!

text.Zagreus: If Hypnos is going to be sleeping on the job, he ought to do it in the lap of luxury.

text.Hades: Hypnos has an important job to do!

text.Zagreus: I won't be needing these but anyone emerging from the Pool of Styx might like them I suppose.

text.Hades: A fair enough adjustment I should say.

text.Zagreus: A marble bust of some old man seems just the thing to liven this place up.

text.Hades: Exactly whose unwanted countenance is that?

text.Zagreus: These undead flower petals ought to add an extra touch of elegance I think.

text.Hades: What are you doing to my central hall?

text.Zagreus: Let's get some undead flower petals over there, posthaste!
The hall to Father ought to look more sinister, I think.

text.Hades: A fair enough adjustment I should say.

text.Zagreus: Can't have too many undead flower petals around here.
A bit more mood lighting in the main hall is certainly in order, isn't it?

text.Hades: The light of Ixion is bright enough.

text.Zagreus: I would like only the brightest-burning, most ornate fireplace available, thanks.

text.Hades: There is sufficient warmth already in that hall.

text.Zagreus: This elegant countenance should look perfect above a roaring inferno in the hall back there.

text.Hades: You'll not be burning down this House, you hear me, boy?
The climate in this House is perfectly attuned as it is!

text.Zagreus: These ought to add a little sparkle each time I revive from the Pool of Styx.

text.Hades: Such an ignoble way to step into this House needs no adornment!

text.Zagreus: I think we can spruce up the centerpiece of the great hall just a bit.

text.Hades: This is my blasted hall, rather than yours!

text.Zagreus: You look a bit uncomfortable, Father. Here, why don't you have a seat?

text.Hades: What, what happened to my... nrgh, another of your foolish pranks.

text.Zagreus: Let's set some decadent old tombs right smack in the middle of the hall back there.

text.Hades: The dead need not be coddled with such things.

text.Zagreus: A nice floral arrangement ought to lighten up the mood a little bit.

text.Nyx: You are too kind.

text.Hades: You would associate my House with flowers, boy?

text.Zagreus: I'm sure nobody's going to mind some lovely flowers there.

text.Nyx: It is appreciated, child.

text.Hades: That is no place for flowers, clean that up!

text.Zagreus: An intricate mosaic just above my bedchambers should make having to go in feel less bad I think.

text.Hades: No mosaic shall eliminate your shame, boy!

text.Zagreus: Nothing like a mosaic depicting my arch-enemy and the Bull of Minos to spur me on.

text.Hades: Do give the champion of Elysium my best regards when next you're slain by him.

text.Zagreus: This should instill a sense of fear in anyone approaching my bedchambers.

text.Hades: What you do with your wretched bedchambers is your business alone.

text.Zagreus: Should make the climate in the lounge a bit more comfortable for some of us.

text.Hades: You wish for warmth, go visit Asphodel.

text.Zagreus: There's not much on the menu in the lounge but maybe this will help.
This one's for all the solitary shades hanging around forever in the lounge.

text.Hades: Now I suppose no work will ever be complete.

text.Zagreus: Huh maybe I can use this to avoid Father's withering gaze and unwanted feedback.

text.Hades: You think you can avoid me through there, boy?

text.Zagreus: These decorative laurels ought to give us an appreciable touch of dignity no doubt.

text.Hades: You would squander your earnings on that?

text.Zagreus: I swear, who would purchase laurels, when they could earn them in sporting competition?

text.Hades: Only those with pure contempt for honest victory.

text.Zagreus: Perhaps my chambers will look even better with these blades ominously displayed on either side.

text.Hades: Those blades don't even work. No wonder you prefer them so.

text.Zagreus: You know I've always had a thing for double-bladed axes?

text.Hades: I've always had a thing for silence around here!

text.Zagreus: I have this crippling compulsion to commission objects I am never, ever going to sit on.

text.Hades: None shall sit besides myself and Cerberus!

text.Zagreus: They say that only Heracles himself can lift these things? I'll take them, then!

text.Hades: You think you have the necessary strength?

text.Zagreus: Always wanted my own entertainment table, and I can finally afford one, I suppose.

text.Hades: Keep entertaining yourself, boy.

CHOICE.Zagreus: That Nectar also amplified one of my Boons.
Who should I give this to...
That a genuine Ambrosia bottle there?
Huh, I can't seem to open it...
Must be something I can do with this.
Someone back home would practically die for this stuff.
That key, it granted me Fated Persuasion.
That key, it granted me Fated Authority.
Wonder where I can use this.
This can unlock a weapon back at home.
I can use this to unlock a weapon.
This can unlock something back home.
I'll just keep this on me.
How many have I got now?
I can use that back home.
All I got was that stupid onion.
Father's famous sense of humor shining through again.
An onion. Instead of... whatever I was supposed to get. Ugh.
Five-second rule. That was five seconds right?
I don't like it, but I'll eat it.
At least they peeled it for me.

text.Zagreus: Hey, it's food!

CHOICE.Zagreus: That ought to keep me going for a bit.

text.Zagreus: Coin from the dead...

CHOICE.Zagreus: That Darkness there felt different than before.
Gemstones, and a little extra for Charon.
Never enough of these back at the House.
Should fetch me something good back home.
Achilles might know what to do with this.
This holds some sort of power, but for what?
Stygius shuddered as I picked it up...
Coronacht shuddered when I picked this up...
My weapon shuddered at the touch of it...
My weapons can grow even stronger now.
This can unlock a hidden aspect of my weapons.
I look forward to making use of this.
Looks like I'm back in the club.
The Head Chef always wants fish.
Fish delivery for the Head Chef.
The Head Chef is going to want this fish.

CHOICE.DROPPED_Zagreus: Who's that new shade there next to Father?

CHOICE.Zagreus: Someone's at the desk next to the throne...
Something's different about that shade next to Father.

CHOICE.DROPPED_Hades: You'll go no further, boy; at least, not yet.

CHOICE.Hades: Everything is as it always was.
Don't you see, boy? You are trapped.
I didn't think you had it in you, boy.
Hmph! I was looking all over for you.
I just got back shortly before you did!
Resolved the trouble with the Satyrs yet?
You're bound to my domain, boy.
<Tsk, tsk, tsk, tsk> Too bad, boy.
To suffer such indignity, from my own kin.
Elysium is up in arms again because of you.
Fought all the way out of Elysium, only to end up here.
The Hydra shall grow back, boy.
Get where I can see you.
Don't you have someplace else to be?
Have you no better way to pass the time?

CHOICE.Nyx: I knew that you were more than capable.
I had envisioned that you would succeed.

text.DROPPED_Persephone: Zagreus? Come here a moment, please.

text.Persephone: ...I spent many days tending this garden... or nights? Quite difficult to tell the time here. But, it's held on longer than I would have expected...

text.Hades: ...Persephone... I...

text.Persephone: Cerberus! I missed you so. And dutiful as ever, aren't you.

text.Hades: ...I'm sorry. Know that I am sorry.

text.Persephone: Hades... you look tired. Though, I am not the only one you ought to be apologizing to.

text.Hades: I know. I know, I.... Why have you returned? If Olympus... if your mother discovers what happened, not even Zeus, not even he could stop what would transpire, here!

text.Persephone: Oh, I've a thought or two about how we can settle that. Though I shall need for you and Zagreus to cooperate with me on a solution. Or, if you'd rather, I could just return the way I came?

text.Hades: A solution? What, do you intend to have them over for Ambrosia? Not even you can fix a broken family, Persephone.

text.Persephone: You're right, Hades! I can't. Certainly not by myself. So, are you going to help me, or what?

text.Hades: ...I would do anything that you would ask of me.

text.Persephone: Then, first, talk to your son.

text.Hades: ...Mm. Zagreus? You have already met Persephone, our Queen. I expect for you to show deference to her, at all times!

text.Zagreus: Wow, Father, you called me by my name! What is this strange sensation that I feel? Perhaps it's this deference of which you speak?

text.Persephone: Oh, stop it, both of you. Don't make me regret this, Hades. Speak honestly with him. About yourself, not me. Go on.

text.Hades: Yes. I... Zagreus. I know there have been times... when I've let my mood reflect on you. I showed very little patience. Questioned your judgment, often, when my own was flawed. Thus, I apologize to you, my son. I have no excuses. And I ask no forgiveness.

text.Zagreus: What about the part where you lied to me about Mother, do you apologize for that? Your foul moods, and venting them on me... I've long since come to expect that from you. And I resented you for it. But I always thought... you're honest.

text.Hades: Your mother did not come here willingly when we originally met. When she left... believing you were stillborn... her decision was final. I believed that she was better off without the lot of us, Olympus included. Deceiving both of you... it tore against my being. But it needed to be done.

text.Zagreus: Well, you didn't need to vent all that inner turmoil onto me throughout my life. Though, I think I understand. I only wish I could have understood sooner. So, uh... what now? I've grown so used to ransacking your domain, I think I'm really going to miss it.

text.Hades: About that... your ransacking revealed many flaws in our security. The types that never get into reports. Our reputation rides on there being no escape from here. Would you... keep trying to break free? Not for my sake. But for this realm. For the Queen.

text.Persephone: Zagreus... If you keep fighting out of here... it shall help keep appearances that everything is as it always was.

text.Zagreus: Question, Father. Let's say I accept. When next I reach the surface... is it still going to be you waiting up there?

text.Hades: Ah, boy. If you think for an instant that I shall go easier on you because of this, you'll soon learn otherwise.

text.Zagreus: So I just battle to the surface and repeatedly kill my own father, then?

text.Hades: You have it half-correct!

text.Persephone: Perhaps you'll also tend to my little cottage while you're in the area? The garden doesn't take much care at all. I'd like to keep the place in decent shape. In case I cannot suffer this for long.

text.Zagreus: Hahaha, well! I guess I'll see what I can do.

text.Persephone: Just do the best you can. And, clearly, I've work to do as well. We have a lot of it ahead of us, I'd say. So, shall we get started, then?

text.Zagreus: to Hades Bedroom, Storyteller
You know I can hear you, old man.

text.Storyteller: The House of Hades: That dark and lavishly appointed lair of the Underworld's King is home not just to him, but to his willful progeny.
What once was a small lounging area within the House of Hades now is sealed off, in utter shambles since the multi-headed Cerberus tore the space apart, mourning the missing Prince.
Shades of the dead mill constantly within the House, complaining of their woes, and seeking audience from any who would listen.
The lounging area within the House of Hades is a dismal place to be, in spite of its intended purpose to enliven the House's grim inhabitants.

text.Zagreus: It's supposed to be updated every so often but it's always Thanatos.
Never made it up there myself!
Won't ever see my face up on that wall I guess.

text.Storyteller: A commemorative board adorns one of the stoic walls within the lounging area, celebrating and proclaiming the accomplishments of those who serve Lord Hades best of all.

text.Zagreus: Still waiting for the festive occasion when we'll open one of these.

text.Storyteller: The ancient casks of wine hidden within the recesses of the House of Lord Hades... few have tasted the intoxicating vintage they contain, and fewer still are permitted anywhere near their vicinity.

text.Zagreus: They fought bravely, but Lord Dionysus was too strong.

text.Storyteller: The stalwart casks of wine within the House of Hades now are almost entirely devoid of content, having bravely stood against the combined thirst of the Olympians during a certain feast.

text.Zagreus: The handiwork of Lord Hephaestus, himself! Sounds like he's been rather busy.

text.Storyteller: A majestic gilded edifice of Mount Olympus, crafted with the utmost care from the true mountain's stone, now shines forever brightly even in the dim light of the House of Hades, as a parting gift from the Lord Master's kin.

text.Zagreus: He's not really that great.

text.Hades: Keep it down!

text.Storyteller: A vast and intricately crafted mosaic depicts the Underworld King presiding over the enormity of his domain, whilst its chthonic residents look on in awe of him.
Seldom does the overbearing throne of grim Lord Hades sit unoccupied; thus the House's denizens all go about their business, daring not so much as to ask why.

text.Zagreus: Not like Mother's cottage, but not bad.

text.Storyteller: The garden of Persephone the Queen, off-limits to the Prince throughout his life, now is laid bare to him at last in all its splendor.
He ventures toward the stately throne of his Lord Father, half-expecting to be caught, but ill-expecting what he is about to find.

He does not know exactly what he seeks. He only knows that something always has felt off to him, that he does not belong. Who is he, really? Lord Hades never would indulge such questions. So, Prince Zagreus would find out for himself.

He rifles through his Lord Father's possessions. There is not much of any import there. Ledgers and administrative parchmentwork. Correspondence from Olympus which he had ignored. No trace of any reference to his son.
But then, there is the note... written finely in a hand and voice the likes of which the Prince had never seen or heard.
Thus did Prince of the Underworld Zagreus absorb the contents of this hidden letter, written in his mother's hand.

text.Zagreus: His mother's hand, my mother's hand, wait, what?! You're saying this Persephone, that she's my... mother...? But, but Father always said that Nyx was my.... That liar. He lied to me, they both did. All my life!

text.Storyteller: Uhhh erm thus did the Prince discover, inadvertently, the well-kept truth about his lineage. Entirely by chance, this did occur....
Persephone... the one-time Queen of all the Underworld... where had she gone, and why? Engulfed by newfound questions and his rage, the Prince decided to confront his Lord and Master.
Responsibility-rejecting Zagreus strides down his Father's hall, quite unconcerned about the urgency with which he is expected to behave under a set of circumstances such as this.
The door to the administrative chamber beckons just beyond the hall. The prince perchance believes that he may enter quietly, without drawing the notice of those laboring within.
Among the countless splendid gemstones hidden underneath the earth, a great many are used to decorate the House of Hades, god of the dead, god of riches.
Water is the source of life, yet still it flows within the darkest Underworld recesses, whilst restless shades of mortals look upon it and recall the short days they could drink it and draw breath.
The gemstone-bearing Prince commissioned such a finely crafted fountain for the House, that all the shades who witnessed it still think of him quite fondly, ever since.
The dead have utterly no use for sustenance, although they try to feast upon it anyway, as though imagining the customs of the mortal life brings them some sense of peace.
Having invested heavily into the cooking-area within the House of Hades, the empty-stomached Zagreus can nonetheless find nothing fit to eat.
Within the House's gallery now sits the bust of a distinguished poet, ruggedly handsome in his age, who, although yet to earn his fated fame, shall probably be better known someday.
The frightful countenance of a bleached Bloodless warrior decorates the hall forever more, eternally in tribute to the savage servants of the House's lord.
The perfect-chiseled physicality of one of Greece's greatest-ever heroes now adorns the House's gallery, reminding most onlookers of many ways in which they fail to compare.
The light provided by the flames of deepest hell enhances the lounging area with a soft glow; and their warmth soothes the few living denizens there.
Time seems to stand quite still within the eternal realm of the dead, evidenced even by the means of measuring its passage.

CHOICE.Zagreus: How's that knife set working out?
Those spices working out all right?
Cooking's one way to pass the time.

text.Zagreus: No. Can't go this way just yet...

CHOICE.Zagreus: Can't believe Father kept this place locked up...
Pom trees are coming in nicely.
Mother's taken good care of this place since she got back.

text.Zagreus: Still can't get over our gift from the Olympians. It's glorious!
Um, Meg...?

text.Megaera: Hmm.

text.Zagreus: requirements are above

text.Megaera: ...I was just leaving, Zagreus. Happened to be in the area, no thanks to you, and thought I'd go retrieve the last of my possessions. I have to say, you've really let this place go to hell.

text.Zagreus: ...She left. Great. Wonderful! I guess we'll just go back to killing each other repeatedly, then.

text.Megaera: Zagreus.

text.Zagreus: requirements are above

text.Megaera: No. We need to talk, again. My sisters are involved now, in all this. You've really stirred up quite a mess.

text.Zagreus: I'm sorry. My mother's out there, somewhere. I won't rest until I can find her. You wouldn't understand.

text.Megaera: You wouldn't know. What I'm trying to say is... with my sisters involved, it changes things. Takes some of the pressure off of me.

text.Zagreus: What are you saying?

text.Megaera: I'm saying... I know you need to find your mother, Zagreus. I have my part to play in all of this, but let me see what I can do, if anything.

text.Zagreus: Meg...! She... ah.

text.Megaera: Zagreus.

text.Zagreus: requirements are above

text.Megaera: No. We need to talk, again. My sisters are involved now, in all this. You've really stirred up quite a mess.

text.Zagreus: I know. I'm sorry. But this is something that I have to do. You wouldn't understand.

text.Megaera: You wouldn't know. What I'm trying to say is... with my sisters involved, it changes things. Takes some of the pressure off of me.

text.Zagreus: Some of the pressure... wait, what are you going to do?

text.Megaera: I'm saying... I know you're doing what you have to do, here, Zagreus. And, my sisters and I will always try to stop you. But I am only doing it because I have to. Understand?

text.Zagreus: Meg...! She... ah.

text.Megaera: Come here.

text.Zagreus: requirements are above

text.Megaera: Zagreus, would you shut up already with your idiotic questions, and get over here? Right now.

text.Zagreus: ...I... you really... oh...
...I thought you'd never ask. But I'm glad you did.
intermission

text.Megaera: Stop being insecure around me, Zag. You should know better than that by now. Though, yes, if you must know... I think we're good. But if you tell another living soul, or even a dead one, I will kill you, understand?

text.Zagreus: I... loud and clear, Meg, yes, I understand. So then... what happens now?

text.Megaera: What happens now? I'll see you at the edge of Tartarus, I guess. Or maybe here. However long we keep this up.

text.Zagreus: However long we keep this up?

text.Megaera: You ask too many questions, Zag. I don't have the answers, and besides: You know more about living in the moment than I do. See you around.

text.Zagreus: ...See you around! ...Yes.

...I... Meg, I'm deeply flattered, and you're very dear to me, it's just... this isn't what I want from our relationship. I fear I must have led you on. Forgive me. Please say you'll still be my friend?

text.Megaera: ...That's all you really want...? To be my friend? Heh. You're hard to figure out sometimes, Zag. But, you know what, we've tried a lot of things. Why don't we try it like you said? I'll see you out there, then.
I need to trouble you for something, Zag.

text.Zagreus: requirements are above

text.Megaera: Shut up already, Zagreus. And come here.

text.Zagreus: ...I... you really... oh...
...I thought you'd never ask. But I'm glad you did.
intermission

text.Megaera: You ask too many questions, Zag. But yes, I'd say we are again, for now. But if you tell another soul, I'll kill you, understand?

text.Zagreus: But... no, wait... not even Than...?

text.Megaera: Than's not an idiot. He wants what's best for you. And he isn't the jealous type. Besides, I have a good working relationship with him, as you well know.

text.Zagreus: Yeah, but... what about you, you're the punisher of jealousy. What if I...

text.Megaera: We're not mere mortals, Zag. Mortals cling to one another viciously because their lives are short. What do we care? If Nyx has taught me one thing, it's that the heart has no bounds. Now quit your worrying, and get prepared for when we meet again out there. See you around.

text.Zagreus: ...See you around! ...Yes.

...I... Meg, I'm deeply flattered, and you're very dear to me, it's just... this isn't what I want from our relationship. I fear I must have led you on. Forgive me. Please say you'll still be my friend?

text.Megaera: ...You're sure? Look, I... it's totally all right. I'll see you out there, then.

text.Thanatos: I need to ask something of you.

text.Zagreus: requirements are above

text.Thanatos: Just tell me one thing, Zagreus. Did you really mean what you told me before, that... maybe we ought to... take our time?

text.Zagreus: I just... don't mean to push you, Than. I know all this is kind of a lot. And I wanted you to know... this isn't some impulsive thing for me. I'll wait for you however long it takes.

text.Thanatos: Khh! You have no concept of which impulses to act upon, and which to keep in check. You say you'll wait, well, let me ask you this: What are you waiting for? What are you waiting for, I'm here, already. Right...?

text.Zagreus: Than...! Hahaha, oh, you're right!
intermission

text.Thanatos: A lot of things. And you will have to grow to like it, Zag. Or, what I mean is... don't take my silence the wrong way, all right? I'd better get going, though, I'm way behind on work, but... see you again. If that's all right.

text.Zagreus: It is. It is.

...I did. Sometimes I need to slow things down. I'm thankful that we've been on better terms, lately. But, I've been coming on too strong. Forgive me. You're my dear friend. I don't want to do anything to hurt you. Or anybody else.

text.Thanatos: I... oh. I see. I understand. You're my dear friend, as well. Though we have done an awful lot to jeopardize that lately, haven't we? Look, take care, Zag. Be seeing you.

text.Zagreus: ...Be seeing you, too.

text.Thanatos: I need to ask something of you.

text.Zagreus: requirements are above

text.Thanatos: Just tell me one thing, Zagreus. Did you really mean what you told me before, that... maybe we ought to... take our time?

text.Zagreus: I just... don't mean to push you, Than. I know all this is kind of a lot. And I wanted you to know... this isn't some impulsive thing for me. I'll wait for you however long it takes.

text.Thanatos: Khh! You have no concept of which impulses to act upon, and which to keep in check. You say you'll wait, well, let me ask you this: What are you waiting for? What are you waiting for, I'm here, already. Right...?

text.Zagreus: Than... hahaha, I'm so glad! It's just... you know that Megaera has been here, too...?

text.Thanatos: Tsch. I've known Megaera much longer than you. Who do you think talked me into this?

text.Zagreus: Hah! She did, did she? That's good! That's good.
intermission

text.Thanatos: A lot of things. And you will have to grow to like it, Zag. Or, what I mean is... don't take my silence the wrong way, all right? I'd better get going, though, I'm way behind on work, but... see you again. If that's all right.

text.Zagreus: It is. It is.

...I did. Sometimes I need to slow things down. I'm thankful that we've been on better terms, lately. But, I've been coming on too strong. Forgive me. You're my dear friend. I don't want to do anything to hurt you. Or anybody else.

text.Thanatos: You're certain? Well... I understand. I'd best get back to my responsibilities for now.

text.Zagreus: ...See you, Than.
Hoh...

text.Thanatos: Hey Zag.

text.Megaera: <Laughter>

text.Zagreus: Hi you two.

text.Megaera: requirements are above

text.Zagreus: Erm, Meg, Than, what... what are you two... what's going on? Whatever it is, I can explain, or... wait, you're both smiling. Oh... let me just... take this in a moment here.

text.Megaera: You give Thanatos and me too little credit, Zag. We've known each other longer than you've been alive.

text.Thanatos: I'd say we know quite a bit by now, all things considered. Isn't that right, Megaera?

text.Megaera: Can't you see we're off duty right now, Zagreus?

text.Zagreus: Hah! Well then... if this turns out to be some sort of dream, I will be very, very mad. Though... I guess there's one good way to find out.
intermission

text.Megaera: Well! I think we've reached an understanding here. I should be off. Until the next one, Zag. And Thanatos.

text.Zagreus: Whew, well, that was... that was... ahem.

...Hey... look. I care about you. Both of you. A lot. I'm happy we're this close... you're this close, rather than being at each other's throats like before. But, I think it's all a little much for me, right now.

text.Megaera: ...You're sure? Look... it's totally all right. You've got enough pressure on you as it is. We'll see you out there, then.

text.Thanatos: Catch up with you some other time, all right?

text.Storyteller: It is the dead of night, or the approximation of it in the realm of Hades. Prince of the Underworld Zagreus rises from a fitful slumber, with much mischief on his mind.
The heavy-sleeping Underworld Prince arises, with the feeling that the brief nap he intended as a respite from the rigors of the day or night apparently was none-too-brief, at all...

text.Zagreus: Hey that must be the Fated List...
Oh come on, it's not that bad, is it?

text.Storyteller: The bedchambers of Prince Zagreus lie in a perpetual state of utter disarray, despite his Lord and master of the House repeatedly insisting that he pick everything up.
The shattered weapons of the siege of Ilion are now reduced to window-dressings in the Prince's ever-cluttered lair.
The valor of the great-hearted Achilles is immortalized upon the Prince's wall, as though it might stir up more courage from within.
The visage of the goddess Aphrodite now adorns the Prince's bedchambers, perhaps to provide consolation after when next he dies.

text.Zagreus: It's like we share a bond, man!

text.Storyteller: The ever-smiling, wine-washed countenance of the great Lord Dionysus now adorns the Prince's chamber-wall, thus radiating questionable influence.
A beautifully decorated, subtly enchanted bowl containing traces of the hapless Prince's past attempts to flee the Underworld now accents a particularly cluttered corner of his room.
A delicately crafted instrument of music-making now resides within the clamor-causing Prince's chambers, doubtless fearing, if it could, his heavy-handed touch.
An object intricately carven solely for the purposes of recreation now resides within the pleasure-seeking Prince's chambers, although his lack for an opponent limits its appeal.
Much of the softness of the richly woven rug the Prince procured cannot be fully felt beneath his flame-licked feet.

text.Zagreus: Already bought it, no need to sell me on it, old man.

text.Storyteller: With its just-right softness and death-themed embroidery, the new bedding of Prince Zagreus is the envy of all those who wish to rest in peace.
The ever-energetic Prince alas remains incapable of sitting still, even with such a supple, comfortable seating arrangement nestled in his chambers now.
A massive set of weights positioned carefully in line of sight of any visitors shall doubtless make them think the Prince is stronger and in better shape than in reality.
The fate-abetting Prince perhaps believes it was through his own choice that he procured the Fated List of Minor Prophecies, but it was preordained.

CHOICE.Storyteller: All is quiet at this time; ever-dreaming Hypnos put a spell upon the House, as willful Zagreus had asked of him. All are fast asleep, save for the Prince. It is exactly as he planned.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Should turn around. My escape route's in the courtyard I just left.
My escape route's back the other way.

CHOICE.DROPPED_Zagreus: I'm back, Room, did you miss me?

CHOICE.Zagreus: I want to go lie down.
Hey what happened to the Pact of Punishment?
I'm back, Room, did you miss me?
I can still rank up within my heart, I guess.
I'm at the highest rank achievable!
Suppose I'm overdue to take a break...

text.Zagreus: It's been a while, Resources Director. I'll be sure to pay you a visit whenever I'm swimming in Underworld valuables and want to feel better about myself in my new role.
Must be something worth a damn in here.
Keeping busy, Resources Director?
Father keeps things orderly I guess...
The master chambers...
Mother didn't change the decor much.
Resources Director!
Hello, Director.
Just me, Director.
I'm back, Director.
Director.
Director?
He's never stopped thinking of her. Ugh, what a fool.

text.Storyteller: In his Lord Father's very private chambers, Zagreus, the lock-removing prince, discovers a most delicately painted likeness of none other than Persephone, herself. A coat of dust suggests it has remained here for some time.

text.Zagreus: I knew it. It's just capes!
Tsch.

text.Storyteller: The stoic Lord and Master of the House possesses wealth beyond imagining, a portion of which he has used for a crisp set of attire for every passing day.

CHOICE.Zagreus: The Eldest Sigil. Nyx needs it upgraded, huh.
The Eldest Sigil should be fully powered up for Nyx.

text.Storyteller: Within the recesses of the administrative chamber lies the Eldest Sigil of the Master's House: a symbol of the Fate-given authority to rule beneath the earth, and means by which to travel the entirety of all that dark domain.
The cool, purified waters of the Styx are available in limitless supply to all servants of the god of the dead authorized to work endlessly within the House administrative chamber.

text.Zagreus: Everybody hang in there!

text.Storyteller: The administrative chamber's ever-working shades remain utterly dedicated to their thankless toil all because of an inspiring rendition of how dedicated they ideally should be.
Amongst the parchment-records of the dead and punished are the sealed documents known as the Knave-King's Sentence, forcing said king to endlessly toil with a boulder till the end of time.

Nestled among the towering administrative parchmentwork of the long-since-deceased lies an old document concerning a special pact signed by a once-living court musician, who attempted vainly to rescue his wife from death.

Buried deep within the archives, holding many binding pacts between Lord Hades and the dead, resides an old agreement; an exchange for services from an extraordinary warrior, for eternity within Elysium for his dear partner.

text.Zagreus: Oh, gods....

text.Hades: Get on with your responsibilities.

text.Storyteller: The day or night's duties are sheer simplicity itself; at least at first, as when the prince simply signs in to signal the commencement of his shift.

text.Zagreus: Damn it...

text.Storyteller: The often-failing prince attempts to sort the ledgers in the fashion necessary for the proper keeping of his father's realm.

text.Zagreus: Ungh...

text.Storyteller: The training-lacking prince's efforts to administer approvals to the judgment terms ultimately leave a lot to be desired.

text.Zagreus: Oh come on.

text.Storyteller: The hard-laboring shades responsible for the administration of the prince's father's realm merely look on at the prince's ill-fated attempts.

text.Zagreus: Doesn't make any sense.

text.Storyteller: The relaxation-loving prince never paid suitably enough attention to learn properly how to arrange the record-bookings of the regions of his father's realm.

text.Zagreus: What...

text.Storyteller: This set of delicate responsibilities is easily achieved, at least by someone capable and trained to do the work, unlike the oft-distracted Underworld Prince.

text.Zagreus: I... ungh.

text.Storyteller: A careful record must be kept of all expenses paid within the House; a delicately-handled tabulation process which the prince is ill-equipped to fully undertake.

text.Zagreus: I'll do it later.

text.Storyteller: A steadily-updated ledger of the House's income in the form of brilliant gemstones, diamonds, Darkness, and the like, is merely one among the prince's least-liked aspects of his work.

text.Zagreus: None whatsoever, yes.

text.Storyteller: Records of expired House Contractor renovations line a desk in the administrative chamber, though the prince has absolutely no desire now to organize them alphabetically, by date.

text.Zagreus: I haven't forgotten, no one told me!

text.Storyteller: Attendance records of the working-shades who toil for the House need to be verified; the shades' due compensation, rapidly approved; and yet the prince cannot remember all the necessary steps.

text.Zagreus: Oh it's faded...

text.Storyteller: Disorderly Prince Zagreus gazes upon the endless stacks of parchment-paper, each containing work-details to be registered and neatly organized, and starts to feel his optimism fade.

text.Zagreus: Correct...

text.Storyteller: Prince Zagreus must have some favored tasks in the administrative chamber of the House; but surely none of them include the tasks demanding his attention, here.

text.Zagreus: Can't understand any of this.

text.Storyteller: Reviewing lists of claims from shades with grievances is a very important service of the House, or so Lord Hades once attempted to impress upon his willful son.

text.Zagreus: Can't understand any of this.

text.Storyteller: A litany of complaints submitted by restless shades across the Underworld must be evaluated, organized, and processed, but Prince Zagreus does not even know where to begin.

text.Zagreus: Eugh...

text.Storyteller: Supplies on all the desks in the administrative chamber must be carefully maintained and neatly placed in a specific way, which the forgetful prince has not yet memorized in full.

text.Zagreus: Eh...

text.Storyteller: Security reports concerning failed escape attempts from Tartarus require timely verification and official response, neither of which Prince Zagreus is fit to give.

CHOICE.Zagreus: OK, I'm done, so... can I go yet, Father?

CHOICE.Storyteller: At last, the work-disliking prince records a summary of the results of his attempts to be of any use to the administrative needs of his grim father's House.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Should check that stack of contracts back there.
Contract I'm looking for should be back there.
Should check the admin chamber for the pact Nyx mentioned...
Never thought I'd come back here again...
Hello, I'll only be a moment!
Just me, pretend I'm not even here.

text.Skelly: I'll level with you, pal. You have impressed somebody well above my pay grade here, and so... they have a little proposition for you, you listening?

text.Zagreus: Let me guess... they want me to fight all the way through the Underworld, having used the Pact of Punishment over there to make the going even more treacherous than it already is, and if I succeed, they'll reward me with some sort of useless trinket?

text.Skelly: Wrong! We're talking something really big, here, pal, you see that thing back there? Trinket. Come on, what are you, scared?

I just knew you had it in you, pal, enjoying your new prize? Pact of Punishment, Shmact of Punishment, no problem, know what I mean? 'Course, that was just the easy one you got there, pretty sure I could've got that one, myself.

text.Zagreus: Wait, just so I understand. I literally toiled through hell and back, and my reward is just... a statue of you? Don't get me wrong, it's lovely, it's just... I don't know what I expected.

text.Skelly: Look, boyo, there was a little mix-up when we put in the request for that thing, see? I told 'em to make something that'll make me look good with my sources, and anyway that's how it all turned out. The other ones turned out much better, though, you'll see!

text.Zagreus: Skelly, let me ask you something. Did you really commission three nearly-identical statues of yourself to goad me into using the Pact of Punishment?

text.Skelly: I am offended, pal! You haven't even seen the third one yet, so how can you insinuate a thing like that?! Maybe I was wrong about you. I thought you really were the one!

text.Zagreus: You're only saying that to get me to apologize and try and unlock the last of your three identical statues, aren't you.

text.Skelly: How could you? I would return those statues for a full refund right here and now, if I could move! And if there was a refund policy on them.

Look I'm sorry I messed up your statues, boyo. Really. When I saw them, I just kind of freaked. But then I figured there's no way he's going to see how they turned out, so, I just rolled with it, you know?

text.Zagreus: You shouldn't have underestimated me, mate. But... I shouldn't have said such awful things about your statues. You must have really gone out of your way to get them here.

text.Skelly: Oh you better believe it, pal! So how about we call it even. We've been through a lot. Both of us! Really learned from this experience, and now, we share a deeper understanding, yeah?

CHOICE.Zagreus: My escape route's back the other way.

My Keepsake Collection! Just what the House Contractor ordered.

CHOICE.Sisyphus: Well, that's just it, Master Thanatos. I never was terribly fearful of you gods, if you'll forgive my saying so. Far as I can tell, all of you seem to have your struggles much like mortals do. A fear of death aside.

CHOICE.Thanatos: What would you know of the struggles of gods? Now you have eternity to think on what you've done. Maybe I'll check again with you after another aeon or two, see if you've learned anything more.

text.Skelly: Nice place you got here, boyo! Name's Skelly, how's it going, but enough with the small talk already, I'm here to do a job. So let me have it! Give me everything you got!!

text.Zagreus: I don't remember having you on payroll, mate. Who's your supervisor?

text.Skelly: Oh-hoh, I'm not about to rat my sources, pal! Just try and beat it out of me!

text.Zagreus: Don't suppose I can talk you into fighting back this time?

text.Skelly: Not a chance, boyo, I'm paid to take it not to dish it out! Now give it to me!!
Hey, you're getting pretty strong, there, pal! Though, I am being paid to tell you that! But not being paid to not tell you that last part...

text.Zagreus: I have to ask you something, mate. What do you even need the pay for, anyway?

text.Skelly: That, pal, is nobody's business but my own! Besides, it's impolite discussing money all the time! Now back to beating me to powder!
Let me give you a piece of advice, boyo. You run across a guy like me out there, you just give him a good stab right in the back without a second thought before he sends you crying back to Papa.

You getting pretty strong, I'll give you that, boyo. Strong enough to smack a guy like me right up against the wall and I'd go straight to pieces, boom! You just remember, when you're duking it out, the walls are your friend!

text.Zagreus: Smack guys against walls. Sound advice as ever, mate.

text.Skelly: Hey pal watch where you throw those bloodstone things of yours, you drop them, you go pick them up, you understand? But if somebody gives you grief, you got my permission to chuck one right in his eye!

text.Zagreus: I'll just aim generally for the midsection since the eyes are a lot harder to hit in my experience.

text.Skelly: You're pretty quick, you know, boyo! Just be sure to use that fancy dash of yours and keep 'em guessing! Don't let 'em catch you standing still!

text.Zagreus: Dash like mad instead of standing still. That's not the worst advice, I guess.

text.Skelly: Little tip, boyo? You find any coinage while you're out there, you be sure to pawn it off to that old Charon, boatman guy? Use it or lose it, pal, use it or lose it.

text.Zagreus: Thanks, mate, note to self: Always spend everything I earn instead of ever saving.

text.Skelly: Once in a while, pal, you're going to see a real fancy bozo try to ruin your good time. You'll know him 'cause he's glowing like a light, but that's his special armor, see? You got to punch right through it, he's going to shrug you off until you do!

text.Zagreus: For a good time, beware the fancy glowing bozos on my quest. Check.

text.Skelly: You know something, boyo, I think you could do a real number on one of these columns holding up this place, and bring the whole thing down in just a few swipes, boom, boom, BOOM! I'd hate to be standing near one of them if you did!

text.Zagreus: Wreck my father's finely crafted architecture every chance I get. That I can do for sure.

text.Skelly: Boyo, next time you make it to the big VIP area upstairs, you watch out for those weapon-wielding gents out there! The eyeball soul thing that pops out when you beat 'em? You got to squash those, too, or else they'll grab their gear and come right back!

text.Zagreus: Crush the souls of Elysium's Exalted shades to stop them from regenerating over and over. I'll definitely do that next time I'm there.

text.Skelly: Exactly, pal, that's it!

If you're having a rough time out there, boyo, you just remember something: You're a god, all right?! Way tougher than you think. They give you trouble, you just turn on God Mode, and you let 'em have it for me!

text.Zagreus: You act as though this God Mode is some sort of lever I can simply switch at will if ever I wish to unlock my latent strength, there, mate.
If I must.
Skelly, how do you know all this stuff, by the way? I mean no offense, but you're a skeleton who just stands around. Yet you have this wealth of knowledge of the Underworld?

text.Skelly: Hey, I know people, pal! We'll just have to leave it at that. Now let's see you break some of these bones, huh?
Yep. Now hop to it!

Well, pal? You have come a pretty long way, let me tell you. I think most of the smarts I've picked up, you know by now. And so... if I'm fresh out of tips for you... I guess there's only one thing left to do.

text.Zagreus: Stand there eternally to be whaled upon at my whim, using whichever weapon suits me at the time?

text.Skelly: Yeah, no, that definitely wouldn't fly.

text.Zagreus: Say, mate? I picked up a painting for our lounge that looked a little like yourself. Reminds me... have you ever even been inside? Should come join us sometime.

text.Skelly: Ah, you know, while I appreciate that, there, boyo... those kind of social spaces, they're not really for me. I kind of like it out here, just me, these bats whizzing around from time to time.... Besides! The old contract makes it pretty clear I got to stay right here.

text.Zagreus: What if I picked you up bodily and brought you in? Contract have anything to say about that?

text.Skelly: Got to say, you're really getting somewhere, boyo, I'm pretty impressed here! And they don't even pay me to do that, I'm just supposed to stand around!

text.Zagreus: Appreciate the vote of confidence, mate. Maybe you're right and someday I'll get out of here. Hey, if I never come back, you won't just be stuck here forever, will you?

text.Skelly: Heh, hehehe, that's a good one! No! Probably not. Wasn't anything in the old contract about that... huh.

text.Zagreus: Appreciate it, Skelly.

text.Skelly: Hitting a wall out there, boyo? Hey I know the feeling. You just keep at it, though! You're getting tougher, getting smarter... between the two of those, I'm thinking you'll pull through soon enough here.

text.Zagreus: Come on, mate, won't you say who hired you? Was it Achilles? Couldn't have been Nyx...? Is it that big a deal?

text.Skelly: I am an individual of some integrity, boyo, and protect my sources with my life! You'll have to kill me if you want to make me squeal!

text.Zagreus: Hrm.
Say, uh, Skelly? How'd you get here, anyway?

text.Skelly: Oh, you know, just kind of zapped right in, like Papa lets us do! Some of us sometimes. Why do you ask?

text.Zagreus: I meant... how did you get to the realm of the dead, in the first place. Lord Hermes whisk you to the entryway? Thanatos scoop you up, Charon give you a lift, what?

text.Skelly: Oh, haha! Well, that's a little personal, don't you think, boyo? I... I don't like to talk about it much. So, if I could have a little privacy...?
Oh, hahaha, but I do!

text.Zagreus: Skelly, is it really true you don't want to talk about how you got here? Just curious who you used to be. What you were like. Your real name.

text.Skelly: Hey, what makes you think this isn't my real name, pal? I'm offended!

text.Zagreus: Sorry, what I meant was... I was just interested to get to know you better, after all you've done to help. Anything you can share? Trade you for a detail about me!

text.Skelly: ...Well all right... I was once a commander of men. Name of Schelemeus. Captain of the Cretan second fleet, sailing on Athens under King Minos. We were unstoppable... but then one day... one wrong turn... and we sailed straight into the waters of Charybdis.

text.Zagreus: Skelly, that's... that's incredible! So then... you and your crew, you perished at sea?

text.Skelly: I, uh, pfff, hahaha, boyo, you are something else, you know? All that Schelemeus stuff, I could have had you eating out of my hand for days!

text.Zagreus: Oh, I get it. You got me. Fine, then, Schelemeus, but I don't appreciate the trick.

text.Skelly: Yep!

text.Zagreus: Skelly... I'm serious. You really won't tell me anything about you? You're just going to leave me to speculate, forever?
Argh.

text.Skelly: Hahaha!

text.Zagreus: Say, Skelly... or should I say Schelemeus? I happened to have a chat with somebody familiar with that name. Large bull-headed fellow originally from Crete. You said you made it all up! What's going on?

text.Skelly: Never said I made it up, pal! I just knew you weren't going to believe me, I mean, look at me! I look like a captain of the Cretan second fleet to you?

text.Zagreus: I don't know. I've never met one. Do they all just stand around doing nothing?

text.Skelly: Well, sounds like somebody's never had to lead like fifty-or-something sailors in a voyage across the sea in a Minoan galley with nothing but the stars to guide 'em! What do you think the captains do, pull the oars?

text.Zagreus: Wait, what about Hermes? He gave me the impression you might have been somebody else. Nobody in particular. Not some great sea-captain.

text.Skelly: What is it with you gods talking behind the backs of all your friends, boyo?

text.Zagreus: Don't change the subject!

text.Skelly: Don't change the subject!

text.Zagreus: Fine. Maybe.
That Lucky Tooth you gave me, Skelly. First off, thanks again, and secondly... is this even yours? Had a run-in with Hermes, who got me thinking.

text.Skelly: What, haha, you going to believe everything that gabby guy tells you, now, boyo? He doesn't know a thing about me!

text.Zagreus: Never said he did. Though since you let on... what's your relationship to him? Working for him?

text.Skelly: No! Nope. Definitely not working for him, closer to a peer relationship. Well, other than the fact that he's a god and I'm just... well, what you see is what you get with me, pal. Hey, you won't tell anyone, will you? I'm just here to help, I swear!

text.Zagreus: OK.
All right, fess up, Skelly, who are you working for? I know it's not Achilles. It's not Nyx. Dusa has no idea who you are. My father... no way. Hypnos? Give me a break. So the House is ruled out.

text.Skelly: Sorry, pal, my lips are sealed. How about we change the subject?

text.Zagreus: How about you tell me who your sources are?

text.Skelly: Nope!

text.Zagreus: Tell me.

text.Skelly: No way.

text.Zagreus: Tell me!

text.Skelly: I said no!

text.Zagreus: Tell me, Skelly.

text.Skelly: Nuh-uh.

text.Zagreus: Come on, tell me, please?

text.Skelly: No. Means. No.

text.Zagreus: Why won't you tell me?

text.Skelly: Nice try, pal.

text.Zagreus: What if I never hit you again?
So help me, Skelly, if you don't tell me who you're working for, there will be no more violence between us, ever.

text.Skelly: No... please, have mercy, boyo...

text.Zagreus: No mercy, Skelly. Tell me. Or else... it will be only pleasantries between us from here on out.

text.Skelly: Nrrrghh, all right! But you got to promise me something, promise not to let on or tell anybody in your fancy House, all right? Or else I'm done for. I'm serious!

text.Zagreus: I promise. So...?

text.Skelly: ...It's Charon.

text.Zagreus: Charon! Huh.

text.Skelly: Yeah. He's rich. He's got connections to guys like me, and I think he's got a horse in this chariot race you've got going on around here with Papa.

text.Zagreus: What's his angle?

text.Skelly: No idea. Maybe he likes you, maybe he's bored.

text.Zagreus: And Hermes... he's working for Charon, too?

text.Skelly: Yep! Now, let's pretend like none of this ever happened, so I can stick around, all right? Remember, pal, you promised!
If you did, pal, I would not be here right now!

text.Zagreus: Skelly, did you tell Charon and Hermes about our little conversation from before, about your sources? Because, I didn't tell them, but... they seemed to know.

text.Skelly: Boyo, thought we agreed we weren't going to be having conversations on the subject from here on. Spares me having to spill my guts with my sources later.

text.Zagreus: I didn't get you into too much trouble, did I?
Appreciate you answering!
Hey, Skelly, what with everything out in the open now, with the Queen and Charon, and all that... mind if I mention some of this to Thanatos? Charon's his brother, after all.

text.Skelly: Oh! Yeah, now that you mention it, I guess that part of the old contract no longer applies. So, go right ahead! Appreciate you asking, pal.
Hahaha, sure!
Pal, thanks again for that Nectar bottle from before, stuff just goes right through me like you won't believe! Though, I hope you're not going around giving that stuff away to every bozo you know.

text.Zagreus: What, Skelly, you worried something bad is going to happen if I express a bit of generosity from time to time through our somewhat-illicit gift-giving custom around here?

text.Skelly: No, I'm worried you'll be wasting your time! If you give that stuff away, don't expect to get anything back. Well, not after the first time, anyway. Usually! I'm just saying... don't get your hopes up.

text.Zagreus: Maybe I just want to show thanks to my friends for its own sake!
Hey, Skelly? You look like you know your way around Tartarus. Found some of this ancient Titan blood out there, and I was looking to score some more.

text.Skelly: Ah, you've come to the right place regarding that, there, pal! It's your mean weapons back there that can find the stuff. Once you get all the way through Tartarus with one, that's all the blood you're going to get! For the time being anyhow.

text.Zagreus: How am I supposed to keep track of which weapons I've earned these with, then?

text.Skelly: I don't know, there's always the invention of writing stuff down? You'll figure something out.

text.Zagreus: Unlock those first, then, huh.
Skelly, you mentioned the ancient bit of blood I found in Tartarus. Know what I'm supposed to do with this stuff?

text.Skelly: Wouldn't know a thing about it! Definitely doesn't have anything to do with those Infernal Arms of yours, some of which appear to still be unavailable to you, as I understand?

text.Zagreus: That's an imaginative theory, mate.
I should go check it out.

text.Skelly: So the strangest thing happened while you were out, boyo! One of your weapon holder things back there, it picked up this eerie glow! Could see it from the corner of my eye!

text.Zagreus: Calm down, Skelly. I'm sure whatever it is is perfectly normal for a legendary semi-sentient Titan-slaying weapon from the dawn of time.

text.Skelly: That's just it! Those weapons of yours, they have seen some real business, pal. You're giving them a real workout, so maybe they're starting to like you or something? Loosening up a bit, you know? Like you and me!

text.Zagreus: Uh... sure.

text.Skelly: You know, pal, when you're not around and it's just me and all your weapons, I mean your Infernal Arms right over there, between us they are making me a bit uncomfortable.

text.Zagreus: Can't blame you, mate. I wouldn't want to be stuck in a chamber with a bunch of legendary, quite possibly malevolent killing artifacts. Anything I can do?

text.Skelly: Oh I didn't mean it like a bad thing, boyo! The weirder you make those things, the more it gives me the shakes, and keeps me hopping like this nice and steady till the next time you get back! So, thanks!

text.Zagreus: All right, maybe I will.
Say, Skelly? Don't suppose you'd care to tell me how the infamous Twin Fists of Malphon came to be right here in this very courtyard, would you?

text.Skelly: Nope! Not any of my business, pal, which is to say, I didn't see a thing! And even if I did, it isn't what I'm paid to do! Don't you have someone in your fancy House there paid to keep watch over stuff like that? Ask them!

text.Zagreus: I miss my fancy sorcery already.

text.Skelly: Hey, just want to say, pal, that spooky crimson phoenix stuff that you were going on about before? I mean, whoa, you just say some nonsense and you get a brand-new spear? I was so impressed, I decided to try that trick for myself!

text.Zagreus: Oh, gods... Skelly, what did you do...?

text.Skelly: Relax, boyo, just had a little chat with your old serving platter over there after you left, is all. That thing hits pretty hard! So, then, I say to it, I see you through the eyes of the crimson phoenix... and you want to know what happened after that?

text.Zagreus: So you carelessly spoke secret words imparted by the Fates themselves to an infernal weapon forged at the dawn of creation, then what? Say, did you walk up to Aegis, or just shout over your shoulder?

text.Skelly: Over my shoulder! Anyway, what happened next was nothing! Your Aegis kept on bobbing like a dummy. So then I went and said that mumbo jumbo to every other weapon, but nope! Doesn't work at all. So much for your fancy sorcery, huh?

text.Zagreus: As likely an explanation as any I guess.
So, what exactly happened with the formerly pink window over there? Now it's got these sinister orange flames and an enormous Pact of Punishment hanging ominously over the exit. Father stop by?

text.Skelly: Pal, I don't know a thing about it, honest! I was just minding my own business, when all the sudden, wham! I get hit right in the back. I fall to pieces, no idea what's going on! When I finally come to, the window job was done...!

text.Zagreus: All right... maybe.

text.Skelly: Listen, boyo: I don't know exactly how to put this, so I'm just going to come right out. I need your help with something, and, I'll be honest, I don't think you're going to like it.

text.Zagreus: If it doesn't involve hacking away at you with reckless abandon, Skelly, I don't want to hear it. But... oh. You're being serious.

text.Skelly: I am. And funny you should put it like that. Boyo, I am asking you to get me out of here. Permanently, if you catch my drift. This standing around stuff... just kind of wears on you, after a while, you know?

text.Zagreus: ...I know. I can only imagine. Tell me what I can do.

text.Skelly: That blade of yours back there. It's got a special power. You got to spruce it all the way up. Your Aspect, not somebody's else's. Then let me have it with that thing... and I'm out of here.

text.Zagreus: Then you'd be dead, forever? You're asking me to kill you.

text.Skelly: I know it's a lot to dump on you, but I got my reasons. I don't exactly have a lot of options, here, so... give it some thought. Till then, we'll act like nothing's changed, all right?

text.Zagreus: All right... maybe.

text.Skelly: Listen, boyo: I don't know exactly how to put this, so I'm just going to come right out. I need your help with something, and, I'll be honest, I don't think you're going to like it.

text.Zagreus: If it doesn't involve hacking away at you with reckless abandon, Skelly, I don't want to hear it. But... oh. You're being serious.
