Why, look, Asterius, the fiend returns! The rumors that he fled to haunt the surface must have been mere lies!

text.Zagreus: Well no, in this case, those rumors must have been quite accurate, it's just, I'm back! Realized I didn't want a future for myself that didn't include crushing you repeatedly like this.

text.Theseus: Oh, hoho, such clever excuse-making from one so versed in treachery! Well, if you are indeed contained within this realm, then we shall be delighted to make sure it always stays that way! Now come and fight!

Have you yet heard, monster?! The Queen Persephone is back! To rule the Underworld in all her terrifying grace! Perhaps one of these days or nights she shall be present in the stands, to witness your destruction at our hands!

text.Zagreus: Yeah, about that? She's my mother. So maybe watch your fool mouth with me, or else I might just put in a bad word!

text.Theseus: Oh, you disgust me, daemon, that you would even dare to say such things about the Queen! Prepare now to be vanquished in her name!
What's this, Asterius? This blackguard thinks that he can saunter in here whilst bleeding profusely, and confront the two of us?! A hollow fool!

text.Zagreus: Ran into trouble on the way with your combative friends here in Elysium. One more unfair advantage in your favor.

text.Theseus: How would you know of fairness, fiend? You belong in the lowest depths, forgotten in the mists of time! Come, let us send you there!
Look at this contemptible fiend, stumbling half-dead already into our hallowed colosseum! What transpired, monster, did perchance my Exalted brethren trouble your dark path?

text.Zagreus: Theseus? I would appreciate it if you could be more considerate of the substantial effort necessary just to reach this point where I can make you shut your mouth.

text.Theseus: Effort, pah! You shall be imminently slain, and effortlessly, I am quite certain of that! Asterius, to arms!!
What hope can you possibly have of vanquishing us, hellspawn, when you are visibly upon the verge of death? You are, more than usual, a miserable sight!

text.Zagreus: Thanks for your concern, there, Theseus. But I trust I have plenty of life left in me with which to destroy you, if not your companion as well.

text.Theseus: Hah! What would you know of trust! Being a vile, grievously-wounded-already creature such as you are! Asterius, let's end his misery!
What's this? Our enemy has come to mock us, Asterius! He holds the Yarn of Ariadne, and would flaunt it in our faces!

text.Zagreus: What, this? I just picked it out of a Well. Was supposed to help me get here. No offense intended, more than usual. What's it to you?

text.Theseus: As if you wouldn't know! That Yarn is a token of days long gone. When Asterius and I battled in the Labyrinth, to the death! Together, we now face a greater threat. Attack us if you dare!
Again you mock me with the Yarn of Ariadne, blackguard. You ought know that woman's name means absolutely nothing to me, now!

text.Zagreus: You seem pretty put off by a random bit of twine, there, Former King of Athens. Care to share your innermost thoughts on the subject, or best keep them bottled up?

text.Theseus: Nothing shall be bottled here, you filth! That she became enamored of me was not my responsibility, besides! She was naive! The same as you.
That blasted Yarn of Ariadne, once again!! Have you no shred of dignity at all, monster? Or would you stoop to any desperate means to draw me out?

text.Zagreus: Just happened to have it on me, Theseus. But it seems to keep upsetting you. Maybe you should seek this Ariadne in my father's realm, and make amends?

text.Theseus: Maybe you should shut up!! That Ariadne's dead to me. She has been since we were alive! I cherish her memory, yes. But only because, if not for her, I'd not have met Asterius! Now, meet his axe!!
Why, look, Asterius! It seems the fiend has brought some sort of nondescript yarn-ball! Not seen the likes of it. Indeed, it holds no sway on me, at all!

text.Asterius: King. The princess Ariadne was my sister, if you don't recall. Please do not denigrate her memory. <Snort> You're making me upset.

text.Theseus: Ah, no, my friend! I meant you no offense! But I'd no love for her, was that my fault?! Pff, forgive me. I... I shall seek her out. Someday or night. But first!! This daemon has to be destroyed. Together, no?!
Why, look, Asterius! It seems the fiend has brought some sort of nondescript yarn-ball! Not seen the likes of it. Indeed, it holds no sway on me, at all!

text.Asterius: King. The princess Ariadne was my sister, if you don't recall. Please do not denigrate her memory. <Snort> You're making me upset.

text.Theseus: Ah, no, my friend! I meant you no offense! But I'd no love for her, was that my fault?! Pff, forgive me. I... I shall seek her out. Someday or night. But first!! This daemon has to be destroyed. Together, no?!
Now hold a moment, fiend! Asterius made me aware that you recently asked of him an autograph. A tribute to his fame! As I am Champion, I am prepared to generously offer mine, as well.

text.Zagreus: Oh! No thanks. Appreciate the offer, though. How about a fight, instead?

text.Theseus: Ah, pffsch, you...! 'Twas merely a jest! I'd not have given you the cloth about my loins, much less my name! But a fight you certainly shall have!
Ready yourself, Asterius, my friend! For our most hated enemy has come to challenge us again, before this loving crowd!

text.Zagreus: I don't understand this place at all. How is it you're still champion after all this time? After losing repeatedly and often, I mean.

text.Theseus: What would you know of it?! There's more, much more, to being champion than empty victories! It is a way of thought. A bearing! A certain dignity which you shall never have!
The gods are testing us once more, Asterius! For, how else to explain this fiend approaching us, bearing such blessings as would normally be fit only for heroes such as we?

text.Zagreus: You do know I'm related to them, right? The god of the dead is my father? I'm sure word's gotten around. Not that I want deferential treatment from the likes of you.

text.Theseus: Good! For you'll get nothing of the sort. The gods are on my side, not yours, monster! What business would they have, abetting you?
Beware, Asterius! The daemon comes! The daemon, who would sever the fraternal bonds we share, if we so much as drop our guard!

text.Zagreus: What? You think I'm here to ruin your friendship? Look, to each his own in that regard, though since you bring it up, I really don't see why Asterius puts up with you.

text.Theseus: You see? Just as I said! Cover your bovine ears, Asterius, for this monstrosity would poison us to get the upper hand!
You know, hellspawn, I have been thinking on this for some time, and I've a declaration I must make: I shall hear no more of your silver-tongued lies. You come here, and we fight, and that is all!

text.Zagreus: What are you even talking about? I barely get a word in edgewise, much less Asterius over there. You know what? Fine. I've had it with you, anyway.

text.Theseus: And I've had it with you! Now, come, Asterius, let's shut this blackguard up! Or shut him down, whichever you prefer.

There is but one thing I shall give to you, blackguard. Other than the razor-sharp point of my blessed spear! You are resilient. Time after time, you challenge us! Sometimes I fear I shall develop some sort of grudging respect for you!

text.Zagreus: I've no such fear, myself, Theseus. Though, I appreciate you noticing. You're quite an inspiration, you know? I wouldn't come all this way to destroy just anyone.

text.Theseus: To be destroyed, you mean! I see you plain, monster. You seek the glory of this fight, before this crowd? You yearn for it! Then, you shall have it! Just as often as you please!
I vividly recall our every clash against you, daemon. Each victory! And even the defeats. But you? You've not learned anything, have you?

text.Zagreus: It's all right, Theseus. We have a splendid painting of you back at the House, for those moments when I invariably forget you exist. You were quite dashing with long hair, you know!

text.Theseus: So, I am honored even in the lowest pits of hell? And yet, remembered in my carefree youth. Not in the wisdom of my latter days! Well then, remember this!
What, ho, that is a handsome spear you doubtless claimed deceitfully from some more-worthy bearer than yourself!

text.Zagreus: Oh, this old thing? How nice of you to notice. It once belonged to the hero, Achilles. A little past your time, but maybe you've heard of him? Seeing as he's much more famous than you ever were.

text.Theseus: How dare you say such things to me! I was the greatest king of Athens in my day! The tales of my exploits with Asterius and many other challenges shall long outlive whatever comes of you!
Tell me something, monster: Whence did you steal that kingly blade you're brandishing about? It seems ill-fitting for one such as you.

text.Zagreus: Oh, this? I wouldn't say I stole it, so much as naturally wooed the Fates into bestowing it upon me. You could say I'm kind of testing it out.

text.Theseus: Ahh, well then! I pity whosoever shall lay hands upon that cursed thing, once you are finished with this testing of yours. I think that we can make it rather quick!

text.Asterius: There, king! He has the weapons I told you about... the fists of Gilgamesh. Follow my lead this time.
There, king! He has the weapons I told you about... the fists of Gilgamesh. Follow my lead this time.

text.Theseus: Prepare to be sent back into the depths whence you came!
Ahh, at last! Come, Asterius, let's vanquish this blackguard!
Come, hellspawn, and get destroyed by the two greatest fighters in Elysium!
Dare you clash against the Champion of Elysium and his most trusted friend?
If you seek a swift and righteous death, you fiend, you've come to the right place!
Come forth and die, preferably with some amount of dignity!
It's time, Asterius! Let us assert our greatness through single-minded combat!
By the gods of Olympus, you'll go no further on your wicked quest!
There is no greater pleasure in Elysium than vanquishing the likes of you!
I swear upon my honor, fiend, you shall not pass!
No matter how you try, you cannot shake the bond we share, monster!
You stop right there, blackguard, and make your plans for death!
We've nothing left to say to one another, hellspawn! Other than: To battle!
Few others in Elysium are so unwise to take up arms against Asterius and myself!
You challenge us to battle, hellspawn?! Then, Asterius and I accept!
Attack us if you dare, blackguard! Asterius and I stand ready!
I see my brethren failed to thwart your advance. Well, you shall go no further!
Come forth, blackguard, and be vanquished by my righteous spear!
Asterius and I shall smite you back into the lowest depths of hell!
You are beneath the notice of the gods, monster! Whilst I have earned their favor!
You return at your peril, hellspawn. You'll get no quarter here!
Upon my faith, you'll take not one more step toward the light of day!
Face us, filth! However many times it takes, until you cannot stand it any longer!
Behold, Asterius! Our hated enemy has come to be dispatched before a loving crowd, once more!
Try as you might, monster, you shall not shake either my own resolve, or that of my dear friend!
Our foolhardy challenger approaches once again, I see! Well, then, prepare to be run through!

text.Asterius: You face the Champion, and me. Ready yourself.
You face the Champion, and me. Ready yourself.
Let us destroy him quickly, king. Or, perhaps slowly.
Let us destroy him quickly, king. Or, perhaps slowly.
Waste not more words with this one, king. Let's fight.
Waste not more words with this one, king. Let's fight.
It is as the king said. You will not leave Elysium except through us.
It is as the king said. You will not leave Elysium except through us.

text.Theseus: Look who has managed to come crawling back, Asterius? Let us deliver him again!
Try as you might, monster, Asterius and I shall stop you!
You must take sick, appalling pleasure in defeat, hellspawn!
I shall never yield the title Champion of Elysium to the likes of you!
You think that you can get through me again, hellspawn? Come try!
I always shall rise up to thwart your wicked plans, monster!

CHOICE.DROPPED_Megaera: About damn time I finally got you, Zag.

CHOICE.Asterius: The Champion and I will reign forever.
May this defeat fill you with vengeful fury.
I will be waiting for you to return.
It will take you more than that to vanquish me.
This is the fate of those who challenge me.
Return to the bowels of hell, short one.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Can I get some applause or something here?
Hope you enjoyed the show out in the stands!
I guess I win this round.

CHOICE.Theseus: That was my friend, you bastard!
That was my friend, you bastard!

text.Asterius: Observe this gleaming coat of bronze with which I am adorned, now, short one. <Snort> Your doing, as I'm to understand.

text.Zagreus: My father is to thank for that, not me. I've proven difficult for him to contain, so now I'm beneficiary of his latest Pact of Punishment. You're welcome!

text.Asterius: I hadn't thanked you, as of yet. Though, come. I'll repay you suitably for having me encased within this... suit.
Tell me, short one, where is your own armored suit? I would prefer not to do battle against one who's ill equipped.

text.Zagreus: You know, my father keeps the dress code very strict down there in Tartarus. No armor in the House! Never tried the stuff.

text.Asterius: Dress code. <Snort> I, too, follow a code. And it's a code that strictly states I cannot let you pass without a fight.
Even with this armor I was unable to best you one-to-one. Perhaps I lack as yet the necessary training to take full advantage of its benefit.

text.Zagreus: I don't suppose you have some good acquaintances with whom to train, until such time as you see fit to face me once again?

text.Asterius: No. <Snort> King Theseus is occupied with preparations of his own. You are my good acquaintance now.
I am returned once more to my more-earthly capability, short one. And I am able to move freely once again.

text.Zagreus: Fine change of pace, Asterius! Who needs that old, spectacular, custom-fitting suit of legendary armor, anyway?

text.Asterius: You mock me. Yet you know nothing of being trapped; enclosed in something and unable to break free. I need no armor to fight you.
You haven't spoken to your fist-weapons yet, have you, short one? 'I see you overcome the wild and make peace with death.' That's what you're supposed to tell them. I'm sure of it.

text.Zagreus: Just been a little tied up lately is all, but I will get to it, Asterius! I guess you'll want to know the result?

text.Asterius: Yes. Here, I'll give you this chance to get home quickly, if you want to know, yourself.
There, on your hands... the weapons you call Malphon. They're just as I saw in my dream. Monstrous. Like me.

text.Zagreus: Former property of someone called Gilgamesh. The beast-man he fought, Enkidu... you said they became friends? What said your dream about us on that front, sir?

text.Asterius: It didn't say much. Only that we would fight. Just as that Gilgamesh and Enkidu once did. Maybe the outcome will be the same, maybe it won't. We'll find out.
You come from the bowels of hell. This is not your place.

text.Zagreus: Agreed on both counts! Just passing through, so if you'll excuse me...

text.Asterius: I will not. <Snort> The Champion of Elysium would never back down from such a contest. Neither will I.

text.Zagreus: Wait, you're not the Champion of Elysium...? You're the Bull of Minos! I can't imagine who's even stronger than you. Is it Heracles? Tell me it's Heracles.

text.Asterius: I will not. <Snort> You talk too much, short one. Come get destroyed.
You come from the bowels of hell. This is not your place.

text.Zagreus: Agreed on both counts! Just passing through, so if you'll excuse me...

text.Asterius: I will not. <Snort> The Champion of Elysium would never back down from such a contest. Neither will I.
You have met the Champion, the king. Let us see if you are fit to face him once again.

text.Zagreus: You mean face both of you, together. Which doesn't seem particularly fair.

text.Asterius: Life isn't particularly fair, short one. Nor death. I'd have expected you to know as much. But here, have your fair fight.
Let us clash here again before you face the Champion. We never will allow you through without a fight.

text.Zagreus: You're nothing like Theseus. Why go along with everything he says and does? You're your own man. And bull.

text.Asterius: King Theseus slew me in life, and saved me in death. I was cast into Erebus. A monster. He found me when he died. And used his influence to bring me here, with him.

text.Zagreus: That's nice of him and all, but sounds like you're even to me. Seeing as he killed you in the first place.

text.Asterius: No; we're not. And I will fight for him, and alongside him, for eternity. As recompense for helping me to understand exactly who I am.
You bested the Champion, himself. Which means that I have little hope of vanquishing you, here.

text.Zagreus: So then, why bother fighting me? You don't have to do this. That Theseus is a highly questionable influence on you!

text.Asterius: I see you plain, short one. I, too, was born of darkness. But, I chose the path of light. Even in death, it was not too late. <Snort> Not even for a monster, such as I. I trust your deaths will likewise be enlightening.
This heat... it reminds me of when I was young. Living in darkness. Learning to fight. To kill.

text.Zagreus: I suppose you're about to put that learning to practice in another moment here?

text.Asterius: I am. The heat fills me with strength. Let's see if it has any effect on you.
Ah. I sense another furious battle here awaits us, short one. Although you're more inquisitive than usual...

text.Zagreus: Uhh, oh! It's just, I have an odd request. You see, the god of slumber, Hypnos? Colleague of mine. Huge fan. He's in desperate need of your autograph. Little personalized message? I don't suppose you'd be so kind. It'd mean a lot to him.

text.Asterius: Autograph. I see. Then, it appears there are such gods as favor me. I will inscribe a bit of parchment for your colleague, then.

text.Storyteller: The god-forsaken Minotaur impresses then upon a parchment a brief message to the god of sleep, and gives it to the favor-asking Prince.

text.Asterius: Know, short one, that this favor is for you and not for Hypnos. Though he may challenge me himself, at any time.
Huh. You mean to fight with me bare-handed this time, short one? I'm not ashamed to say the Champion himself defeated me in such a manner back when we drew breath.

text.Zagreus: Wouldn't say the Twin Fists of Malphon counts as empty-handed, sir, though it surprises me to hear you could be beaten in such a way.

text.Asterius: I was hungry and unprepared. Inexperienced. No longer. Come.
You must take pleasure in having to fight against me, short one. I, too, have come to look forward to it. Even if I end up falling to your strength.

text.Zagreus: Oh, I was going to say, I'd much prefer we settle this more amicably, couldn't we? Perhaps I could interest you in a fine bottle of Nectar? Ambrosia, even?

text.Asterius: No, thank you. These battles are enough. Besides... you won that Ambrosia from us, fair and square.
Well, you're back, short one. Or Prince. Whatever they call you. I'm not much for formality.

text.Zagreus: Not much for it either, here, Asterius. Though, speaking of which, how would you prefer to be addressed? The Minotaur, the Bull of Minos? Those aren't offensive to you, are they?

text.Asterius: They don't mean anything to me. They mean something to others. I have my name. You know it. Use it if you want. Now, enough.

text.Zagreus: Say, you're from Crete, originally, aren't you, Asterius? I know this is a stretch, but... I don't suppose you ever heard of a commander by the name of Schelemeus? Captain of the Cretan second fleet, something like that?

text.Asterius: The king of Crete commanded the greatest navy in the world. Even I knew that, having never seen the light of day, the ships, the sea. Schelemeus, huh...? I might have heard the name. So what?

text.Zagreus: What, Schelemeus was a real person, then? But, Skelly said... ah, you know what, it's nothing, Asterius. Shall we?

text.Asterius: Yes. Let's.

text.Zagreus: I see you overcome the wild and make peace with death!

text.Asterius: You've come, short one. I dreamed of this very moment.

text.Zagreus: Come on, Asterius, we've fought how many times already? What's there to dream about?

text.Asterius: No. I dreamed. And in my dream, there was something I had to tell you. Rather... something you have to tell the weapons you wear on your hands. Tell them, 'I see you overcome the wild and make peace with death.'

text.Zagreus: Hey, I know what that is, that's a waking-phrase. So I'm to speak it to Malphon. Wait, why are you helping me?

text.Asterius: I don't know whether I'm helping you or not. But in my dream... an ancient hero fought a beast of a man, barehanded. They became friends, in the end, after a great battle. I long for a fight like that.
I wonder something, short one. You keep coming back. But I don't know why. You're trying to get out of here, aren't you? But something's killing you up there.

text.Zagreus: You've deduced more or less correctly, Asterius. And yes, let's say there are some challenges remaining once I get out of Elysium. Though I'd best say no more of it than that.

text.Asterius: That's fine. It's good to know you've fallen just as often as I have. I may not be the one to kill you. But I'll soften you up for whoever does.
You ever make it out of here, short one? I wonder, sometimes, what it must be like... the outside.

text.Zagreus: You've never been outside? Oh, right... the labyrinth thing. You lived in a horrible maze all your life. I haven't seen much of the surface, but... it's beautiful. Cold. When I'm there, though, I... feel out of place.

text.Asterius: Out of place. I understand, I think. I don't see why you'd want to go somewhere like that. It can't live up to the stories. Why ruin it? Speaking of which...
Everyone's saying that the Queen is back. Do you know what that means, short one?

text.Zagreus: Well, for me, at least, it happens to mean quite a bit. I'm her son!

text.Asterius: It doesn't mean a thing. We're still here to fight. Though, for what it's worth... my mother also was a queen. May yours treat you better than she treated me. Better than I'm about to treat you, here.
I smell the blood on you, short one. <Snort> You are severely wounded. This will not be a fair fight.

text.Zagreus: An unfair fight is not worth having, then, wouldn't you say?

text.Asterius: I would not. An unfair fight is better than no fight at all.
You're hardly in a state to fight against me, here. Won't take too long to bring you death.

text.Zagreus: Great! Thanks for the encouragement, Asterius. Don't let me keep you waiting on that, then.

text.Asterius: If mere words can sap your will for battle, short one, then know this: You never stood a chance.
You look as though you withstood many foes in getting here this time. Barely withstood, that is.

text.Zagreus: They took a lot out of me, yes. But you have no idea just how long and arduous a trip it is from Tartarus to here!

text.Asterius: What would you know of arduous? Try living in an ever-shifting maze of countless passageways. Now let me finish what your foes began.
We meet again, short one. For further battle.

text.Zagreus: Short one?! That's a low blow, sir. I thought you were the big-honorable type.

text.Asterius: You mock my sense of honor. <Snort> Common tactic. Now prepare.
You choose to challenge me again. Not many in Elysium so dare. Then, I accept.

text.Zagreus: Wait, I never challenged you! The entrance to your chamber looks like any other pathway in Elysium. I have no quarrel with you, sir!

text.Asterius: To step into my chamber is to challenge me. <Snort> It is a custom since the time I lived and breathed in darkness. I will send you into such a darkness now.
My next opponent has arrived in short order.

text.Zagreus: Short order? That was another jab about my height, wasn't it!

text.Asterius: I do not jab. <Snort> All of my strength goes into every strike. Observe.
You have returned to my chamber. I trust you are familiar now with what this means.

text.Zagreus: It means I've challenged you to a battle of strength and glory, because apparently that's all there is to do for fun around here for those such as yourself?

text.Asterius: That... <Snort> Yes. Essentially that is correct. Prepare.
It would seem <Snort> that the time for additional fun has arrived.

text.Zagreus: Ah, yes, my favorite pastime: Getting butchered by a giant double-bladed axe. And sometimes trampled.

text.Asterius: Then, good. You have much to enjoy in store.
Well, short one. It seems I must attempt to maim you here, so that the king and I might finally stop you at the gates.

text.Zagreus: You know, you hurt me with this 'short one' business almost as much as with that axe. Why isn't Theseus 'short one'? We're the same height!

text.Asterius: No. The king is greater. He is the greatest king of Athens! What are you? A willful son of a fickle god. I am beneath your father's notice. And you are beneath the king's. Now fight me.
It is not often that my challengers return to face another slaughter at my hands.

text.Zagreus: Yeah, well. You're kind of in my way. What choice do I have?

text.Asterius: Your choices led you here, and they will lead you to defeat, again.
You are more skilled than I expected, short one. A re-match is most certainly in order.

text.Zagreus: You're going to force a rematch each time I manage to defeat you, aren't you?

text.Asterius: We and our victories are all impermanent here in Elysium. We live, such as it is, for moments such as these.
Your challenge is hereby accepted, short one.
Another challenger. <Snort> Come get destroyed.
I accept all challengers. No prior notice necessary.
You have returned. <Snort> I'm always ready to oppose you.
You enter my chamber once again, short one. Then, good.
I expected you to reappear. <Snort> Let us fight.
Appears it's time we challenged one another once again. Prepare.
Good. <Snort> It feels as though I haven't crushed the life from anything in ages.
Returned to battle me for glory, short one? <Snort> Excellent.
Come fight me again, short one. We have eternity to grow stronger.
Thank you, short one. <Snort> Few in Elysium dare challenge me repeatedly.
The short one from the bowels of hell has finally returned.
I heard you had again entered Elysium. <Snort> At last.
Hold nothing back against me, short one. Now, come.
Let us grow stronger in the ways of battle, short one.
I always am prepared to fight whoever dares oppose me.
Let us battle now before you face the Champion, himself.
You seek the Champion. You must confront me, first.
Hrmm. <Snort> It has been long enough since my last fight.
I've been waiting for another round against you. Let's go. Now.
They said you were headed this way. <Snort> I said I'd stop you. Though, we'll see.
Each time we fight... I think I learn a little more. Let's start.
I had a feeling you would cross my path again. I've been looking forward to this.
I'm going to run you down, or run you through. Your choice, short one.
Told the king I'd try to stop you on the way. He thought I'd have no trouble. <Snort> We'll see.
Come on, short one. I've been waiting too long for this.
You know what it takes to leave this chamber alive, short one. <Snort> Come on and fight.
I have my armor, short one. Let's see what you have.
Let's see if you can cut through my coat this time.
This armor's heavy. But makes me even faster than before. <Snort> Watch.
You are resilient, short one, I will give you that.
I'm prepared to slaughter you again, short one. Come fight.
Interesting. <Snort> Most never challenge me again once I destroy them.
What hope have you against the Champion, if you can't get through me?
You have tenacity, short one. I have to give you that.
You do not take all your defeats to heart, do you? That's good.
You're quick, short one. Let's see if you can get past me again.
Well, short one. I'm curious to see if you can best me once again.
A worthy challenger returns. Let's see you defeat me again.
Glory and honor to you if you can vanquish me again. Come!
I welcome the taste of defeat, short one. It is akin to feeling alive.
I'm still learning all your tricks, short one. Come show me more.
Let's see you get through me again, short one.
I'm the one to challenge you this time, short one.
I have looked forward to repaying you in kind for our last fight.
You're strong, short one. But I am just as obstinate as you.
The Champion awaits, short one. If you can get through me again, that is.
Good. Now I can get you back for last time. All I need is one clean hit.
Well fought. Though, your technique pales in comparison to that of the Champion of Elysium. I expect you'll soon see for yourself.
I respect your strength, short one. The Champion of Elysium awaits. Until such time.
You were a worthy challenger. Most welcome here. Until we meet again.
You have earned your passage. I go now to recover for the next occasion that we meet.
Thank you for sparring with me, short one. I'm glad we've made a habit of it thus.
Urgh... the might of Gilgamesh... I understand it now. But I won't make his friend's mistake. We'll fight again.
Such strength... the strength of Gilgamesh. Thank you for the battle, short one.
Peaaaaace!

CHOICE.Hades: I thought Achilles taught you to be quick.
Kick and scream all you like.
Think you can keep this up?
Not yet persuaded to go back I see?
My foolish brother cannot help you now.
Another contribution from my brother Zeus!
Be thankful that my brother favors you!
Poseidon ought not meddle in others' affairs!
I don't appreciate this, Brother Poseidon!
Brother Poseidon making time to meddle here?
Poseidon must assert himself at every opportunity!
Athena cannot save you from me, boy.
I'll slay you once her shield falls.
Athena would be wiser to stay out of this!
How good of wise Athena to join in!
Where would you be without Athena's aid?
Pah, that meddlesome goddess of love!
You think of her at such a time as this?!
Must Aphrodite get involved in everything?
To Aphrodite all of this must be some sort of jest!
The hunting-goddess ought choose lesser prey.
Artemis! This hunt is well out of your league!
You are the prey, not me.
You'll need more arrows than that!
Boy, you're the one who's being hunted here!
The goddess of the hunt ought know when to retreat.
Predictable the war-god would be here!
You'd best stay out of my affairs, Ares!
This shape-shifting of yours won't last for long.
This must be a delight for your dear cousin Ares, boy!
That Ares can turn any small dispute into a war!
That drunkard's power means nothing to me!
Why are you staining my clothes with wine?!
You think this cause for celebration, boy?!
You cloud your senses with this foolishness!
This is a battle, not a time for revelry!
You would seek aid from drunken Dionysus, then?
Demeter had best stay out of my affairs!
That cold witch worsens the weather still?!
The cold is of no consequence to me!
My foster sister must have better things to do!
That Demeter ought tend some other plot of land!
I'll not indulge such outbursts from you, boy!
You'd pit my own kin, against me?
How vile that you'd drag Olympus into this!
You leave Olympus out of this!
It seems you need all of the help that you can get!
Ah, yes, my dear family being of such help!
So this is how Olympus is assisting our domain?!
How cordial of Olympus to appear!
Megaera, what are you doing here?
Why spring to his assistance, Megaera?
Don't bother to assist him, Megaera!
Get back to your assignments, Thanatos!
Don't you have mortals to attend to, Thanatos?
No need to listen to him, Thanatos!
Distracting Thanatos from his duties, I see!
You needn't drag poor Thanatos into this mess!
Return immediately to your post, you wretch!
You shall be very sorry for this, wretch!
Was that a boulder from the blasted sky?
Your handiwork, I take it, Brother Zeus?!
Was that your foolish doing, Poseidon?!
Another of your blasted boulders, boy?!
A collapse from the Temple, nothing more!
Was that the blasted boulder from before?!
You mean to mock me with such tricks?
A laughable excuse for an assault.
Foul weather is the only kind!
This isn't what we compensate the gorgon for!
Return immediately to your post, gorgon!
You're a custodian, not a combatant, gorgon!
What is the gorgon doing here again?
You summon our custodian for help?
Begone with you, back to Elysium!
The famous spearwork of the Myrmidons!
You've still some spark, then, Shade?
Invite more of your friends, why don't you, boy?
Leave that one out of this!
Who else shall you drag into this?

CHOICE.Zagreus: Down, boy!! No treat. No treat!!
Bad boy! I mean.. good boy?!
Don't have to do this, boy!

CHOICE.Hades: Fight me for real, damn you!
Let's see you deal with this!
I shall not fall to you again!!

CHOICE.Zagreus: If you beat me, I'll just keep coming back!

CHOICE.Hades: Consider that a reimbursement for last time.
You are somewhat stronger than expected, boy.
How arrogant of you to think you are superior to me.
I am still more than capable of besting you.
How many times shall you make me do this?
Keep trying vainly as often as you like.
Your flailing attempts against me are embarrassing.
You're stubborn, boy; however, so am I.
Do not become too prideful with me, boy.
I expected more from you than this.
Where was your savage strength this time?
I expect more consistency from you.
You could have done better than that.
Beats listening to incessantly complaining shades.
I still have some of my old strength, it seems.
You did make it this far at least.
Be mindful of the House while I am gone.
Perhaps next time you shall fare differently.
Sometimes one's best is insufficient, boy.
Next time, I shall expect better results from you.
Not even the combined might of Olympus was enough.
Seek better help from all your relatives next time.
Would that you applied yourself to something worth the while.
I send you home now with nothing to show for it.
You're as disgraceful as our kin upon Olympus.
I told you, boy, that there is no escape.
Someday or night you shall look back on this, and thank me, boy.
If this must be the way to teach you discipline, then so be it.
You mind your manners once you return to my hall.
You well could have expected this result.
Weakling! Remember that I vanquished Titans, boy.
Supposing I shall see you here again some other eve.
Now that we're finished here, I can get back to work.

CHOICE.Skelly: I, uh... I'll just be over here.

text.Hades: You now know that, even if you are able to surpass me, you shall ultimately perish, soon enough. And yet you still persist! Utterly senseless.

text.Zagreus: I found her, Father. And I'm going to find Mother again. And again, and again, until I have some answers, finally. She'd like some answers, too, beginning with why did you never tell her that I lived? You let her go, and left her to her grief!

text.Hades: Silence, boy! Save all your ignorant and baseless accusations. You seem incapable of heeding my request that you not blather on about a matter you shall never understand. Then, I shall save my breath for this fight!
You were never supposed to live. Took all of Nyx's strength to circumvent what should have been a certainty. Now you cannot stay dead. Such is the wry humor of the Fates.

text.Zagreus: Nyx saved me.... So according to the Fates I was never meant to be born, since neither you nor Mother are of the Underworld, something like that? Or was that just another lie you told, to Mother and whoever else?

text.Hades: Bah! You think everything a lie. The realm beneath our feet was appointed to me on certain conditions, not that I had much of a choice. Among them: A one-time surface-dweller such as I would never have an heir.

text.Zagreus: You really believed that? Then why attempt to have a child, anyway?

text.Hades: You don't know anything! Why anyone would choose to have a child is a mystery to me. The Fates said I would never have an heir. Perhaps this was all they meant.
To think Olympus has been aiding you. You must be so grateful to them for their aid, without which none of this would have been possible.

text.Zagreus: Yeah, about that. Father, did... did you let Mother go because you feared Olympus would find out? And... not respond well to the circumstances if they did?

text.Hades: Tsch. Be grateful they have not found out as yet, for all your meddling. You do not know them as well as you think. Ask yourself why she left Olympus, and how. Or better yet, ask her.

text.Zagreus: Well, she seems quite lovely, so... knowing you, you probably tricked her into signing a pact to come join you, or something. Since you weren't allowed on Olympus, why not have Olympus come to you?

text.Hades: Hah! Surprisingly not distant from the truth. I took her, boy! I took her down with me. Is that what you wish to hear? Does that anger you? Come, bring forth that anger, then!
So, boy. Did you ask her? About how she came to join me in the Underworld. Did you confirm all your suspicions, then?

text.Zagreus: You didn't drag her down to hell, yourself, apparently. You're not going to tell me who did, though I can well imagine. Your brothers got to reign forever on Olympus, while you got sent down into the Underworld. So they gave you a consolation prize... didn't they?

text.Hades: You make such accusations, knowing next to nothing. Careless as ever. Poseidon had nothing to do with it! He knows even less than you. If you value her existence or your own, you would be wise to keep it that way. And to turn back!

...She was the Queen. Queen of the Underworld! My Queen. Commanding reverence, and awe, and fear. She was not just... what was the term you used? A consolation prize? You are as disrespectful to her as you are to me.

text.Zagreus: Oh, what would you even know?! You claim so much respect for her, yet you didn't even respect her enough to tell her what happened after she left! But... what am I saying... I know you love her, still, Father. That best explains all the terrible choices you've made.

text.Hades: ...All the terrible choices I've made. By the time you have existed for as long as I have, pray you will have made fewer. Although I fear you shall surpass me in at least this one regard.
Go. Before I reconsider.
...I have done virtually everything within my power to prevent this. All of it... for nothing. The Fates were not content to saddle me within the earth; they mock me, still.

text.Zagreus: Maybe they just think you're in the wrong. And that you're an obstinate, overbearing, miserable excuse for a husband and father. Don't you understand I'm trying to fix the problems you caused? Since you're so unwilling to do it yourself.

text.Hades: You're right. I was unwilling. I made my choices, in all this. I loved her, yes. I loved her terribly. But now... it seems I am merely delaying the inevitable. Go, then. Go to her. But, should harm befall her... I shall bring my worst wrath upon whomever is to blame... including you.

text.Zagreus: What? You're letting me go, just like that? You're just afraid of getting struck down again. You're serious?
To the death!

text.Hades: Heh. Confronting you like this... it's different now. Still... it is a responsibility, just as before. There is to be no escape from my realm. Ultimately, I must see to that, myself.

text.Zagreus: That's the spirit, Father! As for me, I find the candor of our interactions here to be rather refreshing, I must say. Especially the interactions between my weapons and your physique. You're tough, but you're an easy target.

text.Hades: And you are scrawny, though slippery, blast you. All that pent-up rage behind your smiling words... come, unleash it once again. I expect you to go all out. To the death!

text.Zagreus: Let's go!

text.Hades: I was reviewing the terms of the Pact of Punishment to which you are bound. Even when my servants resort to extreme measures, they were still unable to surpass you, then. So now, it is my turn.

text.Zagreus: Caught you unprepared, did I? After Theseus and his Macedonian, I half-expected to see you thundering around on some golden chariot of your own, drawn by sable steeds, that sort of thing. But it's just you.

text.Hades: It is just me, indeed. However... that should be more than necessary, here. No holding back this time, Zagreus. Are you ready?
What have you done with my ancient weapon, boy? I sense Varatha's form there in your feeble grip, but... there's some garish power you've awakened in it, haven't you?

text.Zagreus: Oh, just took a splash of Titan Blood at the right time was all. There's more to your ancient weapon than you gave it credit for, I guess. Though let's not keep it waiting, no?

text.Hades: No, let's not. Gigaros is the mightier weapon, with none of the treacherous past. It needs no fanciful shape-shifting tricks to run you through. Behold!
I never had any respect for Stygius, that blade you bear. Perhaps unfairly, due to Brother Poseidon's sloppy form when once he wielded it. But now it seems quite different in your care.

text.Zagreus: I think we've grown quite close to one another, yes. Enough to where I've come to know a different side of this fine blade right here. This is the aspect of some Arthur fellow! Maybe the two of you could get acquainted properly?

text.Hades: Arthur! No name either of gods or kings of any realm I know. Then, introduce us, as you say! To this new amateur, to whom your blade rendered its services.
The bow is the weapon of a coward, boy. I said so even to Hera's face. I'm unsurprised that you are drawn to it, and yet... something has changed about it, I can tell.

text.Zagreus: What, you mean that Coronacht has taken on the aspect of a divine preserver person of some sort, of whom I've seen mere glimpses but seems definitely very capable, and really rather brave?

text.Hades: I know not why the old Infernal Arms endear themselves to you. And, I entirely care not in whose weakling aspect you bring them forth, only to fall to me.
There you are, bearing my brother's blasted shield... flaunting it about so recklessly. Though, what have you done to it, now?

text.Zagreus: Not much, really, besides awakening the aspect of a supposedly unstoppable, dragon-slaying warrior called Beowulf. If it has the power to protect him against a giant lizard, I figure it may help me against you.

text.Hades: You presently shall find I'm no mere giant lizard, boy. Though we shall see whether this Beowulf is any help to you.
Resorting to mere fisticuffs with me... though, how you got Malphon to look like that, I've no idea. Pray tell, whose monstrous claws are those? A manticore's?

text.Zagreus: These claws, I'll have you know, Father, belonged once to an ancient god-king known as Gilgamesh. You ever meet?

text.Hades: Hrm. Provided he was flesh and blood at some point, then he resides within my realm. Presumably within Elysium somewhere, sadly bereft of his manticore claws, thanks to you. Come, show me what they can do.
You approach me with that loathsome Rail, boy. Emanating a hellish fury more even than usual, at that. Little surprise you took a shine to it. It was the weapon that I hated most of all.

text.Zagreus: Well, someone called Lucifer apparently thought differently, and took a crack at his own father with it, once. This one's for him, then.

text.Hades: Invoking names you know nothing about. Presuming, all the while, far too much. You take that monstrous artifact for another friend? You would be wiser to be wary of its influence. But, let us fight.
Ah, but there you are, boy, finally. Despite my knowing you are always late for everything, here you've outdone yourself by quite some time.

text.Zagreus: Oh shut up, and get your fork, and burn away that regal cape, and let's get to this, then. I'd no idea you had all these capes to spare! Must have a whole entire storage chamber full of them.

text.Hades: Your mockery of me may temporarily embolden you, but achieves nothing useful, in the end.

This cold white substance falling slowly from the heavens. Snow, they call it. Look carefully upon each fleck. Tiny crystals! But structurally weak. They melt! This surface realm... it is held up by mine.

text.Zagreus: If you're quite finished teaching me about this snow phenomenon, can we get on with brutally trying to kill each other, here?

text.Hades: You wish to have your mortal-colored blood spill once again upon this bed of snow, then fine. Let us proceed.
You still have yet to see the sun itself. You know only the light of Ixion, but the sun? It is positively blinding. Hideous.

text.Zagreus: It has been snowy nightfall every single time now that you mention it. I didn't know it snowed so much up here.

text.Hades: It hasn't always. But, that's of no consequence to us. Especially when there's a raging battle to be fought.

If you are here, then... the Olympians must still be lending you their aid. Just as before! I scarce believe the Queen's preposterous idea worked. That all it took to settle an old score was a blasted family feast.

text.Zagreus: Come on, Father, even you must have enjoyed that feast to some extent. We ought to do it more often! Good thing you trusted Mother's judgment on that one. So, then, to the death, once more?

text.Hades: Indeed. To the death, as always, boy. Zagreus. Ready yourself.

text.Zagreus: No. You're going home, not me.

text.Hades: ...I never grew accustomed to the air, up here. It gusts senselessly whichever way it pleases. I suppose you must prefer it to the stillness of the air below.

text.Zagreus: You know, you're right. The air up here seems pretty good so far. But I will reserve judgment till I've had my fill. I have to say, though, Father: The Helm of Darkness suits you. I'm touched you'd dust it off on my account.

text.Hades: It should not have had to come to this. For all your antics with me and around the House, I always kept my temper, have I not? Unlike you.

text.Zagreus: Well, let's see. You've berated me repeatedly and often. You've lied to me. Mustered your wretched forces to kill me, over and over. But, sure, I'll grant you that you've always kept most of your anger bottled up. All that's about to change, then?

text.Hades: We're gods, boy. Killing one another is our lot. Although, I always thought I was above it. I told you that you cannot leave this place. It seems I must enforce my rules myself. I'm sending you home, now.

text.Zagreus: No. You're going home, not me.

text.Hades: ...I never grew accustomed to the air, up here. It gusts senselessly whichever way it pleases. I suppose you must prefer it to the stillness of the air below.

text.Zagreus: You know, you're right. The air up here seems pretty good so far. But I will reserve judgment till I've had my fill. I have to say, though, Father: The Helm of Darkness suits you. I'm touched you'd dust it off on my account.

text.Hades: It should not have had to come to this. For all your antics with me and around the House, I always kept my temper, have I not? Unlike you.

text.Zagreus: Well let's see. You've berated me repeatedly and often. You've lied to me. Mustered a bunch of incompetent wretches to try to kill me. But, sure, I'll grant you that you've always kept most of your anger bottled up. All that's about to change, then?

text.Hades: We're gods, boy. Killing one another is our lot. Although, I always thought I was above it. I told you that you cannot leave this place. It seems I must enforce my rules myself. I'm sending you home, now.
You know now what you're doing here is without any purpose whatsoever. Even if I don't slay you myself, you'll simply perish when you cross that threshold there. And yet you still persist?

text.Zagreus: I do. Besides, making these treks helps pass the time during the ongoing Underworld renovations. And I'll be in tiptop shape once they're complete!

text.Hades: Would that we had a little more support; the renovations could have been complete by now! As ever, you think only of yourself. But if you must insist like this, then you will find me waiting for you once you get here. Every single time.
Why? Why do you keep showing up? In spite of knowing that the outcome shall be just the same as how it always was?

text.Zagreus: Beats having to toil away under your overbearing supervision. And besides, as you may be aware, I've recently made up my mind to leave this place.

text.Hades: Eughh... utterly incorrigible. When next we meet here, then, we'll keep it brief. I have grown weary of our aimless conversations. Now prepare!
You bear the Sigil of the Dead. I wear the Helm of Darkness. Even devoid of artifacts as these, we fight here without witnesses... in shadow.

text.Zagreus: If only everybody knew you had a mighty son most capable of cutting you down to size, with or without the ability to vanish suddenly.

text.Hades: A very boastful son, who often thinks too much of his ability. Come, then! I'll make you vanish suddenly.
...That pomegranate blossom... I caught its subtle scent as you approached. The Queen has her mother's strength. And much more self control.

text.Zagreus: What, you're afraid of a little flower, now, Father? One that imbues me with the fiercest might of Olympus, granted, but still! It looks harmless, at least.

text.Hades: I fear your little flower there much more than you. The Queen and her mother... they possess power over life. Thus, power over death.
Extreme measures permitted, even still? You must have forgotten to change the conditions of your Pact of Punishment.

text.Zagreus: Wasn't an oversight. You're strong, Father. I want to be as strong, and more. Not that I'm taking after you, or anything.

text.Hades: You wish to test yourself against the full extent of my wrath, then very well. You have earned that right. Besides yourself, only the Titans have. Now, then... attack!

text.Zagreus: To the death!

text.Hades: You vanquished me... even when I threw everything I had at you, and more. I fought you as I fought the Titans themselves, and still I failed.

text.Zagreus: Oh, don't take it so hard, Father. There's always next time, right? Meaning, this time. Maybe I won't be so fortunate.

text.Hades: Of that, I am most certain. Come, let us see the limits of our abilities, then. I warn you: I shall hold nothing back. To the death!

...Nary a whif of Mount Olympus on you, this time. How is it that you clambered all this way, without the generous support of your dear family? Doubtless you merely purged their blessings for some coin.

text.Zagreus: Hey, I resent that, Father! I'm more than capable of getting here all on my own, now, thanks.

text.Hades: Such arrogance has led to many a mortal's downfall... and many a god's.
Odd. No stink of Olympus on you, this time. Have you truly come all this way without assistance from your relatives? Or were you overzealous at a Pool of Purging?

text.Zagreus: Wouldn't you like to know? Not even Nyx believed that I could come this far without aid from the Olympians. Maybe I just have a knack for proving everybody wrong.

text.Hades: You have a knack for being struck down in various, ignoble ways, that much is certain. Come, then! Show me what you, yourself, can do!
Be still. These waters... teeming with Poseidon's river denizens. That one there, before me... it's been taunting me, I think, for quite some time.

text.Zagreus: You offering to take me fishing, Father? Sounds more pleasant than having you slaughter me again, or the other way around.

text.Hades: You mistook my meaning. First, you shall have my spear. Then, that thing shall, if it has not yet come to its senses. Though, if you vanquish me, I'm certain your uncle shall not mind if you extract it, yourself.
It is a testament to the awful might of Demeter that, even with the surge of heat created by the Pact of Punishment you toy with recklessly, this place remains a frozen waste.

text.Zagreus: The Pact did make the road here a little more fraught than usual. But if it couldn't stop me, I can't imagine it could stop Demeter.

text.Hades: Forget her, and the blasted Pact. I'll stop you, myself.
Enjoying the delicate warmth of the surface, b Zagreus? Apparently, the generosity of the goddess of seasons knows no bounds.

text.Zagreus: Does feel a bit different, maybe. Though, Demeter said something about how this spot, in particular, would remain bereft of warmth, as a reminder. Do you think she knows what happened with Mother, really?

text.Hades: Demeter may harbor vengeful feelings and suspicions, but she is no fool. Experience teaches us to know when to quit. Though, evidently, that is a lesson you have yet to learn.
Look at yourself, boy. You barely stand, and yet believe you can surpass me in your current state?

text.Zagreus: It's not exactly easy getting here, you know. But I'm not going back. Not yet.

text.Hades: Perhaps not yet. But very, very soon.

Varatha... I recognize its presence, now. That's not just any three-pronged lance you wield. I could never stand to look at it, once my brothers and my sisters and myself... once our foul work was done.

text.Zagreus: You mean once you'd chopped up your cruel and overbearing Titan parents, right? Shame you threw it out. It's quite useful.

text.Hades: Perhaps the Fates decided that its wielders ought to all eventually wind up on its receiving end. Come, then! Let us see what the great Achilles has taught you.

So! You think that you can vanquish me with my fool brother's old, forgotten blade. Poseidon was never any good with Stygius. Grew envious of my spearwork. Now he's famous for that fork of his! Always taking credit where none is due.

text.Zagreus: Must be hard, knowing that everybody's going to think you learned your spearwork from Poseidon, not the other way around. As for Stygius, I can assure you it's in good hands now.

text.Hades: Your assurances mean nothing to me, boy. You think yourself quite capable? Then show me.
You come here bearing brother Zeus' Aegis. I wonder how much more insulting you could be.

text.Zagreus: What? I haven't even started to insult you here yet, Father. Flustered by the old Shield of Chaos, then?

text.Hades: Doubtless Zeus does not even remember wielding it. I never should have relied on him for anything after that! Then, come. Let's see if you're any better with it than your great uncle.
Hrm. It grew distinctly colder just as you arrived. So Demeter has been in contact with you, then. That witch. Tell me how much she knows.

text.Zagreus: What? I don't... wait, this everlasting winter, it's her doing, isn't it? Why? Don't mortals die when it's cold? Sounds like a lot of extra work for you.

text.Hades: Then you are ignorant. Keep it that way, with her. Lest you risk everything, you understand? The consequences would be far worse than a foul stretch of weather. But, enough talk, now.
Hrm. It grew distinctly colder just as you arrived. So Demeter has been in contact with you, then. That witch. Tell me how much she knows.

text.Zagreus: She lost her daughter... who's my mother. But, Demeter still thinks I'm Nyx's son, and... what have you done, Father? This everlasting winter, it's her doing, isn't it? Freezing mortals to death. Why don't you stop this?

text.Hades: The two of you know nothing, then, it seems. Keep it that way, especially with her. Lest you risk everything, you understand? The consequences would be far worse than a foul stretch of weather. But, enough talk, now.

text.Zagreus: Shut up!

text.Hades: ...The sea... the heavens, and the earth. All of this belongs to my brothers. We are their kin by birth. But we are foreigners in their country.

text.Zagreus: No. No mournful speeches. Now get out of my way.

text.Hades: You impertinent brat. Fine. Impulsiveness runs in the family.
There was a time when Cerberus would never have permitted any soul to exit through that gateway there behind you.

text.Zagreus: Oh, that can't possibly be true! What about Orpheus, Theseus, Heracles, Odysseus? Countless tales of brave men delving into the Underworld, then leaving whence they came!

text.Hades: They left on my authority alone. Nor did they take for granted my good graces. You believe you are entitled simply to walk out of here. From your birthright and your responsibilities! But I am here to tell you, no.
My brothers and my sisters and myself. We, too, wanted to slay our parents. The Titans. Bastards. And worse.

text.Zagreus: And you succeeded. Chopped up some of them into many tiny bits, and sprinkled them throughout the pits of Tartarus so that they can't regenerate! Or so I hear. Inspiring, really!

text.Hades: We had no recourse at the time, save to collaborate. Developed a specific plan, and saw it through. And, the Titans...? You think me cruel, yet know nothing of cruelty. But, here, you want something to hate, then have it!
I must admit to something, boy. Achilles taught you reasonably well. I expected that if anyone could train you into martial competence, it would be him.

text.Zagreus: Though you didn't expect that, one day, I would end up using everything I learned from him against you.

text.Hades: I anticipate more than you know. But Achilles merely practiced against mortals. Now, you practice against me.
Come all this way again, to fall to me? Would that you paid me such respects back at the House.
What is it going to take for you to understand that your place is in the House?!
I shall give you no quarter, boy. Although I doubt that you expected otherwise.
The sea and air are very still this eve. Though I suppose that is about to change.
Know only that I take no pleasure in what I am now forced to do.
There you are. Then let us now commence this ugly business yet again.
The heavens and the seas belong to my brothers; but know that you are still in my domain.
You bypassed Cerberus again, I see. Unfortunately for the both of us.
I had other pressing business to attend to. But I cannot let you leave.
No matter how many times you try, your stubbornness shall get you nowhere with me.
You're back, with Stygius in hand. Come then, and show me your technique!
The Blade of the Underworld cannot help you here, you realize that, boy?
Your heart-seeking Coronacht may have brought you this far, but shall not help you, here.
That heart-seeking bow you wield... it is nothing but a tool for cowards, boy.
So, Varatha and Gigaros are to clash again upon this empty field. Let us have at it, then.
I knew someday the Eternal Spear would turn on me. Let's see you wield it, boy.
The Shield of Chaos... what a monstrous thing. How suitable for you.
You bear the Aegis so much like your uncle Zeus once did.
You think the Rail of Adamant can vanquish me? We'll momentarily find out.
You would take aim at me with Exagryph? Then, very well.
You would attack me with the savagery of the Twin Fists? Then, come.
Again, you seek to use the power of Malphon against me. Fine.
You are predictable in your arrivals here. Less so during the fight itself.
I was just thinking on when last I vanquished you. Come, refresh my memory.
No matter how often you defeat me, I shall face you here.
Remember, I can always get here much, much faster than you.
No matter how quickly you're able to get here, I shall be waiting.
Again, you draw me from all my responsibilities back at the House.
I cannot let you go, boy. Some night such as this one, you'll understand.
I shall be interested to see if you can vanquish me again, here, boy.
Come, show me everything you've learned of how to fight.
You've slipped by Cerberus again, I see. Then, draw your weapon, boy.
I see it's time again that we begin our bloody business here.
This blasted place... how can you even stand it on the surface, here?
Who shall be first to return home this time, do you suppose?
It seems it's time again I sent you home, myself.
Your rampage through my realm ends here and now.
I thought you might arrive right about now. Then, let us have our fight.
You'll go not one step farther past this threshold, boy.
The world beyond my realm is not for you. You're going home.
I wonder, boy, who's going to kill whom this time around.
I cannot fathom why you wish to die repeatedly like this.
Already here? It seems our Underworld still has many failings I shall have to deal with, after this.
Come show your father what you've learned of late. Do not hold back.
Would that you cleaned your chambers with the same devotion you show getting to these heights.
Untold murderous wretches in my realm, all at my beck and call, yet still you made it here.
You have circumvented all of my security measures again. But can you get through me?
I trust you have retained enough of your strength through this ordeal to make this worth our while?
Catch your breath if necessary, and then let us see if you shall earn your bonus for this day.
Bah! Not one of my overseers managed to stop you, again? Must I do everything myself?
I've other work to get to! Arm yourself, and let us end this quickly, boy.
It seems our realm has many weaknesses. I shall deal with them shortly, then.
Let us see if the support you're getting from Olympus amounts to anything of use.
Blast, but you're persistent, even now! Though let us see how strong you are, as well.
I should be getting back to my desk. But I suppose the work can wait.
Ah, there you are, boy! I was beginning to think I'd need a thicker cloak.
Well, Zagreus. Even if I vanquish you, arriving here is a sufficient feat.
I must admit, this is a welcome change of pace from all the parchmentwork.
I suppose that you must be eager to repay me for last time, then?
I expect I shall be able to vanquish you again. Though, we shall see.
Perhaps the blasted Fates shall favor me, for once.
Our last exchange left much to be desired, for my part. But this time, we shall see.

text.Zagreus: Oh great.

text.Hades: ...Tsch. To have been brought this low... by my own ungrateful child. I would expect such treatment from my brothers, but from you...? Nrrrgghhh....
...Such contempt, for your own father. But we are not finished here, yet.
...Your youth provides you with a certain mindless strength. But, such power has its limits.
...Now that we had our little warm-up, it is time that we began in earnest.
...You strike at your own father. What choice does that leave me.
...Hmph. All right, then, boy. You've stirred my anger suitably, by now.

text.Zagreus: Are you serious?

text.Hades: Urgh... no... I'm... not... finished... with you... yet!!
I... how... you.... Go. Go, then. Go!! Get out of here! Get out!

text.Zagreus: I told you that I would, Father. And I'm going to. Goodbye.

text.Hades: ...Wait. Wait, just... if you... if you find her. If you somehow find her? Tell her something for me, tell her... Tell her Cerberus is doing very well.

text.Zagreus: What? Wait. I don't think I owe you any favors, here. Though, answer me one question, and I'll give it some thought, how's that?

text.Hades: ...I know your question, boy. But, ask it anyway.

text.Zagreus: Persephone. My mother. Why did she leave?

text.Hades: ...I... urgh... blood and darkness...
I... how... you.... Go. Go, then. Go!! Get out of here! Get out!

text.Zagreus: I told you that I would, Father. And I'm going to. Goodbye.

text.Hades: ...Wait. Wait, just... if you... if you find her. If you somehow find her? Tell her something for me, tell her... Tell her Cerberus is doing very well.

text.Zagreus: What? Wait. I don't think I owe you any favors, here. Though, answer me one question, and I'll give it some thought, how's that?

text.Hades: ...I know your question, boy. But, ask it anyway.

text.Zagreus: Persephone. My mother. Why did she leave?

text.Hades: ...I... urgh... blood and darkness...

text.Zagreus: You're not going to cooperate with me on this, are you? Even now, knowing Mother wants to see me again?

text.Hades: Urgh! Blast you... you shall ruin everything... with all your damnable questions!

text.Zagreus: Then, die, already. And get the hell out of my way.

text.Chaos: <Laughter>

text.Hades: ...Blast you, boy... we should have never sprung from Chaos... none of this...
Urgh.... <Gasp> How... I... I went all out! And still...?
Blast you, boy. You think you are superior to me? You are a fool.
Urgh...! With your youth comes a certain strength, it seems.
Tsch... I... I shall see you back at home.
How? How is this possible, that this... urgh!
Ungh... The world you seek out there... it's even crueler than the one you know.
Augh! Why... I was much stronger once, than this...
Aah, blast! That you of all my kin would be the one, to do this, to me....
Mmph... No matter how many times you beat me... we're family. There's no escaping that.
Again, you have defeated me, somehow. And yet...
What shall it take... what shall it take for you to...
Ungh, you... tell no one at the House. Do you hear me?
Rrngh, you stubborn... you shrug off death as though it means nothing to you...!
...I shall keep coming back... the same as you...!
You... you think that you're the only one... who shall keep fighting?
I must admit... you've learned something. At some point, in all this.
Urgh... were it not for all my wretched kin upon Olympus, you...
Rngh, vanquished again... by my own fool kin....
Guh! Boy, you speak none of this, to anyone!
Urgh! How did... you accomplish this...?
Nrgh! You cannot escape... none of us can.
Augh... then, go, see what awaits you in this realm...
Gah... I, fell to you, again, I... how...?
Gah... you have your mother's perseverance. How is it that you got this strong?
Urngh! It seems... I was no match for you, this time.
Augh... I'm not as limber as I used to be, while you...?
Nngh... for a student of Achilles... I fear that you surpass even his skill, by now...
Umphh... you broke through every one of my defenses, once again...
Argh... you bested me, I'll grant you, Zagreus...
Ungh... Olympus gave you quite the edge against me, then...
Grngh... you owe this victory to all your relatives...
Not this time.
You cannot goad me this time.
Do not keep her waiting.
Go to her, I said.
Enough of this.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Oh, I was just getting warmed up!
Nice fighting to the death with you.

text.Zagreus: You know, Charon, your associate Hermes apparently had a wager with you that I could beat you twice in a row at some point? I'd hate to disappoint him, so... no hard feelings?
Oh. It's because you're going to kill me.
Erm, Charon, look, I can explain. It's just, I've grown very accustomed to taking stuff throughout my father's realm. I wasn't stealing from you, honestly!
That was not an understanding sound. Wait, why are you brandishing your oar in such a menacing way?
You're just testing me, here, right, Charon? I mean, when you place a huge sum of coin conspicuously within my reach, what do you expect me to do?
Sounds good, mate, when I rob you from now on it's just my way of saying Charon, I would like to battle you to the death right now for a quick change of pace.
Got you, mate! Twice in a row. I guess Hermes wins his little wager with you, then. You tell him I said hrrrrrnnnggghh!

CHOICE.Zagreus: What do you know, a Hellfish.
Should save my coin for something I need.
I'd better try some other time.
They seem busy at the moment.
Doesn't seem like a good time.
They're in the middle of something.

CHOICE.Hades: You're not getting out of here.
Did you really think you could just walk away?

text.Zagreus: Got to go!
I'll just be going!
Well, see you!
Oops I got to run!
Bye-bye!
Begging your pardon!

CHOICE.Zagreus: So all I need to do is sacrifice some of my life essence to go in here?
My keepsake from Chaos will protect me.
Let's pay Chaos a visit then.
Time to make some changes around here.
Not what I need right now.
I'd like to see more options.

CHOICE.Chaos: I suppose that this was unavoidable.
That was not what I had in mind.
I suppose that this was unavoidable.
That was not what I had in mind.

CHOICE.Zagreus: How about a different set of choices?
How about a different set of choices, then.
How about some other Boons instead.
I would like none of these.
Not what I need right now.
I'd like to see more options.

CHOICE.Chaos: I suppose that this was unavoidable.
That was not what I had in mind.

CHOICE.Zagreus: The Fates say no I guess.
I guess the Fates won't let me try that here.
The Fates aren't listening to me.
My authority does have its limitations.
My authority does have its limitations.

CHOICE.Hades: What is it that you're trying now to do?
Do not so much as think about it.
I do not think so, boy.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Ow I shouldn't have done that.
Uff should not have done that!

CHOICE.Chaos: You are exhibiting a lack of judgment.

CHOICE.Hades: Even my wretches don't want you to leave.
Do you feel your blood beginning to boil?
Surely you could have avoided that?

CHOICE.Zagreus: They got me. No way to patch up. Got to keep going.
I'm hurt. Can't heal myself. But I can fight.
Nngh, what I wouldn't give for, say, a healing flask of some sort.
This won't end well for you.
These Fists are going to do the talking, soon.
Haven't you learned your lesson yet?
Has to be the last of this lot.
How many more of these are there.
Must be the last of them.
I beat the Bull of Minos.
I guess I win this round.
Who's the short one now, huh?!

text.Zagreus: Now for the juicy center.

CHOICE.Zagreus: I need to purge a Boon to get out of here.
I have to use the Purging Pool back there.
I need to purge one of my Boons first.
Underworld Customs, got to purge a Boon.
Urgh forgot to purge a Boon.
Have to give up one of my Boons first.
I can switch to a different boon.
I'm sure Lord Uncle Zeus won't mind.
Lord Uncle Zeus won't mind, will he?
I'm sure Uncle Poseidon won't mind.
I'm sure Lady Athena won't mind.
I'm sure Lord Ares won't mind.
I'm sure Lady Aphrodite won't mind.
I'm sure Lady Artemis won't mind.
I'm sure Lord Dionysus won't mind.
I'm sure that Demeter won't mind.
Lady Demeter won't mind, will she?
This boon should serve me better.
A better boon for the circumstances.
A change of boons was in order.
Too good an offer to pass up.
Playing me against each other, aren't they.
I can't say no to that.

CHOICE.DROPPED_Zagreus: All right, then, let's get mad.

CHOICE.Zagreus: The wrath of Poseidon at my beck and call.
All right, let's catch some fish.
I know you can't hear me all the way where you are, Goddess. But thank you.
Lord Uncle Zeus lending his support... I never thought I'd see the day. Or night. Whenever.
Looks like I caught a big one! The power of the seas should be of help.
Interested? In the power to break hearts? Sure, I don't see why not.

CHOICE.DROPPED_Zagreus: I sure could use some company now that she mentions it. The power of the hunt sounds handy too!

CHOICE.Zagreus: The power of the hunt sounds like good company to keep.
With your power, Lord Ares, maybe I'll get out of here yet.
Leave it to the god of wine to liven things up around here.
I've the power of the freezing surface, now.
Appreciate the lift, Lord Hermes sir. Now let's go!
Two blessings are better than one.
Let's make some waves, right, Uncle?
Time to pick up the pace.
They must have lots of these upon Olympus.
I'll have to withstand the whims of Chaos to extract the benefits a few chambers from now.
Should be worth it soon enough.
Sounds like a trade to me.

CHOICE.Chaos: I see no reason not to make it so.
If that is your desire, we shall call it done.
Very well, O Son of Hades.
I had suspected you would choose the same.
Go forth, then, Son of Hades.
Do what you think is best.

CHOICE.Zagreus: My boon from Chaos has transformed.
The boon I got from Chaos has a new effect.
My Chaos Boon switched to a new effect.
A curse of Chaos has been lifted.
A curse of Chaos has expired.
My Chaos Boon evolved a new effect.
My boon from Master Chaos has evolved.

CHOICE.Chaos: A small token of my appreciation.
I wish for you to have this.

CHOICE.Zagreus: I got to hurry it up...
This must be here for me. Right?

CHOICE.Megaera: Too hot for you here, Zag?
How can you stand this heat?
So much for a fair fight.
Looks like you have your hands full, Zagreus.
I have to help him, lord!
How much help do you need?
You don't need me if he's here, Zagreus.

CHOICE.Thanatos: Hate to have to do this.
Don't make me do this, Zag.
Just won't stay dead will it.
This isn't what it looks like, lord!

CHOICE.Sisyphus: Let's get the drop on her!
Why if it isn't Master Thanatos!

CHOICE.Skelly: I'm back, what did I miss?
Oh I will be right back!
Be back in just a sec!
Don't think I'm supposed to be here.
You need a skeleton to stand around?
Be there in just a second or two, pal!
I shall answer the call, boyo!
I hear you, pal, hang on!
It's time to get beat up!
Don't need to tell me twice!

CHOICE.Dusa: Something else I can do for you?
Got more need taking care of, Prince?
Oh hi, I'm here, I'm here!
I'm here, I here I am!
It's time for me to shine!
You got it, on the double!

CHOICE.Patroclus: Let's fight a god, I guess!
Don't think this is our fight.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Where's Skelly when you need him?
Don't think that's going to work!
You sure you won't assist me here, Meg?
I can't do that right now!

CHOICE.Megaera: What did you expect to happen there?
No saving you from this one.
What did you expect to happen there?
No saving you from this one.

CHOICE.Hades: No one shall help you here.
You think that Megaera would aid you, here?!
You truly think that Thanatos would defy me?!
What did you think would happen, boy?

CHOICE.Sisyphus: What good would that do here?
Call us when you need us!

CHOICE.Patroclus: Hah, what would that even do.

CHOICE.Skelly: So you want to give it a rest, or what?
All right, pal, you can stop!
Anytime you want to stop, there, boyo.
Uh kind of stuck here, pal.

CHOICE.Zagreus: First, get past the wretched shades of Tartarus.
Easier said than done, and doubtless I'll be running into Meg.
The river of flame ought to be just beyond.
Find a way up to Elysium from there, and after that...
...All right, let's give it another shot.
I can escape from the courtyard back there.
Wasn't this whole expanse once lush and green?
The Bloodless lie in wait out there I guess.
It's nice and warm out here, I'll give it that.
Just a few rides across the Phlegethon, and up we go.
That blasted Hydra must be back by now.
This place has definitely seen better days.
This place has definitely seen better days. Or nights?
Lovely place to have to smash my way through.
Lots of Exalted Shades between me and the exit.
Asterius and Theseus are probably expecting me.
Just need to storm my way through that eternal paradise.
You know, if I was permanently dead maybe I wouldn't mind all this.
For all his faults, Father did make this place look good.
Another day in Tartarus. Or night, I have no idea.
Tartarus... I won't be stuck here all my life.
Just need to get from here across all that.
I've gone farther than I can see from here.
The chambers of Tartarus have probably all rearranged themselves by now.
I'm going to get through all this.
Long way to go. Think I'm ready.
The path toward the surface lies somewhere beyond all that.
I can do this. I can do this. I can do this.
Through all that... the way to the surface...
Wretches of the damned, beware. I'm coming back.
Tartarus... strong enough to seal away the Titans. But not me.
Fine day or whenever to get me out of here.
I won't back down. Not now or ever.
I know you're out there, Mother.
The ever-shifting hell of Tartarus... you can't contain me, don't you know by now?
How many times has it been?
How many times has it been now?
As many chances as it takes.
Just need to keep at it.
What do you see, bat friends?
Let's have a look at all this.
I think it says it's 48 minutes past the seventh hour.
Just need to keep at it.
Just need to keep at it.
Who is this swarthy looking character?
I bet there were far greater poets.
I know you can hear me, old man.

CHOICE.Storyteller: The vastly irritating Prince gets no response.
The Prince decides he's better things to do.

The stone-inspecting Prince gleans nothing more.

CHOICE.Zagreus: I paid for it, I can mess with it.

I can wait till the next Fountain Chamber.

Cerberus looks so happy! Really perked up since Mother's been back.
Father let me hold Gigaros for once.

I can't entirely get used to seeing us together like this.
Mother looks beautiful. And right at home.

Fine work from the House Contractor.
We're proud of you, House Contractor.

The Head Chef is on the board!

Sleep is for the living, am I right?

CHOICE.Storyteller: Thus having once more gained the surface of his grim-faced father's realm beneath the earth, resourceful Zagreus makes his way toward the one-time abode of radiant Persephone.

It is a journey of considerable distances, which he has already completed many times, and which has always ended in the same result. So... imagine he made it there with just time enough to water the crops and tidy up a bit, before...
Once more, tenacious Zagreus achieves his lofty goal, and, just as every time before, except with some sort of new twist of Fate, perhaps, he goes a little distance, then he dies.
Having already seen the splendid cottage of Persephone sufficient times, the stubborn Underworld Prince nevertheless attempts to go there once again. Although, his memory of it shall have to do.
Reflecting on his victory, Prince Zagreus observes how death can take hold in so many different ways, at times quite slowly, and at other times
The master of this realm, Lord Hades, states that death is inescapable. There is considerable credence to his claim.
Imagine, if you will, the Underworld Prince soon meets one of his typical, ignoble deaths.
The Underworld Prince is getting rather good at this. But let us say he perished anyhow.
There are a myriad of tales to be told, of both great deeds and of vainglorious defeats, and this has been a tale that falls somewhere in the middle, overall.

Having gained the surface once again, Prince Zagreus breaths deeply of the wildflowers, and the roses, and the like, among which one of them contains an allergen so intolerably potent, that it causes this:

As he journeys to his mother's cottage in the cold, loudly-speaking Zagreus calls out to hear the echo of his voice, the blast of sound causing a substantive amount of ice and snow to break off from a nearby mountaintop, and fall, and fall, and...

So complicated is the path to the well-hidden cottage of Persephone that surface-walking Zagreus on this particular occasion sadly zigs instead of zags, plummeting from off a precipice into most-familiar waters...

Amid the wondrous ever-springing garden of Persephone, Prince Zagreus discovers a greenish plant of some sort, supple-skinned and covered all in spines, a bit too small to see, until it is too late...
The limitless variety of fauna dwelling on the surface brings to Zagreus no shortage of delight.
Though, when he makes an effort to communicate with one, its eyes so full of calm intelligence, he learns that bears are not as gentle as they seem.

Horned creatures are familiar to Zagreus, having fought countless Satyrs and the like; but he discovers, this time, that not even Satyrs possess the sheer, ferocious power of a startled mountain-goat...
Snakes and serpents rank amongst the creatures somewhat known to Zagreus, due to their presence in the Underworld.
