So it is with delight that he approaches one upon the surface, greeting it as a familiar friend. It greets him venomously back, using its fangs.
Alas, the wisely-spoken Zagreus... stumbled upon a pit of deadly spears, perhaps?
Prince Zagreus proceeded onward toward his certain doom, entirely too graphic to describe.
Beyond this point lies such a horrifying fate that we had better speak no more of it for now.
Just then, erm, how about a very small yet very deadly beetle landed upon Hydra-slaying Zagreus, ending his attempt?
The never-learning Zagreus then... carelessly fell off a precipice, or something, plunging him into the rapids of the Styx.
Although there are innumerable ways for one to die, our danger-seeking Prince has come to know a sizable variety.
The clever-minded Prince again eluded certain death, up to a certain point, but then, predictably made one of his fatal mistakes, again.
The oft-impatient Zagreus appears to take repeated deaths in stride, and so, here comes another one for him.
Having ventured successfully much farther than before, the surface-seeking Prince encounters setbacks far too hideous to be described.
Just then, the carefree-running Underworld Prince runs headlong into a thick and deadly wall of stone, painted to look like the way out.
Filled with such confidence, the Prince neglected to avoid, erm, stepping on a toxic strain of fungus, so rare you'd not have heard of it.
Having somehow defeated grim Lord Hades in a thrilling fight, Prince Zagreus discovers... it was all a dream! A rather deadly nightmare, actually.
Despite having transcended past the confines of the Underworld yet again, Prince Zagreus proves utterly unable to get past this point.
Imagine that Prince Zagreus experiences some sort of joyous outcome, for a change, in contrast to the arbitrary and unfortunately painful death he shall experience... now.
After defeating his lord father, yet again, Prince Zagreus begins to shiver, and catch cold. And, as is well known, there sadly is no cure for such a thing.

As he explores the wonders of the world, Prince Zagreus discovers a quaint farm, in which he carelessly trespasses, stepping on a farming-tool, which swoops up and strikes him in the forehead, fatally.
One might suppose the Prince's tale most likely ends akin to other tales of the heroes of our time, like so:

The favor-doing Zagreus then walks into a chamber, black as night, but with a blood-red pool, and from it comes a voice which says: Would you mind diving in these waters, Prince? To which the Prince replies, Oh! Sure.
Mere moments from his final victory, the Prince, in his great haste, ignored surveying each side of a rather busy crossing, where a swiftly-passing chariot collided with him, very forcefully.
The often-dying Prince, having achieved his purpose, then reflects upon his life and deeds, remembering his many past demises with such vivid clarity, that this occurs:

In his great hurry to explore the country-side, the hapless-footed Prince steps on the peel of a most-exotic sallow-colored fruit, and tumbles backward with such sudden, violent force that you-know-what occurs.
He cannot kill me like this every time, believes the Underworld Prince. He shall eventually have no more ideas. But the Prince, as often is the case, is wrong.

Just when his victory was all but certain, a fissure opens underneath the feet of the ill-fated Prince, and from it vents a cloud of superheated water-vapor; steam, as it is known! And probably you know what happens next.

Upon the surface realm, the mortal-loving Prince would doubtless find that death still comes in a variety of different forms. One of the most common, yet perhaps least interesting, involves simply waiting... long... enough... until...

Having achieved his goal, the Underworld Prince discovers that the mortal realm is utterly bereft of the life-threatening excitement to which he has grown accustomed, and the lack of anything of note to do, the sheer mundanity, results in this:
Then, erm, valiantly striding Zagreus was set upon by seven Bloodless Slam-Dancers, and slain. Or something of the sort.
So joyfully did Zagreus attempt to gain the surface that, why, he just rose too quickly; and we know how that one goes, from Icarus' tale.
...I have no new tales left to tell. But do not think that you have won, Prince Zagreus... for any tale worth telling... is a tale worth telling again, and again, and again. Bye-bye!
The duty-shirking Prince then met another of his fated deaths, in fashion best left to imagination.
One of these days, or nights, not so very long from now, the Prince may finally traverse beyond this point. And then, what shall become of him and I? Well, hopefully, not this:
The unrelenting Underworld Prince again vainly attempted to proceed beyond the current limits of this tale.
The hint-ignoring Prince again attempted to transgress, to no avail, into domains not yet prepared for his arrival.
Thus having somehow vanquished his own father, the grim god of the dead, defiant Zagreus is finally set free to seek the hidden place in which his long-lost birthmother resides.
How shall that all work out for him? Alas, it is as yet too soon to say.
Pretend for now that the Lord Hades absolutely clobbered him.
Beyond this point, our tale of the Underworld's determined Prince cannot further continue at this time. But time does not stand still, and more, much more, shall someday be revealed....
For now, there is no more to say or show from here, so let us say instead that Zagreus was cruelly killed, again.
The trials of Prince Zagreus have only just begun...
Our tale of the Underworld Prince is far from finished. But the rest of it shall have to wait until another time.
The tale of death-defying Zagreus shall continue at a later time.
Thus having stilled the deathless raging of the bone-forged Hydra, willful Zagreus now presses ever forward, upward, toward his goal: the surface, where his long-lost birthmother resides.
The myriad of challenges and dangers that await beyond the flame-hot river shall be revealed and overcome upon a later time.
Let us imagine that the Prince did not go far, before falling once more into his father's house....
Thus having vanquished the heroic king of Athens, willful Zagreus now presses ever forward, upward, toward his goal: the surface, where his long-lost birthmother resides.
Our tale of the Underworld Prince is far from finished. But the rest of it shall have to wait until another time.
Pretend our deftly-footed Prince did not survive the boastings of the Champion back there.
The burning fields of Asphodel again proved unable to stop the flame-resistant Prince, but then, misfortune struck, just like it always does.
Thus did the fate-confronting Prince traverse Elysium, where he discovers to his great dismay such horrors as can only be detailed at some other, later time.
As hero-thwarting Zagreus approaches perilously closer to the surface, he... perhaps gets caught within a rockfall of some sort.
With oft-undocumented dangers of Elysium well behind him, now Prince Zagreus faces an even greater threat... one which I shall get back to you about.
So stifling is the thick darkness past Elysium, that the ill-fated Prince there bumps his head extremely hard, and dies.
Beyond the splendors of Elysium, the ever-patient Prince shall find his fate, eventually, but not right now, becauseoh no, watch out!
Whilst well within arm's reach of victory, the bull-defeating Prince succumbs to a large pack of sinisterly harmless-seeming rodents.

CHOICE.Zagreus: I see your prideful fall down from the heavens to the flames...

text.Zeus: Why, look, Zagreus, here comes brave Athena, first to reach you among all my kin, in all her shrewdness. So proactive, you contacted Zagreus prior to even telling me, my dear!

text.Athena: Lord Father, would that I could settle even more such matters quickly and discreetly, so that only the most vital of them rise up to the level of your notice, sir. Though, I'm certain Zagreus and I are very grateful you have intervened.

text.Zeus: Nephew! By my divine authority, my oft-misunderstood son, Ares, now shall lend you a small token of his power. I'll make him helpful yet!

text.Ares: It shall be exactly as you say, Lord Father. Your wishes are identical to mine.

text.Zeus: Young man, I know you'd like to get to know the comely Aphrodite face to face, or I don't know, you can decide once you arrive at last! He can decide, isn't that right, my Lady Aphrodite, hm?

text.Aphrodite: Why, I never, Lord Zeus! That sounded rather like a crass remark, from you! How shocking that the golden standard for the rest of us should have such words for me!

text.Zeus: Now, Zagreus, once you arrive, we'll have to find for you a suitable mate, won't we? Fine young man such as yourself! Normally, there's much to choose from around here, with some exceptions, of course... such as my cunning daughter, Artemis. Willfully uninclined to take a mate, at all!

text.Artemis: Yes, Zagreus, in spite of all these perfect, chiseled prospects everywhere about, yearning to marry or embarrass me, for some reason, I prefer to spend my time mostly alone or with my nymph friends in the woods!

text.Zeus: Now, now, young man, whatever you have heard about good Demeter, I'm here to clear the air. She's like a sister to me, yes, but only thus. Although her Titan parents and my own met the same fate.

text.Demeter: Why, Foster-Brother Zeus! Such an unlikely bit of candor there, from you! Almost as though you felt compelled to speak the truth only whilst I'm directly within earshot.

text.Zeus: Have you encountered Exagryph and said to it the waking-phrase I gave to you, young man? Why, I'd tell Exagryph myself! Remember, it's I see your prideful fall down from the heavens to the flames.

Now that is an entirely unusual design, even for Exagryph! So then the waking-phrase has worked. That aspect's bearer, Lucifer, was it? Struck his own lord father! Tried to, anyway. A not uncommon story it would seem.
I gather Lady Demeter's already got her frigid hold on you, certainly not the warmest member of the clan, now, is she? But do be patient with her, she's been through a lot.
My good sister Demeter already tried to poison you against me, as I understand, young man? Oh, foster-sister she prefers I say, loath as she is to accept her role as part of our great family.

You must forgive the Lady Demeter her scornfulness, Nephew, for she is still recovering after the sudden disappearance of her daughter, though it was quite some time ago the girl, poof! Just vanished. I try to lighten up the mood around it every now and then, but no, a sore spot, still!

Poor Demeter, young man. We still wonder what became of her fair daughter. Ran away with mortals, there, perhaps? Some of the tales, even more preposterous. Don't go believing everything you hear, and do be sensitive about the subject, hm? Demeter, she's been through quite enough.

The Lady Demeter still prattles on about her missing girl, Zagreus. But I want you to understand something, all right? She's gone. We all have grieved. Perhaps Demeter shall finally accept what has occurred, and we can move forward, having grown stronger as a family.

text.Zagreus: Sure hope this works.... In the name of Hades! Olympus, this is an official message! For you, in all your splendor, Lord Uncle Zeus.

text.Zeus: My, what is this you have for me, young man? Appears to be a message of some sort, bearing my thunder sigil! Though, there's one for everybody on Olympus? Have they as yet received their own? I must know what it says... it's from your father, who else could it be? I'd better check on this!
I eagerly await learning some more about the contents of that fascinating message you had sent up here, Nephew! How mysterious, indeed. I'll be keeping an eye on all the others that come in!

I have to tell you, Zagreus, that it was wonderful to meet with you, at last! We were so pleased to learn Persephone was safe! And Nyx, why, she's as stunning as they say. Shouldn't have lied to us about your parentage, but, I know things get complicated, here, and that what's done is done!
Poseidon sought you out already, hm? My boastful brother gets on with Lord Hades even worse than I, so let me put a little spark into his storms for you!
My brave daughter Athena beat me to you this time, has she? No matter, with her blessing and my own, you shall be nigh unstoppable!
Has lovely Aphrodite put you in a trance already, Zagreus? Or might I offer you the blessing of Olympus to intensify her catastrophic power with my own?
So my elusive Artemis has shown you favor, has she? The little scamp, she seldom shows respect to anyone, not even me! But I'll enhance her blessing nonetheless.
Getting along with Ares, are you, Nephew? Heh. Would that you were my son instead of he, but no, I jest, I jest! Here, take my blessing, please!
It pleases me to know, young man, that you and Dionysus have been getting on so well. He could use a level-headed friend, and you could use my blessing!
Hmm! You've traveled rather quickly to this point... which reminds me, I've not seen swift Hermes anywhere of late! The rascal's likely dallying about!

Nephew, I have somewhat of a favor I must ask. You tell your father, if you so happen to run into him again, that his brother Zeus forgives him, and would like to reconnect, and welcome him into the family again. You tell him for me, hm?

So you are son to Hades by that Nyx, the night-goddess, is that correct, Nephew...? Well I suppose she's closest to a queen as your lord father's like to find down there. I tried to match him up with some more wholesome types, but no, and here we are.
After we learned about your plight and your existence from the goddess Nyx, all of us on Olympus rallied to assist you just as best we could. A family such as mine protects its own!

My brothers Hades and Poseidon once fought bravely by my side, you know that, don't you, Nephew? We prevailed against the Titans and established law upon the earth. Your father then descended to the land of death, and we've not seen much of each other since.

Your father must have told you that his governance over the Underworld is due more to the weaving of the Fates than by his choice. Admittedly, he got the short end of the stick. Whereas Poseidon and myself, why, we've been doing rather well indeed.

My brother Hades always was a lonesome man, you know. I pitied him! But I could never quite extract him from his thorny shell. Now he stews resentfully down there. You needn't bear the brunt of his frustrations.
Old Hades has continued to ignore my every effort to reach out to him, young man. Ah well, but he is obstinate, indeed. You are wise to seek your family's better half.

By the way, Nephew, I hear-tell your mother Nyx is quite the catch! If you'll forgive my saying so, of course. Your father's never had much of a sensibility around companionship, though perhaps this concubine of his brought something out in him, at last!
If and when you reach the surface, Zagreus, you call upon me then and there, all right? I'll personally see to it that you'll be escorted up to Olympus, and your quest shall be complete!
I know just how much you must want out of there, young man. And I want that as well! Heh. Good thing for you, as I get what I want around here. Ask anybody!
You fight your father's legions with Varatha, the Eternal Spear? The irony must not escape him, for he long ago stood by my side against the Titans, with that thing in hand!
It seems the bow called Coronacht is safe and sound there in your hands, young man. I've not seen that old thing in quite some time!
That shield of yours, called Aegis, why, in fact, it's mine from long ago, young man! I've no more need of it, of course, though how you found it, you shall have to tell me once you're here!

Well, if it isn't the one and only Rail of Adamant in your possession, there! To strike one's enemies from afar is really the only way, I think, and it's about as good a substitute for lightning bolts as you're likely to find!

Now, isn't that Malphon the Twin Fists there in your possession, Zagreus? Last god I saw bedecked in those old gloves was Demeter herself, oh, way back when! She was a real fighter at the time, not just a naysayer!

Ah, now that's the Aegis that I know and love! Or used to love, at least, the dear old thing! Now I quite love these shocking bolts of mine. Though I am proud you've given Aegis a good home, and bear it in my name!

Hark, young man, for I've a vision I must share with you! A waking-phrase for Exagryph, to be precise. Please beseech the weapon thus: I see your prideful fall down from the heavens to the flames. An odd connection to a past or future bearer, apparently one who defied a god!

Nephew, I wanted to mention, it was odd how by every account you'd come quite close to breaking free from there at last, of late... only to be abruptly cut off from our contact! I suppose having suffered some ill fate? Perhaps your realm's guardian, Cerberus, is even deadlier than reputed!

Your dear mother Persephone is a shrewd woman, Zagreus. More than an equal to your mighty father! I'm pleased to know you've made amends with her, and taken new responsibilities within your House! Naturally, I'll continue to pitch in. And, I hope that we'll meet again, someday!

I must say, Nephew! Although it pleases me that we, here, reconnected with your father's realm... just between us, it pleases me even more that you are able to keep sticking it to him! You keep that up, all right?
Zagreus, you have a clever mother in Persephone! A very clever mother. And a lordly father! They make quite the team, that's evident! True rivals for Hera and me!

The lord and ruler of Olympus and the world, why, he needs a healthy sense of humor, no, young man? Now there's an awful lot of spoil-sports out here, can't take even a little joke, well, I know all their mothers, fie on all of them, I say! Let's joke away!

I suppose even down in the Underworld, you would have heard such tales of me, young man. They're all untrue, hahaha! Except the tales of my bravery. Those are completely accurate, though all too modest, in most cases, I must say.
Ah, must be my gleaming Thunder Signet that I transferred to you! Why, I could feel its call from all the way up here!
Why you look positively dreadful, Zagreus. That place is doing you no favors, I can tell! Luckily, I'll do you favors aplenty!
You seem in dire need of some assistance, Nephew. So, of course, I dropped what I was doing and then sought you out as quickly as I could!
Zagreus, you must have left most of your lifeblood back the other way, hahahaha! Oh, I jest, I jest! But you look terrible.
No, no one likes to die, young man! But since you seem about to any moment now, you keep your head held high, do you hear me?
Well, let's face it, Zagreus, you are as good as dead right now. But you'll just slosh right back out of the River Styx, and give it a good try again, won't you?
Remember, young man, dying is for mortals. So don't go making a habit of it, there! But if you have to do it, do it fighting, like a hero would!
I wonder, Nephew, whether you're prepared as yet to harness the surpassing power I shall grant you now? Don't take this blessing lightly, and may you use it well.
How about, young man, we cease with all the trifling down there and cause a real storm for once? Take now the fiercest of my powers, and you show your no-good father what you're made of!

text.Zagreus: Is this really him? OK. In the name of Hades! Olympus! I accept this message.

text.Zeus: Greetings there, young man! Look, your father's always been rather difficult, and he's not so much as called in quite some time. You'll have a better home where you belong, here on Olympus! And to help you on your journey, have my blessing.
We meet again, young man! Yours isn't my affair, I know, and yet I cannot help but take an interest in your plight. Your father cast his lot; he need not take his anger out on you.
Hello, young man, and might I offer you a little taste of the heavens themselves? Though, don't go telling your old sulky father I've been spoiling you rotten!
I and all of us upon Olympus are anticipating your success, dear Nephew! Now let me see if I can't help spur you along.
Well, my nephew, you're admittedly in quite a bind down there, but what is life without its struggles, hm? You'll make it here, eventually, I'm certain.
I like the fire in you, Zagreus, and I have every confidence you'll someday clamber from the shadows there into the light!
Here on Olympus, Nephew, we take care of one another and support each other, quite unlike how it must be there in your father's grim domain. No wonder you intend to leave!
I'd ask you offer my respects to your lord father, Zagreus, but I suspect you won't have such a chance anytime soon, considering how far you'll come with my support!
Remember you've as many chances as it takes, young man, to fight your way out of the dark and join us in the splendor of Olympus!
Your grim-faced father's such a spoilsport, Nephew, the way he keeps impeding your escape. Ah, well, just keep at it, hm?
My greetings, young Nephew, and more importantly, my blessing and my strength be with you as you journey towards your rightful home.
Faith and courage, Zagreus, for each and every one of us upon Olympus is behind you all the way throughout this whole affair.
What can I say, young man? You may not make your father very proud, but it is just the opposite with me! Now go, get out of there!
Now, Nephew, how about we put both of our backs into this one, and see to it that you go farther through those depths than you have ever managed yet!
Know that many mortals ask me for my blessings constantly, and I mean all the time, young Nephew, but for you! You needn't ask at all!
Far be it from me to raise my hand against your father, dear Nephew! Although I do suppose old Hades has it coming, doesn't he.
I've every confidence in you, young man! Now you remember that, and take my blessing here, and fight your way on out of there for me!
Nephew, I want you to go and show that surly Hades everything you're made of! And, I've arranged for you a little bit of help along the way!
How is old Hades doing, anyway, Nephew? I suspect he's every bit as prickly as ever, whereas you are nothing of the sort!
I eagerly anticipate getting to meet you face-to-face someday, dear Nephew, just as soon as you can up and out of there!
Good Nephew, I return once more to lend to you my power! I'd like to see your discontented father try and stop you now!
It is my solemn wish, dear Zagreus, that eventually we settle up our differences with your lord father. But for now, we fight!
Hail, my most honorable, beloved nephew, and I bring to you the blessing of Olympus, so that you might finally get out of there, already!
I just know you'll reach the surface here eventually, Zagreus! And I look forward to our meeting when you do!
We'll keep you safe here from your father, Zagreus! But while you're still inside that Underworld, there's only so much we can do.
You've a good head on your shoulders, Zagreus, so stay positive, stay healthy, and let nothing stand between you and your goal!
I wish you well in your continued quest, and offer my sincerest blessings, and of course my power, there, Nephew!
You've seen the sheer destructive power of the heavens! Just imagine what it's like above the surface of the earth!
Someday when we'll be resting easy on these heights, why, we'll look back at this and laugh, I'm sure of it!
Ahh, but if it isn't my most favored nephew! Striving always toward the surface of my world. Your father cannot possibly believe he can contain you, can he?
You have my blessing now as ever there, young man.
I trust you shall be getting out of there in due course, Nephew.
I shall be watching over you, young man, though it is dark down there!
May the might of Olympus guide you through the shadows, Nephew.
Don't let your father get to you, young man, and climb on out from there.
Zagreus, we won't be giving up on you, so you keep at it, hm?
I shall make the heavens themselves now aid your ascent, Nephew.
You'll watch yourself down there, won't you, young man?
All of us, we're here for you, young man!
Please do be careful not to make your situation any worse, Nephew!
I'm here for you, young man, so you take heart, and more than that, take this!
All of us believe in you, though certainly no one so much as I!
Here's something I can do to help, young man!
You just take all the time you need in terms of fighting your way out of there, young man!
Now, don't lose heart, young man, and we'll keep at it with you here, as well!
As my kin, you are a born fighter, Zagreus! So put your back into it, and you climb right up!
It shall be glorious, indeed, the day you finally burst from that oppressive den into the light!
I know you have it in you to surpass your father, Zagreus. Assuming you are anything like me!
How fares your lovely mother? Things still good with her and Hades, hm?
You tell your good lord father that his brother Zeus shall be always watching over you!
I trust your good lord father's treating you all right?
I know you're busy, Zagreus, though someday you shall have to visit us!
I'm never quite so busy that I can't make time for family, young man!
We're all in this together, aren't we, Nephew?
I see the boatman of the Underworld has found the means to reach you with my blessing, Nephew. Such strange alliances we forge these days!
Why here I am, young man, in such strange circumstances I might add! Luckily the boatman Charon is much easier to get ahold of than your father!
Ah, so then the boatman Charon came through for us after all, did he? Whatever means we have to reach you, we'll employ!
Your Charon there must drive quite a hard bargain, Zagreus, if he would keep you from your victory just for a bit of coin!
I thought that ferryman would be content to transfer souls across the River Styx, not rob you on your journey to the surface, there, Nephew!
My blessing isn't good enough for you, is that the way of it, young man? How impetuous of you. Oh, I never!
It isn't wise to go against me, Nephew, both in matters large and small. I am not known for being charitable to the insolent.
Perhaps you have defied me here in jest, young man. Though in such cases pertinent to my authority, you'll find I lack a sense of humor.
Audacity runs in our family, Zagreus, but my advice to you is that you keep it carefully suppressed in your relationship with me.
What have I done, good Nephew, to deserve such scorn? Your lapse in judgment here is not so easy to forgive, yet easily punished.
Your father likewise turned his back on me before, Nephew, and we both know what has become of him. I'd caution you against this.
Apparently, the consequences of displeasing me have slipped your mind, young man. A harsh reminder is in order, then.
I did not restore order to this world, and claim the heavens for myself, only to be insulted by my own nephew!
Why, Nephew, is this all some sort of jest to you? It isn't one that I appreciate!
Nephew, when presented with a choice to side against me or not to be such a fool, do be sure to choose the latter next time, hm?
Don't say I didn't warn you, young man! I only wish that I could say you didn't insult me!
This is outrageous, Zagreus! Even your father would agree that actions such as that can't go unpunished.
Young man, I don't know why you would do this to me, though I trust you're going to think twice, next time!

CHOICE.Zeus: You overstep your bounds with me, Nephew! But I shall make you fall right back in line.

text.Zeus: Ah, very well, good show, young man! And I think I shall let you off the hook, and take you back under my wing, for now.
Commendable of you to live through that, and I suspect you shall think twice next time before so brazenly defying me, won't you?
Now, now, no need to hold such grudges any longer I suppose, but you just mind yourself around your Uncle Zeus.
Do not spurn me again like that, do you hear me, young man? I think you do, so let's put this to bed and move along.
Oh Nephew, but I simply can't stay wrathful toward you, much as I might try! Though, better not to tempt me, just in case.
All right, all right, let's call the score between us settled up for now. Just don't go spurning me again, you understand?
All right, this is becoming unproductive, Zagreus. As you were!
Oh, I don't have the heart to keep exacting vengeance on you, Nephew.
I say, such petty squabbles. Aren't we better than this, Zagreus?
Well, young man, I'd say it's best we put this little slight behind us, wouldn't you?
Pah! All is forgiven and forgotten, Zagreus. What were we even going on about back there?
Hahaha, that is quite enough, that's quite enough, I say! You're still alive, aren't you?

text.Zagreus: Lord Zeus, erm, Uncle? Please accept this offering, and all my gratitude.

text.Zeus: Goodness, Nephew, that's an offering, indeed! I'm thankful for your piety to me, and as a show of generosity to you, in turn, I present this!

text.Zagreus: I thank you, my Lord Uncle Zeus, for your benevolence and your thunderous might.

text.Zeus: You honor me, young man, as well you should, for I am ruler of Olympus, am I not? Such courtesies are shown me constantly, yet I appreciate them all.

text.Zagreus: Lord Zeus, I bid you please accept my humble offering, for all you've done for me.

text.Zeus: Why, that is rather generous of you, and I'm grateful for it, Nephew! How good of you to make attempts at reciprocity!

text.Zagreus: This offering is but a trifle, Uncle Zeus, for all your magnanimity.

text.Zeus: So fine a gift again, my dear Nephew? Would that my sons and daughters on Olympus here would show me such respect from time to time!

text.Zagreus: Please, Lord Uncle Zeus, accept this gift of Nectar in your honor, though it is such a pittance in comparison to all the generosity you've shown.

text.Zeus: I'm very pleased to see a show of such respect and admiration for your uncle, Zagreus. You'll go quite far here on Olympus with an attitude like that! Not everyone's as mannered, nor as wise.

text.Zagreus: If you can hear me, mighty Uncle Zeus, I wish to make to you this simple gift, and with it send my humble wish that someday you and Father settle all your differences, and be at peace.

text.Zeus: Ah, most splendid of an offering, young man. And while we've yet to even meet in person, I already feel as though the two of us are close, why, closer than you must be even with your father! Oh, hahaha! Perhaps we ought go telling everybody I'm your real father, am I right?

CHOICE.Zagreus: If you can hear me, mighty Uncle Zeus, I wish to make to you this simple gift, and with it send my humble wish that someday you and Father settle all your differences, and be at peace.

CHOICE.Zeus: Ah, most splendid of an offering, young man. I already feel as though the two of us are close, why, closer than you must be even with your father! Oh, hahaha! Perhaps we ought go telling everybody I'm your real father, am I right?

CHOICE.Zagreus: King of the Olympians, Lord Zeus! Forgive this offer of Ambrosia, for I know you have no limit of it there. But here, it is the finest gift that can be given, and even still it isn't anything compared to all you've done for me. Thank you, Uncle.

CHOICE.Zeus: Now, now, Nephew, you are most generous, indeed, in showing all this deference to me. But we must keep some distance, shouldn't we? Lest all the others here, why, they would be most jealous if they caught me playing favorites! Even though you are my favorite! Presently, at least.
Olympus smite you!
It shall be so.
That can be arranged!
Easily achieved.
Now is the time to strike!
Hoh, you watch this, young man!
I'll strike them down right now!
I can take care of that!
Don't be a fool, young man.

CHOICE.DROPPED_Zeus: You truly are my brother's son.

CHOICE.Zeus: How dare you, young man.
Best not to make me angry, my nephew.
The sheer audacity!
I ought to strike you down!
Have you gone daft, Nephew?!
Now you ask my favor, Zagreus?

CHOICE.Zagreus: A generous offer, Lord Uncle Zeus.
I can't say no, Lord Zeus.

CHOICE.Zeus: A swift death is a mercy of a retribution.
I did not become ruler of Olympus by forgiving trespasses, young man.
You can't run from heaven.
Struck down.
How do you do, young man.
My blessings, Nephew!
How fares my brother's son of late?
Well I don't see why not.
I've something for you here.

text.Ares: Well, my hellborn kin, I have to say that there are times I wish I could have been acquainted with your father somewhat more, if you'll forgive my saying so. My father and my uncle, here... they're predisposed quite differently than I.

text.Poseidon: Perhaps if you were not so odd, and made more effort to be somewhat more approachable, Ares, then we'd have more in common, you and I! Should you need any tips on that, why, you just let me know!

text.Ares: I wished only to speak to you in private once again, my kin, except, you see...

text.Athena: ...Except you see, dear Cousin, that some members of our family are predisposed toward the unspeakable. I caution you around my half-brother, is all. Now carry on.

text.Ares: You interrupt me once again, dear sister. You know I do not care for that. I warn you to stay out of my affairs. I shall aid my kin as I see fit.

text.Athena: You only do as you see fit, Lord Ares. Mind that you continue pulling in the same direction as us all.

text.Ares: I so anticipate the day you finally arrive upon Olympus. There are few amongst us here with interests such as those I think we share.

text.Aphrodite: There are at least a few of us who share such interests here, isn't that so, Lord Ares? As for you, dearest, you take all the time you need!

text.Ares: Wars waged over love, my kin... can you imagine that? The lady Aphrodite and I can endlessly discuss such circumstances. I trust, from time to time, you stop to ask yourself how come you choose to fight. Not that you need a reason, of course.

text.Aphrodite: Oh, Lord Ares, truly there isn't the need to cloud our little godling's thoughts and judgment with such comments, is there, hm? Let's give him what he wants, and we can carry on in private, about that.

text.Ares: Ah, my kin! I was just inquiring with Lord Dionysus here, under which circumstances are the greatest mortal feasts of all prepared? Because I have a certain hunch, regarding that...

text.Dionysus: Yeah, yeah, Ares, I will hand it to you, man. There's nothing like a feast after a war, all right! Provided you're on the surviving side, that is! Otherwise I guess they'll be feasting with you down there, Zag!

text.Ares: The cold of death is quite becoming of the Goddess Demeter, do you not think so, my death-dealing kin? She is becoming well accustomed to it, too.

text.Demeter: I think that you forget yourself, Lord Ares, sir. For I am much your elder; my famines had already slain the mortals by the tens of thousands by the time such thoughts of doing so first crossed your mind.

text.Ares: Ten thousand souls have fallen to you, now, my hellborn kin. I am rather beside myself, I must admit. Fine work.

text.Zagreus: Here goes, then. In the name of Hades! Olympus, this is an official message! Lord Ares, please consider our proposal... once you're able to decipher it.

text.Ares: My, what is this, my kin? Some sort of invitation for me, I presume. Not just for me... this symbolizes all the others, here? Most intriguing. I shall investigate the meaning of this as quickly as I'm able, then. But first!

I wish to tell you once again I had a splendid time during our recent shared festivities, my kin. At last, I've finally seen your death-filled realm firsthand! I learned a great deal. And I look forward to learning more from our successful collaboration, hm?
Lord Zeus has gotten to you first, I see? My father's gifts are generous, indeed, though... I think I can help in my own way.
The blessing of your uncle Lord Poseidon might have helped you to this point, but here: My gift shall see you further still.
You bear the blessing of Athena, yes? She would protect you from your enemies, whilst I would rather that you slay them, and be done.
Mm, I see you have the Lady Aphrodite's blessing there already. Love and death, together, hand in hand? Sounds most agreeable to me.
So Artemis, my lonely half-sister, got to you first? She merely helps you hunt, whilst I shall help you kill. Observe.
That drunkard Dionysus cannot help you near as much as I, my hell-born kin. Compare the gift he gave to what I offer you.
Our messenger Hermes has been in contact with you by now, yes? Perhaps you shall not see him very often, for my work keeps him rather preoccupied, shepherding souls and such.
I faintly sense the mark of Goddess Demeter upon you, hm? Her power over plentitude is opposite to mine in some respects. But, lately, she has channeled it in manners more agreeable to me.

Ah, you bear your own father's blessing, my kin? Such a surprise... I know the two of you are now in league, and yet... I am still quite accustomed to the thought that you harbor war-like hatred for one another. Perhaps there's still a trace of that, though, hm?
Did you happen to know, my kin, that you have slain more than a hundred foes since you began your quest? You have! For I am keeping count. And I am most impressed.
You are a most impressive death-dealer, my kin. For by my estimation, you have slain at least a thousand souls down there! Souls mostly having died before, but still.

I know that you have many aspirations, my good kin. To be plain with you about my own motive for a moment: As long as you continue bringing swift and steady death, you shall have my unyielding support.
The more you slay your enemies, my kin, the stronger the bond between us, I think. Can you not feel it, too? Though, perhaps your lust for blood overpowers your other senses, hm?
Perhaps you know a god called Thanatos? The two of us are very close associates, you know. Do give him my best wishes, should you see him soon.
I trust that Thanatos is doing well? Although he brings to mortals merciful release, whilst I most certainly do no such thing, I do appreciate his take on it.
It is my understanding that you have grown rather close with Thanatos, my kin? A perfect choice of mate; though I confess I'd not expected Death to have affection for another save himself.
You traveled rather far down there since last we met, my kin. And that means you have dealt incalculable death. I must commend you thus.
Ahh, my kin! I sensed fresh bloodshed from you recently, the real kind! For you have slain the living near the surface, have you not? Mere vermin, yes, but good enough for me.
Recently, there was a burst of violence on the surface, near to where you are, but higher up. 'Twas altogether odd, but must have forced you to return once more. No matter; time is on our side.

I sense so much death at the gates of your father's realm, of late, my kin. Now, I know that seems perfectly ordinary on the face of it, except... there's something more. I wonder if you know the reason why...

I know your efforts to come here have repeatedly been thwarted, my good kin. However, we have caused such violence in the intervening time, that we must take this as a real victory. Let us continue for however long it takes.

Surely you've heard rumblings about a war which has erupted on the surface, here? Doubtless you've seen an influx of fallen mortals. It's quite a decent one, I have to say! Though, unlikely to rise to the ranks of the greats. Too few armies involved in it, I fear.
War's such a wondrous thing, my kin. It solves so many different problems, whilst perpetuating its own inevitability. Let's keep it up, then, hm?

Do you ever think to yourself that you were born a bit too late, my kin? For my part, I wish that I could have been there myself when my father and the others waged ferocious war against the Titans. Ah, it must have been a sight!
I sense that you have forged a greater bond with your instruments of destruction there, my kin. Then that is very good. And may their altered forms serve you quite well.
Why, I believe that is the Frost Fair Blade you bear! I understand it shall become the instrument of choice of yet another god of war, someday. I long to meet him, this fellow student of death.
Ah, that blade of yours... it looks as though it could relieve a mortal of his head with ease. Excalibur, is it? I've studied all the Fates' designs, and this one is among my favorites.
The fated bow Sharanga, in your grasp! That is not a form I'd expected you to wield. You have exquisite taste in weaponry, my kin!
Is that the fire-eating shield of the great warrior Beowulf, which you have there? I knew the Fates had plans for it, but I did not expect for you to be a part!
Those are the gauntlets of the fated king Gilgamesh, are they not? A bringer of destruction, and an agent of the Fates. You are full of surprises, my kin!
You bear the warring instrument of one called Lucifer, I see. I've little to go on about him, but it is clear he knows a thing or two about destruction, is it not?
Ah, you bear the Blood-filled Vial which I granted you! The mortal's blood contained therein... I drew it myself! Too seldom am I able to become directly involved in such matters.
Know that I admire your Lord Father very much. For his grim work lets me continue mine. I trust that one day you shall settle your dispute.
You are the son of Night herself, they say? A fascinating character, ill-liked upon Olympus, although I myself have always longed to meet her.
Ah, my favorite Underworld death-dealer. I so look forward to the pain you shall inflict this time around.
Would that a sudden scourge of war would help you out of your predicament. Why, I would stir one up for you without a second thought.
Ah, my closest kin in all the Underworld, I see you there, I think! What sort of violence shall we sow together this time, you and I?
There's so much insufferable talk of peace up here, my kin. It is quite the relief to focus on much more important things, with you.
You must know I often hunger for destruction, almost uncontrollably at that. Though I am finding you are able to sate that appetite of mine.
May all the death you bring become the stuff of legends told in fearful mortal whisperings around the world, my kin.
Would that I knew the goddess Nyx, myself, my kin! So many of my wars are waged by night. I am most grateful, and I wish her well.
How is your mother Nyx of late, my kin? Have you yet given to her my regards? For I should think that Night and War would share a common ground.
How is Nyx of late, my kin? Have you yet given to her my regards? For I should think that Night and War would share a common ground.
Do tell your mother Night Herself that I am often thinking of her here, although we haven't met. She must believe that there are those upon Olympus who admire her.
Do tell Night Herself that I am often thinking of her here. She must believe that there are those upon Olympus who admire her.
Perhaps once all of this is over, my good kin, you might arrange 'twixt myself and your dark mother, Nyx, some sort of chance to meet? Do think upon it, and declare to her my interest if you please.
Perhaps once all of this is over, my good kin, you might arrange 'twixt myself and the goddess Nyx some sort of chance to meet? Do think upon it, and declare to her my interest if you please.
Your mother Nyx and I, we have begun a correspondence, my good kin. I do appreciate you putting us in touch. She is a lovely specimen, if you don't mind my saying so, perhaps?
The goddess Nyx and I, we have begun a correspondence, my good kin. I do appreciate you putting us in touch. She is a lovely specimen, if you don't mind my saying so, perhaps?
You shall be pleased to hear that your own mother Nyx and I, why, we intend to meet. I'm quite excited to exchange ideas in the flesh.
You shall be pleased to hear that Nyx and I, why, we intend to meet. I'm quite excited to exchange ideas in the flesh.
Please send your mother Nyx my warm regards, won't you, my kin? Would that the others on Olympus knew and understood your kind as I now do.
Please send the goddess Nyx my warm regards, won't you, my kin? Would that the others on Olympus knew and understood your kind as I now do.

You know, my kin, I had misunderstood that Nyx was your mother. But, Persephone? I never took her for the sort to have an interest in your realm. Alas that we never had opportunity to discuss the subject here.

Your good mother, Persephone... dread Queen of the Underworld! I certainly misjudged her when we had occasion to interact whilst she resided on Olympus. Perhaps I, too, should consider a life there in your realm...
You bear Varatha, the Eternal Spear...! I thought it lost! Have you any idea how many lives it drank during your father's glory days?
Ah, you wield Coronacht, the Heart-Seeker. It pierced three Titans in one shot back in the war amongst our kind. Please do take care of it!
You have the Shield of Chaos, Aegis... quite unlike the one my good sister Athena likes to flash around. You have much better taste.
Why, you are wielding Exagryph, the Rail of Adamant! A most fascinating device. Imagine the new face of war, should its secrets someday be revealed, and spread to mortalkind!
Well if it isn't Malphon, the Twin Fists, bound to your very capable hands! So many weapons are so indirect, I think. With Malphon, you are about as close to the destruction as can be.
The greatest wars require great alliances, my kin. And so, I shall entrust to you some of the greatest methods of destruction I've devised thus far.
The winds of war blow fiercely on the surface now, my kin. Thus I am able to confer upon you even greater power than has been my custom.
You seem to be upon the verge of death, my kin. I cannot wait to hear of it! The experience of death, time after time! You are one of a kind!
Ah, my kin, but you have suffered terribly to come this far. No matter, for we soon shall pay your enemies in kind.
So much letting of blood, so much of it, your own. Let's see to keeping you alive and in the fight a while longer, then.
You're on the verge of yet another brush with death, I see, my hell-born kin. Do send some others down with you, would you?
A mortal surely would have already succumbed to injuries such as the ones you've suffered, there. Impressive how you carry on, like that.

text.Zagreus: This one was bound to show up I guess. In the name of Hades! Olympus! I accept this message.

text.Ares: You've got quite the fighting spirit in you there, I have to say. Most intriguing, and yet no surprise for someone born in hell itself. You come on out of there, and tell me all about it. I'm a fellow student of death, you see.
I must say you deal death rather exquisitely. Though, perhaps I could be of some further assistance in such matters, yes?
Ah! I figured that you must have been the source of all that bloodshed underneath the earth. Let me see if I can make your death-dealing a little more efficient.
Well, my hell-born kin, my blessing now is yours to do with as you wish; provided you inflict a little suffering for me?
I've just the thing for you this time, my kin. May I present my instruments of pain?
I surely hope your bloodshed's going well, and long that there shall be no end to it. I am, as ever, here to serve your benefit.
How fares your endless war against the dead? Let it be known that I am happy to take sides in such affairs. Please, I insist!
Death rears its head in all too many forms, I'm sure you know. Though you may never find them all, I nonetheless encourage you to try.
The wretched dead you face perhaps forget themselves. Go, then, remind them of the agony which brought them to your realm.
Life and death are inextricable, and war is often what connects the two. Don't you agree?
This world has a limitless capacity for pain; and so, it truly is no inconvenience to help you to bring out a little more.
The living and the dead alike desire what I represent. Their appetite for bloodshed cannot easily be sated. A goal to strive for, no?
Perhaps the dead you stand against have long forgotten the experience of anguish and despair. I trust that you shall soon remind them for me?
Beautiful, isn't it? The strife which follows you. You have a real knack for this, and I for one am happy to assist.
Some would question the destruction which you sow, but I shall never do so. I fully understand your impulses. Allow me to indulge them.
Not once has your Lord Father thanked me for delivering vast portions of his clientele. Surely you shall be more grateful for my gifts.
Do you suppose the dead feel pain unlike the living? This is for me an endless fascination, so go on, and give me more to think about.
As you continue waging war against the dead, I gladly lend you my support; family to family, no questions asked.
It is a veritable crime your father distances himself from all the rest of us. It is fortunate that you yourself are not so disagreeable.
Let us together deal some death, shall we?
Shall we continue our campaign against the dead?
What do you say we bring the dead some pain, for old time's sake?
The devastation you have caused has not escaped my notice!
We stand before a golden opportunity, to inflict pain. Let us proceed!
There is no problem war cannot sort out.
Ah there you are, my kin! I have a gift to aid your bloody work.
My blessing be with you, and may death follow in your wake.
Please spread some suffering down there for me, my kin.
I shall empower you to acts of greater violence than before.
War needn't carry out solely above the earth, my kin.
I trust that the destruction which you sow is going well?
The recent devastation which you caused, that was impressive work.
Whenever you bring death, why, you've my full support.
How fares the ceaseless slaying of your foes, quite well, my kin?
Perhaps my blessing shall let you deliver death still more efficiently.
Your father's realm shall be quite full, I think, once you and I are through.
The finest instruments of death at my disposal shall be yours.
I'd like to offer you a choice amongst my most exquisite tools which inflict suffering.
What say we start our next war with a special flair, my kin?
I've not seen ample blood spilled recently, so let's please make up for lost time.
There are so many types of death... and yet, the sudden, violent kind is unsurpassed, I think.
I am quite eager to commence jointly killing your enemies, my kin.
What do you say we start another of our famous killing sprees, my kin?
It's not been long since last I saw bloodshed... but far too long for me, nevertheless.
My finest implements of death I now avail to you, my worthy kin.
Let us make this blood-letting truly one to remember, then, hm?
May you sow such destruction as to shake this mountain to its core, my kin.
I shall now give to you the means to wreak such havoc there, my kin!
I was quite pleased to hear again from Nyx of late, my kin.
May the wondrous goddess Nyx continue to watch over you, and darken the eyes of your foes.
To think you have the goddess Nyx's aid, as well as mine!
I knew that foul boatman would come through, and you would find amongst his wares this gift!
I give to you this token of respect, buried though it must have been within the boatman's hoard.
I trust the river-boatman Charon has been keeping plenty busy lately thanks to me?
The boatman Charon ought invest into a boat of more substantial size if he's to keep up with my work, my kin.
Your boatman there is a reliable deliverer of death, it seems. And that makes three of us, I think.
You reject my generous offering of aid? Hahahaha, you must not know me very well. Death shall come, regardless, either to your enemies, or you.
You would deny such aid as I would offer you? How rather disappointing. You've more to learn about the art of dealing death, it seems.
An incorrect decision, there, my kin, to side against me thus. Blood needs be shed, and yours is going to suffice.
It seems unwise of you to thus dismiss my offering. Suffer, then, a while by my hand.
Your choice leaves much to be desired here, my kin. My temper I shall keep in check, but only barely so.
A disappointing choice, my kin, and there are consequences to such choices, every single time.
Your course of action here was ill-advised, my kin. For war shall come to you no matter what, as I shall presently reveal.
The whims of our kind are unpredictable, my kin. But you shall find responses to such acts to be the definition of consistency.
I'll not abide such disregard of our past companionship, my kin. In war, one must take sides, and you had best choose mine.
War shall be waged here, no matter what, my kin. But even still, I am dismayed you would have sided against me.
You wish to have a taste of what a war against me would be like? Well, then, I shall oblige.
Did I detect some hesitancy on your part just then? Perhaps you knew that you were making a mistake. No matter; you'll learn now.

CHOICE.Ares: You shall not goad me into anger with a petty insult such as this, you know. Nevertheless, there is a price which must be paid for it.

text.Ares: A sacrifice in blood is fully paid, and we are squared away. Though think you twice next time before you cross me, hm?
Well haven't you withstood my murderous intent! Resilience as this deserves reward, and I am feeling rather generous.
It is not often I attempt to kill someone and they survive. Bravo! Our score is settled up for now, so let us carry on as friends.
You capably survived my wrath, and I commend you for it. Let us continue on, as friends and kin.
I think that we are squared away, for now. Though, do not test my patience further, hm?
You crossed the fields of death impressively back there. Though, you are fortunate I'm in a giving mood.
When blood is spilled and death is dealt, I simply cannot remain discontented for too long.
What I could see of that display of violence you just sowed was thoroughly commendable, my kin. Then, here.
Your sacrifice to me just now has moved me to forgiveness for the time; thus shall we call a truce.
A war can only last so long, my kin. This one is not worth the pursuit, I think, when we can wage a greater one, together.
Ah, after a show of violence such as that, how can I possibly remain upset, my kin?
Your slight against me is already forgotten; for I was more than pleased to witness such a monstrous show of force.

text.Zagreus: Lord Ares, please accept this offering, for giving me such strength as necessary to succeed.

text.Ares: You are a flatterer, my death-inflicting kin. And I am feeling generous, as well, so here! A small token for you of my affection.

text.Zagreus: Lord Ares, I honor you for all the strength you've given me to overcome my foes.

text.Ares: Such a splendid offering, to me! How very thoughtful, there, my kin. I am taken aback, though I accept!

text.Zagreus: Lord Ares! Please accept this token of my deep appreciation for your generous support.

text.Ares: An offering, for me? Indeed! How gracious that you keep me in your thoughts. Know that, likewise, I keep you in mine.

text.Zagreus: Lord Ares, it is my privilege to have met you, and have learned your death-inflicting way.

text.Ares: I do appreciate this gift to me, although you really shouldn't have! The suffering which you inflict is ample compensation in itself.

text.Zagreus: You have shown me nothing but respect and granted me your favor repeatedly, Lord Ares. This is the least that I can do, in kind.

text.Ares: Most often when I'm given offerings, it is with wishes that I lend my favor in a coming war. Yet from you, my kin, I sense no such motive. I'm quite taken aback by that, I must admit.

text.Zagreus: Lord Ares! As bloodshed has become somewhat of a necessity in my situation, I am very grateful that you're with me in this. I know never to take it for granted.

text.Ares: You're most gracious with me, my kin; and I remain enthralled as ever by your blood-soaked way of life. I trust the violence I have wrought on your behalf has been quite satisfactory?

CHOICE.Zagreus: I offer this Ambrosia in your name and honor, Lord Ares. To the god of war! How many foes have I vanquished with your aid and guidance? But more than that, I'm pleased to know you, and to be your cousin.

CHOICE.Ares: Ah, such an exquisite gift this is, indeed. Yet, the destruction you have sown, the sheer carnage... nothing can surpass that, I should think. Should you ever go to war, my kin... genuinely go to war, I mean... do look me up. I imagine I would take your side.

CHOICE.Zagreus: You have my thanks, Lord Ares.

CHOICE.Ares: Pain and suffering upon you all!
Blood and death, together hand in hand!
Whom do you take me for.
You must know mercy simply isn't in my nature.
What is a war without its tragic losses here and there?
It is unwise to side against me in a war.
Greetings, fellow bringer of death and so on.
How is hell treating you today?
How fares your war against the dead?

CHOICE.Zagreus: I see you drawn in the arms of the seventh avatar...

text.Artemis: Tsk, um, Zagreus... rather than greet you as I normally would do, instead, allow me to present you my illustrious, kind, generous lord father, your greatest Uncle Zeus!

text.Zeus: Erm, thank you for the introduction, Daughter! Now, you run along, go frolic with your nymphs, or something! Leave me to assist my nephew, here. Bestow on him your faint blessing, if you must.

text.Artemis: You know my father and my uncle, by now, right, Zagreus? I don't know which of them is worse. Uh, I mean... superior! Superior, despite technically spending most of his time in the seas, beneath Olympus, isn't that right, Uncle?

text.Poseidon: Oh, Artemis, you needn't boast to little Hades there on my account! Besides! Whether you're in the sea, above it, or beneath, makes little difference to your measure as a god! You two are young as yet! Keep at it, and you'll soon be practically as great as I!

text.Artemis: Hey, uh, Zagreus! There's something I've been wondering, and don't take this the wrong way or anything, OK? Oh, no. It's her.

text.Aphrodite: Why, Artemis, you're absolutely tongue-tied! Due to our little godling in the Underworld, or a little due to me? Hm-hm, you shall figure it all out I'm sure!

text.Artemis: Look, what was I, ugh, just, never mind. I'll talk to you some other time, I guess.

Erm, Zagreus, despite my hunter's instincts here, it seems I was unable to elude Aphrodite in this particular case, who insisted that we present ourselves to you at the same time, for whatever reason...

text.Aphrodite: Oh, come now, Artemis! I'm sure you're very capable of hiding from a common beast, but I can see you plain. Why not be honest with yourself, next time?

text.Artemis: Zagreus, I wish we all could hear you so that good Lord Ares here might be persuaded that my powers are entirely for different purposes than his!

text.Ares: Perhaps our skillsets once were meant for different purposes, dear Artemis; but who are we to doubt the end result? Observe what shall transpire once we grant our kin our combined might.

text.Artemis: Zagreus, I was just hoping for a little privacy before this hunt, which is consistently my preference here, except, you see, Lord Ares always seems to come sniffing about, first sign of any hunting instruments!

text.Ares: Why, my dear Artemis, the hunt is but a prelude to a war, is that not so? For if all mortalkind knew naught of hunting, why, they would not be nearly so adept at killing one another.

text.Artemis: Look, Lord Ares, if I lend you better marksmanship ability, you think that you could bother someone else?
Oh, great, it's you, Zagreus! Here, let me offer you some fine new Boons, as well as Lord Dionysus here, who I am sure would love to talk your ear off just as much as mine!

text.Dionysus: Eh, tells me I'm being awful loud, and to back off, all sorts of nasty stuff like that, what can you do, though, right?

text.Artemis: Oh, hi there, Zagreus, I was just failing to persuade the Lady Demeter to ease up off the snowy stretch that we've been having for a while. Some of the mortals are quite weary of it now, and it sure doesn't make the hunting any easier!

text.Demeter: The mortals are resourceful, Artemis. Their one redeeming quality, perhaps! They'll find a way through our long winter here. They ought to, since they brought it on themselves.

text.Artemis: Um, Zagreus, did you attempt to chat with Coronacht just yet? Remember, tell the bow I see you drawn in the arms of the seventh avatar! Something good's supposed to happen if you do, some divine archer-person's aspect I should think? You going to try it soon, or not?

Hey, look at that! The message must have worked! Practically can see that shiny bow from here! I've never wielded Coronacht myself, at least not yet. Though if the Fates are sending visions to me of its past or future bearers, why, I guess I'm bound to get my shot eventually!

text.Zagreus: Found you, Huntress, here. In the name of Hades! Olympus, this is an official message! Especially for you, Lady Artemis!

text.Artemis: Some kind of special message for me...! Oh, looks like there's one for everybody on Olympus, then. Felt rather special for a moment, there! And now you're making me check in with all the others. Great!

Have to say, I had a pretty decent time with everybody at our little visit recently! Met you, Uncle Hades, even great Achilles! Still don't quite appreciate you tricking us, but eh! I can get over it eventually. Anyway, you still could use assistance from me, right?
Ah, good old Father Zeus, he must have blessed you with his lightning bolts, did he? Always looking out for everyone.
Uncle Poseidon blessed you, didn't he. To think that big, fat oaf is your own father's brother. I'm told to be respectful near him, but it's hard.
You met Athena earlier, I guess? I'd never trade my bow for all that pomp and armor, but... I guess to each her own.
You're pretty close with Ares, aren't you? And here they said it couldn't be done. If I were you I'd watch myself with him.
So Aphrodite reached you first, did she? Sounds exactly like something she'd do. She has a knack for trouble. So, let's just stay focused, here!
That lush and lecher, Dionysus, counts you as a friend? I'm hoping that there must be some mistake, yeah, Zagreus?
You seem particularly light on your feet, there, Zagreus. I'd figure Hermes, himself, was speeding you along, except I've not seen him about in... been a while, really.
So even Demeter's become involved in this! Didn't think she would. Though you'll be glad she did! Provided you stay on her warm and fuzzy side, of course. Working on that, myself!

Something's troubled me a little, about you. You fight so desperately. At first I thought you simply lacked in patience. But now I see it's urgency that drives you. What is it that you're after, really...?

Let's see. You blundered headlong into danger for the past six chambers or more. And you made such a racket I could almost hear it from Olympus. I have to say, your hunting skills are rather unconventional.
I'm with you every step till you arrive here, Zagreus. Then I will probably ignore you like the rest. Just warning you ahead of time, all right?
Say, were you hunting vermin near the surface lately, Zagreus? That's practically just like the real thing! It must have been a thrill!
You've become a right accomplished vermin hunter, Zagreus! Maybe you'll get to use those skills against worthier creatures soon enough.
That Fury down in Tartarus has been a real problem, hasn't she. I see the huntress instinct in her. She thinks she knows your weaknesses. Don't let yourself become predictable.
Hey, I once heard Lord Hades has in his employ the greatest hero of the Trojan War, you happen to know anything about that? I'm kind of a fan. You see Achilles, tell him he's the best for me!
So, I have heard that Achilles, himself, taught you how to fight! No wonder you can hold your own down there, that is amazing...! You be sure to honor him from time to time, got it?
Living on Olympus here, I'm surrounded by my family, but I always felt alone. I know that's not the same as your experience, but, I'm just saying I relate to what you're going through.
I think you might enjoy it on Olympus, there's... a lot of feasting here, I guess, and the air is cool and crisp, and it's much brighter than it is down there. Sounds like a dream, right?
I hope that once you make it to Olympus we'll go hunting sometime, you and I, you know? I like being on my own and all, but it's been nice, talking to you like this.
I grow so tired of the others here, you know? Much rather be out with the woodland nymphs than with these gods upon this mountaintop. You must know what it's like.
Not everybody on Olympus is a total disappointment, Zagreus. Why, someday maybe you could meet Callisto, she goes hunting with me all the time! Bet you don't see many woodland nymphs down there.
Hey Zagreus, that Nectar you sent? Callisto and the nymphs and I, we popped it open recently, and it was really good! Had us positively frolicking about. So, thanks!

You must have a friend or two, don't you? It's hard being alone all of the time. At least I have Callisto and the other nymphs, and... I have you! A distant friend is still a friend, isn't that right?
Hope you don't mind, I told Callisto all about you recently! Don't worry, I was quite discreet about it, the two of us were on the hunt, not like I just shouted out your story from the mountaintops!

Zagreus, if only you could turn yourself into a woodland creature and just fly or burrow out of there! My Callisto, she can turn into a bear, you ever seen those? Monstrous, furry things, quite huggable, if they don't kill you first!
You've never even seen the woods, have you? I hope you do, someday. You could meet Callisto and the others! It's quite beautiful, and green, and calm, it's... anyway.

Don't know what it is about you, Zagreus, but I feel like I can be me with you, you know? Maybe it's that you don't constantly talk over me like everybody else, besides Callisto and the nymphs I guess. Not that I can even hear you, but, you know what I mean, right?
Hey, how'd you get your hands on a nice bow like that? You take good care of Coronacht for me, so I can try it too once you're up here.
Have to admit, you're very capable with Coronacht. Now I can hit a bull's eye in my sleep, but you'll be right there with me if I don't keep practicing I think!
Hey, that's the Eternal Spear, Varatha, isn't it? Your father used to use that, didn't he. A bit ornate for hunting, but a spear's a spear, is what I like to say!

Hey, that can't possibly be the spear once wielded by the great Achilles, there, can it?! The shape is unmistakable, I mean, have you even the slightest just how many mortals got completely slaughtered by that thing? Oh, it has seen some use!
That's not the Coronacht I know, isn't that... Chiron the centaur's bow? So that was Coronacht, as well? Seems every decent bow was just a version of that thing! Except for mine, of course.
Say, that's the bow Stepmother Hera herself once wielded, isn't it? Her aspect of Coronacht! I'd know it from the... frankly rather sinister skulls all over it. It's very Hera, trust me.

When did you get your hands on Malphon, the Twin Fists? Hands in, I ought to say! I heard that one time, Demeter, she smacked her father right square in the face with those! Bet you can probably relate.
Well, look at you, with Exagryph, the Rail of Adamant! Seems much too noisy-complicated as a hunting weapon when you could just use a nice quiet bow, but hey, to each her own.

Now listen, Zagreus, admittedly this is a little strange, even from me. I have a message for your bow! That's right, just go on up to Coronacht next time, and tell it with a firm, commanding voice, I see you drawn in the arms of the seventh avatar! Let me know how it goes, OK?
Hey, that's my Adamant Arrowhead on you! Normally, it's for killing things, but in your case it makes it even easier for me to hunt you down, even in the dark. Now that I found you... here!
Your name, it means 'great hunter', Zagreus! I guess your mother Nyx must have expected someday that you'd pick up a few pointers from myself!

Hey, hold a moment, Zagreus, I could have sworn... you were so close, before, but now you're back? Ah, must have tripped up just when victory was close at hand, it happens all the time. We'll get you out of there, you'll see!
Hey, you all right there, Zagreus? Wouldn't do to have you die on me just moments after meeting here like this.
Oh! Look at you, you're hurt there pretty bad, but, just stay focused on the hunt, and it'll help to keep the pain at bay.
Look, I'm just goddess of the hunt, not medicine, so... I don't know if this is going to help right now, but, here!
Your hunt has evidently not been going very well so far, I see. Though, maybe we can still turn it around.
Well, one good thing about all of the blood you've lost is it was even easier to track you down this time!
All right, get ready for this, Zagreus, because I seldom share the greatest of my hunting secrets like I am about to.
All right, no need to keep on toying with your prey. Here comes one of my finest blessings, now!
I don't reveal my greatest hunting techniques for just anybody, Zagreus, so you better appreciate what you're about to get, and use it to go far!
How about we not take any chances this time, Zagreus? So here, this is the best I've got. You better not waste it!

text.Zagreus: There's only one heavenly archer I know of. Well, several, really. Anyway! In the name of Hades! Olympus? I accept this message.

text.Artemis: I heard about you. Look, I'm not like all the others on Olympus. The power of the hunt helps keep me company, so... maybe it'll help you, too!
Hey. You're not alone. You're not alone down there, OK? Here, let me show you.
The dead must make a rather easy target, wouldn't you say? Let's see what you can do to them, given your choice of these.
You busy, Zagreus? Thought maybe I could interest you in some of these old hunting tricks of mine.
How fares the hunt this time around, OK? I bet it could be better, so, erm, here! Maybe this'll help.
Let's take a little hunting expedition, yeah? You'll do most of the work, but hey, I'll be with you in spirit!
Sorry you're still stuck down there. Sometimes I feel stuck myself, but, a good hunt always sets me straight.
When I am on the hunt, my mind is clear, and nothing stands between me and my target. Though, have a blessing just in case you can't relate!
I'd love to know about your life down there. I'll try and help you live through it this time so that way you can tell me?
The wretches whom you face down there have died already, sometimes more than once. Should make for easy targets, right?
I've never come across a target I couldn't take down. I expect the same of you, you hear me? Hopefully you hear me.
Good hunting, Zagreus! The sooner you get out of there the sooner you can save me from my insufferable relatives. Please?
Hey, Zagreus, good luck out there, this time. I'd tell you 'may your aim be true' but I can guarantee it, actually.
The hunt requires utter concentration, so, I'll leave you to it, and... just watch your every move in silence over here...
You want to make it out of there, you... don't have to listen to a word I say, to be quite honest, but... my huntress blessings ought to help.
Well, Zagreus, you getting out of there this time, or am I going to have to keep on hunting by myself for the time being? Probably?
Looks to me like you could use a little help, so I'll just have a look in my big bag of blessings here, and, oh! Here's just the thing.
The hunt comes down to kill-or-be-killed. Except for us immortals, who have to live with our shame, which is worse?
Those wretched things harassing you throughout that Underworld just won't give up, will they? Well, just keep killing them, I guess!
Need a hunting partner, Zagreus? Not that I'm able to join you myself down there, or even hear you respond for that matter, but, anyway, here.
Zagreus, it's me! I'm here to join the hunt with you again. Let's show them what we can do.
Hello again, you ready for this hunt? Me, I've been looking forward since last time, so, let's get on with it.
Stay on your guard, tread lightly, and all that.
Keep a sharp eye out there, won't you?
Good hunting down there, Zagreus.
What are you hunting this time, I wonder.
I'll be looking out for you. If you don't mind of course.
Remember, Zagreus, kill-or-be-killed.
How about I join you for this hunt, OK?
Hey, you take care of yourself, all right?
Got you something I bet you could use.
The finer points of hunting are not easy to communicate, though you're learning from experience, at least!
My senses sure are going to be sharp if I keep trying to keep up with you like this in all that dark down there.
A good, clean shot is all it takes, most of the time!
You getting anywhere down there yet, Zagreus?
What are you waiting for, let's get to hunting, then!
Not much of a hunt when your prey knows exactly where you are, but it'll do!
I hope your every strike cuts to the vital bits of all your prey, there, Zagreus.
I brought some hunting gear for you to try, if you could give me your attention, Zagreus?
All right, Zagreus, catch your breath, decide, and then what say we get you out of hell maybe?
What are we hunting this time, Zagreus? Don't tell me wretched dead, again?
You see how easily I tracked you down? Unless you went out of your way for me, that is?
I have a Boon for you, here, Zagreus, though just be sure you don't embarrass me.
Well, perfect timing, Zagreus, now stock up and head out.
You want to make it out of there, my Boons are just about the only way to go.
Don't you let your father or let anybody push you around, Zagreus.
Bet I can help you break out of your father's realm in no time, Zagreus!
Decided I would pack you something extra for this hunt, if you can handle it!
Enough toying around with our prey, there, Zagreus. What do you say we finish it, this time?
I know it must be such a struggle for you, Zagreus, so here! In case this helps.
A great hunter ought to have great tools, Zagreus, so here! Please allow me.
Wish I could hunt with you myself, but here's the next best thing, all right?
You know how long it took Callisto to become a master of the hunt? I'm sure you can still learn a thing or two!
I was about to head out with Callisto for a hunt, though I can spare you a quick Boon, I guess!
I have to meet Callisto soon, but it won't take me but a moment here to get you on your way!
Someday perhaps you'll join me and Callisto for a hunt! But as for now...
Greetings to you from the forest! Callisto and the woodland nymphs say hi!
You'd make a real asset on the hunt, I think. Not that Callisto and I need assistance, though.
You know, one thing I'll say for Charon there? He doesn't talk too much. And since neither do you, I'm letting you have this.
I guess this means you must have paid the boatman's ransom here, and whatever price he charged you, it was worth it.
Even there in your Underworld, it seems quality hunting gear doesn't come cheap, apparently!
If you're quite done with shopping, Zagreus, what say we cut straight to the chase from here?
You hunted down a real bargain there in Charon's shop, though how about we try a slightly bigger deal on for size right now?
Why would you side with...?! Ugh, why do I even bother with some lesser god!
I thought we had an understanding, Zagreus. But, this wouldn't be the first time I was wrong about someone.
Huh, so that's your choice! Maybe you're more like my relatives than I'd care to admit.
Good shot, there, Zagreus! I guess you got me. Now why don't you go take a shot at this.
Don't be messing with my feelings, Zagreus. My loyalty's hard-won, and quickly lost.
You really missed an easy shot, here, Zagreus. But I will not. You'll see.
Ah, good! Just when I had almost forgotten what an arrow to the back felt like!
Am I some kind of pushover to you, Zagreus? Is that what you think?
Oh, look, turns out it's time for target practice once again! Start running, Zagreus.
What made you think I'd stand for this, from you?
Ah-hah, I knew you'd pull this old maneuver, Zagreus. And I am ready for you, now.
You're getting quite predictable when you betray me like this, Zagreus! Start running, then.

CHOICE.Artemis: Oh really, that's the way it's going to be? You Underworld gods are all alike!

text.Artemis: Fine, I'm not angry anymore, not really anyway, but you just watch yourself with me, you got it?
Oh you're still there I see. Well then, all right, let's call it even for the moment and get on with this.
All right, all right, I'm going to forgive you now I guess, no need to beg, you just think twice next time OK?
Got to say you handled yourself pretty well back there. I can't stay mad after a show like that.
Good hunting just now, Zagreus. You passed my little test, so now we're good, just like it never happened.
So you survived, so what. Here, why not take a Boon, and then be off?
I will admit mistakes were made back there, so you just don't make them again, next time all right?
You know what, I decided not to kill you, Zagreus. No sport in cornered prey, so here, get on with it.
Good thing you're nowhere near our mountaintop or I'd have shot you for that stunt, myself.
Well, Zagreus, it turns out you need all the help that you can get, so here's a pity Boon for you!
I could keep hunting you until you're dead, but there's too little meat on you to make it worth my while.

text.Zagreus: Lady Artemis, I hope that you'll accept this offering, for all your kindness and support.

text.Artemis: Hey thank you for this, really. And, I've just the thing to offer in return. It's just a gift, OK?

text.Zagreus: My lady Artemis! This is nothing, next to all your grace and favor.

text.Artemis: Hey wait, this is an offering, for me? I, oh, that's very kind, though, let's get back to hunting, now, OK?

text.Zagreus: Lady Artemis! I am indebted to you, for the strength and cunning you have given me.

text.Artemis: Look, Zagreus, I don't know what to say, except for... thanks!

text.Zagreus: My lady Artemis, your favor's been invaluable to me. No finer huntress ever walked the surface of the earth, or underneath.

text.Artemis: You're being very nice to me, and that makes me suspicious, understand? So, you want more of that... you keep this up.

text.Zagreus: At the risk of incurring your wrath, Lady Artemis, I hope you will accept this from me, and see that my gratitude for all you have done for me is genuine.

text.Artemis: What do you know, another gift of Nectar, that's... quite thoughtful of you, Zagreus! Normally don't care much for the stuff, but, every now and then, I mean... why not?

text.Zagreus: In your honor, Lady Artemis! Your mighty blessings have helped me through so many trials now, and I always welcome your level-headed presence here.

text.Artemis: Look, I like being worshiped just as much as anybody, Zagreus, though bear in mind that you can always leave the worship of me to the forest nymphs, all right?

CHOICE.Zagreus: I know you have no shortage of Ambrosia on Olympus, Lady Artemis, but I imagine it's less often that the stuff go all the way from there to here, and back. What can I say? You make me proud to be a member of this family.
