I was at times uncharitable with the goddess Nyx, when we were closer, long ago. After she bore her first children, I nevertheless expected her attention to remain undivided. I kept creating. When finally I slowed, I realized my mistake. But our connection had been severed, by that point.
I sense that something is the matter, Son of Hades. Speak, then, what is on your mind? I can decipher some of it without your telling though would rather hear it from you voluntarily.

text.Zagreus: Erm, Master Chaos? The goddess Nyx, she... seems to want to speak with you again. I wonder, would you maybe contact her sometime? She seems convinced it is your move to make if you so choose.

text.Chaos: The goddess Nyx wishes to hear from me...? Now that is unexpected, Son of Hades, and I wonder if, perhaps, this is a jest of yours. Though, your intentions evidently are sincere. Then, I shall make no promises in this, except that... I am considering the possibility.

Son of Hades, should eventually you spawn your own offspring... I recommend maintaining sub-infinite distances with them in space and time. Even if they are most tiresome, there always seems to come a point when one wishes to be in their presence once again.

After some consideration, and on your recommendation, I attempted lately to make contact with the goddess Nyx again. She is quite distant from me now, of course. If you happen to know... did she receive the message well? Respond.

text.Zagreus: Well, Master Chaos, she can be a little difficult to read at times, but... I got the impression she was quite surprised, even excited to have heard from you again. She said that she would think about how to respond. Or, whether to respond.

text.Chaos: I see. Well, she shall find a way, if it is warranted. I always did expect the world from her. There were times when I expected her to shine as bright as day, though she is Night. When she achieved a certain level of ability... she left. And I could not find her.

My daughter, the goddess Nyx. When I learned the Olympians mistakenly assumed she was your mother, I did not fully consider the possibility that she essentially was a mother to you... the technicality of birth, aside. She cares for you to the extent a mother can.

Prior to your intervention, Son of Hades, I expected that the goddess Nyx had forgotten about me... whether purposefully, or from passage of time. I believed that to be forgotten was the one true inevitability. Perhaps, however, I was incorrect.

I find that it is difficult maintaining my connection with many consciousnesses, such as yours, and that of the goddess Nyx. Yet I am also finding that this difficulty is fully warranted. Our connections give me much to consider as I await our next exchange.
Ah, here is my favorite among those immortals dwelling underneath the Earth. How may I change your life today, O Son of Hades?
May you enjoy a moment's peace within my space before venturing on in uncertainty. To my surprise, I must admit I do appreciate the company.
Have you grown trusting yet of the Olympians, for all their generosity? Perhaps you ought to let them know the truth about your journey's goal. They are vain, and think that it is them you seek.

text.Zagreus: I'll never get out of here if not for their help, but... I can't let them know about Mother. She wants to remain hidden from them.

text.Chaos: A difficult position to be in, Son of Hades. The Olympians may not appreciate being misled. But you can trust that I shall keep your secret. I wish to see how your predicament plays out.

Such darkness emanates from you, O Son of Hades, that I once again did not entirely anticipate you would arrive just now. I suspect even your father must have difficulty keeping track of you through the domain he calls his own.

You move in darkness, practically unseen, Son of Hades. It is quite difficult even for me to sense your presence at times. The Olympians catch their glimpses now and then. But you are always in a shroud. Thus is the influence of Nyx.

How strange it is to be subjected to the Fates. But do not fall into the cognitive delusion that they have already made your choices for you, Son of Hades. Rather, they are keen about anticipating every choice that everyone shall make. Such as the following.
I sense your consternation, Son of Hades, as you look about this space; you have another question, and are free to ask.

text.Zagreus: Oh, it's just... I sometimes wonder, Master Chaos... if you created all of this, then... who created you? What was this place before you arrived?

text.Chaos: All of this simply came to be, and so did I, presumably after a former time had finally reached its end. I hesitate to say it was an act of will. It was more like a sudden shift, as when a conflagration happens from a spark. I arrived at such a time, and all else then arrived, from me.

When you expire, and then suddenly return to life within your father's residence, perhaps it is akin to when I first gained consciousness so long ago. Perhaps I, too, had just expired, only to reawaken.

You may have wondered, Son of Hades, how it is you came to find me in this space, when I have gone unseen by most for quite some time. I have wondered this, as well, and think that our connection to Goddess Nyx is the most likely answer.

Son of Hades, I believe I have deduced something I ought have sooner recognized. Your mother must have been one who called herself Persephone. Her stay within the Underworld was brief, from my perspective, but impactful, nonetheless. You seek her now? Respond.

text.Zagreus: I do. She's somewhere on the surface. That's why I keep on finding you like this. I'm trying to find her.

text.Chaos: I hope that your attempts achieve success. She is beyond my senses, presently, though of course I am still able to assist you in your journey, thus.

Son of Hades, I believe I have deduced something I ought have sooner recognized. Your mother must have been one who called herself Persephone. Her stay within the Underworld was brief, from my perspective, but impactful, nonetheless. You seek her now? Respond.

text.Zagreus: Oh, Master Chaos... you should know I have located her, already. Though where she is, I cannot stay for long. So I am visiting, as often as I can. It's... not unlike our visits here. Only, somehow, even harder to get to where she is.

text.Chaos: I see. Then, it is good to know that you have been in contact. And I trust that your successive visits shall be worth their while. Not unlike our visits here.
Son of Hades, if you locate the one who called herself Persephone, shall it then come to pass that we no longer see each other in this way? Respond.

text.Zagreus: Oh! I... Master Chaos, I don't know what to expect from there. But, to be direct with you, if I could leave the Underworld forever... I think I would. Though, I would miss you. Many others here.

text.Chaos: ...I would miss you as well. Thank you for telling me.
Tell me something, Son of Hades. If the one who called herself Persephone is back, then... why do you continue to return? Respond.

text.Zagreus: Master Chaos, it seems I've developed something of a talent around breaking out of here. Or, there, I mean, the Underworld, so... it's become more of an official role for me, I guess. If escape shouldn't be possible, then someone needs to find the gaps.

text.Chaos: Indeed. Then, you shall visit with me still, despite accomplishing the principal object of your journey back when first we met. Good.
I am impressed that you were able to procure a specimen out from the flowing currents here in my domain, with nothing but a simple instrument. I shall look forward to your subsequent attempts.

I trust the small round catalyst which I provided you has been of value, Son of Hades? It is my hope it makes your journeys to this space less difficult, perhaps inducing them on a more frequent interval.
You have arrived within a certain shroud of darkness, Son of Hades. The goddess Nyx's ancient shawl. I had not sensed its void in a considerable amount of time.

You have traveled recently beyond my senses, Son of Hades. I persist here only in the fathomless depths. I know what lies out there, having created it. But I know nothing of what it is like, right now. Do not tell me. I prefer to think of all the possibilities.

From the rumblings of the earth, I have deduced your father, himself, stands against you when at last you are about to leave these depths. It must be quite an interaction between you. Have I deduced correctly? Respond.

text.Zagreus: That's right, Master Chaos. My father personally takes it upon himself to stop me in the event none of his underlings beat him to it. He... can be a handful.

text.Chaos: Well, then. Consider bringing to one of your future interactions the small round catalyst, which I provided you. The one in the shape you call an egg? It shall serve no purpose there at all. Yet if you succeed, then it shall bring us some amusement, shall it not?
It seems to me that you are very close to death, O Son of Hades, and yet you deigned to visit me within my space. I could hasten your demise, if you so choose?
I almost did not notice you, O Son of Hades, for you are closer now to death than life. Perhaps, though, we can stave off the inevitable for a little while.
Your deaths are but a temporary setback, Son of Hades. Though it appears to me you are quite close to having such a setback, now.
Your next experience with death seems to be imminent, though let us see if I can hasten or forestall it.
It may seem cruel that I would wish you death, O Son of Hades. But from my perspective, it means you are much more likely to return to me.
Although you may succumb soon to your injuries, please make the most of your remaining life, rather than anticipate the next. The future is uncertain to all save the Fates.

You come to my domain bearing an all-seeing artifact that sprang from me after the dawn of time. It is considered a defensive instrument, I do believe. Though, I suspect you have discovered, or soon shall discover, it is nothing of the sort.

I expected your arrival, Son of Hades. For I am able to see through you. Rather, through the all-seeing artifact, which sprang from me after the dawn of time, and now resembles, in your hands, its foremost form. Respond.

text.Zagreus: What, you must mean the Shield of Chaos, here? Your shield, Master Chaos, I should say. It's a remarkable artifact. Imposing, too! Your original creations must have been astounding.

text.Chaos: Your response is acceptable. And I am grateful to have had my recent firsthand glimpses of this vast domain.

Ah, you have that all-seeing artifact of mine, but in the old guise that the great Lord Zeus once used when he retaliated violently against his parentage. I watched his movements through it for some time.

I bear a message for you, Son of Hades. One recorded in an age when certain concepts it describes did not yet all exist. Remember this: I see you stand your ground against the serpent's flame. A waking-phrase, to which you and the all-seeing artifact of my creation may respond.

text.Zagreus: A waking-phrase... and an all-seeing artifact, you must mean Aegis, right? So I'm to say to it, I see you stand your ground against the serpent's flame, and it'll wake right up. Though, can you tell me what it means, or who?

text.Chaos: Oh, I can tell you almost anything. However, I would much prefer it if you learned most of the answers you seek by yourself.

text.Zagreus: This is not someone I recognize... so, in the name of Hades! Erm, hello? May I ask who's calling?

text.Chaos: ...The Olympians have all grown soft... would you not agree?

text.Zagreus: Erm... have we met?

text.Chaos: Oh, we have met, in a way. I know everybody, here, and there. You wish to leave this place? Then, it is my wish to make your doing so a little bit more interesting... and, if you encounter the Olympians someday, do give them my regards.
I sensed a certain rumbling here within the bowels of the earth. It is as though it had ingested something that did not sit well... perhaps the earth itself wishes to spit you up and out...?
The Olympians are vying for your favor, are they not? So often they forget themselves. They force their blessings onto you, whilst I? I merely offer you a choice.
Your path is yours to shape as you see fit, regardless of the Fates' design. Together we may twist that path a bit, if you would like.
I both expected you to come and am surprised to see you, Son of Hades. Where shall your journey take you from this point?
Please tell me how my power over all existence may be of small assistance to you this time, Son of Hades?
The tremors underneath the earth foretold of your arrival at this very moment, Son of Hades; and, I have anticipated it.
You chose to visit me again within these darkest reaches of the earth, as I, in turn, now choose to offer you the means to alter your reality.
Back when I conceived the world and the immortals, Son of Hades, I did not expect you would be standing here before me now.
You have arrived at last, just as I wondered how we might best alter one another's courses of existence here today.
Son of Hades, let me welcome your return here to my space within the Underworld, and bid you choose an alteration to the fabric of reality.
It pleases me that you are here again; for, through you I can tinker with reality, along the fringes that are not yet fully formed.
Your presence never ceases to intrigue me, Son of Hades; for you are not like the Olympians on high, who have forgotten me, or thusly choose to act.
From my perspective I have summoned you, whilst you believe you came of your volition; both statements can be true, is that not so?
Come forth, O Son of Hades, and together, let us sow my namesake through the depths of what your father thinks his own domain.
How fares these days the never-ending cycle of rebirth and death for you, O Son of Hades? Sufficiently amusing, I should hope?
Out of the infinitely spanning possibilities before us, Son of Hades, I have arbitrarily selected only three again from which to let you choose.
The Fates have much in store for you, O Son of Hades. Perhaps, however, we can tamper with their weavings here to some extent.
Let us conspire to expand and frustrate your lord father's sense of both what is and is not possible within his Underworld.
Infinite possibilities can be tedious to choose from, so, let me provide you with a significantly smaller set with which you may yet change the Fates' designs.
Through the expanse of time, I often wondered, is it necessary to be fair? The immortals are my offspring; surely I should treat them equally. And yet I find that there is little sport in doing so.
Among infinite possibilities, consider only these.
Choose carefully, in general, and now.
We are the sum of all decisions that we make, and that are made for us.
This space grows far more interesting when you occupy a small amount of it.
How you evaluate decisions is of limitless interest to me.
The burden of the passing time shall force a choice from you.
Is there not pleasure in determining an outcome, Son of Hades?
My mark be with you, Son of Hades. You need merely choose its shape.
Though the waters of the Styx may wash away my mark, I can restore it.
The rhythm of your visits here over the course of time is pleasant, Son of Hades.
You are already back, and you are always welcome, Son of Hades.
Please visit me as frequently as you would like or dare.
I find myself anticipating your arrivals, Son of Hades.
I require no exchange of words with you. Merely a choice.
Once more you have returned to my domain.
I have a proposition, Son of Hades.
I bid you welcome here within my space.
How fares the solitary Son of Hades?
What shall we do for one another, Son of Hades?
You are within my presence, Son of Hades.
What brings you here to me this time around?
Your such visits are agreeable with me.
How may the force of Chaos alter you?
You have arrived before me once again.
I see that you are here, and so am I.
You stand before me, Son of Hades.
How shall we alter the intentions of the Fates?
How might I mend the fabric of existence for you, Son of Hades?
There need not be a reason for your visit.
How may I shape reality for you?
You are always welcome here within this space.
What occupies your mind at this occasion?
Let us consider certain possibilities.
Among infinite outcomes, I propose these three.
Choose how to circumvent the Fates' design.
Hail, Son of Hades.
I am amused to see you once again.
You have descended to my space once more.
You have returned to me.
You are most welcome here.
Your presence is appreciated, Son of Hades, but please leave us here, for now.
Forgive us, Son of Hades, as we are amid exchanging memories.
Son of Hades, I am pleased the goddess Nyx returned to me.
Forgive me, Son of Hades, but I must continue this discussion with the goddess Nyx.
I had not seen the goddess Nyx in quite some time.
I am quite unaccustomed to having all this company of late.
My daughter was just in the midst of telling me the latest occurrences about your House.
As you are able to observe, the goddess Nyx and I are in the midst of conversation now.
Perhaps you did not think that I would seek you out among the boatman Charon's trifles, which precisely is the reason I have done it.
The boatman Charon understands my whims, and his loyalty is purchased easily by one for whom base wealth is meaningless, so, I am here.

text.Zagreus: Master Chaos? Everyone makes offerings to my relatives upon Olympus. I wish to make an offering to you. Thank you for... everything.

text.Chaos: How droll of you to make attempts to tempt me with material things. Here, then, please in turn allow me this attempt at reciprocity.

text.Zagreus: This is for you, Master Chaos. Everyone beneath the heavens and earth enjoys this stuff.

text.Chaos: You honor me in making such an offering, though please; it is not necessary to endear yourself using material means, for it is the thought alone which counts.

text.Zagreus: Master Chaos, forebear of the gods, it is an honor to have met you. Please, accept this gift.

text.Chaos: Seldom do mortals or immortals think of making offerings to me. As I do not expect such token gestures, I am very much amused, and I accept.

text.Zagreus: Master Chaos, I pledge never to forget you or your good graces. May your wisdom and your whim forever guide me.

text.Chaos: Is this an offering of fealty or friendship, Son of Hades? I do not wish to know from you the answer, so that I might dwell on it and all the possibilities.

text.Zagreus: I'm ever-grateful that my journeys through the Underworld mean that we can get to know each other, Master Chaos.

text.Chaos: Your repeated generosity with me is starting to become a bit predictable, and yet... somehow, I nonetheless appreciate it, still. How very odd.

text.Zagreus: Master Chaos, it's little wonder all existence sprang from you, because I see the noble qualities in so many I've met embodied in you. Please, accept this gift.

text.Chaos: If it is unclear yet, Son of Hades, I shall not be giving more to you in exchange for your repeated offerings. You give them to me knowing it shall serve no purpose and achieve no end. I know that there are some among both mortals and your kind for whom this is quite unacceptable.

text.Zagreus: This is the greatest delicacy of Olympus, Master Chaos. It's for you. I think normally it would be difficult for the Olympians to get it to you here.

text.Chaos: You make an even greater offering to me, knowing it shall produce no material result. You are aware that I am not persuadable? Yours is a squandering of resources and time. Although, of course, we do have each of these in great supply. Now then, respond.

text.Zagreus: ...I just think the act of giving isn't quite the same as an exchange. I know I won't be getting any sort of other talisman or something in return. But, through these offerings, I can express my thanks. That's worth it by itself.

text.Chaos: ...I see. So then, the action is akin to theft. For you are getting something in return that I did not intend to give. I still have much to learn from my creations, Son of Hades. So let us say that we have made an even trade. My learning for your worth.

CHOICE.Zagreus: If you'll forgive me, Master Chaos, this Ambrosia is intended to be given to those whom I care about, and I can think of few recipients I'd like to have it more. Please.

CHOICE.Chaos: I shall accept this, as a final offering, O Son of Hades. For I have given it additional consideration, and decided that my previous analysis of your intentions was too narrow, too inaccurate. And, I regret comparing what you have been doing to an act of theft. Respond?

CHOICE.Zagreus: Don't even mention it, please, Master Chaos. All of this is new for me, as well. I try never to overanalyze... my father does enough of that for all of us. I just know, when I encounter the primordial creator, I am going to give thanks. For everything.

CHOICE.Chaos: ...I see. Then, your response is quite acceptable. And, since the act of giving is not an exchange, let us say that you already had my gratitude.
This was one of the potential outcomes of my gift.
All of this was in accordance with the Fates' design; or perhaps not.
I expected you would perish soon; but I knew not exactly how.
Your demises are unfortunate and yet a source of some amusement.
Be careful with me, Son of Hades.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Time to mix up my style.
That's just the edge I need.
Let's see what I can do with this sword.
Time to tune up this sword.
Now to fix up this spear.
This spear's due for a little maintenance.
Should get this bow back into tiptop shape.
This bow could use a little fine tuning.
Should put some extra punch into this shield.
This shield's about to get a whole lot stronger.
New styles for the Twin Fists.
Time to fix up these Fists.
Some modifications to the rail are in order.
Let's see how we can modify the rail.
Daedalus, wherever you may be right now, thank you.
Need all the firepower I can get.
A blade fit for a god.
They'll fear me with this spear.
These Fists are hungry to fight.

CHOICE.Hades: Your foes shall have to watch their backs.
All right, I heard you, boy!

CHOICE.Zagreus: That looks like a Daedalus Hammer!
Looks like I'm due for an upgrade.

text.Hades: You hung the painting where I asked?

text.Zagreus: Yes...

CHOICE.Achilles: Suggest you hurry in there, lad...

text.Dusa: <Gasp>

CHOICE.Megaera: ...the problem that I have with that wretched shade is his attitude.
...I don't know which of them is worse, I swear to you.
...He truly is an idiot, I'll give you that.

CHOICE.Thanatos: That takes care of that, I guess. See you.

text.Zagreus: Um... hello...?

text.Persephone: Hello, indeed!

text.Zagreus: Wait, can, can we just...?

text.Orpheus: My friend?

text.Nyx: Haaaaah.

text.Zagreus: You... why...

text.Hades: Stupid boy. I told you nobody gets out of here, whether alive or dead. Though, how was your wanton ransacking of my domain?

text.Zagreus: Greetings, Father. My ransacking was a delight, thank you for asking. So, I'll just be on my way, again.

text.Hades: Be on your way, indeed. What do I care? You shall never reach the surface. Go, see for yourself.
What is it, now? I've a mountain of infernal parchmentwork.
Out of my sight, now, go.

text.Zagreus: No thanks!

text.Hades: To what do I owe the pleasure, boy? For I'm unaccustomed to being approached by you here in my House.

text.Zagreus: Oh, you know. Just thought I'd check in, see what you were up to. Parchmentwork going all right, I'm sure?

text.Hades: Oh yes, the parchmentwork is going splendidly. Would you care for some? There is no shortage of it, you see.

text.Zagreus: Father, what happened to the lounge? The only place for anyone to have a little fun around here, and you seal it shut.

text.Hades: Oh, I had little choice about that, boy. You see, after you fled the first time, Cerberus, why he was very much upset. Utterly tore the place to shreds. It's now under repair. All thanks to you.

text.Zagreus: You're really blaming me for not minding the dog while I was out, and while you all were here?

text.Hades: I lay the blame entirely upon you, yes. Who else? It's fortunate that Cerberus has calmed himself since then! Come to his senses, I should say. May you yet come to yours.

text.Zagreus: Nice.
Who's that sniveling shade to your immediate left, there, Father? Already found someone new to do the busywork. And here I thought I was utterly indispensable.

text.Hades: That shade, boy, is my newly designated contractor; one whose responsibility is to work on this House. Though, who shall pay for everything my subjects here demand, I do not know.

text.Zagreus: You're trying to guilt me into funding the exorbitant furnishings you desire.

text.Hades: Perhaps once we are finished with repairs for all the carnage you have sown throughout my realm, then we might finally have time for all the needed renovations that have piled up.
You have been keeping our contractor rather busy, I must say. Commissioning these frivolous projects around the House with the wealth you wrest from my domain. What are you hoping to achieve?

text.Zagreus: Oh, you know, just giving back to the community. Figure if I'm to keep getting dragged back here it might as well be somewhat livable.

text.Hades: Livable! When last I checked, making the Underworld livable was not among our top priorities. Just remember, in your brazenness, whose House this is.
Hrm.
You have been keeping our contractor rather busy, I must say. Commissioning these frivolous projects around the House with the wealth you wrest from my domain. What are you hoping to achieve?

text.Zagreus: Oh, you know, just giving back to the community. Figure if I'm to keep getting dragged back here it might as well be somewhat livable.

text.Hades: Hrm.
Go occupy yourself someplace else.

text.Zagreus: There's quite a lot of renovating to be done, isn't there, Father. Your House Contractor there has shown a wide variety of pending jobs.

text.Hades: I've ordered Nyx to supervise that list. Entirely her problem, boy. And likely yours. How does it feel, knowing that your rampages create the need for so much maintenance?

text.Zagreus: Feels pretty good, now that you mention it. Keeps everybody occupied, no?
You know, Father! I must say ransacking your domain beats having to toil endlessly in the administrative chamber. Far less painful, really.

text.Hades: Hah! Is that your way of asking me for your old job back, boy? You were a scourge upon every administrative duty to which you were assigned.

text.Zagreus: Yes, please, Father, give me back my old, wretched job, won't you?

text.Hades: Privileges are earned not begged for, boy. Unless you plan to reimburse this House for all the income that we lost because of you, then you shall not so much as set foot in the administrative chamber, again.

text.Zagreus: How much is the reimbursement fee, anyway?

text.Hades: Whichever exorbitant amount the House Contractor has on record, now leave me be!
So help me, boy, I cannot fathom why you would have bought back the authority to enter the administrative chamber once again.

text.Zagreus: I knew you thought I'd never do it under any circumstances, Father. That seemed reason enough. Though, fear not, I've no plans to reapply for a position there.

text.Hades: That does alleviate a deeply rooted fear of mine, in fact. The scene you caused in your brief time there yet remains a widely talked-about event among the shades who toil for me still.
You're better off.

text.Zagreus: Always wanted to ask you something, Father. Whose skull is that there on your shoulder? If it's not too personal.

text.Hades: I did not chronicle all Typhon's wretched offspring, boy. No one did. Some of them sit upon our shoulders now, lest we forget that things could easily have turned out rather differently, and much, much worse.

text.Zagreus: So these are just the remains of the spawn of the most hideous monstrosity of all time, which you and your brothers slew, got it. I guess putting the dead in their place is all part of the job. I can hardly imagine what it was like before you and the Olympians took charge.

text.Hades: Indeed.
Be certain that you take appropriate precautions with the Sigil of the Dead that you now bear. Should some misfortune come to it through negligence, it cannot be replaced.

text.Zagreus: I can't imagine what I'd do without your blessing, Father! But, thank you again. I don't often inherit Fate-appointed honors, and will take good care of it. Though... what if the Olympians catch on? Wouldn't do for everybody knowing that you're aiding me even a little, right?

text.Hades: Correct. It would not do, at all. Fortunately, the power of the Unseen can remain well-hidden as it pleases. What is it your instructor always says?

text.Zagreus: ...Fear is for the weak?

text.Hades: Those Chthonic Companion things you have from Nyx, or whoever they ended up with... I know they have been benefiting you.

text.Zagreus: Yeah, well... I'm to attempt to escape this place by any means necessary, right? I figure if I can call on Olympus for aid, maybe some of my friends can help me in a pinch, as well.

text.Hades: Not what I mean. Some of your friends have been reluctant to engage against me during our scuffles on the surface. Know that I have authorized them to proceed, if necessary.

text.Zagreus: Wait, really? You're saying it's OK for your own loyal subjects to side against you up there? You won't take it out on them?

text.Hades: I consider it an expansion of their responsibilities. Now, go.
See to it. And... well done.

text.Zagreus: So tell me, Father. Just how much did it hurt your soul knowing my face is up there on the Featured Houseservant Board, for all in the lounge to see?

text.Hades: Has it occurred to you that I, alone, have final say about whose countenance is shown up there? Although, others who shall not be named did put in a good word for you, repeatedly.

text.Zagreus: Blood and darkness... all my life I thought that board was a joke. But seeing my face up there... it felt good. Thanks, Father. Maybe it won't be the last time.

text.Hades: Indulge me for a moment, boy. Why bother to construct a sundial, there? Knowing full well it was my wish to have one installed. To demonstrate your awe-inspiring authority? Or to deny me the small pleasure of doing it myself?

text.Zagreus: Maybe a little of each? Or maybe you ought not second-guess my every motive and decision, constantly, searching for some sinister agenda that has yet to cross my mind?

text.Hades: Pah! I would have chosen an entirely different marble texture for it, anyway.

text.Zagreus: Oh, it's no trouble at all.
Guess what, Father? The lounge is all tidied up. Your House Contractor there is quite efficient once you muster up the necessary funds. You should try it sometime!

text.Hades: Are you expecting words of thanks because you paid the contractor to fix a bit of devastation that you caused? I fear it shall take rather more than that.

text.Zagreus: What if I replaced every furnishing in this blasted place, would you treat me any better then?

text.Hades: I suppose, boy, that there's only one way to find out. Though I suggest you save yourself the trouble.

text.Zagreus: Good talk...? Good talk..

text.Hades: I see you've decided to come home. Changed your mind yet, or looking for more pain and suffering?

text.Zagreus: More pain and suffering, for sure. After all, you taught me to appreciate the finer things.

text.Hades: You keep telling yourself that, boy. But, mark you my words, sooner or later, this life that you have chosen for yourself shall teach you I was right.
Well that was quick. What news, boy, ready to give up, or no?

text.Zagreus: You'd like that, wouldn't you? Lucky I've got other family who believe in me.

text.Hades: Be careful whom you give your trust. My brothers frolic on Olympus while we work. While I work! You're just like them. No wonder they like you.
EndCue  /VO/ZagreusHome_0018,

text.Zagreus: In that case, I'll spare you the details.

text.Hades: Fine. Your failure is quite easily imagined. How often it recurs! Almost as though my realm is built to keep you here. You, and every single soul that's ever lived. But, by all means, continue struggling.
EndCue  /VO/ZagreusHome_020,

text.Zagreus: That's all right, Father. I'm not feeling very hungry at the moment.

text.Hades: ...I've asked repeatedly for the construction of a sundial, but every time, they tell me no, can you believe it? Your impertinence with me inspires all.
EndCue  /VO/ZagreusHome_2259,

text.Zagreus: That's all right, Father. I'm not feeling very hungry at the moment.

text.Hades: ...I've asked repeatedly for the construction of a sundial, but every time, they tell me no, can you believe it?
Blood and darkness, but this place is falling apart... nobody works an honest day down here.

text.Zagreus: Father, everybody's dead. Give them a break.

text.Hades: What would you even know of honest work? At least the wretched dead yet honor me as Lord. I cannot say the same for you.
Have you yet satisfied your foolish urges? Perhaps a lashing from the Furies' whips would set you straight.

text.Zagreus: I had it out with them already, thanks.

text.Hades: Such nonsense. First you defy me openly, and now you lie. On my next meeting with the Furies, we'll have a word about all this, you rest assured.
Why, I can scarce believe my eyes, is that you, boy?! Cerberus, look who it is, he's back!

text.Storyteller: Cerberus looks mournfully toward the Prince.,

text.Zagreus: No need to drag the dog into this, Father.

text.Hades: Anything you say to me, you say in front of Cerberus! You might even learn a thing or two from him of listening, and of obedience!
He's back already, Cerberus! Just as I indicated.

text.Zagreus: I'm standing right here, Father.

text.Hades: I'm sorry he disturbed your rest again, Cerberus, you've done a good job. The realm is well defended still, to the high standard that you set.
What did I tell you, boy? Ever wasteful of your time, and mine. How fares my Underworld, hm?

text.Zagreus: I don't know how you can stand it.

text.Hades: Well, at least some things are running smoothly still. Next you go to die again, do give the tortured souls out there my warm regards.
Ah, for shame, boy. I thought perhaps you'd finally made it out.

text.Zagreus: Really...? I mean, oh, wait, you're not serious. That famous sense of humor shining through.

text.Hades: I jest, of course, you'll never make it out; as I keep telling you to no avail. But you've gone farther than expected. So, who knows....
...You've been gone a while...

text.Zagreus: I'm going to find Mother. No matter how long it takes me.

text.Hades: For the last time, you're not to speak about that woman in my House. You want to know of her so much, you go find her, indeed.

text.Zagreus: Pleasure doing business, then.

text.Hades: I know that Nyx has been abetting you. You wish to take advantage of her pity? I care not. Her powers have their limits, anyway.

text.Zagreus: How can you... Nyx is the Night Itself, and can do as she pleases, isn't that correct, Father? You think I asked she get involved in all this business?

text.Hades: You, boy, have already dragged this entire household, not to mention my fool relatives, into this mess, which you've created. Which you dare call business.

text.Zagreus: Heartwarming.

So, tell me something, Father, if you please. Since we're more candid lately in regard to matters of my birthright here, and all... did you and Mother... how to put this? Any brothers or sisters I should know about?

text.Hades: I thought I told you never to invoke her here! Be thankful that you have no blasted kin. You've such weak blood, and such a temperament... why, then, would you think I'd risk another, such as you?

text.Zagreus: Sure, that's fair enough, it's just not all such things occur as planned, as I am told. From tales of your brothers and so forth.

text.Hades: Oh, blast my brothers, and blast you, as well! All those who know me know I have no heir. You could not rise to the occasion if you tried! And, there is no one else. You've only me. And I have only you.

text.Zagreus: Contractor, mind locating the Court Musician's Sentence when you get the chance?

You call my chambers a mess, look at your desk, Father! Whatever happened to your court musician, huh, where's his sentencing parchmentwork? Stuck in Tartarus, all because he stopped singing for you on command?

text.Hades: My desk is far more organized than you, boy! And if you're so concerned about our court musician, why don't you commute his sentence, yourself? Seeing as I haven't gotten around to it yet.

text.Zagreus: Sure, happy to oblige. I'll just ask the House Contractor since you're too busy.
Your methods didn't seem to do the trick.

text.Hades: I understand you have attempted to persuade our court musician to resume his craft. That is among the relatively useful tasks to which you have applied yourself of late.

text.Zagreus: I can't be completely sure but, what you said just now I think contained some of the component pieces of a compliment?

text.Hades: I'm certain that your boasts and twists of words shall soon inspire him to greater acts of compositional superiority, one of these days or nights.

text.Zagreus: ...I hope.

text.Hades: I had a feeling that our court musician would eventually come back to his senses and his talents, boy. Here, yet again, my intuitions were correct. Though, you appear a bit perturbed. Don't like the song? It's about you!

text.Zagreus: It says I'm really the bastard son of Zeus, but also indelibly connected to the god of wine, and how your parents tore me to pieces, giving rise to mortals, but that I'm always going to be stuck here.

text.Hades: You fill Orpheus' mind with nonsense, he produces nonsense. Nonsense I presume shall spread from this place far and wide, so everyone might know that I have nothing to do with you.

text.Zagreus: I'm not worried. Orpheus plays for a very small audience.
Tsch.
Father, I met an oak nymph called Eurydice. You know her name, I think. Is it really true what happened between her and Orpheus? They say you almost let her out, so why not me?

text.Hades: Pah! Orpheus is a talented musician, and a fool. I knew he would never get his beloved wife out of here. There's no escape for her, or anyone, including you.

text.Zagreus: So you tricked him. Or maybe offered him a deal in bad faith. No matter. What's it going to take to waive the separation order between them?

text.Hades: That's non-negotiable, boy. Waiving a separation order! That's a veritable fortune in dues alone. Off the table. Now, go mind your own affairs, and leave the waiving and the ordering to me.

text.Zagreus: Who knows, they might surprise you.
Father, have you ever considered that Orpheus might be much better as a court musician if you permitted him to see his muse again?

text.Hades: I have considered many possibilities, boy. And I trust Orpheus considered many possibilities before he signed away his rights to see his so-called muse when once he invaded my realm!

text.Zagreus: So you're forcing him to stay here for eternity just because he signed a contract with you?

text.Hades: Contracts with me are binding! Until such time as they dig themselves out of the archives and tear themselves up! And I don't see that happening anytime soon.

text.Zagreus: We'll see.
Father, let's say, hypothetically, that I could pay the dues to waive the separation order between Orpheus and Eurydice. Would you honor the new terms, or spitefully cheat me out of a fair deal?

text.Hades: I honor the terms of my commitments, boy. The rules we put in place are all that keep this Underworld in any semblance of a shape! But, what you ask is utterly absurd. The costs of processing a separation order are well beyond your means.

text.Zagreus: Looking forward to it.

text.Hades: You voided the contract with our court musician. Used your own authority against me.

text.Zagreus: So what if I did? Just gives him a bit of break from time to time. He's still your court musician, isn't he?

text.Hades: He is. And he knows better than to undermine me, I think. Out with you, then! I'll deal with your insubordination some other time.

text.Zagreus: He has.

text.Hades: You voided the contract with our court musician. Used your own authority against me.

text.Zagreus: So what if I did? Just gives him a bit of break from time to time. He's still your court musician, isn't he?

text.Hades: He is. And he knows better than to undermine me, I think. Though, I suppose the Queen would take your side that he has paid his dues in full, by now...?

text.Zagreus: That's good to know!

Father, let me ask you something work-related, here. I know the shade called Sisyphus once wronged both you and Thanatos, and has since paid a heavy price. But don't the Fury Sisters now have better things to do than torture him?

text.Hades: You come to me to question how I allocate my resources? Preposterous. I care nothing for that wretched shade. That he is tortured for eternity is but a technicality resulting from his arrogance. The terms of his incarceration are long lost!

text.Zagreus: So then if I could somehow find those terms, then theoretically, I could grant him a pardon...

text.Hades: If you could somehow do your job, and enact miracles, then yes! You could do anything, then, I suppose. Including waste your time on those of his undeserving ilk.

text.Zagreus: Not if those responsibilities matter.

text.Hades: You altered one of my own pacts, without so much as seeking my consent... undoing terms that were agreed upon. Do you intend to undermine everything in this House, boy? Or only me?

text.Zagreus: Only you, Father. Good thing I've inherited some of your Fate-given authority, being your son and all. Otherwise some of your most loyal subjects would be bound by exploitive terms for eternity.

text.Hades: Terms that they chose, themselves! Terms to the benefit of this House. What if Achilles were to leave his post for the green pastures of Elysium, what then?

text.Zagreus: You could find a replacement? But it's a pointless question anyway, because he's here! He isn't leaving. He might even do better at his job, now that he has increased ability to step away from it.

text.Hades: A naive hope, at best. The more you step away from your responsibilities, the less you shall want anything to do with them.

text.Zagreus: That's strangely comforting to know.

text.Hades: Megaera tells me that you surpassed her while out there. How utterly embarrassing for her, to say the least.

text.Zagreus: I suppose you're going to punish her in some cruel fashion, then?

text.Hades: Oh, I've already seen to that, of course. You think she volunteered to deal with you? Nobody did. That's how ignoble a task it is.

text.Zagreus: Looking forward to it.

text.Hades: Tell me something, boy, did you enjoy the searing heat of Asphodel? You must have thought that you'd be more resilient to it.

text.Zagreus: I'm open to a change of climate. Even if it gets a bit uncomfortable.

text.Hades: You know nothing of discomfort, yet. Making it out of Tartarus is nothing in comparison to what lies ahead for you.

text.Zagreus: You'll find out soon enough.

text.Hades: I understand that you created quite a stir within Elysium. An all-out brawl within eternal paradise!

text.Zagreus: You call that paradise? It's just a bunch of shades bored out of their former skulls, itching for a chance to feel alive again.

text.Hades: What would you know of it! The greatest mortals have their every need fulfilled within that place. I dread to hear what they shall say of all of this.

text.Zagreus: See you up at the Temple then, I guess.

text.Hades: Tell me something, boy, because my own set of ideas on the subject is beginning to run dry: What, exactly, is it going to take for you to understand that you're not leaving here?

text.Zagreus: Perhaps you ought to have me bound next to Prometheus, and have the dreaded Eagle peck my liver for eternity?

text.Hades: You would have me resort to such barbarity? Blast you, boy. Punishment is not the path to rehabilitation; it is for its own sake. I'd have expected all your trips through Tartarus to have taught you as much.

text.Zagreus: And there it is again.

text.Hades: I'm truly sorry that he's troubled you again, Cerberus. I know how much you value resting here, and yet, I have no better means to bar the entry to our realm than you.

text.Zagreus: I thought you'd figured out by now that guilting me into abandoning my quest won't work. You're the one who should feel guilty, forcing Cerberus to block my path.

text.Hades: What would you know of it? Cerberus cannot be forced to do anything. He simply understands he has responsibilities.

text.Zagreus: No!

text.Hades: Ah, verify something for me, here, boy. According to the latest reports... you attempted unsuccessfully to shoplift from Charon, himself? And were consequently slain? Utterly ignoble end, even for you.

text.Zagreus: Erm, I was borrowing, OK? Not shoplifting. Why didn't anybody ever tell me Charon was such a monster? I thought the boating mercantile thing made for a peaceful life.

text.Hades: You incur the wrath of ancient chthonic gods, and then are surprised to be destroyed by them? Have you learned nothing, after all this time?

text.Zagreus: Sounds good.

text.Hades: How are you finding my old trusty spear, then, hm? Or perhaps you have a preference for my brothers' and my sisters' former arms. Kept under lock and key, and yet, they're now in your possession, it would seem.

text.Zagreus: The weapons in the courtyard. Of course you know about them, by now. I stole them. Why not just take them from me? I'd be stuck.

text.Hades: The thought has long since crossed my mind. However, I'm not fool enough to tamper with those cursed things. They go where they please. They cannot be contained. Like you. Now, why don't you go entertain each other more?

text.Zagreus: Didn't think things could get any more awkward with her.
Megaera and her sisters ganged up on me that time. I didn't think anyone could talk her into working with Alecto and Tisiphone again. Or even be in the same chamber.

text.Hades: I can be quite persuasive under certain circumstances, boy. Though my advice to you, not that you'll take it, is not to discuss the matter openly. Megaera is a professional; but she has made her feelings on the matter clear.

text.Zagreus: Pushovers.

text.Hades: It is woefully infrequent that I've cause for this, but I do have to thank you, boy. You've culled the Satyrs and the vermin bringing ruin to our Temple, there! Blasted creatures multiply at an alarming rate.

text.Zagreus: They're not doing your bidding, yet they're every bit as bothersome as all your wretched servants I've met. I'm surprised you aren't getting along.

text.Hades: They are a plague upon this realm, although we have them well contained, for now. And once they are rightly dead, they tend to swear to me their fealty.

text.Zagreus: You're right. I don't.
Father, you always said the Olympians wanted nothing to do with our kind. But doesn't Charon work directly with Hermes? Maybe it's you who wants nothing to do with them.

text.Hades: I want nothing to do with them, correct. My hasty nephew assists Charon out of necessity, alone. Not even Thanatos is able to keep up with the rate at which mortals expire and must then cross our borders.

text.Zagreus: Want me to pitch in? Just give me your blessing and I'll head straight for the surface.

text.Hades: Hahaha, no. I think not, boy. You are born of this realm. The surface is a wind-swept waste. You don't know how good you have it here.

text.Zagreus: Sorry, Father. I'm not afraid of you.

text.Hades: She is gone, boy. She is gone. You are never going to locate her. I thought you would have come to that conclusion for yourself, by now. But apparently it must be said.

text.Zagreus: You mean Mother. How would you even know? You said reaching the surface was impossible as well, and I'm in striking distance.

text.Hades: This is my final warning to you, boy... to cease this mindless quest. Or else, the consequences shall be worse than what you have experienced thus far.

text.Zagreus: Works for me!

text.Hades: Whatever you did to my blasted seat is of no consequence to me. From my vantage-point, I can't even see it! A foolish prank and waste of valuable resources, nothing more.

text.Zagreus: It's more for everybody else than you, Father. Think of it as a tribute to Cerberus! Besides, you really should think about changing up the look of this place from time to time. Keep things fresh!

text.Hades: The limitless work keeps things fresh enough as it is. Though if making aimless changes in this House is how you choose to spend your limitless time, I'll have no part of it.

text.Zagreus: I figured.
Father, of all the skeletons and such in your direct employ... you wouldn't happen to have any here around the House, would you? Out in my courtyard, for example?

text.Hades: Skeletons! I'm sure they'll welcome you when next you visit Asphodel. You may not realize it, boy, but we have a certain standard of decency we uphold around here!

text.Zagreus: That's certainly a way of looking at it.
You ever think of giving Thanatos a break, Father? He seems to have more than his fair share of work of late.

text.Hades: Blame the blasted mortals for perishing so easily, or blame Lord Ares, prior to accusing me. With their surface wars, not only do they kill each other readily, but also often subsequently perish from the consequences of it all!

text.Zagreus: What wars, what's going on up there? Why don't the other Olympians do something?

text.Hades: Pah! How should I know? The mortals are equipped to settle their petty differences by any number of means. We have to make room for them all sooner or later, regardless.
So, you had a run-in with the Minotaur out in Elysium, did you? Perhaps the only soul within this realm more bull-headed than you.

text.Zagreus: How long have you been waiting to use that line, Father? Wouldn't put it past you to have sent the Bull of Minos to Elysium entirely so we could have this conversation now.

text.Hades: You give me too much credit, boy. The Minotaur resides where he resides because of an entirely different arrangement.

text.Zagreus: He's working for you, isn't he? You think he can stop me.

text.Hades: Most in Elysium jump at the opportunity to do my bidding. Not that you know what that is like. Now go, see how you fare against the bull.

text.Zagreus: They should have asked the expert I suppose.

text.Hades: How goes your heated rivalry against the greatest king of Athens lately, boy? Your battles with him and the Minotaur must be the talk of the Underworld of late.

text.Zagreus: Admit it, Father. Theseus was the only hero you were able to recruit to stand against me. All the while he gets to boast about being the champion. What, was Heracles too busy for the task?

text.Hades: Speak not to me of Heracles. You know these heroes by their deeds, not by their character. Heracles is fortunate he's in my brother's favor. Else he would be in Tartarus where he belongs. The mortal concept of what constitutes a hero is absurd.

text.Zagreus: My pleasure.

text.Hades: I know what you did. Stay out of Nyx's affairs next time, boy. She is needed here! Not wallowing in the primordial dark.

text.Zagreus: You're just angry because some of us still want to have anything to do with their parents.

text.Hades: Parents, pah! You know nothing of what parents are capable of. Conspire all you like against my wishes, I care not. Get out.
So you were able to dispatch my Hydra, boy. Right down to the last hateful head. It's an accomplishment I felt was certainly beyond your talent set. Though, here you are again, nevertheless.

text.Zagreus: You cheated me. There wasn't anywhere that I could go! I could have gone much farther. All the way to Mother!

text.Hades: You shall do no such thing. Besides, if you were any help to me, you'd know vast portions of my realm are presently still under renovation. You won't be getting farther than you have.

text.Zagreus: I can wait. You can't just keep this place on lockdown for eternity. The mortals up there wouldn't stand for it.

text.Hades: They have no patience, yes. The same as you. Then wait, with all the rest of them. It matters not to me. For I have other work to do.
Now you begone from here, get yourself killed some more for all I care.
Well, boy. Word has reached me that you were able to dethrone the Champion of Elysium as well as his bull-headed companion. Tell me, how did you accomplish such a thing?

text.Zagreus: First, you tell me when I can get out of there. The path guarded by Theseus was sealed! Is there even a surface? Is the outside world all a lie?!

text.Hades: Ah, now you are asking the big questions! Comforting to see such growth of character. Well if there is an outside world, you shall not be seeing it for quite some time. You know why, don't you?

text.Zagreus: Ongoing Underworld renovations?

text.Hades: Ongoing Underworld renovations. Now go and let King Theseus drive that sharp spear of his into yourself some more, until such time. The mortals soon shall force me to reopen, and then what?
Now you begone from here, get yourself killed some more for all I care.
You are late, boy! Have you any idea what time it is?

text.Zagreus: No. Wait, what? I just vanquished you in single combat, and that's all you have to say to me?

text.Hades: Vanquished me? Hah, hahaha, nonsense. Don't you think I would recall such an event?

text.Zagreus: You can't be serious. You're going to pretend as though it never happened?

text.Hades: Everything is as it always was. And so shall it be, until the Fates determine otherwise. Or until our ongoing Underworld renovations are finally complete. Whichever comes first.

text.Zagreus: Excellent, can't wait!
So you're really not going to answer my question about Mother from the other time, until the Underworld renovations are complete?

text.Hades: I know not what you're going on about, there, boy. Although, my focus is entirely upon our renovations, yes. Perhaps someday or night when this place is in proper working order, I shall have more time for your insipid questions.

text.Zagreus: I know where we can continue this discussion, then...

text.Hades: You are late, boy! Have you any idea what time it is?

text.Zagreus: No. Wait, what? I vanquished you in single combat and finally found Mother, and that's all you have to say to me?

text.Hades: Hah, haha! Nonsense. Don't you think I would recall such an event?

text.Zagreus: You can't be serious. You're going to pretend as though it never happened? She wants answers, same as I do. She demands you let me pass! Let me go to her again.

text.Hades: Silence! This discussion is over. I hardly think this is the time or place to indulge your overwrought imagination.
No! I'll hear no demands from you.
I told you, boy. I told you! There's no escape from here. Learned that the hard way, then?

text.Zagreus: You could have told me more important things. Mother left because she never even knew I was alive. Thanks to you! She's got a lot of questions, herself, as you can probably imagine. I'm headed back to her. You going to cooperate?

text.Hades: Hahaha, nonsense! Listen to me: If you have any sense remaining in that head of yours, I caution you not to discuss this here and now.

text.Zagreus: Let me go. Let me find her. She demands it!
Count on that.
Quite a mess you've created, I must say, Father... after being of no help whatsoever when it comes to disentangling it all. Though, this isn't the place to talk, right?

text.Hades: No! It most certainly is not. Though, I take it it shall not be long before another of our private meetings, then.

text.Zagreus: Until such place and time, then.
Something the matter, there, Father? You seem a little quieter than usual. Dare I say even a little somber and remorseful, for some reason?

text.Hades: Silence, boy! And better yet, why don't you get out of my sight? I've more important things to do now than indulge your boastfulness. We'll have to catch up at some other place and time.
Oh, I'm certain I shall figure something out.

text.Zagreus: You know, Father, while I'm sure you don't appreciate all the distractions as of late, your ceaseless toil has had some noticeable effect. Is it my imagination, or are the ongoing Underworld renovations almost complete?

text.Hades: There you go, getting ahead of yourself, again. The final stages of renovation are some of the most vital! Second only to the initial planning. There's a great deal of important work ahead!

text.Zagreus: I wasn't saying it wasn't important, I was just saying maybe there's finally an end to it in sight. What are you going to do with all your spare time, then?
It's a deal.
What's the giant pact posted out in the courtyard, Father? You offering me a job?

text.Hades: Perish the thought. It's so that all your toiling can be more painful, nothing more.

text.Zagreus: Why would I want my toiling to be more painful than it already is?

text.Hades: Who knows, boy, or better yet, who cares? To make the mortals up there worship you for all your labors? Go on, then, go get yourself dispatched some more, so I can make well certain that my realm can properly contain you.
Enough. Get out.
My records indicate that you've collected earnings based on some of your accomplishments, there, boy. I suppose you need an income of your own, having decided to cut ties and all.

text.Zagreus: What, you mean the bounties that you've offered up to anybody capable of beating Meg and all your other guardians out there? Don't you think that puts a lot of undue pressure on them, knowing that you've turned them into targets?

text.Hades: They must do better than they have, else they shall be replaced. If they're to grow in their respective roles, they have to know their weaknesses. And so do I. That you collect the bounties for it matters not.

text.Zagreus: What about the bounties for vanquishing you? Who's your replacement going to be?

text.Hades: Enough. Get out.
My records indicate that you've collected earnings based on some of your accomplishments, there, boy. I suppose you need an income of your own, having decided to cut ties and all.

text.Zagreus: What, you mean the bounties that you've offered up to anybody capable of beating Meg and all your other guardians out there? Don't you think that puts a lot of undue pressure on them, knowing that you've turned them into targets?

text.Hades: They must do better than they have, else they shall be replaced. If they're to grow in their respective roles, they have to know their weaknesses. And so do I. That you collect the bounties for it matters not.

text.Zagreus: Be sure to add those to the list of words you'll eat someday.
Tsch.

Saw your new Pact of Punishment out in the courtyard, Father. Impressed that you could find a parchment large enough to fit all the unpleasant stipulations. So you're taking even harsher measures to contain me?

text.Hades: Whether you consent to the terms of the Pact is entirely up to you, boy. But, in all your comings and goings, it is important that we have full knowledge of which property is being carried from the premises.

text.Zagreus: Plenty of room for improvement...

text.Hades: You've taken more advantage of the Pact of Punishment than I would have expected, boy. I almost wish to commend you for doing such a thing.

text.Zagreus: Almost? I've been rampaging through the worst your realm has to offer. Causing you untold inconvenience and likely a fortune in repair costs. I thought you'd be upset.

text.Hades: Upset? Heavens, no. Through your repeated bumbling, you have revealed a number of shortcomings in our operations, which my underlings are busy working to address.

text.Zagreus: You know you sound especially despicable when you say underlings, don't you?

text.Hades: Don't let me keep you any longer, boy, go forth! Try to escape again. You're helping make the Underworld a better place.

text.Zagreus: Sure. Sorry about your Pact.

text.Hades: Explain to me something: How did you do it? I mean the Pact. For all of the conditions it imposed... you still surpassed me. How?

text.Zagreus: Plenty of practice, regular exercise, a positive attitude, the blessings of assorted family members you don't like, and your discarded Titan-slaying weapons I suppose. Nothing special. Why do you ask?

text.Hades: To think that you would squander such a talent on frivolous pursuit. You do not even realize what you have achieved, do you.

text.Zagreus: Wait, wait wait wait wait, care to repeat that first part that you said back there? The talent part?

text.Hades: Would that you had a talent for listening. Begone for now.

text.Zagreus: Bet I can take you.

text.Hades: Back to your senses, then, boy? The Pact of Punishment is not something one ought to trifle with unknowingly, in case you've yet to notice.

text.Zagreus: Father... the Pact... you were so blasted strong. I had no idea! All those other times we fought... I can't believe that you were holding back. You were desperate to stop me, you could have!

text.Hades: We are bound by the Fates to this realm. It is ours, and we belong to it, in turn. And... I did not hold back against you. Rather... I had forgotten my old strength. Some of it since returned to me.

text.Zagreus: Must have been all our vicious battles to the death? Or maybe it's from Mother being back in your life?

text.Hades: Pointless to even ask. What motivates us is a complicated thing. But if you long to face me with the power I once held during my own youth... you have available to you the means.

text.Zagreus: I'm thinking there shall.

text.Hades: Urgh... come, get your gloating well out of the way, so I can get back to this parchmentwork. It piled up, in my prolonged absence!

text.Zagreus: Not here to gloat, Father. Well fought back there. I can't believe I got you.

text.Hades: ...Nor I. Next time, the Fates may not decide to favor you like that. If there shall be a next time.

text.Zagreus: Loud and clear.
Father... look, Lord Uncle Zeus, I've been in contact with him, and he wishes to make peace. He asked for me to tell you. To tell you he forgives you for... whatever happened.

text.Hades: My brother Zeus... forgives me? Zeus forgives me?! How dare that blasted little brat! His beard may be luxurious but he's as much a child as are you. Forgives me, bah!

text.Zagreus: What did you do...? What happened between you?

text.Hades: None of your business! Go on now and frolic with that Lord Uncle of yours, the both of them! And don't you ever speak of him to me again, you hear me?

text.Zagreus: ...You can't hide the truth forever.
Question for you, Father. The name Kore happen to mean anything to you, by any chance?

text.Hades: What, where did you...?! Ahh, the cold witch brought it up, did she? Never repeat that name again, not here, nor anywhere, you hear me, boy? Know only this: The one called by that name despised it even more than I.

text.Zagreus: So let's see. Demeter's daughter went missing. She wound up down here. I... happened. Mother left. Demeter, and everyone else on Olympus apparently, has no idea. That about right? Tell me what happened.

text.Hades: I'll tell you nothing! Keep meddling in matters that you cannot understand, and you'll incur the wrath of Olympus on all that you hold dear. And, know that it is not for my sake that I'm warning you.

text.Zagreus: ...I'll have to try that, thanks.

text.Hades: What is it now? I see that sneering look upon your countenance, which must mean you have yet another one of your insipid questions, haven't you.

text.Zagreus: Oh, this one's not insipid in the slightest. Let me get this straight. My mother's Persephone. Her mother's Demeter, but her father... evidently was some farm-boy? My red blood comes from him? And my propensity to die I guess.

text.Hades: You blame your ancestors for your own weakness? You should be thankful you were born with immortality! Though, your meddlesome curiosity and constant need for affirmation must certainly be from your mortal side.

text.Zagreus: Then, Mother, did... she grow older with age? Is she just going to expire as the mortals do? With demigods I hear it can go either way.

text.Hades: I said never to speak of her, blast you! You said, yourself, she is the daughter of the goddess of seasons! Use your fool head, for once.

text.Zagreus: ...Hard to imagine.

Greetings, Father. Ran into Lady Demeter out there, on my last outing. Or should I say, my grandmother? What's she to you, then, ex-mother-in-law? Source of abject terror? Hard keeping track. Our family's rather complicated.

text.Hades: Do not invoke her name inside my House, you hear me, boy? You do not know at all what she is like. Though I can see why you two hit it off. She hated her father. Though understandably, as he was worse even than mine. Even than yours.
I do. Your mother the Queen is working on that.

text.Zagreus: Greetings, Father. So! I can just... head on out there again whenever I want? Don't need to stick to any rigid schedule?

text.Hades: Your unpredictability is one of your assets. Our defenses must always be on guard. So, yes: Go about your business as you best see fit!

text.Zagreus: And the Olympians are going to keep helping me, thinking I'm trying to get away from you, to them. We can't keep this up with them forever, you know.
You're welcome.

text.Hades: Tell me something, boy... Zagreus... why did you do all this? Return the Queen. Go to such lengths. At a certain point... you must have learned the way I felt about her. Yet still you persisted. If I were you... I'd not have done me any favors.

text.Zagreus: I didn't often stop to give it much thought. I just knew I needed to find her... and then as soon as I did, I knew I needed her in my life. In other words, doing you any favors was never a priority, Father. Just ended up that way, I guess.

text.Hades: ...I see. I appreciate your candor. Nevertheless... I thank you. I do not know how you accomplished what you did, but know that I am grateful for the outcome. Even if I fail to act like it, much of the time.

text.Zagreus: Can't wait!
Say, Father... back when you drew lots with your brothers, and wound up with the Underworld, rather than the heavens or the seas... which would you have claimed, if the choice was yours?

text.Hades: I do not deal in hypotheticals, boy. Each realm has its host of unenviable problems. You have never experienced the cold and sopping sea, or the blinding heights of Olympus. I have. And I assure you, you're not missing much.

text.Zagreus: Didn't you try to leave the Underworld, yourself, at some point? You once gave me that impression. I always thought it was because you hated it here.

text.Hades: I hate not having any choice. Enjoy the freedoms that you have. As you grow long in years, you gain more burdens and responsibilities, until they bind you.

text.Zagreus: Sounds like you've got it all under control.
Father, all these shades... aren't they going to let on that Mother's back? What if word spreads... and the Olympians find out?

text.Hades: You are so well-accustomed to defying me that you forget there are no others, either living or dead, who would so dare. None in this House shall speak of this until we are prepared to make any announcements, on our own terms.

text.Zagreus: Sounds great!

text.Hades: Regarding your responsibilities: Our Resources Director is available to you. In my private quarters. Normally, it would be I, alone, transferring excess resources back into our realm.

text.Zagreus: The fabled Resources Director! So, now I get to give away the hard-earned resources I've painstakingly gathered over time?

text.Hades: You get to do precisely that. It is not necessary that you do. But if you wish to rise above your current station, you shall do it.

text.Zagreus: What's the point in rising above my current station? I thought our work was to be done in secrecy.

text.Hades: It is. There is no point but pride. And pride is dangerous. Do what you will. I care not, as long as everything gets adequately done.

text.Zagreus: Sounds great!

text.Hades: Regarding your responsibilities: Our Resources Director is available to you. In the administrative chamber. Normally, it would be I, alone, transferring excess resources back into our realm.

text.Zagreus: The fabled Resources Director! So, now I get to give away the hard-earned resources I've painstakingly gathered over time?

text.Hades: You get to do precisely that. It is not necessary that you do. But if you wish to rise above your current station, you shall do it.

text.Zagreus: What's the point in rising above my current station? I thought our work was to be done in secrecy.

text.Hades: It is. There is no point but pride. And pride is dangerous. Do what you will. I care not, as long as everything gets adequately done.

text.Zagreus: Thank you.

text.Hades: Briefly, now, boy: Our Resources Director informs me you've advanced in rank. Commendable. That's all.

text.Zagreus: OK!

text.Hades: You are advancing through the ranks of your position, and returning to our realm the vast resources you have claimed. As well you ought. Carry on.
We cannot speak of this, except... Unseen One... the highest ranking that we can bestow. I never once imagined that you could achieve that rank, yourself. Or any rank of note.

text.Zagreus: You always thought too little of me, Father. Though, thank you for taking note of that. I figured I ought to give back to the realm that made me what I am.

text.Hades: Yes. For this is the only world we know.

text.Zagreus: I will... take care, Father.
Father... all this stuff with the Olympians... will you just tell me what's going on, for once? How did Mother come to join you here? What's your problem with Uncle Zeus?

text.Hades: I thought she already told you...! Urgh. Come with me. Now.
...Swear to me that you shall never repeat what you are about to hear. Swear it!

text.Zagreus: All right, all right, I swear. I swear, in your own name, I'll keep what you're about to say between us.... So?

text.Hades: So... you had it mostly right, before. After I inherited the Underworld... your Uncle Zeus felt sympathy for me, he says. Your mother, he knew she was unhappy on Olympus. And... he knew I was drawn to her. So what did he do? He brought her here. Gave her to me as a gift!

text.Zagreus: You weren't expecting a gift like that. But she didn't want to return to Olympus, and you liked her, so you didn't send her away. And you're angry with Zeus for putting you in that position? Cut ties with him?

text.Hades: Yes!! The blasted fool, with all his flights of fancy! He does whatever he wants! He could have achieved a similar outcome in a limitless number of reasonable ways... rather than resort to what was tantamount to kidnapping! Even if she wanted to leave!

text.Zagreus: And now if Demeter and the others found all this out, you and Mother... even Zeus would be in a bad spot, wouldn't he? He must have a temper on him to match yours.

text.Hades: You know nothing of tempers if mine is your frame of reference, Zagreus. Now, enough of this! You know the rest. Remember your oath.
Nrgh...
One thing, before you depart again, boy. Until the Queen's intentions with Olympus come to pass... not a word to anyone about her presence, here. Do you understand?

text.Zagreus: I do. But she won't have to hide forever.

text.Hades: The work nevertheless has to be done!

text.Zagreus: So, now that the festivities are over with, it's back to work like this, the same as ever?

text.Hades: Do you have any idea what happens when you announce the Underworld has a Queen, boy? Urgh, damn it! Zagreus, I mean. You become inundated with well-wishes from every blasted shade that wants something.

text.Zagreus: You're responding to well-wishes? Aw. Don't you think some of your subjects are sincerely happy for you?

text.Hades: They are very easy to maintain!

text.Zagreus: I never stopped to think about why pomegranates grew here in the Underworld. Mother's doing from before, then? And all that stuff she told the Olympians, about how they bind you to this place... it's all nonsense?

text.Hades: You know full well that the pomegranates in my realm hold a certain power beyond the tartness of their taste, boy. The Queen... she has a way with plants, you see. A bit of her own mother's gift, applied more sensibly.

text.Zagreus: You kept them growing all this time... flourishing, even, because of her.
All right, all right.
So, what happened, when Mother first arrived, if I may ask? Some of your residents seem to remember the Queen from before. Yet the Olympians just never found out?

text.Hades: They had no jurisdiction here. No knowledge of our goings-on. Well, Hermes did, perhaps, but in a very limited capacity. As far as anybody knew beyond this realm... our Queen was Nyx. Ask nothing more of this.

text.Zagreus: Glad you're handling it fine.
Father... how are you doing without Mother around? Will she be all right, on Olympus?

text.Hades: Clearly she is more than capable of handling herself. And we here have been well accustomed to not having her about.

text.Zagreus: So everything's back to normal, then? That sounds lovely.

text.Hades: Nothing is normal, anymore. Besides! She shall return. Knowing that she shall return, is that not sufficient for you? Be patient, for once.

text.Zagreus: Zagreus.

text.Hades: ...Zagreus.

text.Zagreus: It's good to see Mother's back. Not that I was too concerned, but... I was definitely a little concerned.

text.Hades: I shared in that particular concern, and yes... it is good the Queen has once again returned. And she shall have to depart again before we know it, so cherish your time with her, boy!

text.Zagreus: They have.

text.Hades: Tell me, in brief, boy. Our own upon Olympus... are they continuing to aid you as expected?

text.Zagreus: Still showing up and lending their support. I think some of them are a little disappointed I'm not planning to come join them, though... I think they understand now that they owe the Underworld a debt. We all have to do our part, looking after the mortals. Whether alive or dead.

text.Hades: Indeed. I half-expected they would disappoint. Abandon you to toil on your own. At least thus far they've honored their commitment, then.

text.Zagreus: But, they're family...

text.Hades: Pah.

text.Zagreus: So, are you maintaining better contact now with Uncle Zeus, Uncle Poseidon, and the rest? Oh, and... is it all right for me to speak about them here?

text.Hades: Urgh... I'm certain the superficial messages we have exchanged shall taper off, with time. We have always been apart, irrespective of the distance separating us. I know Zeus is content with your mother's version of events. Thus we are at peace, for now.

text.Zagreus: Wait, what do you mean, for now?

text.Hades: I mean only that our family is prone to causing problems for itself. Never content to leave things well enough alone. But if we have little to do with them... their quarrels, all their nonsense on Olympus... it should be of no consequence.
Precisely.

The latest reports indicate that mortals are fully twice as fearful of ending up in Tartarus as in our last evaluation period, thanks to the destruction you have caused. You are an unseen power in the Underworld. Commendable.

text.Zagreus: Commendable, me? An unseen power, huh. Surprised you're giving me the credit, Father.

text.Hades: I give credit where it's due. But the mortals? They know nothing of what transpires here. Only rumblings we permit to escape our realm... rumblings that reinforce their deepest fears about what shall transpire after their demise.

text.Zagreus: So the more havoc I wreak in the Underworld, the more mortals hear about all the unpleasantness, and... it makes them fearful of this place? If more of them lead upstanding lives, it'll keep Tartarus from overflowing, I guess.

text.Hades: Whatever you may wish to say, I do not wish to hear it.
You're interrupting me during my time at work.
I think I've heard more than enough from you lately.
You're willfully wasting my time, aren't you.
Go, get out. Don't let me stop you.
Shouldn't you be getting skewered by the dead?
Go to your room, or anywhere but here.
Blood and darkness, what is it with you?
Have you come up with more impertinence to spout at me?
I'll not be bothered with your disrespect.
Has it occurred to you that I'm preoccupied?
I am uninterested in conversing with you, boy.
Your presence is no longer welcome here.
How possibly could I have given the impression that I wished to talk?
You realize just how much property of mine you have defaced?
Fail all you like, you're never getting out of here.
You'll learn your place, the hard way, evidently.
To suffer such indignity, from my own kin.
Such foolishness as yours I scarce can comprehend.
We've nothing left now to discuss between us.
Whatever you may wish to say, I do not wish to hear it.
Have I mentioned that you're never getting out of here?
You're here to stay, boy. All of us are.
I'm busy now, as you can plainly see.
Blasted parchmentwork, it never goes away.
Your recent efforts have proved useful to this place.
Go instill some fear in those wretches out there, would you?
He's back again, Cerberus! I'll try not to keep him for as long, next time.
Doubtless I shall get you for that one next time.
Another satyr outbreak to look out for next you venture there...
Be certain to give your regards to your mother as well!
Repairs for all the carnage that you sowed are already underway.
What else can we do to contain you, I wonder...
I have some catching up to do, as you can see.
Ah, we ought to reconvene the court now, I suppose.
As you can see, I must attend to all this parchmentwork.
I must say, you made a hollow mockery of Theseus that time.
Our security efforts in Asphodel are evidently lacking.
Go rest yourself if need be. Though the Underworld is ready when you are.
Against my better judgment, I went easier on you that time.
Thus starts and ends our brief exchange of pleasantries.
Continue to perform your duties as you have.
Cerberus there was anticipating your return.
Your mother expected this most recent result of yours.
Do I appear as though I've time for conversation, boy?
Let us discuss your work performance at some other time.
Your infamy throughout Elysium has only grown.
I must admit... that was a job well done back there.

text.Zagreus: Hey, uh, Father. I thought, maybe, you know, here.

text.Hades: Where did you get this...? You think you can butter me up with such trifles? Give me that, and then get out of here.

text.Zagreus: Hey, uh, Father. I thought, maybe, you know, here.

text.Hades: You owe me nothing, certainly not this. And I've nothing to give you in exchange. But fine, I'll honor our custom. Give it here.

text.Zagreus: Erm, Father... I know we can't exactly change the past, but we can try to move forward. Look, I know I'm not even supposed to have this stuff, but everyone likes it, won't you try it, at least? Here, take it, either way.

text.Hades: Hrm. I... can dispose of this properly. Speaking of disposal... I've no further need for this, here, so... rid me of it, why don't you? On your way out.

text.Zagreus: Why not!
