Glad you like it, mate. Thank you for helping me out with your supply. Even if you fleece me with those prices!
You enjoy that, mate! And, when it comes time to reconsider your price structure, hope you think of me!
Enjoy it, Charon mate! Don't go thinking I'm just being kind to get you to lower your prices for me, that would be unconscionable!
You know, I thought you'd say that, Charon mate, but I insist you take it and enjoy, all right?
I'm pleased to have you as a friend as well, Charon. The pleasure's mine.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Charon, I realize you have a very busy schedule and certainly needn't keep going out of your way for me like this, so here. Just a small token of my appreciation for you. If you ever want to talk, know that I'm here.
I don't know what to say, mate.

text.Orpheus: Oh, hello, Zagreus. I understand you liberated me from my eternal punishment. And so I have returned to serve your father here. Thanks.

text.Zagreus: Orpheus, you're back! Look, don't get on Father's bad side like that and you're going to be fine. Besides... right now I think he's angrier with me.

text.Orpheus: I grieve for you, my friend. But if you've come to ask me for a song, why, I'm afraid I must stand firm about my answer.
Oh, hello, Zagreus. I understand you liberated me from my eternal punishment. And so I have returned to serve your father here. Thanks.

text.Zagreus: Orpheus, you're back! Look, don't get on Father's bad side like that, and you're going to be fine. I've fought with him enough for all our sakes.

text.Orpheus: I grieve for you, my friend. But if you've come to ask me for a song, why, I'm afraid I must stand firm about my answer.

Oh, hello Zagreus. I was just wondering if you had ever heard of any other court musicians who had lost the will to sing? Your father's asked me to explain myself and honestly it has been rather difficult.

text.Zagreus: If it's any consolation, mate, I'm certain every single undead court musician serving in the throne room of the god of the dead has been through everything you're going through.

text.Orpheus: If you insist, my friend.
It's awfully quiet here, you know, when you're out and about? Makes me a bit self-conscious, truth be told, seeing as ostensibly I'm the musician of this court.

text.Zagreus: Look, if you decide to start strumming on that lyre again, I'm sure nobody here is going to mind. Though you take care, OK?

text.Orpheus: Oh, hello Zagreus. You look a little down. And so I was just wondering, would you perchance fancy a song right now?

text.Zagreus: How about The Lament? You used to play that one a lot!

text.Orpheus: Oh, fancy that one do you? Alas, I've not the heart to sing it anymore. I'm glad you like it, though.

text.Zagreus: How about In the Blood? That's one of your old hits, right?

text.Orpheus: Oh, fancy that one do you? Alas, I've not the heart to sing it anymore. I'm glad you like it, though.

text.Zagreus: How about Argonauts, didn't you sail with them?

text.Orpheus: Oh, fancy that one do you? Alas, I've not the heart to sing it anymore. I'm glad you like it, though.

text.Zagreus: Orpheus, forgive my bluntness here, but I have to ask. Why won't you sing? You were a legend, mate! Our court musician!

text.Orpheus: Why, it's that I have lost my muse, my friend. It isn't harder to explain than that. Have you not had such moments in your life, where you had lost the will to chase your passions?

text.Zagreus: I, I suppose I have, yeah. But recently I found my drive again, and that's why I have to get out of here.

text.Orpheus: And I am truly happy for you, friend. Alas, I've had no luck in my own search, not that I'm searching any longer, so, I'll just be over here, OK?

text.Zagreus: Anything I can do to help you find your muse, mate?

text.Orpheus: I fear my muse is long since lost to me, my friend, though truly thanks for asking. I suppose she must be out there somewhere still, since I once traveled 'cross this land in search of her, and found her then. But that was quite a while back.

text.Zagreus: Wait, you found her? What happened?

text.Orpheus: Well, this was back when I was still alive, you understand. Your father, why, he doesn't care for anyone to leave this realm, and, basically now I'm stuck here as well! Not seen her since, and, I'm not much for travel anymore.

text.Zagreus: That's... I'm sorry to hear that. Thank you for letting me know. I hope you get to see her again someday.

text.Orpheus: I appreciate the sentiment, my friend, though please don't worry about her or me. I mean, we're dead! We're fine.

text.Zagreus: Mate, if you don't mind, I'd love it if you told me more about your muse.

text.Orpheus: My muse... never has somebody been as splendorous as my Eurydice...! She was so gentle, yet so stout of heart that it would make yours ache, just thinking on it. She inspired innumerable songs of mine.

text.Zagreus: That's quite a few. She sounds like she was a real catch all right. I'm sorry for your loss. Thank you for sharing your memory of her with me.

text.Orpheus: Thank you for listening, my friend. Eurydice, she likewise used to listen to me all the time....

text.Zagreus: Mate, if you don't mind, I'd love it if you told me more about your muse.

text.Orpheus: My muse... never has somebody been as splendorous as my Eurydice...! She was so gentle, yet so stout of heart that it would make yours ache, just thinking on it. She inspired innumerable songs of mine.

text.Zagreus: Eurydice...? I know a... anyway, she must have been a real catch! I'm sorry for your loss. I have to go look into something here.

text.Orpheus: Thank you for listening, my friend. Eurydice, she likewise used to listen to me all the time....
I understand you've journeyed well beyond the pits of Tartarus, my friend? Another most heroic feat of yours, and truth be told I find it quite inspiring.

text.Zagreus: Inspiring enough to... make you want to sing, again?

text.Orpheus: Oh, that's a rather bold insinuation, Zagreus. I don't know that I've the will for that, I... just, I need some time to think, is that all right?

text.Zagreus: It sounds like Father's very cross with you, Orpheus. Won't you consider singing once again? You know his threat of further punishment is not a bluff.

text.Orpheus: Your father can be.... most persuasive, yes, my friend. However, this time, I am... putting my foot down! I have no plans to sing for him again.

text.Zagreus: Well then how about for me? Or for your other friends among the court?

text.Orpheus: I... no. Please. My muse is gone to me. I can do no such thing.

text.Zagreus: Appreciate it, mate.

text.Orpheus: You seem quite agitated, as of late, my friend. Is anything amiss with you, perhaps?

text.Zagreus: Oh! No, I'm all right, Orpheus. Just a lot on my mind is all, sorting out what's next. Stuff I need to work through on my own.

text.Orpheus: Ah, well, I truly understand. I was reluctant to discuss my long-lost muse, really for quite some time. Well, if you do require some emotional support, know that I likely shall be standing over here...

text.Zagreus: Oh, Orpheus? I heard from Hermes, messenger and god of travel, and all that? It's odd I'm giving you his message in this case, but he says hey! Admires your musical ability, as well.

text.Orpheus: Oh, that was kind of him, my friend! When I first ventured deep into this realm, whilst searching for the soul of my lost muse... after I failed utterly, it was Lord Hermes who whisked her away. It happened so fast. He did an excellent job!

text.Zagreus: I always meant to ask you, Orpheus. Where did you learn to sing like that? Was it really Apollo himself who taught you?

text.Orpheus: Oh, why, I learned from many different sources, Zagreus. That is before all of my inspiration started coming from a single source. I credit my accomplishments to her, and to Apollo, and the gods. And to considerable time spent practicing!

text.Zagreus: Orpheus? I know Father appreciates your songs, to the extent he's capable of appreciating anything. Though, has Nyx ever responded to them? She's always right nearby yet you two don't seem to talk...

text.Orpheus: Almighty Nyx appears to tolerate my presence, Zagreus. For she could cast me into everlasting darkness if my song failed to be pleasing to her. She is a most-discerning listener!
Are you the one whom I should thank for this most wondrous music stand, my friend? Why, it is positively splendid, isn't it?

text.Zagreus: Our renowned court musician ought to have the finest means available, I think. I'm pleased you like it, Orpheus. Though, tell me something, how can it play your music when you're not even here?

text.Orpheus: Who can explain the secret art of Daedalus, my friend? Know only that, whenever it produces music for your listening enjoyment, that the sound you hear is coming from my soul!

text.Zagreus: Same goes for me, mate. Same goes for me.

text.Orpheus: So, I am quite confused, I must admit, my friend. The Queen Persephone, she is your mother, then? How is it that she came to reside, here?

text.Zagreus: Well, erm... it all started when my father saw her on Olympus, and... they fell madly in love. He swept her off her feet, and brought her here. The Olympians, they got pretty worried when they saw she was gone. But now it's OK! Everything's out in the open.

text.Orpheus: But, surely the Queen's mother on Olympus, the great goddess Demeter... surely she would quite like it if she saw her daughter still, from time to time?

text.Zagreus: Oh, that! Thing is, Mother ate some... pomegranate seeds when she was here. And we have rules about that stuff, you know! It means she cannot leave this place for very long at all. I'm sure Demeter will understand. And unfreeze everything when her daughter's around.

text.Orpheus: Ah, yes, pomegranate seeds, of course, of course! Though, there is one more subject I don't understand, which is... how you fit into all of this. Were you not trying to escape from here?

text.Zagreus: Forget about me, Orpheus! This isn't about me, it's about Mother. What's important is she's here, where she belongs.

text.Orpheus: I see! I understand. Well, thank you, then, for clearing all that up. It is a splendid tale, I must say, and every part of it makes sense to me, at last.
I've decided I should give this singing thing another shot for now, my friend. I hope you like it.

text.Zagreus: This is amazing, mate. So does this mean you found your muse?

text.Orpheus: Oh no, I never found my muse, my friend. It's just... seeing you carrying on like this time after time, I was reminded I ought to get on with my life, too, such as it is right now.
I've decided I should give this singing thing another shot for now, my friend. I hope you like it.

text.Zagreus: This is amazing, mate. You sing quite beautifully, with or without your muse.

text.Orpheus: How kind of you. It's just... seeing you carry on like this, time after time, I was reminded that I might as well get on with my existence, too. Such as it is right now.
I've decided I should give this singing thing another shot for now, my friend. I hope you like it.

text.Zagreus: It's beautiful, mate. If only Eurydice could hear you right now.

text.Orpheus: How kind of you, my friend. It's just... seeing you carry on like this, time after time, I was reminded I ought to get on with my existence, too. Such as it is right now.
I became so enthralled with song once more, my friend, that I have been inspired to compose another one. For old time's sake, perhaps.

text.Zagreus: This is amazing, mate. You sing quite beautifully, with or without your muse.

text.Orpheus: How kind of you, although... my voice is nothing but the crunch of gravel underfoot compared to hers, which soars as though on wings.

text.Zagreus: Say, Orpheus? I ever tell you I once single-handedly slew a multi-headed bone hydra within the magma fields of Asphodel without so much as breaking a sweat?

text.Orpheus: My, that is wonderful to hear, my friend! Another in a litany of such heroic deeds, more noble than the heroes of our verse, and even great Achilles over there!

text.Zagreus: I'm glad you think so, mate! These tales of my valorous accomplishments do seem to cheer you up, so, I will keep reporting back once I rack up some more.
Hey Orpheus? You know about the time I vanquished seven legions of Bloodless warriors with both hands tied behind my back while hopping on one foot? Lord Poseidon dared me to do it, you know.

text.Orpheus: Why, that is a spectacularly vivid tale, Zagreus, and most deserving to be chronicled in song! Would that there were a poet here still willing to commit such deeds to verse.

text.Zagreus: Hey, Orpheus? I take it you know all about the time I burned my father's hands to a crisp the moment I was born? He grasped me by the feet, and they caught fire! And that's why he still wears those fancy rings: to cover up the hideous scar tissue.

text.Orpheus: But that is such a splendid tale, Zagreus, deserving to be sung both far and wide, until it turns into the stuff of myth, as deathless as the gods themselves! I'll gladly tell that one about!

text.Zagreus: Hey Orpheus, you've noticed the resemblance between me and Dionysus, haven't you, mate? I'll tell you a little secret but you have to promise not to tell... We're really the same god. I love a good feast, don't I?

text.Orpheus: But, Zagreus, that is a striking revelation, the connection you describe. I see it! I can see it now! To think the god of wine and you are intricately linked, it isn't obvious, is it?

text.Zagreus: Oh, there's more to it! A bit grim, really, as I'm a little older than I look. You see, the Titans, they once tore me limb from limb, but then my heart was saved, and that's where Dionysus comes from! That is the connection between us, you understand me, mate?

text.Orpheus: Your tale stirs my soul, it truly does, my friend. It is a marvel to me that such heroism isn't widely known, and I'm committed to the spread of all such truths.

text.Zagreus: Hey Orpheus, you know I've just been messing with you, with those Dionysus tales, and all that? Just trying to liven things up for us, mate.

text.Orpheus: Oh, Zagreus! There isn't need for such humility, not when one's deeds of heroism are as great and numerous as yours! It is an honor to have heard such deeds first-hand!

text.Zagreus: You know, mate, sometimes I worry that you're taking my tall tales rather seriously. You're not really going about and telling everyone this stuff, are you?

text.Orpheus: Come now, my friend! I know this is a test of faith! Of course I am committed to the spread of such heroic deeds as yours. And I do so enjoy getting to hear them first!

text.Zagreus: Hey, Orpheus? I figure that you've heard by now about how I bested the Minotaur Asterius, alongside Theseus, the Champion of Elysium, himself? I don't think I even broke a sweat.

text.Orpheus: I scarce can possibly imagine such a spectacle, my friend! But certainly I shall attempt to try!

text.Zagreus: Orpheus, you have to hear this straight from me. I vanquished my own father, on the outskirts of the Temple of Styx. At the surface! I know how this looks, since I'm back here, and so is he. You believe me, don't you?

text.Orpheus: Of course I do, my friend! Though, you must know, your father has requested his relationship to you be kept quite clandestine. You'll understand if I not sing your praises in this case, won't you?

text.Zagreus: Orpheus, sorry to interrupt, it's just... I couldn't help but notice that new ballad that you're playing, there.

text.Orpheus: Technically, one ought consider it a hymn, my friend! In honor of your numerous travails, prior to your current set of circumstances, which must pale in comparison to all the rigors you've endured to date!

text.Zagreus: Erm, the thing is... none of the information in your hymn is accurate. It's nonsense. I was just kidding with you, mate! I tried to make that clear. You get so lively when I tell you my tall tales, you know? You're not angry with me, are you...?

text.Orpheus: Heavens, no, my friend! Your humility is matched only by your perseverance in the face of adversity! May your great deeds live on forever, much like you!

text.Zagreus: Say, Orpheus. You wouldn't happen to know the nymph Eurydice, would you? Tall, woodsy type? I get the impression maybe you know each other.

text.Orpheus: What? Why... yes. I know Eurydice. Or, I once knew her, I should say. Whyever would you ask me such a thing, my friend?

text.Zagreus: I saw her, mate. In Asphodel. She's doing fine up there! All on her own. The two of you, you used to know each other, then?

text.Orpheus: We more than knew each other, Zagreus. We were husband and wife. She was my muse. To think that we are doomed to be apart during our afterlives. Ah, well!

text.Zagreus: Ah, well? Don't you have a message I could bring to her, if we should meet again? Something like that?

text.Orpheus: I do not wish to trouble her again, my friend. Speak not to her of me, all right? I have my memory of her; it is enough.

text.Zagreus: Say, Orpheus. You're not going to believe this. I happened on a certain nymph during my journeys recently. It was Eurydice. Tall, woodsy type?

text.Orpheus: What? Why... truly. I knew Eurydice resided in your father's realm, but... I had not anticipated you would cross her path. You're certain of this, then?

text.Zagreus: I saw her, mate. In Asphodel. She's doing fine up there! All on her own. You said the two of you were very close, isn't that right?

text.Orpheus: We were much more than that, Zagreus. We were husband and wife. She was my muse. To think that we are doomed to be apart during our afterlives. Ah, well!

text.Zagreus: Ah, well? Don't you have a message I could bring to her, if we should meet again? Something like that?

text.Orpheus: I do not wish to trouble her again, my friend. Speak not to her of me, all right? I have my memory of her; it is enough.

text.Zagreus: Orpheus, I saw Eurydice again. I... couldn't bring myself to do exactly as you asked, I... sort of mentioned you.

text.Orpheus: You what?! Or, what I meant to say was: Oh. Did you perchance get the impression she yet harbors toward me feelings of resentment, and the like?

text.Zagreus: You seemed to be a bit of a sore subject, yes. What happened to the two of you, if I may ask?

text.Orpheus: Oh, it's just... I almost saved her soul from this domain, back when I lived and breathed. But in the final moments of my rescue, my faith faltered. She is lost to me forever, now. Though, I'm pleased to hear she isn't lost to you!

text.Zagreus: Orpheus, I saw Eurydice again. I... couldn't bring myself to do exactly as you asked, I... sort of mentioned you.

text.Orpheus: You what?! Or, what I meant to say was: Oh. Did you perchance get the impression she yet harbors toward me feelings of resentment, and the like?

text.Zagreus: You seemed to be a bit of a sore subject, yes. You really almost freed her from the Underworld, huh?

text.Orpheus: Almost, my friend, almost. But in the final moments of my rescue, my faith faltered. She is lost to me forever, now. Though, I'm pleased to hear she isn't lost to you!
Pray tell me something, Zagreus. How is she lately, hm? Eurydice, I mean. Her hair, fall colors, or full bloom? Her poise, as proud and supple as the oak?

text.Zagreus: She's all right, Orpheus. Seems comfortable within her little place in Asphodel. The only thing that seems to bother her at all is... when I mention you. Is there nothing you can do to patch things up?

text.Orpheus: Alas, I cannot change the past, my friend. So, no. As you can plainly see by now, I'm dead to her. Rightfully so, at that.

text.Zagreus: But that's just a technicality! I mean, you're here, she's there! So what if you're not breathing anymore, you have all eternity ahead of you. Don't you want to see her again?

text.Orpheus: Don't I want to see my Eurydice again...? Why, yes. That, more than anything, my friend. Provided she wanted to see me. I tried once to disturb her everlasting rest, as you well know. And that did not pan out as I had hoped....
What news of late about Eurydice, my friend? She is as delicate as I described, no doubt? Ah, but... I am dwelling on her once again, it seems.

text.Zagreus: I knew she was a talented musician, mate, but you never let on that she is an amazing chef, as well. She's been hospitable to me each time we've met. Though you still seem to be a bit of a sore subject.

text.Orpheus: How very understandable, indeed. Were I to have been failed to be rescued from the depths of hell, mere moments from escape, I too would be quite cross with my attempted rescuer. And for quite some time.

text.Zagreus: Orpheus, I don't suppose you know how come I keep running into Eurydice in particular out there? For all the shades resting eternally in Asphodel, it seems beyond coincidence I always find the one that's dear to you.

text.Orpheus: I have no knowledge of the weavings of the Fates, my friend. Perhaps they trample on what used to be my heart for leisure or for sport, do you suppose?
I know no other way, my friend.

text.Zagreus: Say, Orpheus, Eurydice told me your songs, some of them came from her? She seems quite brilliant. You choose your muses well!

text.Orpheus: I owe my everything to my Eurydice. She authored many of my songs, indeed; and she inspired many, many more. Whilst living, we collaborated frequently, you see.

text.Zagreus: But weren't you the famous one? I don't understand why she doesn't share your renown.

text.Orpheus: It is but one of life's injustices, I fear. I always sang her praises every chance I had. And she asserted herself splendidly. Yet even still, our listeners believed our songs, they came from me... what else could I have done?

text.Zagreus: I don't exactly know the ways of mortals, mate. But I'm pleased to hear you always giving credit where it's due.
Then, word will spread. I'm sure of it.
Orpheus, you said that it was one of life's injustices that Eurydice doesn't get her fair share of the credit for the songs she wrote. Isn't there something we can do?

text.Orpheus: Why, I don't know, my friend. Once people set their minds to certain things... it can be difficult to show them other possibilities exist. What's to be done?

text.Zagreus: I don't know... tell them they're wrong? Politely, perhaps not? Or... tell them what's right. Get the word out about what's right? Can't we do that?

text.Orpheus: Get the word out...? But I am court musician of this House. My songs no longer reach too many ears. Although... I do suppose all of these shades about... they are my audience, as well. I shall make certain that they know whose songs I sing.

I must confess something to you, my friend. My mind still wanders to Eurydice quite often, and my memories of her. Despite my best attempts to move along with my existence here. I would call it a fatal flaw, except, I am already dead.

text.Zagreus: Don't torture yourself, mate. You've been through enough. As has she! You still care for one another just don't have a way to get the point across. But I have an idea.

text.Orpheus: I, too, once had ideas, Zagreus. Ideas, and inspirations. It was so very wonderful, to have a muse...

text.Zagreus: I got you something, Orpheus. It's a new song. From someone who still cares for you.

text.Orpheus: My friend, you wrote a song, for me...? Oh, but this is not from you, it's from... Eurydice... I, no, I don't know what to say, I... I...

text.Zagreus: You sing beautifully, mate. If only Eurydice could hear you singing this right now.

text.Orpheus: Oh. Thanks for the sentiment, my friend, it's just... when I sing this song of hers, why, I've this feeling where my heart once was that, well... perhaps she can.
I've decided I should give this singing thing another shot for now, my friend. I hope you like it.

text.Zagreus: You sing beautifully, mate. If only Eurydice could hear you singing this right now.

text.Orpheus: Oh. Thanks for the sentiment, my friend, it's just... when I sing this song of hers, why, I've this feeling where my heart once was that, well... perhaps she can.
Thank you. I shall. I shall!
Zagreus! The most amazing circumstances have occurred. The terms of my employment, they've been altered such that... I may visit Asphodel sometimes. May visit her.

text.Zagreus: That's great! Orpheus, what are you waiting for, mate? Go and find your muse out there! You two have lots to catch up on, I think.

text.Orpheus: I think you're right. I am so very anxious, I must say. But I must also thank you, for this opportunity, and... for speaking with me all this time. So, how might I repay you?

text.Zagreus: Why is it always talk of payment around here? You're my mate. And your songs have lifted many spirits here, including mine. Now go, and make the most of this, will you?
Great to hear it. I can only imagine.
Hey Orpheus, you're back! How was your trip? I hope it was all right.

text.Orpheus: It was more than all right, my friend. Why, it was positively inspirational. But I've returned as promised to this House. My love is there, whilst my responsibilities are here.

text.Zagreus: You sound despondent again, mate. You must wish you were there right now. I'm sorry you had to come all the way back.

text.Orpheus: Oh, on the contrary, Zagreus. It dawned upon me that having some distance between my responsibilities and my domestic life, why... it is not so bad. Besides, Charon makes travel to and fro quite simple for me, really.

text.Zagreus: You're doing wonderfully at it, mate.
I have to ask you something, Orpheus. It seems like everything has been all right for you, except... you don't look very happy to me, mate. Is everything all right? Between you and Eurydice, I mean?

text.Orpheus: Oh, haha, but your concern is much appreciated, friend. I feel I am in everlasting bliss. It simply does not show upon my countenance. Perhaps through song is how I best express myself.

text.Zagreus: Well, thank you also, mate.

Hey, Orpheus. You know I'm very happy that things turned out well between you and Eurydice, but... looking back, I think I might have overstepped my bounds with you a bit, and wanted to say I'm sorry.

text.Orpheus: You're sorry, Zagreus? Whatever for? If not for you, I fear I never would have seen my muse again.

text.Zagreus: Well, it's just... when I met her, and I found out the two of you were having problems, I... well, I just wanted to see you patch things up. But, it wasn't any of my business, and you never asked my help. Neither did she. I could have made things worse.

text.Orpheus: But, you didn't make things worse, my friend. And... truth be told, I do not think I ever would have asked for help, at any point, because... I don't entirely know how. So I am grateful to you, and your generous instinct.
I highly doubt it, no.
I shall give it some thought, I think.

text.Zagreus: Say, Orpheus! I heard what must have been a song of yours, it went something, something, in the blood, you know that one? It was amazing, mate.

text.Orpheus: Oh, that one, yes, I know! I mean, it was a favorite, I was told, by those who listened to the music I created with my muse. It was a most productive time, back when we were alive!

text.Zagreus: Would you ever sing it again?
Hey, Orpheus. The keepsake that you gave me... it's come in useful, thanks. I can't quite see what's in the container, though. I shouldn't open it, should I?

text.Orpheus: No, Zagreus. Unless of course you wanted to set loose a cherished living memory of mine, and take from me that fleeting bit of joy?

text.Zagreus: Orpheus, the Distant Memory you gave me... it's a bit of your past with Eurydice in there, isn't it. I'm grateful, but... why give me such a precious gift as that?

text.Orpheus: I'm glad you like it, Zagreus. Some memories are cherished, yes, indeed. But there can come a point where they provide more benefit to others than ourselves. Don't you agree?
Of course, my friend.
Have you considered doing music-making as a recreational pursuit, my friend? You have such slender hands, why, I believe you'd do quite well at it.

text.Zagreus: Not really been at the top of my list of late, mate, but who knows. It's something I've been meaning to try at some point, I suppose. Thanks for the words of encouragement!
Hey Orpheus! I got myself a lyre much like yours, except I'm absolutely miserable when I try to play! Got any advice?

text.Orpheus: Oh, why, that's splendid, Zagreus. And I can certainly show you a thing or two. First, the proper posture is important, here...
...now remember to practice the plucking technique which I taught you, and mind your off-hand constantly. And, above all, continue practicing! The joyfulness is in the practicing itself.
Zagreus, I heard your recent lyre-playing from your bedchambers. Let no one lead you to believe it's not a reassuring start.

text.Zagreus: Oh, come now, mate, I'm terrible and you know it. You pulling one over on me as payback?

text.Orpheus: I'm being serious, my friend. It is a challenging pursuit requiring a dedicated state of mind. The progress shall come. You shall discover what I mean.
It's almost everything to me, my friend.
Your music-playing has improved substantially. Perhaps in time you shall surpass my own abilities!

text.Zagreus: I highly doubt that, mate, though thanks for noticing. Creating music's quite rewarding once you get the hang of it!

text.Orpheus: I must commend you on the most splendid lyre-playing emanating from your bedchambers, my friend. It seems we have a second court musician, now.

text.Zagreus: Thank you for encouraging me to give it a shot, mate. And for the kind words.

text.Orpheus: ...You called upon your humble court musician, as I understand, Lord Hades sir? Referring to myself of course?

text.Hades: Well, Orpheus... if you're quite finished with your little stint within the depths of Tartarus, I'd like to ask again: Play us a song, already. Or else next time I'll not be quite so charitable with your punishment.

text.Orpheus: Oh, that. I must apologize, again, Lord Hades sir. For I'm afraid that I've no wish to sing as yet. In spite of your persuasiveness even. And, that, um, is my final word upon the subject. At this time.

text.Hades: Is that so...? Why, then, I'll go ahead and wait. I've all the patience in the world.
Help me to understand something here, Orpheus. Why do I bother keeping such a worthless shadow of a court musician in my House? You prattle ceaselessly, yet I can't get even a single note out of you?

text.Orpheus: If I may be so bold, my lord? Perhaps the merest sight of me still stirs in you a memory of my performances of yore. It gladdens me you used to like my songs.

text.Hades: I used to tolerate your insolence. We're finished here. You find your voice. Immediately! You have one hundred years, and not a moment more.
Finally returned to your senses, haven't you, Orpheus. A court musician who refused to sing! Such nonsense. I trust there shall be no more insubordination from you, moving forward?

text.Orpheus: I'm gladdened that my songs yet stir your soul, my lord. But, I have to confess my choice to sing again was motivated largely by the Prince. And by my muse, of course.

text.Hades: Still going on about your so-called muse, I see. You had your chance with Eurydice. You squandered it. And now you're here; a deal is a deal. I expect you to comply with your end of our agreement.
Nrgh...

text.Zagreus: Good thing that's settled, then.

text.Orpheus: ...I'm pleased to know my new, more flexible arrangement remains to your satisfaction, still, my lord. I must admit I feared that my departure would result once more in a protracted stay within the pits of Tartarus.

text.Hades: Don't give me such ideas, Orpheus! Instead, you go about your business, there, and play your blasted songs when circumstances call for it.

text.Orpheus: I shall be happy to oblige, my lord. Eurydice and I are grateful for your magnanimity.

...You're much too modest, Lord Achilles, for someone with such a number of heroic deeds and glorious decapitations to his name! You ought to be more like ever-boastful Zagreus, and talk it up some more!

text.Achilles: Oh, fear not, Orpheus, I was quite boastful in my day. And would you look at where it got me? Besides, I've not the imagination to come up with tales as tall as those of our Prince Zagreus.
Now that you mention it... I can't.

text.Zagreus: I can!

text.Orpheus: ...Do you miss it, yourself, Lord Achilles, sir? The freshness of the air. The need to have meals several times a day, and such.

text.Achilles: I scarce remember it, my friend. Although your songs do stir up memories, sometimes. I'm used to things the way they are, I think. But you, not so much?

text.Orpheus: Oh, on the contrary, sir, I am profoundly satisfied. We are most fortunate to have employment even after death. Imagine, merely resting for eternity, when you could work!

text.Persephone: Oh, you're too kind!
...Ah, but to think that our esteemed musician of the court is none other than you, Orpheus! In matters of music, at least, Hades and I have similar tastes. Anyway, I don't mean to keep you!

text.Orpheus: I shall be honored to perform my songs, Your Grace. And, might I add, Your Grace bears many of the striking features of your son? I understand now where he gets his charm.
I'm sorry I've no will for singing, Zagreus.
I feel a bit self-conscious seeing as I must refuse to sing...!
I remain your humble court musician, Zagreus.
I'm truly pleased to see you, Zagreus.
Would that I could aid you in some way, my friend.
It's awfully quiet whilst you're not around. Still rather quiet now!
Nice speaking with you, Zagreus.
I'm afraid I haven't much to say on this occasion, Zagreus.
I hope your day or night, I guess, is going nicely, Zagreus.
Please do be careful out there, Zagreus.
I wish I could direct you towards a much more lively court musician.
Normally I'd offer up a song for such occasions, Zagreus.
Be strong out there, my friend, OK?
I'm cheering for you all the way, my friend.
Good luck to you out in that deadly hellscape, Zagreus.
Thank you for checking up on me, my friend, although I'm quite all right.
I'm still fresh out of songs or will to sing them, Zagreus.
I'd ask if you remember what it's like to feel inspired, my friend, but I don't want to know.
Oh, hello, Zagreus....
Wishing you a pleasant day or night as ever, my good friend...!
May you emerge from all of this unscathed, my friend.
I trust your neverending toil in the Underworld is proceeding well, my friend?
I have an optimistic feeling about your next attempt to run away, my friend!
May you yet find your muse somewhere out there, my friend.
Each failure brings new opportunities for self-reflection, right, my friend?
Please keep me well apprised of all of your incredible achievements, Zagreus.
It lifts my spirits when we briefly interact, my friend.
I pray the Fates not ruin all your dreams as they did mine!
I'm in the middle of a song my friend...!
I'd best get back to singing, Zagreus.
Let's talk when I'm not singing, Zagreus?
Hello, my friend, let's get back to my song?
I'm kind of singing at the moment, Zagreus.
Terribly sorry I can't speak with you right now.
I thought I'd lost even the gift of music, Zagreus. So, thanks again for helping find that one for me!
I must say, it's nice having some music in my life again, and hopefully in yours!
We all could use a little song from time to time, isn't that so?
It's nice that I no longer have to live and breathe, and can be focused purely on my song...!
You rescued me from an eternity of not getting to sing, my friend.
I hope your day or night is just as splendid as my own, my friend.
I pray the Fates fulfill your dreams as they did mine!
Oh, Zagreus, how wonderful to see you once again!
I was just thinking of you, Zagreus.
My greetings to my very dearest friend.
I am in concert as perhaps you see, my friend!
Begging your pardon, Zagreus, but I'm amid performance at this time!
I'm quite preoccupied with singing all your praises, Zagreus!
This hymn is dedicated to your deeds, my friend!
I cannot talk right now, my friend, for I must sing!
I trust my music brings some lightness to our gloom-filled times, my friend?
The tale of your birth is so complex, my friend!
I ask you please hold your applause until the end!
To think Lord Dionysus and yourself share such a bond!
May my performances spread wide your fame, my friend!
Your parentage need not be secret any longer, Zagreus!
I shall keep singing of your praises, far and wide!
You've helped inspire me to song, my friend!
I must stay focused on my singing, Zagreus.
I trust my hymn provides some solace to your days or nights?
My muse writes absolutely wondrous songs, don't you agree?
Ah, this reminds me so of my Eurydice...
Would that I were together with her now...
The songs of my Eurydice are without peer...
This is a favorite song of mine, and perhaps yours?

text.Zagreus: Hey, mate, here. I got this for my favorite court musician.

text.Orpheus: Oh, my, but you can't simply be this kind to me without retaliation on my part, my friend! And so, in turn, I have a gift for you!
Why, this is absolutely splendid, Zagreus. Is this really for me? It's so very kind of you to think of me like this.

text.Zagreus: I want you to have it, Orpheus. You've brightened up our lives down here more than you know. I only wish that you could see that.

text.Orpheus: Oh, why! I'm very much obliged that you have thought of me again, for such a wonderfully thoughtful gift!

text.Zagreus: It's nothing, Orpheus. Thank you for all the inspiration through your song. I love your work, mate.

text.Orpheus: You're always much too kind, you know, my friend? Now typically I would express my gratitude through song, except, you understand, don't you?

text.Zagreus: I understand completely, Orpheus. I think we'll both get through this rough patch in due time.

text.Orpheus: You always offer means to quench my thirst, my friend. A wonder that I have such feelings, even now.

text.Zagreus: Now that you've started singing once again, I figured it was thirst-inducing work! Your music stirs so many souls around here, mate.
Take care, mate.
Hey, mate! What do you say we share this over in the lounge?

text.Orpheus: Oh, I, certainly, why, I don't see why not. I mean, it's not as though I've got something to do that isn't that.
...And, anyways, I oughtn't have looked back, I mean, the moral of the story is to not look back when you are told not to look back, you understand, don't you, my friend?

text.Zagreus: Don't look back, huh. I'll try not to. Though, you can't be blamed for doing it yourself, just the one time. What happened to you... it wasn't fair. If you ask me.

text.Orpheus: ...I quite enjoyed our outing, Zagreus. So, I suppose I shall be seeing you around?
I am indebted to you, Zagreus, both for your friendship and embarrassment of generosity.

text.Zagreus: And I, in turn, am indebted to you, Orpheus, for your calm demeanor and ability to accept life's greatest challenges. You inspire me, and I wish you the best.
Hey, Orpheus, mate! I have something good for you right here... Ambrosia! All the way from the surface. I want you to have it.

text.Orpheus: Ah, but this is splendid, Zagreus. And I must say, apart from my Eurydice, I've never felt as strong a bond of kinship as with you.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Hey Orpheus, you know I once wrested this bottle of Ambrosia from the Champions of Elysium, defeating them two against one, just so I could bring it here to you personally?

CHOICE.Orpheus: Please, my friend! I feel I am undeserving of such a relentless show of kindness on your part. I shall accept, but you'll relent, won't you? As well as forgive me?

CHOICE.Zagreus: Mate, if that is your wish, then it will be my pleasure to oblige. Though, may this gift symbolize the strength of our friendship for an eternity to come. I've learned so much from you.

CHOICE.Orpheus: Thank you, my friend. Would that I had capacity to take some joy from this.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Orpheus is with Eurydice I guess.

CHOICE.Orpheus: That makes it difficult to sing, my friend.
I resolved never to fight, my friend.
I fight only through song, my friend.
I am attempting here to sing, my friend?

text.Orpheus: UseText  UseListenNPC,

text.Eurydice: Yeah. So, if you would excuse us for a little while, hon? I'm not finished catching up with him just yet. But first, before you go!

text.Zagreus: UseText  UseListenNPC

text.Orpheus: A splendid compliment, my friend. Doubtless the Fates themselves conspired to ensure Eurydice and I would meet, and sing together. Fall in love. And then be cruelly separated for some time!

text.Eurydice: Now don't you start with that again, you get me, Orphy? Got our whole entire afterlives ahead of us! And lots of songs to catch up on.

text.Orpheus: Why, you're correct of course, my dear. If you'll excuse us, Zagreus? Our calling beckons.

text.Zagreus: UseText  UseListenNPC

text.Orpheus: Oh, things are going very wonderfully, my friend. I never thought I'd see Eurydice again, after I...

text.Eurydice: Orphy still just can't shut up about that time, hon. But we're making progress. Thanks for having him stop by. I'm sure he needed plenty of encouragement.

text.Zagreus: UseText  UseListenNPC,

text.Orpheus: Oh, it is certainly my pleasure, Zagreus. This song of Eurydice's and mine, I've a connection to it, I suppose. Reminded me of some fond memories!

text.Eurydice: Hey, nice of you to visit us, Your Royal Majesty! For you!,
Orphy and I, we're doing great here thanks to you. You take care, hon!,
Hope you find yourself someone to sing with, too, hon.,
Don't fret, Your Majesty, I'll have him back to work on time, you hear that, Orphy?,
Orphy and me, we're like your typical old married couple, hon.,
If you find happiness out there, hon, don't look back.,
Things aren't so bad here, hon. Hope you can say the same.,
What can I say, hon? We like practicing our favorite tune!,
Well if it isn't the Hades kid come to pay the both of us a visit!,

text.Orpheus: ...You must know, you sound as wonderful as ever, now, my dear!,
Is she not truly wonderful, my friend?,
We sing, and sing, and never once grow weary, Zagreus!,
I never thought I would see her again. You are to thank for this, my friend.,
When we thus sing together, Zagreus, I lose all track of time.,
Is the singing of Eurydice not the most splendid thing that you have ever heard?,
Shall there ever be a voice as lovely as Eurydice's, my friend?,
It gladdens me that you could join us here, my friend.,

text.Eurydice: Guess what we've been up to lately, hon? Now if you'll excuse us?,
We just finished eating, here! Got plenty left over.,
The one thing better than singing, hon, is singing with somebody you love.,
Orphy here's just practicing for when he's got to sing next for Hades Senior!,
What do you know, we were just in the middle of a song here, hon!,
Not much luck trying to teach Orphy to cook, but he can sing, all right!,
Look, Orphy, we've got an audience! So sing your heart out!,
Don't mind Orphy, here, hon. Can't snap him out of it once he gets singing!,
You know this tune, hon? It's one of our old hits!,
We were just thinking about old times, Orphy and I!,
Thought we'd mix up our singing just a bit here, hon!,
Got to tell you I've warmed up to this old song over the years!,

text.Orpheus: I know that you enjoy this one, my friend!
This one reminds me of my days alive with my Eurydice...!
This song had quite a bit of popularity, one time.

text.Zagreus: Hey Orpheus! I got myself a lyre much like yours, except I'm absolutely miserable when I try to play! Got any advice?

text.Orpheus: Oh, why, that's splendid, Zagreus. And I can certainly show you a thing or two. First, the proper posture is important, here...
...now remember to practice the plucking technique which I taught you, and mind your off-hand constantly. And, above all, continue practicing! The joyfulness is in the practicing itself.

text.Megaera: Tsch. The prodigal son returns.... Everyone's saying I went easy on you, Zag.

text.Zagreus: Don't worry, Meg. I eventually managed to get home the painful way after all.

text.Megaera: Look, I've a reputation to uphold. You get past me again like that, you best go all the way. Now, leave me be, and don't think you're going to be so lucky next we meet out there.
Tsch. The prodigal son returns.... Everyone's saying I went easy on you, Zag.

text.Zagreus: Don't worry, Meg. I eventually managed to get home the painful way after all. Though... I managed to get much farther than you'd probably expect.

text.Megaera: I expected you to not get past me, yes. Look, I've a reputation to uphold. Don't think you're going to be so lucky next we meet out there.
Tsch. The prodigal son returns.... Everyone's saying I went easy on you, Zag.

text.Zagreus: Don't worry, Meg. I eventually managed to get home the painful way after all.

text.Megaera: Look, I've a reputation to uphold. You get past me again like that, you best go all the way. Now, leave me be, and don't think you're going to be so lucky next we meet out there.
Tsch. The prodigal son returns.... Everyone's saying I went easy on you, Zag.

text.Zagreus: Don't worry, Meg. I eventually managed to get home the painful way after all. Though... I managed to get much farther than you'd probably expect.

text.Megaera: I expected you to not get past me, yes. Look, I've a reputation to uphold. Don't think you're going to be so lucky next we meet out there.
Leave me alone

text.Zagreus: Hey, uh, what's that you're drinking, Meg? Anything good?

text.Megaera: Whatever it is, it's weak. Enough to be mistaken for your blood.

text.Zagreus: Nice! Well, I'll just leave you to it, then.

text.Megaera: I'll tear you limb from limb out there next time, you mark my words.

text.Zagreus: What are your sisters up to these days, Meg? I've not seen them around.

text.Megaera: We're stretched a little thin, as you can see. Some kind of war up there meant lots of business here. I'm left to hold the line. And deal with you.

text.Zagreus: What are your sisters up to these days, Meg? I've not seen them around.

text.Megaera: We're stretched a little thin, as you can see. Some kind of war up there meant lots of business here. I'm left to hold the line. And deal with you.
What do you want from me, leave me alone. We've nothing to discuss here anymore.

text.Zagreus: I was just checking up on you, just... let me know if you wanted to talk, for any reason.

text.Megaera: I am not interested in having company, especially from you. You stay the hell away while I'm off duty.
I told you to back off.
What do you want from me, leave me alone. We've nothing to discuss here anymore.

text.Zagreus: I was just checking up on you, just... let me know if you wanted to talk, for any reason.

text.Megaera: I am not interested in having company, especially from you. You stay the hell away while I'm off duty.
I told you to back off.
Excuse me, is there something I can do for you, Prince Zagreus?

text.Zagreus: It's nothing, I just thought I'd say, that was well fought back there.

text.Megaera: There's no returning to the way things used to be, Zag. Now can I offer you some words of advice? Get over yourself. And get ready to die out there next time we meet.
Zagreus. Good, I wanted to tell you something. Your victories against me? They don't count for anything.

text.Zagreus: Sounds like you've been giving this a lot of thought, there, Meg. How do you figure?

text.Megaera: Nyx's Mirror. You couldn't possibly beat me without its help, or hers.

text.Zagreus: I'm not competing with you, Meg. I'm trying to get past you, to the surface.

text.Megaera: Call it what you want. You're doing what you have to do. I understand. But you are not stronger than me. You just have more help.
EndCue  /VO/ZagreusHome_0751,

text.Zagreus: Meg, what is it going to take for you to quit treating me like I'm incompetent? Have I not grown even a little since we met? You were supposed to teach me something; what does that make you?

text.Megaera: Tsch... why don't you raise your voice a little louder so that all the House can hear. Is that what you want? For everyone to know that you're superior to me?

text.Zagreus: You're not hearing me, Meg. I know it sounds a little disingenuous considering we keep fighting to the death and all, but... I never meant to hurt you.

text.Megaera: You give yourself far too much credit, Zagreus. Leave me alone.
EndCue  /VO/ZagreusHome_0751,

text.Zagreus: Meg, that isn't why I'm here, you know that isn't how I am. Why can't you see it? All I've ever wanted was to prove myself to you.

text.Megaera: Tsch... you think that you can prove yourself to me by winning in a fight?

text.Zagreus: Sometimes I think that I can never really win with you, Meg. If I held back, what would you have thought?

text.Megaera: If you think you know me so well, Zagreus, then you ought to know better than to keep this conversation going with me, now.
EndCue  /VO/ZagreusHome_0751,

text.Zagreus: I had to see if I could do it, Meg. I've learned so much from you, I... thought maybe this was a way that I could prove myself to you. And to myself.

text.Megaera: Prove yourself, to me...? You must not be as comfortable in your own skin as you let on. I can't decide if I like that about you. Now leave me alone while I give it some thought.
So, Zagreus. How's it going with that Pact of Punishment you signed? You've made some meaningful improvements to the Underworld.

text.Zagreus: I'll fight my way out of this place, or earn it. The Pact is nothing to me other than a way to keep things lively.

text.Megaera: You are delusional. I'll never understand you or your father. Anyway, if you're looking for more punishment, you know where to find me.
So, Zagreus. How's it going with that Pact of Punishment you signed? You've made some meaningful improvements to the Underworld.

text.Zagreus: I'll fight my way out of this place, or earn it. The Pact is nothing to me other than a way to keep things lively.

text.Megaera: You are delusional. I'll never understand you or your father. Anyway, if you're looking for more punishment, you know where to find me.

text.Zagreus: Anything for you, Meg.

text.Megaera: Zagreus. I heard Lord Hades served you with a Pact of Punishment. You must be very proud.

text.Zagreus: What, you mean the gigantic infernal contract reserved only for extraordinary circumstances? Yeah, I suppose I'm pleased that Father's gone to all that trouble just for me.

text.Megaera: Well, when you're finished being smug about it? Know that all of us are bound by its terms. You can force a lot of things to change if you're not careful.

text.Zagreus: A lot of things, such as how you refuse to reason with your positively charming sisters, Meg?

text.Megaera: The Extreme Measures condition... you wouldn't dare. Do you have any idea what you're talking about?

text.Zagreus: Yeah.

text.Megaera: Well, how was it up there, Zagreus? Within Elysium. You'll have to tell us all about it every time the greatest strike you down.

text.Zagreus: You've never been there, have you? It's... lush? Is that a word? It feels closer to the surface. Closer to the sky.

text.Megaera: How poetic. You could have visited as part of your responsibilities. Instead, you trespass. Incurring wrath of fallen champions in service of your father.

text.Zagreus: Yeah.

text.Megaera: Well, how was it up there, Zagreus? Within Elysium. You'll have to tell us all about it every time the greatest strike you down.

text.Zagreus: You've never been there, have you? It's... lush? Is that a word? It feels closer to the surface. Closer to the sky.

text.Megaera: How poetic. You could have visited as part of your responsibilities. Instead, you trespass. Incurring wrath of fallen champions in service of your father.

text.Zagreus: I suppose not...

text.Megaera: So you cleared out some of the Satyr infestation near the surface, then. How come the change of heart? Not like you to assist Lord Hades in such things.

text.Zagreus: I wasn't trying to do my father any favors, Meg. Those Satyrs seem to hate me just as much as him. My one way out involves a detour straight into their dens.

text.Megaera: An interesting coincidence. At any rate, that's one less problem for the rest of us to deal with. Until the Satyrs all come back, at least, which won't be long.
You've been through hell more times than you can count by now, haven't you, Zag. You getting used to it? No wonder that you're friends with Sisyphus.

text.Zagreus: I'm getting used to it, all right. I'll keep going, for as many chances as it takes. I'll look forward to our next appointment out there.

text.Megaera: Appointment. Indeed. Don't keep me waiting. For all your toil, I'm sure you're not even close.

text.Zagreus: I will not let that happen.

text.Megaera: Zagreus, please tell me that the rumors are untrue. You really vanquished him? Have you completely lost your mind? You're going to destroy this blasted House!

text.Zagreus: Come on, Meg, Father had it coming for some time. What's your concern, besides? The House is safe.

text.Megaera: He's not going to take this lying down. He'll find some way to take it out on you. On all of us. You watch yourself, or all of us will pay.

text.Zagreus: I will not let that happen.

text.Megaera: Zagreus, please tell me that the rumors are untrue. You really vanquished him? Have you completely lost your mind? You're going to destroy this blasted House!

text.Zagreus: Come on, Meg, Father had it coming for some time. What's your concern, besides? The House is safe.

text.Megaera: He's not going to take this lying down. He'll find some way to take it out on you. On all of us. You watch yourself, or all of us will pay.

text.Zagreus: It is.

text.Megaera: What are you doing here? I heard you finally made it out. What, did you break out of here, only to die in some pathetic way on the surface?

text.Zagreus: Long story, but yeah. Boils down to what you said, more or less.

text.Megaera: So you're going back out there, again. Well, it's your business, not mine. For your sake... I hope it's worth it.

text.Zagreus: It is.

text.Megaera: What are you doing here? I heard you finally made it out. What, did you break out of here, only to die in some pathetic way on the surface?

text.Zagreus: Long story, but yeah. Boils down to what you said, more or less.

text.Megaera: So you're going back out there, again. Well, it's your business, not mine. For your sake... I hope it's worth it.
None of my business, I said.

text.Zagreus: Meg, did you... did you ever meet the Queen...? Remember anything about her, at all?

text.Megaera: It was not my place to address her. I barely ever saw her. Then, at some point... I never saw her again. And, unlike you, I know better than to get involved in things that are none of my business.

text.Zagreus: How is it that this place has this secret Queen for I don't know how long, then suddenly she just vanishes, and no one speaks a word of it?
I think that she can be the judge of that.

text.Megaera: How is she doing, Zagreus? The Queen, I mean. She was... I had admired her.

text.Zagreus: Mother... she's doing well, I think. She's in good spirits every time we meet. Happy to let her know you're thinking of her, by the way!

text.Megaera: Don't, it's... it isn't necessary. She doesn't need you telling her about this place. Sounds to me like she is better off without.

text.Zagreus: We'll make it official, all right.

text.Megaera: Just so I understand. Breaking through everything in your path, taking resources from your father's realm, trying to get through me... all officially part of the job description?

text.Zagreus: I guess that's right... but, before you ask, I'm not doing it for him.

text.Megaera: I didn't think you'd have it in you. To leave this place for good. But I didn't think you'd take responsibility for anything, either. Anyway... we'll just have to kill each other more officially, I guess.

text.Zagreus: Hope to find out.

text.Megaera: I never thought I'd see the Queen again. I still can't quite believe she's back... and staying? Is that really your doing?

text.Zagreus: It's her doing, not mine. So you know her? Because... you could have told me. About her. Who she was to me.

text.Megaera: Don't know her all that well. But I do know Nyx, and I've been bound to secrecy as part of my oath to this House. I flay oathbreakers and liars, Zagreus. Wouldn't do for me to be no better than them, now, would it?

text.Zagreus: No, I suppose not. So what does this mean for Nyx, now that she's back? Or for you, for that matter?

text.Megaera: The Queen always gave Nyx her space. Your father, though... I don't know what it'll be like for him, if she decides to stick around this time.

text.Zagreus: Exactly!

text.Megaera: So the Olympians are backing you officially now? Doing their part to help the family business, finally. Lord Hades probably never thought he'd see the day. Night? You know what I mean.

text.Zagreus: Seems only fair they should help in some capacity. They all work together on the surface, and, let's face it, they're responsible for a good number of shades pouring into this realm. Least they can do is help shore up the whole 'there is no escape' reputation we've got.

text.Megaera: By making you unfairly stronger by the time you try to get through me?
Heh. Guess you'll find out.

text.Zagreus: Heh.

text.Megaera: Well, Zag? You like things nice and complicated, don't you. Apparently so do I.

text.Zagreus: If you're asking if I have any regrets about what happened between us, the answer is no. Being with you... any complications there are worth it.

text.Megaera: You don't need to tell me. Two rules, if you want to keep this up. First... we set the personal aside when we're out there. I better not hear a soul say I'm going soft on you. And second... keep up this slightly more mature thing you've had going for you recently.

text.Zagreus: Wasn't planning on sliding back into the insensitive nonsense of youth, so I don't think the second thing will be a problem. But the first... can we really just keep killing each other out there like nothing happened?
Thanks, Meg.

text.Megaera: Tsk... Come off it, Zag. Are you really going to act all uncomfortable every time you see me now? More than usual I mean.

text.Zagreus: No, it's just... I felt terrible, turning you away. It's just... I've been so confused lately, and... I trust you. You're someone I can talk to. I guess I'm... afraid to lose that.

text.Megaera: Don't be an idiot, and you won't. We've been through a lot together. Grown, maybe. This particular relationship... it can't die so easily, I think.

text.Zagreus: I refuse.
I feel like everybody knows about us, Meg. Even Aphrodite, herself, seemed to know we were involved. It's not like I've been going around boasting. You wanted to keep things quiet, didn't you?

text.Megaera: Zagreus. Are you happy with how things are between us now? Or do you have a problem with it?

text.Zagreus: Well, I could do without the kill-or-be-killed stuff if we're being honest, that part is still a little weird, but otherwise... yes, I mean... I'm happy. You're you.

text.Megaera: Then, that's enough. Let them say what they want. What does it matter? We're gods. The things they say about us... even other gods... you pay too much attention to it, it'll drive you out of your mind.

text.Zagreus: But... I know how important your career is to you. This won't create a problem?

text.Megaera: We've already crossed that bridge, I think. Stop worrying.

text.Zagreus: Heh.
Megaera... you ever been in love with somebody?

text.Megaera: ...Hm. Yes.

text.Zagreus: Who?

text.Megaera: ...Shut up.

text.Zagreus: Well, thanks. I guess I am.

text.Megaera: Never in my wildest fantasies did I imagine you'd ever end up on the Featured Houseservant Board, Zagreus. I still can't entirely believe it.

text.Zagreus: Whoa, back up! Can you elaborate a bit about these wildest fantasies, Meg?

text.Megaera: I'm serious. You should be proud. Not arrogantly proud to a fatal fault or anything, but a little bit is all right in a case like this.

text.Zagreus: I'll keep putting up a fight if it's any consolation.

text.Megaera: Got to tell you something, Zagreus. I'm not getting any more used to losing to you like this. I mean... you don't even stop to rub it in. You know how humiliating that is?

text.Zagreus: Wait, you're saying you would feel less ashamed about the outcomes of our fights if I were to gloat more about beating you? How does that make any sense?

text.Megaera: You know what doesn't make any sense? That you keep beating me. I must be getting sloppy if I'm that predictable... too bad none of the other wretches I have to deal with put up much of a fight.

text.Zagreus: You and your sisters really don't get along well, do you.

text.Megaera: Alecto and Tisiphone and I each have a different outlook, I would say. We've learned mostly to stay out of one another's way.

text.Zagreus: That doesn't sound like a healthy basis for a relationship between siblings.

text.Megaera: Are you lecturing me about healthy relationships with family, Zagreus? Your family, your father's family, is the most broken and corrupted in the history of the entire concept.

text.Zagreus: ...Fair point. I... didn't mean to sound like I had any meaningful advice, there, Meg. We're stuck with our bloodlines and our relatives, aren't we.

text.Megaera: Your family cut their Titan parents into pieces and then scattered them in Tartarus. Remember that when next you tell me about family.

text.Zagreus: You know, while it was brutal squaring off against the three of you, I have to say, Meg... I was happy you were with your sisters. Nothing like a common cause for bringing bitter rivals together, right?

text.Megaera: You have your Pact of Punishment to thank for our reunion, there. We have to answer to its terms. But my sisters and I, we got on better than I had expected, I will give you that.

text.Zagreus: So you've patched things up, then? Going to start spending more quality time together and all that?

text.Megaera: Hm, let's not get carried away. A work assignment forcing our cooperation is not exactly a big step in the quality of our relationship.

text.Zagreus: Alecto's really something else. She must have been a real handful, huh?

text.Megaera: My youngest sister takes a lot of pleasure from her work. I've learned something of that from her. But that's as far as we relate, I think.

text.Zagreus: She could learn a thing or two from you, I'm sure. About having a little common decency, perhaps.

text.Megaera: She won't be learning anything from me. The contempt you get from her is unconditional. I learned not to take it personally.

text.Zagreus: Erm, so, about Tisiphone, is... uh... everything all right with her? Talk of murder, all the time, and all.

text.Megaera: Tisiphone is charged with punishing the worst that mortals have to offer. More than charged. Her work is everything to her.

text.Zagreus: No time for family or recreation, then, I take it? Pity what happens to those overly obsessed with work.

text.Megaera: I get what you're insinuating, Zagreus. I'm nothing like her. Not even close. And don't you dare compare the two of us again.
You know, that's a good way to put it.
So you've been trying to give Tisiphone speech lessons between fights to the death. Are you bored, or just naive?

text.Zagreus: Come on, if her vocabulary consists of two different although admittedly almost identical words, there's got to be room for growth, there. Besides, I feel like... maybe she's lonely, or something. Has anyone ever tried to teach her anything?

text.Megaera: Maybe, just maybe, you're projecting your own insecurities onto her a little bit? Tis can take care of herself. Always has. Talking's not her strong suit like it's yours. But if you, in all your wisdom, think you've got something to teach her, you go right ahead.

text.Zagreus: You've tried already, haven't you? She's pretty dead-set on the murder thing, then?
You'd think!
You and Thanatos don't work together much anymore, do you, Meg?

text.Megaera: No. Though he still brings me my assignments every now and then.

text.Zagreus: Oathbreakers, traitors, and the like? Sending them straight to Tartarus, huh. Must be quite an experience going from living and breathing, to... being dead, to being whisked off by Thanatos, straight to you and your whip.

text.Megaera: If that's not the experience mortals are looking for, they need only keep their oaths and not betray the ones they're closest to. It's not that hard.

text.Zagreus: Have you tried sulking in the lounge?

text.Megaera: Hmm.

text.Zagreus: You're not too broken up about how things ended between you and Hypnos, are you, Meg?

text.Megaera: I'm still in a state of shock. I'll have to pick up the pieces somehow, and figure out how to get on with my existence.

text.Zagreus: It's a change.

text.Megaera: You got that court musician to pipe up again. I know you can't shut up, but didn't know it was contagious.

text.Zagreus: Hey, it was all Orpheus, not me. Can't sing like that without a lot of motivation, inner turmoil, who knows what else. Why, don't you like it? This lounge seems better with a little song.

text.Megaera: This lounge is fine. And the singing... not used to it yet.
You always do.
Not seen the court musician sulking over there quite as much lately. Your doing, I hear?

text.Zagreus: You'll just have to sulk for the both of you, I guess, then, Meg. But if you must know, on my authority I have released Orpheus from the terms of his old, rather unfair agreement with Father, so he can see his wife at least from time to time.

text.Megaera: And Lord Hades is OK with you just picking out old binding contracts and nullifying them? You're exploiting your status.

text.Zagreus: I'm doing no such thing. Father wanted me involved in all this business with his pacts, and presiding over the dead, then fine. But I'll do it my way.
Hoh now let's not get ahead of ourselves, Meg.
What do you think of all the lounge decor, there, Meg? Looking a little better these days, wouldn't you say?

text.Megaera: You know, it isn't bad. Though I have heard the strangest thing, that you're responsible, for all of this? I couldn't understand why you would even bother, honestly.

text.Zagreus: Well, it's a popular locale for off-duty Underworld officers to take a load off between shifts, and so I figure... least I can do is pitch in and make the place a little better than I left it, right?

text.Megaera: How very selfless of you, Zagreus. Soon doubtless it'll be your portrait hanging on that wall back there.

text.Zagreus: Good!

text.Megaera: The prism-sphere in the corner is maybe a little much. But the fireplace... the bat-cage... the aquarium... this lounge is practically comfortable. Lord Hades would strongly disapprove.

text.Zagreus: Good thing he never sets foot in here, then, huh? Wait, you don't miss when things were all sad and dreary in here, do you?

text.Megaera: I'm still getting used to it. But, no.

text.Zagreus: That she is.

text.Megaera: How's my little Battie doing, Zag? The one I gave you. Was just a little pup. I figured she'd be better off with you. Please tell me I was right.

text.Zagreus: Battie's doing great, Meg. Reminds me of you every time I think of her. Helps keep me company throughout my little jaunts outside. So you've a thing for bats, then?

text.Megaera: That's good. And yes, the bats around here, they and I have always shared an understanding, you could say. I usually care for the pups myself. But Battie? She seemed more your style.

text.Zagreus: How is this my fault?
Meg, what's going on with Nyx and Dusa, do you know? I think they've been butting heads a bit lately.

text.Megaera: I can't imagine why. Nyx has her under strict orders, yet you keep on stopping by for your little chats. You think she doesn't notice?

text.Zagreus: What does she care? I talk to everybody around here at least a bit.

text.Megaera: It's not my business, Zag. Not even for Dusa. But you watch yourself.

text.Zagreus: Nrgh...

text.Megaera: Damn you, Zagreus. She was my friend. And now she's gone.

text.Zagreus: Who, you mean Dusa? Like I had anything to do with that. It's Nyx you should be cross with, not me!

text.Megaera: I don't think so. Nyx warned you. Ungh, you know I can't go to her myself about this, so fix it!
This never should have happened, Zagreus.

text.Zagreus: You saw Dusa's back, right, Meg? She's getting another chance. Nyx reconsidered!

text.Megaera: I saw. Nyx doesn't often change her mind when it comes to this House. But I won't second guess what happened or why.

text.Zagreus: You don't sound all that pleased...
Of course.
I'm so proud of Dusa lately, Meg! Chief Custodian of the House, was it? That's quite an honor coming from Nyx.

text.Megaera: I thought all the added responsibility would stress Dusa out worse than usual. But she's taking it in stride.

text.Zagreus: You're always looking out for her. Thanks for that.

text.Megaera: Not doing it for you. Though... thanks for looking out for her, yourself.

text.Zagreus: Appreciate your open-mindedness.

text.Megaera: I did not appreciate you sending Dusa after me out there, Zag. You leave her out of this! Though... it was good to see her out of this damned House for a change.

text.Zagreus: See, I, too, thought she could use the fresh air. Or... however you'd describe the quality of the air on the edge of Tartarus. You know she'd never mean you any harm, right? In her mind... I think she's trying to keep it friendly between us.

text.Megaera: Eugh, she said the same thing to me. Look, you know what, fine. If that's the only way to get her to take a break from this place, I guess it's for the best.

text.Zagreus: Hey, Meg, I understand you're under orders to kill me on sight out there, but... do you really have to go so hard on Sisyphus?

text.Megaera: That wretched shade isn't who you think he is. Do you have any idea of the magnitude of his crimes from when he led a mortal life?

text.Zagreus: He cheated death. Tricked Thanatos and maybe Father, too.

text.Megaera: Before that, he did worse. He was an awful man. I think that is the real reason that your father punished him.

text.Zagreus: What if he's changed? Or... is that impossible. No coming back from certain crimes.

text.Megaera: No coming back from certain crimes, indeed. Though you may have more mercy in your heart to spare than I in mine.

text.Zagreus: It's a deal.
I have to ask you for a favor, Meg. And I'm willing to make it worth your while, if you'll hear me out.

text.Megaera: A proposition, Zagreus? Let's hear it, then. While I'm in a charitable mood.

text.Zagreus: It's about Sisyphus. If I can get my father to alleviate his sentence, would you just... ease off of him, a little bit? You and your sisters. I think he's suffered quite enough under your whips.

text.Megaera: I don't know what you see in him, I swear. But you don't need to ask such things of me. If you can overturn his sentence with Lord Hades, I'd like nothing better than to never see that miserable shade again.

text.Zagreus: ...I... I think so.
Megaera, I have to ask you something, please. We really need to talk.

text.Megaera: ...For once, I think you're right. Although, I'm curious, what is it that you think we have to talk about?

text.Zagreus: I still have feelings for you. At least... I think I do. Isn't there... isn't there someway for us to, you know... work through all of this?

text.Megaera: In spite of everything that's happened, and that's happening right now? What are the outcomes, Zagreus? Either you eventually succeed, and leave this place, or else, what, exactly?

text.Zagreus: ...I haven't thought that far ahead. But I don't think it has to be this way. I don't hate you, Meg. I don't think I can ever hate you.

text.Megaera: ...Despite my best intentions. Unfortunately, I don't know that I can say the same. Look, I'm at a very difficult point in my career. I need to focus on that now. Do we understand each other?

text.Zagreus: ...I... I think so.
Megaera, I have to ask you something, please. We really need to talk.

text.Megaera: ...For once, I think you're right. Although, I'm curious, what is it that you think we have to talk about?

text.Zagreus: I still have feelings for you. At least... I think I do. Isn't there... isn't there someway for us to, you know... work through all of this?

text.Megaera: In spite of everything that's happened, and that's happening right now? What are the outcomes, Zagreus? What, exactly?

text.Zagreus: ...I haven't thought that far ahead. But I don't think it has to be this way. I don't hate you, Meg. I don't think I can ever hate you.

text.Megaera: ...Despite my best intentions. Unfortunately, I don't know that I can say the same. Look, I'm at a very difficult point in my career. I need to focus on that now. Do we understand each other?

text.Zagreus: I will. Thanks, Meg.
Meg, you know what's going on with Than and me, don't you? I just... want things to be out in the open, between us.

text.Megaera: Oh I know everything about you, Zag. And Thanatos, maybe even better. Though I appreciate you telling me. It's fine.

text.Zagreus: It's fine? I mean... upon Olympus, jealousy runs rampant, as I'm told. But here it's not even an issue, then?

text.Megaera: If you prefer the way they do things on Olympus, then I think you know the way. As for me... dealing with jealousy is what I do. Tell me, should I feel threatened by Thanatos?

text.Zagreus: No... he thinks so highly of you, he... he'd never wish to cause you any harm.

text.Megaera: And I feel much the same. He and I, we're not the same to you. I think we both see that, and understand. Now quit your second-guessing me, all right?

text.Hades: ...Make certain of it, Megaera. I am finding, lately, that the help within this House is much more lacking than it used to be. I trust that you shall set it back on course.

text.Megaera: ...If that is your will, Lord Hades, then it will be done. To the fullest limits of my capability.
<Scoff>
...Give me another chance, Lord Hades. I can do better. Don't... bring them here.

text.Hades: It is already too late for that, Megaera. They have been notified and are en route to Tartarus even as we speak.

text.Megaera: You know what they're like. They are best left to their specific tasks. Not this.

text.Hades: Megaera, trust me when I say I know the feeling all too well. However, surely, in your ingenuity, you may yet find a way to get your sisters to see eye to eye.

text.Megaera: ...I cannot work with them, Lord Hades. Please. They don't respect my words, or even listen.

text.Hades: Enough! Besides, Megaera, this is not your failing. It is mine. I must attend to these affairs more actively.

text.Megaera: ...I've often tried, but never to a satisfactory result. You're asking the impossible of me.

text.Hades: I am not asking, Megaera.

text.Megaera: ...But, I don't understand, Lord Hades. I have fallen to him countless times. How can this be...?

text.Hades: You and your sisters have protected Tartarus unerringly. The Prince has proven uncontainable. The fault is mine, not yours. Your duty to this realm must be commended.

text.Megaera: You honor me... I have done nothing to deserve this. There must be something more that I can do?

text.Hades: There is, and isn't, Megaera. I ask only that you remain committed to this realm. Bar passage in and out of Tartarus. And, if the Prince continues to show up... you give him hell.

text.Megaera: Lord Hades, it will be my pleasure, sir.

text.Nyx: ...We each have our commitments to this House, Megaera. There is no shame in yours. And whilst your sisters are away, you bear their burden of responsibility, as well.

text.Megaera: I understand, it's just... am I supposed to keep pretending nothing's changed? This House is cracking at the seams, and no one's going to admit it?

text.Nyx: The House shall stand eternally, although in what condition, it is ours to decide. Our obligation is to keep the House in order.

text.Megaera: I know. You're right of course, you're right... I'll do my best. I'll do my best for both our sakes, Nyx.

text.Nyx: ...We all do that which is within our power.

text.Zagreus: ...Not my business.

text.Nyx: ...and so, who else is there to be depended on...? You are a trusted overseer, Megaera. Your station is no accident and there is no one better fit for what you do. I urge you to look inwardly. How you approach your work is vital to the end result.

text.Megaera: ...Thank you for the advice, Nyx. I don't know what I'd do without you. Or what this House would be if not for you.
<Scoff>
...But, how can you do this to me? Blast your Mirror. By taking sides with him, you're standing against me...!

text.Nyx: Neutrality ceases to be an option when a crisis rises to a certain point, Megaera. You, yourself, shall have to choose allegiances. I have steadfastly told you this throughout our shared ordeal.

text.Megaera: I thought that both of our allegiances were to this House, Nyx. It seems I was mistaken. Do you have any idea what sort of pressure I am under here...?

text.Nyx: Use caution with the tone you take with me, Overseer. I am the mother of the Fates, themselves. I do not act by whim or by mistake. Mind your own station, and perform your role. All shall unfold eventually as it must. I like the intervening time no more than you.
Mmm.

text.Megaera: ...Nyx, you'd tell me if I made a terrible mistake, or even just a bad one, wouldn't you? I need your guidance on this one, or maybe your approval.

text.Nyx: You shall always be the best determiner of what is right about such matters, Megaera. Though, if you seek my blessings or encouragement in this particular pursuit, please rest assured... you have them both. You know the way, from here.

text.Megaera: I hope that you are right. You always have been, it's just that... I wish I had your confidence in this.

text.Nyx: I do know where to find you, Megaera.

text.Megaera: ...I think I understand, now, Nyx. You've been here longer than the rest of us combined. You've seen this House go through a lot. Even before Lord Hades took his place. I never should have doubted you.

text.Nyx: To doubt is an important instinct, Megaera. Without it, we could not conceive of better circumstances than the ones we know. Besides... I am the Night. Others shall always doubt me. You may doubt me again. I ask only that you heed well your intuitions, from now on.

text.Megaera: I will. I promise, Nyx. And if there's anything you ever need that I can do, well... please, just ask of me.
I understand.
...They can't be reasoned with, Nyx. You know that. What use are they to us, trying to manage this? They'll make things worse.

text.Nyx: They are your sisters. They are part of your life, whether you like it or not. Your relationship with them is yours to mold.

text.Megaera: I'm afraid there isn't much for me to work with. You have a lot more faith in them than I do.

text.Nyx: I have a lot more faith in you, Megaera. There are many obstinate personalities with whom we regularly interact. Thus, we do what is possible.

text.Megaera: ...Would you look at that, Hypnos. Care to repeat to me the unsolicited advice you just now offered, now that Zagreus is here?

text.Hypnos: Oh, hahaha, well, it is my custom to give pointers to our visitors, who come involuntarily, because, I do pick up a lot of bits and pieces, talking here to everyone! About, you know... dying?
