Fight like my friend here used to fight, stranger.

First a visit from Achilles, and now you.
Please stay as long as you would like here in our little glade.

text.Zagreus: Hey, look, I can tell you're struggling right now, and... maybe this isn't the way to help you through it all, but... I want you to have this.

text.Patroclus: Ahh, so you are taking pity on me, then? Well, I've no pride like many others here, so I shall take it. Though, let's make it a fair exchange, shall we?
Why would you waste a proper vintage on the likes of me? Questions that are better left unanswered, I would guess.

text.Zagreus: If this eases your burden even for a little while, then it's in good hands, as far as I'm concerned.

text.Patroclus: Ah, a means to drown my sorrows temporarily. That's good. And rather kind of you, I have to say.

text.Zagreus: It's nothing. Thank you for not trying to slay me where I stand and boast about it, like seemingly everyone else around here.

text.Patroclus: Oh. Here in Elysium you have to win this stuff, so I have rarely had occasion to enjoy it. Thanks.

text.Zagreus: I'd say you earned it more than anybody else I've seen around here, lately. Though I don't make the rules.

text.Patroclus: You owe me neither time nor generosity, and certainly not this. But if you truly have no better use for it...

text.Zagreus: It's not a matter of owe, sir. Please open your mind to the possibility, nay the fact, that there are those who care about your wellbeing.

text.Patroclus: Just the relief from misery that I was looking for. A fleeting feeling, really, but I'll take a fleeting feeling over none.

text.Zagreus: That's both very dejected and very astute of you to say. Take care of yourself, will you?
Here, sir. The drink of the gods, themselves. Thought maybe you would like to try it! Just a small token of my appreciation for your selflessness with me, time after time.

text.Patroclus: You'd give the precious gift of Ambrosia to someone like me, stranger? A gloried thing like that. Why bother...? I should be just another shade to you.

text.Zagreus: Well, you're not. You're someone I look forward to seeing here in Elysium, which is more than I can say for just about anybody else around here, so... please, enjoy it. Perhaps with Achilles.

text.Patroclus: Well... perhaps I'll try. You're not so bad, you know that, stranger? Careful with that, or you'll undermine the ruthless reputation that you have.

text.Zagreus: I don't see that last bottle of Ambrosia anywhere, which I can only take to mean... you need another. Here, sir. Thanks for seeing me through all of this, time after time.

text.Patroclus: You're thanking me, stranger? I've been here for some time, I think, and yet... some of your customs I'll admit remain quite strange to me. You've done more for me than I've any right to expect, from anyone.

text.Zagreus: It's just a bottle of Ambrosia, sir, it's really no big deal. OK, fine, it's rather difficult to come by, but still!

text.Patroclus: You jest, but I do not. I'd offer you my lifelong gratitude, but... well, you know.

text.Zagreus: You've got the rest of your life ahead of you, as far as I'm concerned. Here's to starting anew, right? You can call me Zagreus, or stranger, whatever suits you.

text.Patroclus: And... I'm Patroclus, by the way. I'm realizing now... we've not officially met. It's good to know you, Zagreus. Stranger.
You're much too kind to such a wretched shade, you know. But I'll not turn away this type of thing.

text.Zagreus: You don't attack me indiscriminately, I give you Nectar. I don't think I'm being over-generous!

text.Patroclus: Forgive my bluntness, but, why go out of your way for me like this...?

text.Zagreus: I'm not going out of my way, sir. Look, I don't pretend to know the depths of your despair. But when I look at you, I'm reminded of how I've often felt. When I was in that dark place, someone said to me: Don't give up. If nothing else... it gives you something to do.
I am most grateful to you, sir.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Just checking up on you, sir.

CHOICE.Patroclus: Makes little difference I should think.
It's all the same to me.
I doubt it'll be of much help.

text.Eurydice: Hey, you must be the Hades kid! How's it going, then, Your Royal Majesty? Nice to meet you, I'm Eurydice. What brings a big important guy like you up to a place like this?

text.Zagreus: Hi there! No need for formalities, I'm Zagreus. Just heading out on some official business! Surveying the magma situation firsthand. Don't mean to be rude, though I'm in a bit of a rush.

text.Eurydice: Well don't you have your hands full, hon! I'll let you go, but there's one rule in my place, which is: Nobody leaves here empty-handed, you got that? So take your pick, my treat!
Hey you must be the Hades kid! How's it going, then, Your Royal Majesty? Nice to meet you, I'm Eurydice. What brings a big important guy like you up to a place like this?

text.Zagreus: Hi there! No need for formalities, I'm Zagreus. Just heading out on some official business. Past the menacing Bone Hydra. Don't mean to be rude, though I'm in a bit of a rush.

text.Eurydice: Well don't you have your hands full, hon! I'll let you go, but there's one rule in my place, which is: Nobody leaves here empty-handed, you got that? So take your pick, my treat!
Hey you must be the Hades kid! How's it going, then, Your Royal Majesty? Nice to meet you, I'm Eurydice. What brings a big important guy like you up to a place like this?

text.Zagreus: Hi there! No need for formalities, I'm Zagreus. Just heading out on some official business. Say, if your name's Eurydice, I don't suppose you know an Orpheus, do you? Quite musically inclined, a little dour, impressive hair?

text.Eurydice: He put you up to this? Look, hon, why don't you get on with your business, then. But you can't leave empty-handed, that's the rule, so take your pick, my treat! Nothing for him, though.
Hey, hon, what's going on, speak up! I know when something's up down to my roots, and something's up.

text.Zagreus: Well it's just, I think that you may know an Orpheus, don't you? Quite musically inclined, a little dour, impressive hair? He's court musician in my father's house. Calls you his muse. Says he misses you terribly. I... thought you should know.

text.Eurydice: Orpheus said all that, huh? Tell you what, the next time you run into him, you ask him about the time that he came all this way to try and save me, even though I was already dead. Can you guess how that turned out?

text.Zagreus: Erm... yes, I do believe I can. Look, I didn't mean to upset you.

text.Eurydice: Yeah, well, neither did he! But you know what? Actions beat intentions, hon. Now, here, how about a treat and you can be on your way.
Hey, hon, what's going on, speak up! I know when something's up down to my roots, and something's up.

text.Zagreus: Well it's just, I think I wanted to tell you more of Orpheus, since... he's court musician in my father's house. Calls you his muse. Says he misses you terribly. I... thought you should know.

text.Eurydice: Orpheus said all that, huh? Tell you what, the next time you run into him, you ask him about the time that he came all this way to try and save me, even though I was already dead. Can you guess how that turned out?

text.Zagreus: Erm... yes, I do believe I can. Look, I didn't mean to upset you.

text.Eurydice: Yeah, well, neither did he! But you know what? Actions beat intentions, hon. Now, here, how about a treat and you can be on your way.
What is it, hon? Oh no, don't tell me you've come all the way from Tartarus to ask me more about your good-for-nothing court musician friend.

text.Zagreus: Certainly not! I'm merely here for your wonderful singing, cooking, or conversational ability. Though, since you mentioned it, you... seem to have a lot to say to him. Is there anything I can do?

text.Eurydice: So let me see if I understand. Orpheus blew it with me like an idiot, but now I'm supposed to be reaching out to him? Sorry, hon, but that's not happening. The two of us are finished. And, you know what? I think we're finished here, too. If you'll excuse me!
Hey there, hon! So what do you think, pretty good tune, right? Don't know how come everybody doesn't sing. Lightens the mood, passes the time. What's not to like?

text.Zagreus: It's a beautiful song. Even though you're angry with him... Orpheus, I mean... you're always singing, still?

text.Eurydice: Oh it's not Orpheus' song, you kidding me? This one's all mine. He always did like going on about how I'm his muse, well, that's 'cause I wrote half his songs for him! Bet he didn't mention that, did he.

text.Zagreus: Well, not exactly in those words, but... Orpheus can be a little hard to parse.

text.Eurydice: He can be a little hard to tolerate. A quality I hope isn't going to rub off on any of his mates. I should get back to practicing, see you.

text.Zagreus: Look, Eurydice, I promise not to bother you with this each time, but... you should know your husband's shattered by what happened with the two of you. He's genuinely sorry, and he loves you very deeply, still, I'm sure of it.

text.Eurydice: Tsk... and what am I supposed to do with that, Your Royal Majesty...?

text.Zagreus: I... I don't know yet. Though, you know what? You shouldn't take my word for it. You should take his.

text.Eurydice: Don't think I will be running into him anytime soon from what I understand. But you're the Hades kid! You want to pull some strings on our behalf, go right ahead, I guess. But I won't hold my breath. Even if I could.
So, uh, how's Orpheus been doing lately, anyway? Still keeping his hair in those neat little curls? I guess his tan must have faded by now.

text.Zagreus: Curls? Erm, not exactly, no. But he's doing all right! For him. He's started singing again, lately, which was a big step. He never used to, before. Would go on about how he'd lost his muse.

text.Eurydice: And now he knows I'm out there, still, huh. That's... well, thank you for the update, hon. Music's his gift. Good to know he's not thrown everything away.

text.Zagreus: Eurydice, can I ask you for a favor here? Not that you owe me anything, but, would you hear me out?

text.Eurydice: Yeah, sure, hon, what is it? Though you had better not be asking for my recipes. Closely guarded family secret! I'd say I'd take them to my grave, but... yeah.

text.Zagreus: It's not your recipes, though they are wonderful. It's your song. I'm sure it'd be a hit around the House! And, I know someone who really needs to hear it. Don't suppose you've got a parchment-copy I could have?

text.Eurydice: Your Royal Majesty, you want my song? You are aware it's called 'Good Riddance', right? Tsk, but sure, why not. If music's going to be playing in your House, it might as well be great. And let me give you something to go with it.
...What'd he say, hon? I mean about the song. Bet he loved it, didn't he! But, I don't know for sure. And I've been wondering, kind of a lot, I guess.

text.Zagreus: No need to wonder any longer. He sings it beautifully, around the House sometimes. It... has a sadder sound to it than when you sing, but... you've inspired him again. As you've done many times before, from what I know.

text.Eurydice: Huh. So it's a hit, is what you're saying, then. I had a feeling about that one. Sometimes you put some words together and right then and there, you know that you've got something special.
What happens now, hon...? What I mean is... now you got me thinking about Orpheus again, so... what am I supposed to do with that?

text.Zagreus: Even if you can't be together right now, I hope it feels better knowing how much he cares for you. And I will try to pull some strings, like you said. I can't make promises where my father's concerned, but... I'll do everything I can.

text.Eurydice: Well, what can I tell you? Thanks, Your Royal Majesty. That means a lot. No pressure, though. I've been all right without him all this time, and I will be all right, no matter what. If only he could say the same.
Hey, listen here a moment, Hades kid. Look, I... Thank you. From the bottom of my heart. For bringing Orphy back to me again, and everything.

text.Zagreus: Eurydice, you're more than welcome, really. You've helped me through the flames of hell, time after time. Least I could do is coax old Orpheus out of his private pit of despair so you and he could set things right between the two of you.

text.Eurydice: Well, you're a real sweetheart, hon. You'll still be seeing Orphy all the time around your House, but now, I get to see him, too. Nice having something to look forward to, you know? Bet someone out there feels that about you.
Hey! What's the matter, Your Royal Majesty? You're looking kind of down. Normally you're all smiles, for whatever reason!

text.Zagreus: Oh, I... well, looking back, all this stuff between you and Orpheus, I realized... well, I hope I wasn't too pushy about the whole thing. It wasn't any of my business to pry into your personal life. I should have asked.

text.Eurydice: Oh, that? Pff, come on, don't even worry about it. If you were being too pushy, you better believe I would have put you back in your place, royalty or not. But hey, can't ever be too careful when it comes to people's past and feelings and stuff, right?
Got to tell you, hon. Orpheus sure is different since last he and I met. You know, back when he was still living and breathing and all.

text.Zagreus: I think the experience of trying to rescue you, failing, dying, becoming court musician, refusing to sing, then being locked in solitary confinement, then finding out about you probably did a number on him. Why, is everything all right? You seemed to be getting along last I saw.

text.Eurydice: Oh, we're getting along great! Better than ever. He used to be a bit more of a hotshot, but now it's like, he's a little more... what's the word... sensitive? Now I can always tell exactly what's on his mind.
Hey, Your Royal Majesty! I must say you've accomplished some truly amazing feats, according to Orphy at least! But don't worry. Your secret's safe with me.

text.Zagreus: Oh, no, he's been boasting of my fabricated exploits to you? I've tried to tell him I was only joking with him but now he just thinks I'm being modest.

text.Eurydice: That modesty won't get you anywhere with me, either, hon, Your Greatness. I'm honored to merely be in the presence of one with so many wild exploits to sing or speak of!

text.Zagreus: Hey did Orpheus really use to have curls, and... something called a tan? I've only ever seen him looking... well, how he does now.

text.Eurydice: He did! And a tan is like... well, when you stay out in the hot sun up there long enough, your skin kind of starts to bake a little bit. But nicer than that sounds! Got to say, though, the years have been kind to Orphy, don't you think?

Say, tell me something, there, Your Royal Majesty. You know a lot of shades. You wouldn't happen to know an Orpheus, would you? Spindly little thing, whiny voice? Heard he's officially serving in your court. Making music!

text.Zagreus: Of course I know Orpheus, we're mates! Wait, why do you ask?

text.Eurydice: You're mates, huh. Just as long as you don't count on him for anything. Hasn't even mentioned me, has he. Well if he ever does, you tell him I am doing great! I'm great.
What's the latest, hon, anything been happening down in your fancy House lately?

text.Zagreus: Well, you mentioned Orpheus... my father had him locked up for a little while for refusing to sing. Being court musician and all. But he's out now, and doing OK! I think.

text.Eurydice: Not following instructions, huh. Sounds like Orpheus, all right. Well, if that's the most exciting thing you've got going on, then I haven't missed much being out here.
Hey, what's up, hon? Say, you must know a lot of big shots, don't you? Other gods and all that?

text.Zagreus: I know a few. As a matter of fact, I heard recently from Hermes, wanted you to know he felt sorry for how things ended up. That something to do with when Orpheus went in here after you?

text.Eurydice: Oh, that's sweet of him! Nice enough guy, for an Olympian. Yeah, he was the one who dropped me off here in the first place. No hard feelings here, he was just doing his job. It was Orpheus who messed everything up.
Sure don't see a lot of other nymphs around here, huh! We don't die too easy, most of us. Makes me feel all special!

text.Zagreus: I've never met another nymph, now that you mention it. Heard of a few! The goddess Artemis, sounds like she spends more time with nymphs than the other Olympians.

text.Eurydice: That's what I heard! Though it's not like we all hang out, I mean, you've got the dryads, and the naiads, and the nereids, and the oceanids... pretty much every type of terrain up top, there's a kind of nymph who loves it! Maybe we need a name for Underworld nymphs, too.

text.Zagreus: Eurydice, did you by any chance ever meet a Persephone during the whole thing when Orpheus came down to try to get you?

text.Eurydice: Oh, her? Yeah, she was with Hades Senior, why? Wait. Whoa. Are you...? I thought...

text.Zagreus: It's complicated. And, please keep it quiet. I was just wondering... what was she like? If you recall.

text.Eurydice: Didn't get much of an impression, but I can tell you this: She had good taste in music! Orpheus and I, think we won her over with our little duet. Haven't seen or heard from her lately, though. Look, I hope everything's OK.

text.Zagreus: Eurydice, did you by any chance ever meet a Persephone during the whole thing when Orpheus came down to try to get you?

text.Eurydice: Oh, her? Yeah, she was with Hades Senior, why? Wait. Whoa. Are you...? I thought...

text.Zagreus: It's complicated. And, please keep it quiet. I was just wondering... what was she like? If you recall.

text.Eurydice: Didn't get much of an impression, but I can tell you this: She had good taste in music! Orpheus and I, think we won her over with our little duet. Haven't seen or heard from her lately, though.
Hey, everybody's saying Persephone... she's back? That sounds like a bit of good news, there, isn't that right, hon?

text.Zagreus: Hey, she is back, and yes, it is good news, thank you. She and I have a lot of making up for lost time left to do, though I think we're off to a pretty decent start.

text.Eurydice: Well, that's a relief. And, you're still here! So I guess you've got more official business to take care of, which means I've still got somebody to taste-test for me every now and then!
Orphy tells me the Queen, she's been settling in just fine down at your House! Must be different having a lady like that around. How's Hades Senior taking it, if I may ask?

text.Zagreus: Oh, he's taking it... about as well as he's taken anything ever, now that you mention it. Still very much himself, mind you, but still... it's been a welcome change.

text.Eurydice: Glad to hear it! Orphy always liked singing for an audience more than I did, and it sounds like she's a good one.
You ever play any music, or sing or anything yourself, Hades kid? It's good for you, you know!

text.Zagreus: I play a bit of the lyre, as a matter of fact! Orpheus himself gave me some pointers on it. Never really tried singing, though. I can't even imagine it, really.

text.Eurydice: Well, might I recommend giving it a shot at some point? Who knows, you might be the next Orpheus!
You been snacking on onions or something, there, hon? No offense or anything, but you smell like you ate a whole one of them raw.

text.Zagreus: Erm, yes, but... wait. How else are you supposed to eat those things?

text.Eurydice: What, are you kidding me? You can grill them, saut them, fry them, boil them, pickle them, roast them! Oh, hon. You've been missing out.
You got anyone special in your life, by the way, hon? You seem like you'd be good for somebody out here.

text.Zagreus: You know what, yes, I do, Eurydice. Things have moved so fast for me lately I barely stopped to think about it, though. It helps not having to go through everything alone... just knowing I'll see them again soon.

text.Eurydice: Know what you mean. And hey, that's great! Long as you can still be yourself. I've known too many nymphs, their whole lives revolved around somebody they loved. I bet whoever it is that loves you... it's because of who you are.

text.Zagreus: Eurydice, how long have you been down here, anyway, if you don't mind my asking? Seems like you're pretty settled in. It's quite a lovely place!

text.Eurydice: How long have I been down here, hon? Huh! I don't have the faintest. You lose your sense of time once you're a shade, or maybe once there's not a sun or moon over your head. But yeah, I found myself a decent spot and fixed it up a bit!
You're just in time, Your Royal Majesty! Got something real good cooking right here that you are going to love. You hungry, yeah?

text.Zagreus: Am I ever. You're always so generous. And you're always cooking! And singing. Do you have many guests come by? Your place seems... somewhat off the beaten path.

text.Eurydice: What, you think I get a lot of guests, here? Haha, no, but I like cooking anyway! It's like singing, in a way. Keep getting better the more you try, turns out a bit different each time.

text.Zagreus: Eurydice, how can you cook so much with all the searing heat around these parts? Has it been magma-flooded like this all the time?

text.Eurydice: The searing heat? Haha, I am dead, Your Royal Majesty! Searing's just a cooking technique to me. Don't need to sleep, either! I can just keep cooking up a storm. It's not so bad!

text.Zagreus: You know, I've never met a nymph before. You're closer to the gods than mortals, right?

text.Eurydice: Yeah, gods that can die! How is that fair? Was just a stupid snake bite in my case, can you imagine something more embarrassing? You're just minding your business, and then snap! You're dead, and on your way down here.

text.Zagreus: I... know the feeling better than you might expect.

text.Eurydice: Well, I was going to end up here sooner or later. Might as well while I'm still looking good. Though, I guess you do kind of get to lock in whatever age when you register. Bet everybody dying of old age pushed that one through.
What's your official business, anyway, Your Royal Majesty? Seems like it's bringing you through Asphodel an awful lot lately.

text.Zagreus: It's... look, the truth is, I am trying to get out of here. I've hit some stumbling blocks along the way, but, I think I will make it there, eventually.

text.Eurydice: Oh really! Say no more, I know how that is. Hope the Fates will look the other way for you. Getting out of here, huh. Not thought of that myself in I don't know how long...
Of all the lava rocks in Asphodel, the Hades kid found this one once again, wouldn't you know! You got a map or something to this place, or what?

text.Zagreus: Don't know that a map would help me much since things keep shifting out here every single time. Though it is an interesting coincidence how I keep running into you.

text.Eurydice: Coincidence? Come on, hon, you're a god. Someone out there is sending you my way. Maybe it's just the Fates. Ah well! I sure don't mind a little company. And I have lots to eat!

text.Zagreus: RequiresMaxKeepsake  true,

text.Eurydice: Oh, not just any plants, hon! Trees! Big gnarled oaks and things. Some of them live hundreds of years! Way up there as mortals go. You take good care of it like that, maybe it'll grow to be something special for you, too!

text.Zagreus: Hey, this is sort of a weird question, but... this Evergreen Acorn, it's not... related to you, is it? Since, you know, you're... partly oak, aren't you?

text.Eurydice: Yeah, I'm part oak, that's right. But maybe not the part you're thinking of, I mean, you think I would just hand you one of my babies or something? Hahahaha, that's disgusting!
Hold on, hon, is that... huh! Almost felt like Orpheus was with you there. Would you listen to me? Must have been singing too many high notes, or something.

text.Zagreus: No, wait, you're onto something... I think you must have sensed Orpheus' Distant Memory! He gave it to me as a keepsake of our friendship. Though, something like this... I feel like it should belong to you.

text.Eurydice: Oh, that's him in there all right! See, I never should have second-guessed myself. Well, you hang onto that, as I've got plenty memories of him already, thanks!
Oh, hon, you look awful. What did you get yourself into? Here, one of these should make you feel a little better.
Oh, you look like you've been through a lot, Hades kid. Maybe a decent bite to eat will help!
Oof, you're a mess, there, hon. You save your strength and see if this will do you any good.
Hey, don't go bleeding on my floor, hon. I just cleaned the place! Take one of these, maybe it'll tide you over.
AngleTowardTargetId  514554,
Sing when you're happy, sing when you're not, Your Royal Majesty.
Hey, it's the Hades kid! So what's it going to be this time, Your Royal Majesty?
I'd say make yourself at home, hon, but you look like you got cooler places to be!
You are just in time, Your Royal Majesty! Cooked up something special just for you.
Why, Your Royal Majesty, you're back! Well, see you later!
And here I was just thinking it's been too long since the Hades kid stopped by!
So what'll it be this time, Your Royal Majesty, hmm?
Oh you look positively famished, hon! Here let me help with that.
You must be hungry, hon. Got something ought to keep you going!
How nice of you to stop on by, Your Royal Highness! Here!
How's it going lately, hon, you eating well and everything?
Just singing to myself and cooking up a storm. You know me, hon.
Eat up, hon! Not like I got other mouths to feed!
All's well in Asphodel, Your Royal Majesty! You take care of yourself. I'll be here.
You want the best cooking in all of Asphodel, you know where to go!
Hey, it's the Hades kid! What's it going to be this time, hm?
Take care of yourself out there, all right, Your Royal Majesty?
Don't let Hades Senior get you down, hon. Here.
I know you've got important business to attend to, so thanks for checking in, Your Royal Majesty.
You look like you're in a rush, though there's always time for a quick snack, right?
Hey, welcome back, Your Royal Majesty, you're just in time!
Been trying to perfect these recipes for I don't know how long!
You look like you haven't eaten since you were here last!
You're always welcome here Your Royal Majesty.
I get you something for the road there, hon?
What's it going to be, Your Royal Majesty?
You just be sure to tell that good-for-nothing Orpheus I'm looking good.
Hon, I'd ask how old what's-his-name is doing, but I don't even care!
Bet you Orpheus hasn't had any strokes of musical genius lately, now, has he?
Better not be Orpheus putting you up to visiting here all the time like this.
This song's better than anything Orpheus ever came up with I can tell you that.
If you'll excuse me, Your Royal Majesty, I'm not exactly in the mood for an extended chat.
You best have no more messages from no-good Orpheus this time.
Here, have a snack, hon, and tell Orpheus it was delicious.
You keep an eye on Orpheus for me, all right, hon?
Do one thing for me, hon. Make sure Orpheus knows I'll be right here.
I've got to be honest with you, hon. Sometimes I kind of miss him.
Sometime you'll visit me like this and Orpheus is going to be here too.
Don't let Orpheus get into too much trouble, won't you, hon?
I'm fine here on my own, hon. But, I wouldn't mind if he was here.
Hope Orpheus is on the up-and-up down where you live.
I'd ask you to bring one of these to Orpheus, but they're no good unless they're perfectly fresh.
Orpheus tells me you've been a good friend. Thanks, hon.
I love Orpheus and all, hon, but it's nice having a little time here to myself!
I know you can't stay long, hon, so eat up and stay safe out there, all right?
I sing when Orpheus is here, I sing when he isn't. Simple!

text.Zagreus: Eurydice, thank you for making me feel welcome in your pleasant home. Can't say the same for most places I've been lately. I've a small gift I wanted you to have.

text.Eurydice: Aw, that's awful sweet of you, Your Royal Majesty. Bringing me fresh ingredients like this! Know what, here's something for you, too, help keep you safe out there!
Just the ingredient I needed, hon, thank you so much! You know, you aren't near as bad as I'd heard!

text.Zagreus: Oh, don't worry, we're still getting to know each other! Plenty of time for me to live up to my notorious reputation. Though I'm surprised you've heard of me at all.

text.Eurydice: Aw, for me, really, Your Majesty? This will be perfect for my latest recipes.

text.Zagreus: You know, of all the souls I've ever met, I feel like you put this stuff to the best possible use.

text.Eurydice: You read my mind, hon! I go through this stuff awful fast sometimes.

text.Zagreus: And I, in turn, shall go through your incredible cooking awful fast, given the opportunity.

text.Eurydice: Hey, mighty generous of you to keep me stocked up on this stuff, Your Royal Majesty!

text.Zagreus: My pleasure! I'm always pleased to see you during my otherwise generally unfortunate travels in Asphodel.

text.Eurydice: Thanks, Your Majesty! Though you're not going to get in trouble bringing me this stuff, are you?

text.Zagreus: Hah, no! I don't think I can get into more trouble at the moment. May this make your dishes that much more delectable!
Eurydice, I was thinking maybe this would benefit your culinary practice. Here, please.

text.Eurydice: Whoa, this is Ambrosia! Hard to come by this stuff around here. You sure I can have this?

text.Zagreus: Absolutely! Least I could do for all your friendship and support. Always happy to hear your voice when I'm out here.

text.Eurydice: I ever tell you you're a real sweetheart, hon? Because, if not, I'm telling you right now. Where would my culinary practice be if not for you?

text.Zagreus: I think your culinary practice would be every bit as extraordinary, though I'm pleased to have done small service to you in this great pursuit.

text.Eurydice: Well, we both know you've done a lot more for me than that. I wasn't expecting to make any new friends here anytime soon, so all the more reason it's been a real treat to get to know you. If I may say? You're a hell of a guy, Your Royal Majesty.

text.Zagreus: Thanks so much!

CHOICE.Eurydice: As you wish, Your Royal Majesty.

text.Zagreus: However long... it takes...
Urgh... can't... hold... on...

text.Persephone: Pray, who might you be, wandering all the way out here? You're trespassing on private property, you know. Speak up!

text.Zagreus: Erm, you must be... Persephone. My name is Zagreus, and... I think I might be your son.

text.Persephone: What?! How dare...! Get out of here! Get out, or I shall make you!! Out with you!

text.Zagreus: No!! So then you are her. I, I don't care if you hate me, but I'm not leaving until I get some answers! I never even knew you existed. Why did you leave me?

text.Persephone: You died! You, you died...! Those burning feet, they... sputtered out, when you were born. But... now you're standing here before me. How...?

text.Zagreus: I died? I died... what, you mean permanently died, but, I'm alive! Oh, gods... you never even knew I existed, either.

text.Persephone: Alive! Zagreus, he... even kept your name! You live, how can this be, you live? You live...! Oh, the cruel Fates! My son!

text.Zagreus: time passes

text.Persephone: Ah. He told you that, did he. That's good. That's good! Though, tell me something, Zagreus. How... is it that you found me? To have journeyed all this way, I scarce believe it.... Zagreus?

text.Zagreus: Ugh... Oh, it's... guess I'm just a little tired, that's all. Not accustomed to the weather, as I think you call it.

text.Persephone: No... no, that isn't it, it's that... you cannot stay here. You can't stay here.

text.Zagreus: Really, you're... heh... kicking me out? Why?

text.Persephone: The Fates are cruel, Zagreus. You're bound to that place... same as your father. So they would have us say good-bye, for now. My heart soars, knowing you live. Then it breaks, that our time together was so brief.

text.Zagreus: No... I can... come back... I can come back, now that I found you, he... maybe he'll just let me come back.

text.Persephone: You tell him I demand it. And I demand he also tell me how come he, or for that matter Nyx, never sent notice that you lived! Olympus is all rife with schemers, but I was so naive to think that they were different.

text.Zagreus: I'll tell him... I'll tell him, I... feel awful. I... I have to go.

text.Persephone: The Styx shall take you, then. Oh, Zagreus. Farewell, my son. Won't you come back to me? When you are able, please. Come back. I shall be waiting here. However long it takes.

text.Zagreus: Until we... ungh.

text.Persephone: I begged the Fates that you'd return to me. Perhaps I ought to be more careful how I speak of them. Tell me, how was your journey? What happened?

text.Zagreus: Father didn't make it any easier for me. Nor would he tell me why he never sent for you, after you left. So, I don't know, what's going on, still, but... I wanted to see you, again.

text.Persephone: I wanted to see you, too. Come, speak quickly with me, that our time together here may be as full as possible, all right?

text.Zagreus: I just... I need to know what happened, between you and Father. Why are you here, and not with us?

text.Persephone: I couldn't live with myself anymore, down there. After I left Olympus, a long story in itself, I came to be with your father, in the Underworld. It was a shock, to say the least. The others in your father's house were welcoming enough, but... I never felt that I belonged.

text.Zagreus: I know the feeling, I think. But you stayed. Long enough to have me. Those whom I've spoken to about you, it's as you said, they have fond memories of you. And then, you even had a child. Did Father... did he mistreat you?

text.Persephone: No, no. Your father could be very difficult. Though, he was gentle, with me. Soon enough, we got on fine, better than fine, at times, but... when I was with child... why, I struggled terribly. Because... a child born of surface-dwellers could not live, down there.

text.Zagreus: Could not live down there, according to whom, exactly? The Fates?

text.Persephone: According to them, yes. According to your father, and to Nyx. Even having heard... I took my chances, anyway. But when you emerged stillborn... it was too much. I fled. I fled, and came to reside here. Above the notice of the Underworld. Beneath the notice of Olympus.

text.Zagreus: Urgh... but... why would Father lie to you? If he never wanted you... or never wanted me... surely he had the means.

text.Persephone: I don't know. I'm wondering the same. But, oh, look at you, Zagreus! We're running out of time. It's happening again! Stay with me, please?

text.Zagreus: ...I'm trying... but I can't... stay that much longer... I don't think.

text.Persephone: Oh, my dear son! Then please... ask Hades what you asked of me! Why he would lie? Tell him I must know, the same as you. And you farewell. Until we meet again!

text.Zagreus: It's just... a hunch... of mine...
I'll... be... back...
Mother, I... discovered how come Father led you to believe that I could not survive past birth. He didn't lie to you, exactly. So he says.

text.Persephone: Wait, slow down, Zagreus, what do you mean? He told me you would not survive your birth, yet here you are. How wasn't that a lie?

text.Zagreus: Because... he thought it was the truth. The Fates appointed him dominion over the entire Underworld. But he would never have an heir, so he was led to understand. He never expected me to be born, much less survive.

text.Persephone: He never expected you to survive? Then, forgive my asking, but... why did you? How did you? The Fates are not known for making mistakes when it comes to such things.

text.Zagreus: Nyx saved my life. Or gave me life, I guess. Then raised me in your absence. The Fates are her daughters, right? Maybe she persuaded them to go easier on me. She cannot say more. In any case, apparently it took her quite a while to revive me, and... by then, you were gone.

text.Persephone: Nyx... of course she was involved. I only managed to escape because of her. Then, she restored my stillborn son to life, and nurtured him? And, I never would have known, unless that child, fully grown and having learned the truth, defied his father, and then found me here?

text.Zagreus: Yes. Although, we still don't know how come Father and Nyx never sent for you. Though, ungh, let me ask you something, Mother, if you please. If you had found out... that I was born, and very much alive... would you have come back?

text.Persephone: Would I have come back... to see my only child? Had I but known you lived... I would have gladly gone through hell again to see you, Zagreus. Of course I would have.

text.Zagreus: Well then... what if... urgh... what if Father... didn't want you... doing that?

text.Persephone: What if he didn't want me coming back to him? Or seeing you? Oh no, you're fading again, Zagreus. You've pushed yourself too hard! But what is it you meant, by what you said?

text.Zagreus: I... I won't be long...
Urgh... mmm... ungh...

text.Persephone: So good to see you, again, Zagreus. Since last you left, I couldn't help but think the worst, about what happened after I had left... or soon before. You mentioned Nyx... you don't suppose that she and Hades... wanted me out of the way?

text.Zagreus: I just... don't think that can be. Though, let me ask you. How long did you know Father? And Nyx, for that matter? Did they seem trustworthy?

text.Persephone: Yes. I knew them long enough to have decided yes, that they were trustworthy. As much as anyone I've ever met. But I also know never to be trusting to a fault. I have to consider the possibility I was deceived.

text.Zagreus: Especially since neither of them is being forthcoming with me even now, right? And yet, I have this feeling something else is going on, Mother. The way that Father speaks of you, the way Nyx speaks of you... I think... they care for you.

text.Persephone: Ah, hahaha! Well, they have a funny way of showing it, I think. Your father, so... you have to get through him each time you visit me?

text.Zagreus: I do. Mother, what if... what if Father thinks that he's protecting you? Have you... considered that?

text.Persephone: Protecting me? Why Zagreus, what do you mean by that? As you can see, I can fend for myself.

text.Zagreus: Well... urgh... you're from Olympus, aren't you? But... the gods, none of them seem to know... you're here... so...

text.Persephone: What, how would you know something like that? Zagreus? Ah, curse the Fates, you're leaving me again...

text.Zagreus: When I... return...
Khh... uhhh... urgh...

text.Persephone: Son, I have to ask you, how much do you know about your relatives upon Olympus?

text.Zagreus: I think I know quite a bit by now. I've been in steady contact with Athena, Zeus, and other members of the family ever since I first left Father's House... they've been assisting me in getting here.

text.Persephone: No... Zagreus, what have you done? You've led them here?

text.Zagreus: No, no, they think... they think I'm trying to escape from Father so that I can join them on their mountaintop. At least I think that's what they think. Most of them, anyway.

text.Persephone: But then... does Hades know of this? That Olympus is involved?

text.Zagreus: He does. Both he and Nyx. In fact, it's Nyx who put me and Olympus into contact. I could never have broken free of the Underworld if not for their help.

text.Persephone: So Nyx and Hades are against each other, then. And Olympus is helping you... but they don't know I'm here, as far as you're aware?

text.Zagreus: That's right. More or less. Nyx and Father seem to put up with each other. Don't seem to have much of a choice. Though, ever since I learned of you, Nyx has been helping me to find you... while Father's tried to stop me.

text.Persephone: That fool... what was he thinking? What is he thinking...? Do you suppose... he thinks that he's protecting me from them? Oh, no...

text.Zagreus: I... urgh... I think maybe he does think so, indeed... because, now having met my relatives upon Olympus, I... can definitely see that they can be a bit... vindictive about things.

text.Persephone: Vindictiveness runs in the family, my son. Then, if Olympus is involved, that would explain a lot. I'm here, not there with them, as you can see. But, oh, it seems we'll have to speak some more, when next you return...

text.Zagreus: When I... return...
Khh... uhhh... urgh...

text.Persephone: Son, I have to ask you, how much do you know about your relatives upon Olympus?

text.Zagreus: A little. I've been in contact with Athena, Zeus, and other members of the family ever since I first left Father's House... they've been assisting me in getting here.

text.Persephone: No... Zagreus, what have you done? You've led them here?

text.Zagreus: No, no, they think... they think I'm trying to escape from Father so that I can join them on their mountaintop. At least I think that's what they think. Most of them, anyway.

text.Persephone: But then... does Hades know of this? That Olympus is involved?

text.Zagreus: He does. Both he and Nyx. In fact, it's Nyx who put me and Olympus into contact. I could never have broken free of the Underworld if not for their help.

text.Persephone: So Nyx and Hades are against each other, then. And Olympus is helping you... but they don't know I'm here, as far as you're aware?

text.Zagreus: That's right. More or less. Nyx and Father seem to put up with each other. Don't seem to have much of a choice. Though, ever since I learned of you, Nyx has been helping me to find you... while Father's tried to stop me.

text.Persephone: That fool... what was he thinking? What is he thinking...? Do you suppose... he thinks that he's protecting me from them? Oh, no...

text.Zagreus: I... urgh... I think maybe he does think so, indeed... because, now having met my relatives upon Olympus, I... can definitely see that they can be a bit... vindictive about things.

text.Persephone: Vindictiveness runs in the family, my son. Then, if Olympus is involved, that would explain a lot. I'm here, not there with them, as you can see. But, oh, it seems we'll have to speak some more, when next you return...

text.Zagreus: No... what have I done...
Grr... I... can't...

text.Persephone: I could not stand it on Olympus, Zagreus. The blustering, the posturing... my overbearing mother... none of it. I would have left the mountain voluntarily, except...

text.Zagreus: ...Except Father absconded with you, didn't he? Dragged you down with him into the Underworld. So if Olympus were to find that out... I shudder to think of the consequences.

text.Persephone: That fool is trying to protect me even now. It wasn't he who absconded with me, my son. And it's more complicated even than that. I was content to leave. Willing to make my life within the Underworld. With your father.

text.Zagreus: I dare not ask who did bring you to Father, then. So, essentially, you ran away from home, to live with him? I mean no disrespect, but... did you realize what you were getting yourself into?

text.Persephone: We have a tendency to be impetuous when we are younger, Zagreus. I'd heard all about your father before we met. Admired paintings of him. It was very awkward, at first. But he had a bluntness I fancied. A sense of principle. I much preferred him to his brothers, I can tell you that.

text.Zagreus: So, urgh... then you secretly left Mount Olympus to be with the god of the dead in the Underworld. And Olympus never found out. What do you suppose would happen... if they did?

text.Persephone: ...I think... there would be war between Olympus and your father, Zagreus, if they found out. Especially now. After all this. And after all this time. They slew their parents once. If the Titans could be wiped from this world, so can we all.

text.Zagreus: So it makes sense... if Father, he agrees with you, and thinks... that leaving you in hiding here, that it's the only way... he can prevent that war...

text.Persephone: I can see how your father, shrewd but also single-minded as he was, might have followed such a line of reasoning as that. Oh, Zagreus... what have I done?

text.Zagreus: Mother... I... blast...!

text.Persephone: Goodbye...!
Zagreus... it's wonderful to see you, but... I need to ask something of you. That you not visit me again, here in this place. Both for your safety, and for mine.

text.Zagreus: Wait, what? Because of what would happen if the Olympians found out? So, after everything, you're taking Father's side in all of this?!

text.Persephone: I am. Your father is no fool when it comes to matters such as this. Besides... all that has happened... it's my fault. I was selfish! And now both sides of our family threaten to be torn apart.

text.Zagreus: Your fault? So let's say you never left Olympus! Then it'd be just like you thought, until quite recently, I think. That I'd never existed! Besides, they haven't found out any of this. What makes you so sure they will, all the sudden?

text.Persephone: Nyx may be veiling you from them as she veiled me when I fled here myself. But even her own powers aren't infallible. Each time you visit me, you are incurring risk. One small slip, and they shall find me. Discover your deception. Go home, Zagreus. Please.

text.Zagreus: Go home with me, Mother! You came here under false pretenses. I haven't fought all this way, over and over again, only to turn back now. I need you in my life! How can you just... turn me away like this?

text.Persephone: Oh, Zagreus... I cannot return. After all that happened between Hades and me, and everyone, I just cannot fathom the idea. Besides... the risks we're taking would be even greater if Olympus were to find me there, with him. And you.

text.Zagreus: Then... ungh... you're just... going to stay here? Alone, in the middle of nowhere, in this little garden... forever? After we part ways, just like that?

text.Persephone: My son... I know you've made hard choices and sacrifices to be here with me. And I'm forever grateful to have finally met you. But this is my home, now, yes. While your home is below. Please, if not for your sake, then for mine... do not return. I love you, Zagreus. Good-bye.

text.Zagreus: We... have to...
No... not... yet...
You can't do this to me, Mother. You said Father is no fool, and neither are you. There has to be a way to fix this. Not just with you and Father, but with everyone. There has to be a way!

text.Persephone: ...You have your father's stubbornness. Listen to me. You're endangering everything you care about by coming here. Don't you understand? Besides...

text.Zagreus: What? Besides what? Tell me, please.

text.Persephone: ...The truth is that I like it here, Zagreus. I have done well for myself on my own. And your father, he has his domain to look after. The feelings he once had for me... feelings we shared... they fade, with time. You'll understand, someday.

text.Zagreus: No! I won't be understanding anything of the sort. Father still loves you. I'm sure of it! And, he owes you an apology, damn it! I cannot make amends with you on his behalf. It's something only you can do together.

text.Persephone: What do you mean he still loves me, Zagreus...? How would you know?

text.Zagreus: Because... ungh... I'm his blasted son, that's how I know! But trust me isn't ever good enough, I know that, too. I'll prove it to you, Mother! Just you wait and see.

text.Persephone: You're fading, Son... you don't need to prove anything to me. Please don't do anything rash. All of us made our choices. Now we have to live with them. Isn't it enough, to know that I am safe? That I'm content to be alone?

text.Zagreus: No... urgh... it's not... it's not enough, for me, because... this blasted family... it cannot just keep hiding from its problems! Running from them! We're stuck with one another, we... we have to do everything we can... for one another!

text.Persephone: I... oh, my dear boy...

text.Zagreus: But... you are... the Queen...!
Mmph... rrkh... ungh...

text.Persephone: ...Of everything down in that gloomy House, I miss old Cerberus the most, I think. But, I miss other things as well. The lack of light was gentler on my skin. Not being as cold. And Nyx, and her young sons. It was all very odd, but...

text.Zagreus: Mother... in Father's bedchambers... mind you, there's almost nothing there, just neatly sorted rows of all his samey capes... but on his nightstand... is a portrait of you. Wearing a regal crown of red laurels. A Queen. His Queen.

text.Persephone: I was fitted for those garments when I first arrived. They... were not my customary style. So Hades has a portrait of me, still. Why would he put it back on display, now?

text.Zagreus: No, no, he's never let anybody in his bedchambers! I broke in. Don't you see? He didn't put your portrait back on display. It's always been there! Ever since you left. So, Mother, why do you suppose he would do that?

text.Persephone: Because he... because he loves me still. Is that what you want me to say?

text.Zagreus: Have you ever loved him, yourself?

text.Persephone: All I really wanted was to leave Olympus. I didn't exactly abscond. I doubt I had much of a choice, but I went willingly. Perhaps Zeus knew how I felt, and thought he was doing me a favor. As for Hades... I grew to love him, yes. He always gave me my space.

text.Zagreus: Won't you... urgh... won't you please talk to him? Or visit Cerberus again, or Nyx? As for Olympus... surely all of you... can figure something out...?

text.Persephone: ...I just don't know, my son. Olympus is behind me. And the Underworld... I cannot imagine I would be very welcome there after all this time.

text.Zagreus: Mother, wait, what is all this?

text.Persephone: Oh, Zagreus, I almost missed you. Truthfully, I hoped that I could make it a surprise...

text.Zagreus: Make what a surprise?

text.Persephone: My arrival. I'm going. To your home. To Cerberus. Nyx. Your father.

text.Zagreus: You're... really?! Mother, you, you're serious?

text.Persephone: I am. Now if you could just help me pack up my remaining things? Only a few loose odds I'm bringing, just in case. If we hurry, maybe you could join me, rather than return the customary way. Not something a mother ever wants to see.

text.Zagreus: Join you, but... wait, how are you going to get back? I... hadn't thought that far ahead.

text.Persephone: Pan to Charon
Doubtless he has pressing matters to attend to. So let's not keep him waiting any longer, Son. Come on, then!,

text.Zagreus: Load Return01

text.Persephone: You're on the River Styx. No longer in the mortal realm, entirely.

text.Zagreus: I can't believe that this is happening.

text.Persephone: I know. My heart is racing. Nothing like a river journey to remind oneself that there's no turning back.

text.Zagreus: Seriously. Though, even after all of this... it's like we only just met. I have so many questions for you still.

text.Persephone: We'll have plenty of time for them, I think! For now, best we keep quiet. Pretend we're just a couple of dead souls on their final voyage.,

text.Zagreus: This is embarrassing, but... I don't know the way to get back in. Except, you know, the customary way.

text.Persephone: That's quite all right; I do. In the name of Persephone, the Queen!! Open the gates!
Indeed.

text.Zagreus: How has it been for you so far, Mother? Reacclimating to all this. You said before it was a struggle. Must be very strange, being back. Being in darkness all the time.

text.Persephone: You know, I think it's gone all right so far! Thank you for asking, Son. Everyone has been quite welcoming. The darkness is a pleasant change of pace, and while this dress can be a little difficult to move in... I quite like it.

text.Zagreus: That's good to hear. I have to admit I was a little worried you'd be desperate to return to your cottage by now. This place can be a little much.

text.Persephone: I'm sure it can. And I do miss my little cottage here and there, but... I think I'm through running away. There may be times when it is necessary, of course. But no matter how far you run, it doesn't make your problems go away. You taught me that, you know.

text.Zagreus: I did? But... I tried desperately to run away, myself.... Oh.
Never! Kidding. Of course.

text.Persephone: Turns out there's still an awful lot to do around here, isn't there, Zagreus? I'm still getting caught up on day-to-day affairs.

text.Zagreus: Day-to-day, how can you even tell it's day around here, anyway, Mother?

text.Persephone: Well that was just a guess, now that you mention it. In any case, forgive me if I don't get swooped up in every household detail, all right?

text.Zagreus: I like them, too.
So, Mother, all the pomegranates around here... those are your doing?

text.Persephone: Not a lot of fruit trees take to this environment, my son. Though, there's something about pomegranates! Maybe it's that their seeds so resemble the gemstones your father likes so much. Or that they don't need much water.

text.Zagreus: ...Fruit trees, huh. I grew up around all these poms and never thought much of it. Are there many other types of fruit trees on the surface, then?

text.Persephone: Well... I suppose there are a few. But I like pomegranates most of all.

text.Zagreus: Sounds good.
This garden isn't quite the sight yours was back on the surface, is it, Mother.

text.Persephone: On the contrary, Zagreus! It has its own unique charm. As each garden does. I was impressed it wasn't left entirely to rot after my absence.

text.Zagreus: It was totally off limits to me. Though I guess Father must have taken care to maintain it as best he could.

text.Persephone: He did, all right. Minus the part where you weren't allowed. Though, let's look after it from here, shall we?

text.Zagreus: Still can't believe he let me hold his spear.
You know, that painting in Father's... I mean your bedchambers, it turned out rather well, didn't it? Some very talented shades around here.

text.Persephone: Oh, it's beautiful! I tried to persuade your father to hang it out in the hall but he's too coy about such things. Though, I like it where it is... a reminder to us, every day and night.

text.Zagreus: <Inhale> And it smells fresh, too!

text.Persephone: This garden may not have all the varieties available up on the surface... though it's coming along rather nicely, I should say!

text.Zagreus: Cheers, I'm glad you like it!

text.Persephone: It's lovely what you've done to this place, Zagreus! It's looking better than ever, thank you.

text.Zagreus: I will. Thank you, Mother.

text.Persephone: Were you able to make it to my cottage on the surface, Zagreus? I hope my lavender patches are doing all right.

text.Zagreus: I, erm... I couldn't make it all the way there, Mother. It's like... without your presence on the surface, I'm unable to hang on for very long at all.

text.Persephone: Ah, I was afraid of that. Well, don't despair. I placed a charm upon my seedlings there that ought to keep them flourishing well on their own. Your duty now is simply to escape. You keep it up!

text.Zagreus: Sometimes I think he tried.

text.Persephone: Tell me something, Zagreus... sometimes I fear... do you hate him? I mean your father. Regardless of his intentions... it sounds as though he made your life extraordinarily difficult. All his pent-up fear and anger... you bore the brunt of it.

text.Zagreus: Do I hate him...? Mother, I don't know that I hate anybody, really. The tales of him and the Olympians rending their immortal Titan parents to bits... I can't relate to how they must have felt. But, I resented him, for sure. And... I don't know if I'll ever get over that, entirely.

text.Persephone: I understand. I think that when Hades told you he asked no forgiveness, he understood as well, and meant it. Well, for all his failings, I'm thankful that he did not teach you how to hate. For your own sake, if not for his.

text.Zagreus: Yes. I'm glad for you.

text.Persephone: So, how has it been between you and your father lately, Zagreus? I know the two of you have lots of work ahead of you. Especially him.

text.Zagreus: Well, it's been all right, I guess. I think he's set in some of his ways. But at least we have some sort of understanding now. Even if he acts like everything is still the same when I'm out there on the job.

text.Persephone: He says it's so you put forth your fullest effort every time. All this is a big adjustment for him as well. Not that it's any excuse for how he's treated you. Are you... all right, seeing us together?
Hahaha, no. You're plenty.

text.Zagreus: Erm, so are things with you and Father... everything all right, so far?

text.Persephone: Things are good, Zagreus. I'm from Olympus... all the relationships I've ever known have been the complicated sort. But with your father... despite our different dispositions and interests... beneath it all, we share a simple understanding.

text.Zagreus: And... what understanding is that? If you can share.

text.Persephone: That we're all we've got. And that we love each other. Through thick and thin.

text.Zagreus: Wait, you're not... you're not thinking about having more children, are you...?
I'm sure she did.

text.Persephone: Nyx has a very steady presence, doesn't she? I want to say she hasn't changed a bit since before you were born, but... I know that she's been through a lot.

text.Zagreus: She's always managed, and quite gracefully at that. Never seen her break a sweat over anything. Even when I confronted her about you. Though, you two seem closer than I realized, I think.

text.Persephone: Well, your father isn't always the conversationalist, and Nyx... she was the first chthonic god I ever met. I suppose she welcomed having another lady about the House.

text.Zagreus: Hahaha, it's a deal.

text.Persephone: Zagreus... how am I doing? As a mother. Tell me honestly. Nyx has had so much to share about raising you. Foods you hated or enjoyed, your natural abilities, your friendships... she knows everything! Sometimes I wonder how I can ever compete?

text.Zagreus: Mother, I think you're doing great. And I'm sure you know it's not a competition between you and Nyx. I just get the benefit of having two great mothers rather than one. Or zero.

text.Persephone: Thank you, my son. I know I wasn't there for most of the hard part, but... I'm here, now. Though, when I inevitably, inadvertently trample all over your feelings at some point, please tell me, all right?

text.Zagreus: No idea what a calling card is, but, OK!
Mother, one thing I was wondering about was, how did you summon Charon to your surface residence? Especially without, you know, being dead.

text.Persephone: Oh, why... he gave me his calling card after he graciously helped get me out of here the first time. No doubt at Nyx's request, but still. Never thought I'd use it, but... I still kept it. Just in case.

text.Zagreus: At least we've some of that in us.

text.Persephone: Indeed, my son.

text.Zagreus: Mother, you'll forgive my asking, but... your mother used to call you by a different name, didn't she?

text.Persephone: Ah, don't remind me. Imagine if I called you Zaggie-poo from when you were born to this very moment, that's how that name felt to me. I much preferred the name my father gave to me.

text.Zagreus: Your mortal father, right...? So he called you Persephone. What was he like?

text.Persephone: He was kind to me. And funny! Little bringer of destruction, I was to him. I liked that. He was right, I was a terror. But then he passed. I was very little still. My mother never spoke of him again.

text.Zagreus: Demeter mentioned him a bit to me. She seems... I don't know, but I don't sense that she regrets the relationship or anything. Just sad about the outcome I think.

text.Persephone: I suppose I can see that. I thought I might end up like Father... growing old, wasting away. Then the time flew by, and I realized I was closer to Mother's side. Mortals certainly don't have it easy. But their limited days, it means... they live their lives to the fullest, I think.
We can, and shall.

text.Zagreus: Mother, just how long has it been snowing on the surface, do you know? Because, it seems to me that Demeter... Grandmother, I should say, she... well, it's been very cold up there each time I've been.

text.Persephone: I was afraid of that... I wanted to believe the snow about my cottage, it was native to the climate there, but... seems that Mother took my absence harder than I thought. Oh, what have I done. All those poor people.

text.Zagreus: It's not your fault. You couldn't have known. And we can fix this, right?
Least I could do.

text.Persephone: Nyx told me that you helped her reconnect with her parent... after a long, long time. That was very kind of you. She never asks for anything. But we all owe her a lot, don't we?

text.Zagreus: I think so. If not for her... I can't even imagine, really. Did Nyx ever speak to you of Chaos, before I was born?

text.Persephone: Not really, no. Nyx is very private when it comes to personal matters. But she has feelings and desires same as anybody. Well, mostly, but the point is... I know this meant a lot to her.

text.Zagreus: Thank you. He more than deserved it.

text.Persephone: It seems Achilles had a complicated arrangement with your father. I understand you simplified things for the better, there, and he was able to visit Elysium at last. Well done.

text.Zagreus: I'd no idea.

text.Persephone: So Orpheus was finally able to reunite with Eurydice because of you, my son? Ah, I'm so glad! Your father's arrangement with him was quite severe. Though he did ask for a lot, for a mortal soul to return to the land of the living...

text.Zagreus: Is it even possible, for Father to return a mortal back to life if he so chose? Just by letting their shade escape, or something?

text.Persephone: Oh, I've no idea, probably not? But we were so moved by Orpheus' plea and song, that, well... I think your father took pity on him.

text.Zagreus: Wait, we were so moved? You were there when Orpheus came to try and rescue Eurydice?

text.Persephone: I was. Your father knew I loved their music. Imagine my surprise to see him as our court musician, here!

text.Zagreus: They are. Thank you, Mother.

text.Persephone: I always fancied Thanatos, you know. So put together and everything! I'm pleased to see you've grown so close. Things good between you two?

text.Zagreus: She does. She's great, Mother.

text.Persephone: That Dusa sure has quite the uplifting presence around here, doesn't she, Zagreus? Sometimes I see you chatting and it warms my heart.

text.Zagreus: Urgh... yeah....

text.Persephone: Zagreus, I know you're upset about what happened between Nyx and Dusa. Before you ask... I need to respect Nyx's space and authority on this one, all right?

text.Zagreus: Most definitely, yes.

text.Persephone: I saw that Dusa had returned. I trust Nyx's judgment, though I must admit I was pleased to see she decided to give her another chance.

text.Zagreus: I know what you mean. I'll let you know when it's done.

text.Persephone: All right. We've matters with Olympus to resolve. They don't know I'm here, most of them, besides Zeus, maybe Athena. They think you're Nyx's son rather than mine, and that your goal is still to join them on their mountaintop.

text.Zagreus: What a mess. What can we do? The gods of Olympus have all been very good to me, for the most part. I don't feel great about deceiving them. They keep trying to help me escape!

text.Persephone: What can we do? We can make peace with them. And let them know the truth. So much of it as they would tolerate. Diplomacy is not your father's strong suit. But I am going to need you two to do exactly as I say. Do you understand?

text.Zagreus: Yes, Mother. So what do you intend to do, and how do I fit in?

text.Persephone: We're going to invite all of them to a little family gathering! Here. And you shall personally deliver them their invitations, Zagreus.

text.Zagreus: Mother, are you serious? So, we're just going to have a bash with them, and they'll just see you after all this time, and be fine with everything?

text.Persephone: They certainly shall not be fine with everything. But, Hades and I, we'll be prepared to tell them what they need to hear. Don't worry, I shall do the talking.

text.Zagreus: What are you going to say?

text.Persephone: Oh, you know! That we met, fell in love, eloped. Had a child. A child who, once grown, sought desperately to reconnect with his extended family. To the chagrin of his grim lord father...

text.Zagreus: That's... that's all true. As individual statements, at least.

text.Persephone: ...Fortunately, our loving and dutiful son at last persuaded his mother and father to reveal their secretive relationship, and make an effort to rejoin their great family.

text.Zagreus: Your mother won't be happy that you left.

text.Persephone: I'll deal with her. Perhaps I'll have to visit her and the rest of them from time to time, if that's what it shall take. But I'll be back. I've no choice! Did you know that if you eat the seeds of an Underworld pomegranate, then you cannot leave for one month out of the year, per seed?

text.Zagreus: What? No, I never knew that.

text.Persephone: Neither do they.

text.Zagreus: How soon is this family gathering you have in mind going to take place?

text.Persephone: Soon after you invite them all, I hope. Now, go. And trust in me, all right? We have a lot to learn of trust, I think.

text.Zagreus: You got it, Mother.

text.Persephone: How goes the doling out of invitations, Zagreus? Have the Olympians been amenable to the idea?

text.Zagreus: Not just amenable, Mother. Positively intrigued. I can't believe you scrambled the invitations in such a way that, only with the lot of them combined will they get all of the details!

text.Persephone: A bit of collaboration seemed in the spirit of things. We're a great, big family, Zagreus. Past time we started acting like one, no? Now, keep it up. And thank you for your help.
Mm-hm!

text.Zagreus: Mother, this family gathering you're planning... are all our relatives welcome? Because I was wondering if I could extend the invitation to a distant ancestor... you know... Chaos.

text.Persephone: Nyx's parent... you've been in contact, then? Look, if you feel it's the right thing to do, I trust your judgment. The spirit of this event is to bring the family together.

text.Zagreus: Thanks. I doubt Chaos would be able to attend, though would still appreciate the thought.

text.Persephone: Sounds good. I'll see you then.

text.Zagreus: It's done, Mother! Father. The invitations. Personally sent to everyone with whom I've been in contact. So, what do we do now?

text.Persephone: Excellent, Zagreus! Congratulate him, Hades! On a job well done.

text.Hades: Grr. Persephone, how can you be so certain your request was executed to your satisfaction?

text.Persephone: It's known as trust, Hades. Or faith? They're similar. Try one, sometime! It'll be good for you. As for what we do next... why, we've a great, big feast we must prepare!

text.Hades: This House is not a suitable location for such guests! Dionysus, alone, shall bring ruin to this place! Or... urgh... the faith thing that you said.

text.Persephone: Yes, good! Now then... we have a lot of work to go around, so why don't we call everyone on staff, and let them in on this, and dole out suitable responsibilities, all right?

text.Hades: All right....

text.Zagreus: All right.

text.Persephone: All right!
...Whew! I'd say that went about as well as could have been expected! And the cleanup wasn't all that bad. For the most part.

text.Zagreus: We're fortunate Uncle Zeus seemed to catch on right away, and went along with it. But, this whole elaborate tale you spun... I remember how hurt I felt when I found out Father lied to me about you. Now we're lying to Olympus. What if they find out? Even if they don't... I don't like it.

text.Persephone: Zagreus... I may not be an expert... but here's what I've come to understand about how families work. At least our own. The thing is... how we speak to one another is even more important than the words we use. I think, deep down, everyone in our family knows this.

text.Zagreus: You're saying they all knew you weren't being perfectly honest, and went along with it anyway? I guess the pomegranate thing in particular was a bit of a stretch.

text.Persephone: The common ground in our family is that we want peace. Besides Ares, though even he would rather the conflict occur elsewhere. That elaborate tale... it's less a deception, and more a concession. A way of saying let's move on from the past, and start anew. No hard feelings.

text.Zagreus: You don't have hard feelings? What about Father? What about Demeter?

text.Persephone: Well, let's see. My hard feelings are nothing next to the joy of having my son in my life. Your father never imagined his relationship with me could be out in the open. And my mother... she's just glad I'm alive.

text.Zagreus: And Uncle Zeus is glad things didn't turn out worse for him. I get the sense he acts a bit impulsively at times, and deals with the consequences later.

text.Persephone: What can I tell you, Zagreus? We're family. You said it yourself to me before: We're stuck with one another. That any of us like each other in the slightest... it's a wonder and a blessing, I think.

text.Zagreus: Yeah. I know what you mean. Thanks, Mother. Think I'll be heading out again soon. See you when I get back?

text.Persephone: I'm going to miss you too, Son.

text.Zagreus: I have to say, Mother, that was a clever plan. Convincing Father to finally let somebody have some fun around here.

text.Persephone: Haha, well! I'm glad it worked out for the best. There's just one thing that happened that I ought to tell you about, Son. No secrets between us, and all. This... is quite difficult for me to say.

text.Zagreus: It's about Demeter, isn't it. You two were talking half the night. She wants you to come home with her, doesn't she? You'll always be her little one, something like that?

text.Persephone: Indeed... something like that. You're quite perceptive, have I ever told you, Zagreus? But yes, my mother, she was quite conflicted. Didn't know whether to smite me or to hold me, maybe both. And, yes. She asked that I come home... to my responsibilities.

text.Zagreus: So... you're leaving...? No, Mother, you can't be leaving, you just got here!

text.Persephone: Oh, it's not as bad as that, it's just... if we are to keep the peace down here, then, I must spend some time up there. Every so often! But, I shall always return, in no time at all. I promised Hades, and I promise you.

text.Zagreus: Well then... when are you going to go?

text.Persephone: Soon, Zagreus. Perhaps by the time you're back.

text.Zagreus: I don't suppose... I can come with you, can I?

text.Persephone: Tsk, you know the surface isn't good for you! Besides, you're needed here. But, if you really want to see it for yourself, someday, who knows? Perhaps eventually we'll figure out a way.

text.Zagreus: I'm going to miss you, Mother.
At least she forgave.
Welcome home, Mother! How was your trip, things go all right with you and Demeter? With... Grandmother. Still getting used to thinking of her that way.

text.Persephone: You know, it's funny... I think she was so overwhelmed to see me again that maybe something finally changed in her. I always thought she was utterly unyielding. She asked me if I truly came here by choice, and I put her at ease.

text.Zagreus: Ah, that's a relief. Grandmother can be rather intense, but... she's been kind to me, and very helpful, too. Do you suppose she'll ease up on the whole eternal winter thing there on the surface, now that she knows you're safe?

text.Persephone: I asked. She told me that she would. Warmth shall return to the surface. Some of the time, at least. Likely on a rigid schedule, knowing her. And perhaps not in the vicinity of our domain. She's not the sort to forgive and simply forget.
Well, we need them.
...Oh, come on, Hades! Mortals are much more resilient than that! What, you think they'll show up at your gates here, all at once? They have our family looking out for them.

text.Hades: That is what I'm afraid of. Do you truly believe my brothers and the rest shall take the sort of care of them while they draw breath, as we do here after they have expired?

text.Persephone: It's true we have to look out for them indefinitely, while Olympus need only look out for them for a little while. But our relatives are always watching from their mountain! And if they do turn a blind eye once in a while... mortals aren't bad at fending for themselves.

text.Hades: But they are never satisfied! Always begging us to provide more, and more.

text.Persephone: They like us, Hades! They praise us, tell one another about us. What do you expect? Would you rather they forgot about us?

text.Hades: ...No. No, I suppose not. But they need us!
...He has.
...And what of the complaints from Elysium? They wanted the lawns thoroughly manicured for their athletic contests.

text.Persephone: Already taken care of. Though, the flooding in Asphodel, hm, that doesn't look like something we can clear up for quite some time. Fortunately, the residents seem to be getting accustomed to it.

text.Hades: There have been fewer reports about it as of late. And what of the Satyr problem? Blasted things are rampant up there, still.

text.Persephone: Well, they're probably contained up there, at least. And Zagreus has been keeping them in check, hasn't he?

text.Hades: Our best... that I can promise you.
...Well, be that as it may... if they pester you at all, do let me know, and I shall have them dealt with quickly.

text.Persephone: Oh, Hades... I think the shades around here have been through enough as it is! I don't mind them. After all the time I spent on my own, having some company has been a welcome change.

text.Hades: You are certain all your needs have been provided for? Because if there is anything that you require...

text.Persephone: Require? Look at this place, Hades. Look at me! I have everything! And so do you. Try not to worry quite so much. And be patient with your son. That's all I ask.

text.Hades: Persephone, I cannot promise you such things, they're... not my strengths. Besides, I have a reputation to uphold! God of the dead! If the wretches do not fear me, or you for that matter... what, then?

text.Persephone: I'm not going to tell you how to balance your work, your marriage, and your parental responsibilities. I don't think anybody on Olympus or below knows quite how best to manage that. So long as we do our best.

text.Hades: Indeed.
...Sometimes, I... still cannot believe that you are here. Returned to us. Your radiance, in all this darkness... you must miss seeing the coast.

text.Persephone: The coast was nice enough, Hades. But nothing is ever perfect, right? No matter how hard you try. Still... I think we get quite close around here, every once in a while.

text.Hades: You have taken much less time adjusting to this place than when first you joined us. Part of my surprise. I, myself, was forced to be here. I never thought anyone would come from the surface here by choice.

text.Persephone: The heart can make us do the strangest things, can't it?

text.Nyx: Mmm.

text.Persephone: ...So if there's anything that I can do for you, Nyx, you need but ask, all right? I plan to pull my weight.

text.Nyx: Your services were always welcome, here. Please acclimate yourself at your own rate. I am available to answer any questions you may have at any time.

text.Persephone: Thank you, my friend. I have to tell you... it's good to be back.

text.Nyx: Precisely, yes.

text.Persephone: ...I just don't know how I can ever repay you. For raising him. For everything. After I left... besides old Cerberus, I think maybe I missed you most of all.

text.Nyx: I can remember feeling similar emotions at the time. However, it is quite unnecessary to give thanks to me this way. You are the Queen, safely returned where you belong. I did what anybody would have in my place.

text.Persephone: Anybody would have lovingly raised my estranged son, while keeping safe my secret, eventually orchestrating an elaborate plot to reunite him with me, so that I might someday return, to have a Nectar with them in the lounge?
Oh, Cerberus! Doubtless you deserve the biggest thanks that this House still stands, don't you? Did you enjoy the treat I brought you from the surface?

text.Storyteller: The surface-treat-devouring hound of hell provides the Queen a most decidedly affirmative response.

text.Persephone: I thought you might. You wouldn't know it wasn't made of meat, I'll bet! I'll see if we can't grow you plenty more.
You're such a good boy, aren't you, Cerberus? Yes you are! Guarded the place while I was out. And even let my son come visit me!

text.Storyteller: The ever-vigilant and terrifying Cerberus merely accepts the praise.

text.Persephone: I'm sorry, Zagreus, I've pressing matters to attend to now.
Do let me know if I can help with anything, all right?
Your father's prouder of you than you think.
Go make us proud, my son.
Keeping the realm secure as ever, right?
It's always nice to have a chat with you.
I think the House is well enough in order as of late.
I hope your last assignment turned out well.
Do give yourself a break from time to time!
I ever tell you you're the best son that a mother's ever had?
Hope my little cottage on the coast is holding up!
Please keep an eye on my garden on the surface when you get a chance.
I'd say this garden's doing quite all right for now.
Don't let your father get to you too much, all right?
You're looking just as well as ever, Zagreus.
You show your father who's in charge next chance you get, all right?
The pomegranate trees are coming in nicely still, the tough old things.
You'll let me know if there's something that I can do for you?
We have to say farewell again, for now, my son. Olympus calls, but I'll be back, all right?
I shall be leaving again for Olympus soon. I'll miss you, Son.
I must go visit Mother on Olympus, Zagreus. I'll tell her you said hi.
I have to go again, soon, Zagreus, all right? I'll see you soon.
I'm due to visit Mount Olympus once again, so please be good to one another while I'm out.
Time that I headed up to Mount Olympus, though you keep an eye on things till I get back?
I have to go now, Zagreus, but I shall see you just as soon as I return.
Things are well enough upon Olympus. Though, it's a relief to have come home again.
Don't think I'll ever get fully accustomed to Olympus, Son.
Zagreus, you're the most welcome sight I've seen in quite some time.
Always such an exhausting journey, from Olympus down to here.
I trust that you and Hades have been good to one another since I left?
I'll tell you, it is so much colder up there on that mountaintop.
This is a welcome sight from all the snow-capped mountaintops.

text.Nyx: <Smirk>

text.Persephone: Oh we're busy just formulating more of our dark schemes together, Zagreus.

text.Nyx: Mmm.

text.Persephone: Nyx here is a wellspring of parental advice, as it turns out!

text.Nyx: Mmm.
