text.Persephone: Nyx was just telling me some more about your early days, my son.

text.Nyx: Hmm.

text.Persephone: It seems I failed once again to persuade Nyx to take some personal time!
Please excuse your father and me for the moment, Zagreus.
Go on, Hades. Try saying something nice to him, for once.

text.Hades: Grr....

text.Persephone: Your father and I still have a bit of work here to wrap up.

text.Hades: Indeed.

text.Persephone: The work certainly never ceases, Zagreus!

text.Hades: <Scoffing>

text.Persephone: More than enough parchmentwork to go around!

text.Hades: Euugghh...

text.Persephone: Plenty of parchmentwork to contend with, I can assure you, Zagreus!
Don't go too hard on each other out there, all right?
I've heard that you've been doing great out there lately, Zagreus.

text.Zagreus: Erm, Mother? Was it always a custom in Father's House to secretly give Nectar to those you care about? I guess it also could have been a thing on Olympus. Look, I wanted you to have this. I'm so glad I found you.

text.Persephone: Oh, Zagreus, you're so thoughtful, truly! Your father never permitted Nectar out in the open so I'd practically forgotten its savor. Though, just a moment, I have something for you, too!
For me? Are you quite sure? You know, this vintage must have made it all the way up from the surface, to the mountains, then to here. We've both had distant journeys, haven't we?

text.Zagreus: Well, I, for one, am certain this vintage here has journeyed to the right place. Please enjoy it.

text.Persephone: I must confess I do enjoy having a good bottle of Nectar, every now and then. And you appear to have a careful eye for such bottles, from what I can tell!

text.Zagreus: My careful eye has got to be the green one, hasn't it. To having a discerning eye, Mother!

text.Persephone: Thank you very much, my son! You know, gift-giving customs of the Underworld are just so much more straightforward than the complicated social graces of Olympus!

text.Zagreus: If there are other ways of showing one's appreciation than with Nectar and the like, well, they must pale in comparison I'm sure!

text.Persephone: Oh, this is wonderful, except... I'm wracked with guilt for having nothing much to give you, in return. You never even got a mother's love from me.

text.Zagreus: Please don't say that, it's just a gift, all right? Besides... can't we start now? Mother and son type things. If you would like.

text.Persephone: I'd like that even more than this fine Nectar, Zagreus!

text.Zagreus: Perhaps I am part plant!

text.Persephone: Somebody raised you very well indeed, my son. Nyx, I suppose. I'll never be half the mother she is. She's done it for aeons! While I'm only getting started.

text.Zagreus: For what it's worth, I happen to think you're off to an excellent start. Nyx did teach me a lot. Achilles, too, and Father, in a way. But there is no replacing your presence. I felt that before we ever met. And now I know for sure.

text.Persephone: Thank you, Zagreus. Let's hope you're right. I nurtured very many plants, at least, of that I can assure you! Perhaps my gardening experience provided a bit of a head start on this whole mothering thing.

text.Zagreus: You're very welcome, Mother.
Mother, I know there may not be many things you miss from living on Olympus, though I wondered if perhaps Ambrosia may be one of them. And got you some, because... well, here.

text.Persephone: ...Why, this really is Ambrosia! How did you even acquire this, Zagreus? It brings back memories, for certain. And, never the bad ones, which... I think it must be why we prize this stuff so much. This is for me?

text.Zagreus: It is, it is, of course! And, it's my dearest hope that, at some point long from now, when you're relaxing with a bottle of Ambrosia, dare I say perhaps with Father... that these memories will be among the ones that spring to mind.

text.Persephone: Oh, my son... I shall certainly not need Ambrosia to think back upon getting to know you with the greatest fondness. Thank you very much.

text.Zagreus: Here, Mother. More bottled pleasant memories for you. I know you're glad you've long since left Olympus, but... I'm glad you were there, because the experience of it must have played no small part in making you who you are.

text.Persephone: You know, the last bottle you gave me brought more pleasant memories than I expected. No telling just how many more of them I've tucked away. Say, would it be all right if I shared this with your father?

text.Zagreus: It is yours to do with as you please.

text.Persephone: Haha, almost sounded like a no to me!

text.Zagreus: No! I mean, yes, please share it with Father, if he would be willing... I imagine what few pleasant memories he has are all of you.

text.Persephone: Nonsense, there's also Cerberus! Present company excluded. Come on, Son. Your father has a lot of work to do, but I'm absolutely certain that he has fond memories of you. Though, I know that isn't reassuring, coming from me.

text.Zagreus: Everything is somehow reassuring, coming from you, Mother.

CHOICE.Zagreus: I thought about it more, Mother, and I would like very much if you and Father were to share this. Though, maybe don't let on where you got it, just in case?

CHOICE.Persephone: This is splendid, Zagreus, but please! If there's one thing I've learned since we met, it's that the trust we share is at the very foundation of our relationships. Why shouldn't he know who this is from? Besides, I think he could figure it out.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Well, when it came to the Olympians, you said yourself that there was only so much truth that they could tolerate. Are you sure Father would be tolerant knowing I got this for the both of you?

CHOICE.Persephone: I'm sure enough! And if he isn't, I suppose it's more for me.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Haha, well! Just as long as someone puts it to good use.

CHOICE.Persephone: ...You know I always wanted to be a mother, Zagreus? But after you were born... I was certain I had lost my chance. Then one fine morning you just walked into my life. And here we are. I still cannot entirely believe it. What I mean is... I love you, Son. I'm doing my best.

CHOICE.Zagreus: I know. I love you, too, Mother.
Mother must still be on Olympus.
Hope this can get me out of here.
Should be able to get back through here.
Let's just go down this Satyr hole.
Get you for last time, Father.
I'm leaving, Father. Try and stop me.

CHOICE.DROPPED_Zagreus: Should check the admin chamber just in case.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Should have a look in the administrative chamber there.
Thinking I ought to check the old administrative chamber now.

CHOICE.DROPPED_Zagreus: I ought to check the old administrative chamber there.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Should check the admin chamber just in case.

CHOICE.DROPPED_Zagreus: Should have a look in the administrative chamber there.
Thinking I ought to check the old administrative chamber now.

CHOICE.Zagreus: I ought to check the old administrative chamber there.

CHOICE.DROPPED_Zagreus: Should check the admin chamber just in case.
Should have a look in the administrative chamber there.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Thinking I ought to check the old administrative chamber now.
I ought to check the old administrative chamber there.
No. Can't go this way just yet...
Not poisoned at the moment, thanks.
A Satyr sack for my boy Cerberus.
Cerberus just loves... whatever this stuff is.
A whole entire sack of something!
A sack fit for a huge three-headed hound.
Just what I need, a foul sack!
Just the foul sack I need.
Cerberus can never get enough of this stuff.

text.Zagreus: That must be one of those Infernal Troves!
That is an ominous-looking portal on the ground right there.
What is that portal thing there on the ground?

CHOICE.DROPPED_Zagreus: I need a higher Pain Level with the Pact of Punishment to go in this.

CHOICE.Zagreus: I need to power up the Pact of Punishment back home to go in this.

CHOICE.DROPPED_Zagreus: My Pain Level isn't high enough.
I need a higher Pain Level to go in.
My Pain Level's too low to get in.
Need a higher Pain Level to go in there.
Not getting in without a higher Pain Level.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Not authorized to go in there.
The Pact back home's the key to getting into this.
I'm not cleared to do that.
Could use the Rod of Fishing there.
Hey think I see a fish.

text.Zagreus: I broke free after all! Sort of.
I know Stygius like the back of my hand.
Coronacht and I are close by now.
Aegis has seen me through how many fights?
Varatha, has there ever been a greater spear?
Malphon's always there for the direct approach.
Exagryph, you and I have been through a lot.
Can't believe Lady Athena's fighting for me.
Lord Uncle Zeus sure has been generous.
Grateful for your help, Lady Artemis.
Lady Aphrodite... showing me favor.
Where there's violence, there's Lord Ares.
Uncle Poseidon... so different from Father.
Never a dull moment with Lord Dionysus around.
Glad to have Lord Hermes on my side.
Lady Demeter seems to have taken a shine to me.
The greatest boons of the Olympians... what an honor.
The Olympians aren't all on the best of terms I guess.
The gifts of Master Chaos...
I think Master Chaos just likes messing with me.
My extended family seems an interesting lot.
Good to have friends in low places..
Nice to have my ancient legendary weapons there.
Guess I have been rather busy as of late.
My weapons have revealed their hidden power.
Where would I be without my friends?
I guess it is a pretty decent statue.
Was this lot the best you have, Father?
I get the perks of getting to slay Father's forces.
The Contractor's been plenty busy thanks to me.
Charon must have made a fortune off of me.
Achilles' Codex... I'm getting somewhere with it.
Not even the Pact of Punishment can stop me.
The Mirror of Night... it's made me strong.
I guess I'm glad Skelly's not permanently dead.
Took some figuring out, but so does any decent plan, I guess.
We're one big happy family. No issues whatsoever!
Nyx... this was the least I could do.
I guess Sisyphus is even freer than before.
Tartarus is gloomy enough without Orpheus in it.
Hope Orpheus and Eurydice can be happy again.
May Achilles and Patroclus make up for lost time.
Dusa's got everything under control, I hope.
I shall procure all the fishes.
I'm no Orpheus, but I'm no slouch.
The Frost Fair Blade... what a weapon...
Holy Excalibur... thank you for your strength.
Celestial Sharanga... it was my honor.
Naegling's Board... nothing gets past you.
The Claws of Enkidu helped me scrape by to the top.
Igneus Eden... where in blazes did Lucifer find you?
Always happy to oblige Master Chaos.
Anything to cut Theseus down to size.
This one's for you, ever-bloodthirsty god of war.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Hermes really believed I could pull this off.

text.Storyteller: Concealed in the dark recesses of the Underworld is the land of Erebus, wherein the dead await eternal sentencing; they long for the attention and good graces of their master, the Lord Hades.

text.Zagreus: Nice place you got here, mate!

text.Storyteller: A hidden stretch of the boundless river Styx cuts through misty Erebus, providing for the river-boatman Charon a locale in which to deal with the unruliest of souls.

text.Persephone: 'Hades: I can no longer tolerate my life here in this place. So, I am leaving, even if it kills me. I won't be returning to Olympus. If there is a place where I belong in this world, it must be somewhere between heaven and hell. Perhaps it's on the coast and has a little garden. Take care of Cerberus; I shall miss him.  Persephone'

text.Storyteller: Having traversed the flaming river Phlegethon to gain this vantage point, relentless Zagreus must now confront a foe of unimaginable savagery, who lies ahead, awaiting patiently its time to strike.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Get out of this damn heat.

text.Storyteller: Well past the flaming river escalates the hidden stair toward the most well-guarded, splendorous environment within the Underworld: the heavenly Elysium, home eternal to the greatest souls which ever lived.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Huh, a little quieter than usual.
Thought Voidstones didn't get this big...
Time for another voyage 'board the Barge of Death.
The Barge of Death is always here for me.
Have to say, the Barge of Death is never late.
Ready when you are, Barge of Death.
Why it's the Barge of Death.
Somebody lose a spine out there?
Don't let it go to your head?
Until next time, gigantic gorgon head.
Well I, for one, had a lovely time.
Let's do this again sometime all right?

text.Zagreus: I'm sure the Witches Circle will reconvene soon enough.

text.Storyteller: The act of sorcery often ends in an untimely death and an eternity in Tartarus for careless souls, though some are able to perfect the trade, and take up permanent residence elsewhere...
The searing flame and ashes of the river Phlegethon mean nothing to the ferryman, Charon, who travels all the waters of the Underworld, bearing the dead, the damned, and all their fineries.

text.DROPPED_Storyteller: The gods were pleased with all his bravery.

text.Storyteller: Hidden well within the limitless inferno of the river Phlegethon, somehow, a trickle of life-giving water yet remains; as though provided by the Fates themselves unto the very lucky Prince.

CHOICE.Zagreus: What's this doing all the way out here?
Is that a sight for sore eyes.

text.Storyteller: The once-verdant plains of Asphodel are now engulfed in scintillating flame, having been flooded by the river Phlegethon, whose hideously superheated contents could bring death swiftly even to those resistant to most heat.
Within the suffocating heat of Asphodel reside the vast majority of those who lived upon the earth and died. There they persist until the end of time.

CHOICE.Storyteller: From within a humble residence in Asphodel reverberates the golden-sounding voice of lorn Eurydice, who once attempted to escape the Underworld, and failed, utterly, much like Prince Zagreus.

text.Storyteller: The magnificently ominous facade of the great Elysian Stadium looms tall above the rabble-rousing Prince, as if to goad him into such a competition which he cannot hope to win.

CHOICE.Zagreus: ...This has to be some kind of bad dream.
Thanks for believing in me, my good Shade!
I dedicate this victory to you, good Shade!
That shade there, have I got a fan?
I won again, Shade, thanks to your support!
That was for you, good Shade!
Hope you enjoyed the show, my good Shade!
Thank you for your support, my Shade!
We got them, my good Shade!
Showed them who's boss, didn't we, Shade?
Was not about to let you down, my Shade!
Makes up for last time I hope, my good Shade?
Should be another such performance soon!
Enjoy the rest of your existence, shades!
I'll take the service exit, thanks!
Be seeing all of you next time, all right?
I can do this. I can do this.
I'll keep my soul for now, thanks.
Farewell for now, sinister ball of butterflies.
Butterflies better stay away from me.

text.Storyteller: The vast and multitudinous riches of both the surface and the Underworld are hoarded by the river-boatman, Charon, whose services are often tendered to the wealthiest within Elysium.
Within the delicately hewn constructions of Elysium exist places of peace so utterly serene and absolute as mortalkind is seldom to experience during the average short and often-painful coil.

text.Zagreus: Hey, that's Achilles, isn't it!

text.Storyteller: Amid Elysium's moss-covered chambers, carved of stone, stand untold numbers of eternal monuments in tribute to the greatest heroes which mortality can offer, there to honor them in life as well as death.

CHOICE.Zagreus: This what the outside world is like...?
Champions of Elysium, I have returned.
Another day or night in paradise.
The dead must have it pretty good up here.

text.Storyteller: The rare, heavenly splendors of Elysium, reserved for only the most great of mortal souls, spread forth luxuriantly all about the fire-stepping Prince.
The enshrouded river of forgetfulness, Lethe, flows through the hallowed chambers of Elysium, numbing old pains and memories of the most-noble shades residing there.

CHOICE.Nyx: I thank you for this, child.

text.Storyteller: The deepest reaches of the Underworld... the void from which all life and consciousness sprang forth during the dawn of time... the realm of Chaos. A land almost unseen even to denizens of death's kingdom.
The fathomless expanses hidden in darkest corners of the Underworld stretch well past the notice of Lord Hades himself; and yet, the interfering Prince somehow discovers passage there.
Within the Underworld's quietest, most solitary, darkest abyss lies hidden evidence of the beginning of all things, of Chaos! The most ancient sculptor that has shaped this world.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Go clop your hooves in hell.

text.Storyteller: Inside the filth-encrusted lairs carved into the looming edifices of the Underworld lie such terrible abominations that not even grim Lord Hades is inclined to speak of them.

CHOICE.Zagreus: The Satyrs must be fashioning those things...
Satyr sack already, what do you know.
Been looking all over for you.

text.Storyteller: Deep within the desecrated lair of the god-defiling Satyrs lie the noisome contents of their profane rituals, so foul as to be indescribable.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Well, Guan Yu...? Take good care of Varatha for me.
We made it, Stygius. I hope this Arthur serves you well someday.
We're here, Coronacht. May you serve Rama well... if you haven't already done so, I guess...
Here we are, then, Aegis. This Beowulf will be most fortunate to have your protection.
All right, we made it, Malphon. Appreciate you lending me the might of Gilgamesh.
Here's the surface, Exagryph. Maybe it's as rare a sight for that Lucifer as it is for me.
I guess there's only one thing left to do. Isn't that so, Father?
I don't think I'll ever get accustomed to the breeze.
One last bit of business to take care of, then.
You're not going to stop me.
It's kind of nice out here.
Looks like the realm needs some adjustments still!
Got here as quickly as I could.
Hate to keep you from your parchmentwork.
You're looking very stately, there, Father.
Think you can beat me this time, Father?
I'm going to get you back for last time, you know.
Still chilly out here thanks to Grandmother...
What's with the air up here.
Hope it's nicer outside than it is in here.
I'm sure the Satyrs are back...
No more dead to deal with at least.
Just got to get through Cerberus up there.
Gods grant me a swift Satyr sack.

text.Storyteller: At last the willful prince has ventured all the way up to the surface of the mortal realm, yet still he is encased within the earth itself: the gateway to the Underworld, a threshold from which there is no escape.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Father must have put you up to this.
Working on getting you your treat still, boy.
Want something to eat, boy? Huh?
You hungry, Cerberus? I bet you are!
One Satyr sack for one good boy.
Got this delicious sack of meal for you, boy.
That's quite a stash there, Charon!
Should stock up for the road ahead.
Now for a chat with Cerberus.
One Satyr sack coming right up!
I can leave, or explore more tunnels.
Should I go fight some Satyrs, or get out of here?
Maybe I should check the other passageways before I leave.
Could check the other passageways before I go.
Need to keep looking down those passageways.
Got to find something for Cerberus.
Cerberus is back on duty. Got to find him something to eat.
There's Cerberus. Won't budge till I find him a treat.
Time to find old Cerberus a Satyr sack.
Won't get out of here until I find something for Cerberus.
Cerberus guarding the gates as always.
Time to clear some Satyr tunnels and get out of here.
Now to get Cerberus to step aside.

text.Storyteller: The vast Temple of Styx and its innumerable dangers now are all that separate the Underworld Prince from the land outside, which he so desperately longs to see.
Not far from here, the dead begin their journey to their final resting-place down in the depths below; and so the river-boatman Charon often passes through.
The widely-feared and many-headed Cerberus, the Underworld's sentinel, presides over the entrance to this realm, devouring whole those fool enough to make attempts to flee.
A crudely-hewn network of tunnels grows from one of the cold Temple's flanks, containing vicious denizens unwelcome in this realm, even in death.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Beyond the frozen overlook... await the first glimpse of the sun to your left... then onward through the cold.
Beyond the frozen overlook... await the first glimpse of the sun to your left... then onward through the cold.
Beyond the frozen overlook... await the first glimpse of the sun to your left... then onward through the cold.
Beyond the frozen overlook... and all that.

text.Zagreus: It's... beautiful.

text.Storyteller: The surface, wind-swept, wracked by freezing cold, nonetheless instills within the prince a sense of awe, and the sublime. For it is unlike anything that he has seen.

text.Zagreus: What are these things...

text.Storyteller: All manner of fruits and vegetables thrive within the hidden gardens of Persephone, the one-time Queen of all the Underworld. A world of life, far from the realm of death.

text.Zagreus: I'm leaving. Try and stop me.

text.Storyteller: Beyond the present chamber lies the outermost perimeter of Tartarus, promising terrifying dangers far beyond the Underworld Prince's reckoning.

text.DROPPED_Storyteller: The gods were pleased with all his bravery.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Got a feeling it's Tisiphone this time.

text.Zagreus: They'll just have to try harder next time.

text.Storyteller: The Erinyes; known also as the Furies, they are the trusted sentinels of Lord Hades, charged with torturing the worst of mortalkind... and ridding the Underworld of any fool enough to trespass where they do not belong.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Well, Father? I'm trespassing through your secret hall, and going up.
I'll just be a moment, Father.

text.Zagreus: Lovely.

text.Storyteller: The path from Tartarus is finally laid bare. Far above, the heat from Phlegethon, the river of flame, is faintly felt already... even as its dangers lie in wait.

text.Zagreus: I barge where I please.

text.Storyteller: None, other than those in the trusted inner circle of Lord Hades, are authorized to enter the intricate chambers connecting the vast regions of the Underworld; but the Prince decides to barge in, anyway.

CHOICE.Zagreus: See you next time, I'm sure?
Stay out of my way next time.
You stab me, I stab you.

text.Zagreus: Let's do this again sometime!

text.Storyteller: The most violent wretches of Tartarus are sealed away even from other condemned souls; their only visitors, those fool enough to attempt escape.

text.Zagreus: They basically turn into big crystals.

text.Storyteller: Damned, lost souls with nowhere left to turn congregate in deepest Tartarus, where they fuse together with the earth itself into odious forms which defy description.
A place of calm and respite, whilst perhaps unimaginable in the Underworld, occasionally is to be found, in fact.
The infernal wares of the stygian boatman, Charon, lie sprawled about, available for sale to whomever would be willing to quench the boatman's great thirst for riches.
The River Styx flows infamously through the Underworld, offering the boatman Charon expeditious travel from the realm of mortals to the lowest depths, where many of their shades reside forever.

text.DROPPED_Storyteller: The gods were pleased with all his bravery.

text.Poseidon: I have to tell you something, little Hades: My relatives and I, we've been holding back one of our greatest gifts!! To see if you were worthy. And you are! My aid is yours, so call me if you need anything! Especially to smash your enemies to bits.

Nephew! I'm mightily impressed with your ability to cull those rivers there of all the denizens of my domain! Your crusty father's not entitled to the bounties of the sea! But, on my limitless authority, you are! You have my Rod of Fishing... now have this!

CHOICE.Zagreus: Should help me on my way.
No harm in giving it another shot.
I'm not staying. Not even for him.
I'm not staying. Not even for him.
I'll have to be more careful.
What's life without a little pain.
Mortals know to make the most of it.
I wonder if I'll beat you once again.
At last I know the gods more than by name.
I'm leaving, Father. Try and stop me.
At least Zeus is helping me.
Glad I'm on his good side...
I'll find my place all right.
I've found my place I think.
My place is with my mother.
We've put each other through a lot, haven't we, Meg.
I'll show you neat and orderly.
I'll be the judge of that.
Oh, I don't know, the surface is quite nice.
I'll leave my mark all right.
Not even the Pact of Punishment can stop me.
Who's ready for the real afterlife experience?
I take some pride in making messes, yes.
How about I take a closer look.
You don't need me, and I don't need you.
If only you could see me now, Father.
Time for another blood spree, then.
Just have to cross a couple rivers, then.
I'm sure you'll think of something soon enough.
I am the god of blood.
I'll be sure to say hello.
Headed over to Elysium right now...
Not afraid of you or your damn spear.
Guess I'll see what I can do about it, Father.
My differences have made me strong, all right.
Here's to my friends and family...
Still figuring our boundaries out I guess.
You taught me that, at least.
It's nice enough to visit, anyhow.
I'll see what I can do.
Wait for me, Mother. I'll be there soon.

text.Storyteller: Composed of such innumerable ever-shifting interlocking chambers, the Underworld of Lord Hades all but guarantees the dead shall there remain until the end of time.
Each time the Prince delves back into the Underworld, its ever-shifting chambers realign to frustrate his attempts to perhaps map it out.
Within the depths of Tartarus reside the most wretched of all the shades who linger for eternity within the Underworld, whose Lord and Master is especially unkind to those attempting to cheat death.
Few tales are told of Hades, whose very name inspires fear and penitence, reminding us of the inevitable fate which we all share.
I, however, mean to tell you such a tale. Listen carefully...

text.Hades: Family? Death is your only family. Death, and I. Best get accustomed to the both of us.
Death is inescapable. If you think otherwise... why, then, don't let me stop you.
Nobody gets out of here, boy, whether alive or dead. You think I jest? You think I haven't tried?!
That dog is not your plaything, boy! Cerberus defends our realm so that no-one gets in alive, or gets out either way.
You are a weakling, boy! Disgraceful!! Now, strike again, and make it hurt, this time!
Watch where you step, you oaf! My House is not a sty through which to track your filth!
A mortal's life is short, and fraught with pain; is that truly the life you yearn for, boy?
What have I wrought, that such a witless, careless brat would be my progeny?
The fear of death keeps mortals well in check. You'd best learn to fear something yourself, you hear me, boy?
How dare you, boy! Learn well to shut that foolish mouth of yours, or I shall shut it for you!
You have a tendency to ask too many questions, boy. Would that you had a tendency to wonder silently, instead.
You're not to speak of that accursed Mount Olympus in this household, do you hear me? Nor shall you invoke the names of its inhabitants.
Say it: Blood and darkness. It's a curse, boy. Say it with me. Blood. And. Darkness. Each available in high abundance here.
Time you learned the bearing of the gods, and to assert yourself. For this I have employed the greatest of the Greeks, or what became of him.
Where do you think you are? Who do you think you're talking to? Nobody gets out of my domain, whether alive or dead.
You wish to meet your uncle Zeus someday? Imagine me, with a luxurious white mane, without a modicum of self-control. That's your Zeus.
In my domain, you either find your place, or learn your place. There's work enough to go around, believe you me.
This is where you belong. You feel out of place? Where would you even go, what would you have me do? Your place is here.
One thing the mortals have on us is that they quickly become men. This is the Fury, Megaera. She shall accelerate the process in your case.
The dead are judged and sent to Asphodel, Elysium, or Tartarus. We keep the process neat and orderly. Everyone gets in, no one gets out.
Nyx is the Night herself; her twin sons, Sleep, and Death! But, you? I cannot think of anything, I fear! Except the god of talking back to me.
Your place is here, and nowhere else. The same as it is mine. There's naught of any worth to see beyond this realm, besides.
Poseidon's an incomparable fool I am ashamed to call my brother. He can shake the earth up there all he pleases; he is unwelcome here.
Elysium? It isn't for the good; it's for the great. Great kings or killers. Oft one and the same. They left their mark upon the world. Shall you?
For their mistakes in life, the wretched shades of Tartarus are bound to me in death, however hatefully. They answer to me; quite unlike you.
How many times must I explain this, boy? Each Pact of Punishment needs to be promptly signed, and sealed, and filed. Rather than pile up!
What exactly is it, boy, that makes you feel entitled to show me such disrespect? You dare not say such things to Mother Nyx!
Asphodel has flooded once again, with flame! Not quite the afterlife experience promised to the dead residing there, now, is it, boy?
Upon my name, you lack the cheerfulness of Hypnos and the competence of Thanatos, but have more willfulness than both, combined!
Sometimes I think this mess you call your chambers is one which you've cultivated with great pride, is that the way of it?
Do not stray far again into the pits of Tartarus, or become lost like all its residents. Content yourself to look upon it from afar.
Sulk in your chambers all you like, for I care not! I have eternity to finish with this work, so your assistance is entirely unneeded.
Why do you bleed like mortals do? An aberration, nothing more! And nothing to be proud of. I suggest you keep it to yourself.
Don't you dare look at me like that, boy, with your mismatched eyes. You save it for yourself. You have a mirror in your chambers, don't you?
How suitably disgusting. Fling your blood at me like that again, boy, and I'll have you cast into the Styx, where you can drown in it.
The surface is off limits. And furthermore, you are forbidden from the Temple of Styx, until such time as you are fit to tend the situation there.
You wish to feel the breeze against your skin? Perhaps the coolness of the seas? You shall writhe from such sensations, I assure you.
You are immortal, boy, but in a manner, you can die; as you now understand. A most unpleasant feeling, is it not?
The rivers flowing through this realm divide its regions suitably enough. And every shade knows better than to try and cross them!
Why are some chambers in my House off limits? Someone deserving access would not ask. You can't always go where you please.
The Infernal Arms are sealed away for a reason, boy! Your curiosity exceeds your common sense, but heed my words, you stay away from those accursed things!
Heroes? Mere mortals, same as all the rest. Someday you shall visit Elysium and meet some of these heroes, and discover that they are quite different than the songs suggest.
How dare you to insinuate Poseidon has the slightest jurisdiction, here! Once waters from the surface flow beneath the earth, they become mine. Each of the rivers, they are mine, not his!
You would have better conversation with your chamber-walls than with the boatman Charon, boy. Not all those of the Underworld are prone to ceaseless chatter quite like you.
Now, fling the blasted thing again, I said! And put your anger into it, this time, like so. Or if you've not anger enough for it yet, you'll learn, I promise you.
Never lay hands upon Gigaros, boy, ever again. The power in that spear could tear you to pieces finer than the ones to which some of your ancestors were once reduced.
All of this realm are born of darkness, boy. It's part of everything you'll ever see. The mortals on the surface, they all fear it, foolish as they are. Unable to even see its power.
These gemstones that you mock, boy, are a symbol of the power of this realm. To you they're merely trinkets, but to mortals, gemstones hold more value than their very lives.
Another vermin outbreak near the surface, then. Would that I had someone dependable to deal with it. Where are those blasted satyrs coming from, and to what end? The vile things.
You seek such fame as your great relatives upon their mountaintop? Seek to be valuable, not to be known. Obscurity is not what makes you weak. Worship from mortals is a nuisance, not a boon.
You need to learn to hold a spear, observe! A sturdy grip is necessary, here and here. Though, we must find for you an instructor with more time to spare.
You must accept that you are not like all the others here. Your differences do not make you deficient. They can make you strong. It's up to you.
I have no idle time to spare you, boy! Have you observed the parchmentwork upon my desk? Go play with Thanatos, or Hypnos, or the dog. I need to finish this!
Your grandparents? The Titans, they were called. Long since passed from this world, boy. You have my assurance, however, that you did not miss much, in having never met.
Keep to yourself, then! Our House is not so great in size, thus boundaries must be set. I shall refrain from entering your chambers, as you shall never again try to enter mine.
Waste not your time, though it is limitless. Busy yourself in doing things of use. Learn. Learn how to learn. I cannot teach you everything myself.
The Eldest Sigil shall never work for you, boy. Only a privileged few have unconstrained authority to traverse this realm, and you are not among them, I'm afraid.
You call this shouting?! This is not shouting, boy. This is merely having certain expectations, which you have not met. Now, try once again.
Look to me for clear instruction, boy! Not for the embodiment of the standard to which you are held. Set your aim higher than to be like me.
Forget about the surface, boy! You are not missing much. Here we have warmth, and wealth. Stability! Up there? Nothing of the sort.
Speak not to me of failure! Failure is the greatest instructor of all. Your existence is a sequence of mistakes; avoid making the same one twice.
Ask Nyx about such things, do not ask me! She is the one born to this realm. I am a foreigner. Moved here to take this job, can you believe it, boy?
Mortals believe that there is no return from here. They are correct! And we all must do our part to keep it that way. We have a certain reputation to uphold.
Why am I never proud of you? Don't take it personally, boy. I'm never proud of anything. Pride is perhaps our family's worst trait. See how many mortals are with us, because of it?

CHOICE.Zagreus: Exagryph, the Rail of Adamant; annihilate all who oppose me.

CHOICE.DROPPED_Zagreus: Exagryph, the Adamant Rail; come turn my foes to ash.

text.Zagreus: I need the rail.
Ready, Exagryph?

CHOICE.Zagreus: Coronacht, the Heart-Seaker; let's deal some death.

text.Zagreus: Think I need my bow...
Let's go, Coronacht.
Coronacht hungers.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Aegis, Shield of Chaos; lend me your power.

text.Zagreus: My shield...
Aegis, protect me.
Aegis hungers.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Varatha, the Eternal Spear; join my pursuit.

text.Zagreus: Should take my spear...
It's time, Varatha.
Varatha hungers.

CHOICE.Zagreus: Stygius, Blade of the Underworld; I need your strength.

text.Zagreus: My blade...
Come, Stygius.
Stygius hungers.
Malphon, the Twin Fists; what say we crack some skulls.
Twin Fists of Malphon; our strength combined surely cannot be stopped.
Could use the Fists.
Let's punch things up a bit.
Ready, Malphon?
Malphon hungers.

CHOICE.Megaera: You are a waste of time.
You want a taste of this?
I'll kill you where you stand!
I'll kill you where you stand!
I'll kill you where you stand!

text.Zagreus: New tricks, there, Bone Hydra?
Now that's not nice at all.
Whoa that's not good...
Oh gods, now this?
I do not appreciate that!
Oh that's not good...

CHOICE.Theseus: I swear I'll get you yet!
Fiend! Who taught you such sloppy technique?!
Fiend! You are unfit to walk these hallowed passageways!
Monster! Your battle prowess leaves much to be desired!
Monster! You have no bearing, and no grace or courage!
Hoh, blackguard! How your spirit must be quivering inside!
Well, hellspawn! Not ready to admit defeat, as yet?
You have a lot of nerve, hellspawn! But little else!
Come, monster! Attack with everything you have!
I do not fear you, fiend! Your presence is a stain upon Elysium!
Well, fiend! Are you yet fearful for the inevitable end to your foul quest?
So, monster! You think you have the wherewithal to achieve victory?!
You, blackguard! By my honor and the gods, you shall soon be destroyed!
Now it is abundantly apparent that you are beneath me, fiend!
Have you anything to say for yourself, daemon? Before I slay you once again?
What now, filth? Are you prepared to be sent screaming back to the hellish darkness?!
Back, foul daemon, or be vanquished even faster than you've come to expect!
Cower uncontrollably, you monster, for there's naught else you can do against my might!
I warn you, filth, you'll gain no quarter from me, or my good companion over there!
Undeserving fiend, all which you think you have achieved was merely handed you!
What is the matter, fiend? Is your weak sense of resolve already shaken?!
Foul daemon! We shall thwart your each and every trespass in Elysium!
Attack me if you dare, blackguard! Either way, I shall crush you!
Hold, you unwelcome pustule! I shall run you through!
Your slouching form is but a laughingstock compared to my superior technique!
You've no defense against my blessed spear, blackguard!
You are all talk, you know that, don't you, filth?!
Cower all you wish! My blessed spear shall find you, anyway!
Come fight me in the open, fiend, or are you quite afraid?!
He thinks that he can vanquish us, Asterius!
You have insulted me too many times, blackguard!
You'll get no quarter from me, daemon!
Oh, stand and fight, and quit it with your writhing there, hellspawn!
You are unwelcome in Elysium, and I shall happily escort you out!
A monster such as you shall never have a chariot as fine as this!
You shall be imminently crushed beneath my chariot, you filth!
Either I'll run you down or else I'll run you through, hellspawn!
Do not think for a moment that you can outrun the Macedonian!
You truly think you shall withstand our unsurpassable Bullhorn technique?!
There is no greater pleasure than to send my spear straight into you and back, daemon!
Fiend! Who taught you such sloppy technique?!
Fiend! You are unfit to walk these hallowed passageways!
Monster! Your battle prowess leaves much to be desired!
Monster! You have no bearing, and no grace or courage!
Hoh, blackguard! How your spirit must be quivering inside!
Well, hellspawn! Not ready to admit defeat, as yet?
You have a lot of nerve, hellspawn! But little else!
Come, monster! Attack with everything you have!
I do not fear you, fiend! Your presence is a stain upon Elysium!
Well, fiend! Are you yet fearful for the inevitable end to your foul quest?
So, monster! You think you have the wherewithal to achieve victory?!
You, blackguard! By my honor and the gods, you shall soon be destroyed!
Now it is abundantly apparent that you are beneath me, fiend!
Have you anything to say for yourself, daemon? Before I slay you once again?
Would that you, too, had a chariot, so I could conquer you in racing just as in battle!
What now, filth? Are you prepared to be sent screaming back to the hellish darkness?!
Back, foul daemon, or be vanquished even faster than you've come to expect!
You shall be imminently overrun, I can assure you, blackguard!
Cower uncontrollably, you monster, for there's naught else you can do against my might!
I warn you, filth, you'll gain no quarter from me, or my good companion over there!
Undeserving fiend, all which you think you have achieved was merely handed you!
What is the matter, fiend? Is your weak sense of resolve already shaken?!
Stand your ground, hellspawn, and I shall run you down, or run you through!
Foul daemon! We shall thwart your each and every trespass in Elysium!
Attack me if you dare, blackguard! Either way, I shall crush you!
Hold, you unwelcome pustule! I shall run you through!
Lord Zeus, I call upon your might!
Lord Zeus, I need your strength!
Lord Poseidon, I invoke your might!
Lady Aphrodite, I invoke your aid!
Goddess Athena, lend to me your strength!
Goddess Athena, I need your aid, now!
Lady Artemis, make my strength be true!
Lady Artemis, I beg you guide my spear!!
Lord Ares, give me your power!
Lord Ares, lend me your might!
Lord Dionysus, lend me your power!
O Goddess Demeter, I must have your support!
Goddess Demeter, I beg of you, assist me!

CHOICE.Hades: I suppose that you must hate the very sight of me. You'll understand, then, why I wear the Helm of Darkness.
You are blind even to simple truths.
Souls of the dead, to me!
All you damned souls, come on!
All you dead souls are mine!
Become as darkness, wretches, and destroy him, now!
Come, wretches! I shall turn you from our sight!
Arise, wretches, and fight without a trace!
Come forth, wretches! And dispose of this unfilial oaf.
Wretches of the Underworld! Heed me, and rise from the earth to do my bidding!
Hear me, wretches! Rise now from my realm, and fight again!
On my authority, as Lord of Death! Awaken, wretches, and defend your king!
Upon my name, I order all you wretches of the Underworld to attend me, now!
To me, wretches! Destroy my kin, and an eternal torment to you if you speak of this!
Rise, wretches, and fight with the ferocity with which you once clung to your meager lives!
Wretches of the Underworld, I command you now to rise and fight for me!
Awaken, wretches, and fight once more upon this surface-realm where you were slain!
Heed now my summons, wretches, and come bring my wayward son down to your depths!
Deathless wretches, I compel you to fight!
Heed me, wretches, on my authority!

CHOICE.Zagreus: I thought you planned to handle this yourself!
Why don't you tell your loyal subjects to stay out of this!
Upon my name, I'll bury all you wretches here and now!
I'll send your wretches back where they belong!
Why don't you let your wretches rest in peace?
Then I'll just have to attend to them!

text.Zagreus: I do not appreciate that!
